webTitle: FA Cup third-round replay: Scunthorpe 1 - 1 Burnley

fields.headline: Dawson's late equaliser lets Scunthorpe take penalty prize
fields.trailText:
Scunthorpe 1 - 1 Burnley
Scunthorpe win 5-4 on pens.
fields.body:
Scunthorpe advanced to a fourth round tie against Bolton after edging out Burnley 5-4 on penalties. When the experienced Burnley striker Andy Payton struck in the 72nd minute of an entertaining replay last night it looked certain to set up a local derby against Bolton but Scunthorpe deservedly took the tie into extra-time with an 82nd-minute free-kick from 25 yards. It was the least Town deserved for an impressive performance which belied their Third Division status.

They had shown their threat with a 68th-minute shot from Bjarni Larusson, which was turned on to the post by keeper Nik Micholoupos.

Postponed seven days earlier because the Glanford Park pitch was frozen, the tie was again in doubt until an hour before the kick-off last night. A floodlight failure was eventually repaired as fans were queuing to get into the ground.

The electricians' intervention was timely because this developed into an entertaining match on a greasy surface which contributed immensely to the action.

Scunthorpe, in particular, relished the conditions as they again refused to be intimidated by a team two divisions above them. They had been impressive in the first tie which slipped away from them with a Burnley goal in the dying seconds of stoppage time. They continued in the same vein last night.

Lee Hodges, a bubbly and abrasive midfielder, was particularly influential. He almost made the breakthrough in the final minute of the first half when Michopoulos diverted his angled shot into the side-netting. Michopoulos had already dealt capably with free-kicks from Andy Dawson and Larusson.

Burnley's only response came on the half-hour when Payton threatened to break clear before he was robbed by a superbly timed tackle from Nathan Stanton. Hodges, a £30,000 signing from West Ham, kept Town ticking over in a second half which became increasingly fraught for the First Division side.

Within five minutes, he set up Larusson for a 20-yard shot which troubled Michopoulos, then the midfielder cut inside to force the best save of the match from the Greek keeper on the hour.

Burnley's manager Stan Ternent responded by sending on Glen Little for Paul Cook, but his first contribution was a booking for protesting after claims for a penalty were turned down.

Scunthorpe United (3-5-2): Evans; Jackson, Stanton, Wilcox; Sheldon, Larusson, Hodges, Calvo-Garcia (Graves, 73min), Dawson; Torpey, Ipoua.

Burnley (3-5-2): Michopoulos; Cox, Davis, Thomas; Weller, Ball, Cook (Litton, 50), Johnrose, Branch; Moore, Payton.

Referee: G Frankland.

fields.headline: Sedgwick reins in Saddlers
fields.trailText: Walsall 1 - 1 Rotherham
fields.byline: Richard Rae at the Bescot stadium
fields.body:
A rainstorm of biblical proportions burst over the West Midlands half an hour before kick-off last night. At many other grounds the match might have been called off, but for once the heavily sanded Bescot stadium pitch came into its own.

Instead of the game being ruled unplayable, though, the spectators were subjected to a match that was for the most part unspeakable, given this was third against fourth. Coming into the game Walsall were averaging over three goals a game at home, but Rotherham's central defenders Guy Branston and David Artell were able to cope comfortably with Brett Angell and Jorge Leitao.

The nearest the Saddlers came to opening the scoring was through Paul Hall's lobbed return of Rotherham goalkeeper Ian Gray's scuffed clearance after half an hour. At least the Rotherham centre-forward Alan Lee hit the target but his header was also directed straight at the Walsall goalkeeper Jimmy Walker.

The second half had shown no sign of improvement when, to general disbelief, the sides exchanged two rather good goals. First Darren Byfield picked up Leitao's flick and finished well from the angle of the penalty area; eight minutes later Chris Sedgwick, like Byfield a substitute, showed similar composure.

Had Walsall won, they would have equalled the club record of eight consecutive home wins, but more importantly moved into the second automatic promotion place behind Millwall. As it is, the play-offs remain the more likely goal for both teams.

Walsall (4-4-2): Walker; Brightwell, Tillson, Roper, Aramalde; Hall, Bennett, Keates, Matias (Wrack, 69min); Angell (Byfield, 69), Leitao.

Rotherham (3-4-3): Gray; Artell, Wilsterman, Branston; Bryan, Garner, Watson, Hurst; Lee (Barker, 68), Robins (Sedgwick, 76), Warne.

Referee: M Cowburn.

webTitle: FA Cup preview: Gillingham v Chelsea

fields.headline: Thrills, Gills and giants to kill
fields.standfirst: Gillingham's player-manager has Chelsea in his sights, says  Jon Brodkin
fields.trailText: Jon Brodkin finds Gillingham's player-manager hopeful of upsetting a Chelsea side without an away win since April.
fields.body:
Beneath Andy Hessenthaler's left knee was a gash nine inches long and two inches wide, but it has done nothing to dim the glint in the Gillingham player-manager's eye. It is not only because he "can't see us losing" to Chelsea on Sunday; he knows that when Kent wakes up to a cold day this morning he will be in the sun.

Having had 16 stitches removed from a wound big enough to keep his mobile phone in, the 35-year-old received an unexpected all-clear to join his squad in La Manga. With its pristine pitches and lush golf courses the Spanish resort seems a perfect place to prepare for the Cup holders' visit, provided the fire extinguishers are locked up.

In fact Hessenthaler trusts his players not to follow in Stan Collymore's foamsteps and sounds undaunted by the thought of pitting his wits against Claudio Ranieri, who was in charge of Napoli when the late-developing midfielder was working on a building site in 1991.

He did not book the trip to get a little continental coaching experience. "Last week preparing for Crystal Palace we were outside one day and the rest had to be indoors because of the state of our training pitches with the weather we've had," he says, and the decision to go abroad looked all the wiser this week when Gypsies set up camp at the training ground.

Limping round his office, Hessenthaler does not hide his disappointment at missing the Chelsea match, yet there is relief in his voice as well. He knows that the excruciatingly painful injury he sustained at Bournemouth in the previous round, which required two operations and had him still on 24 tablets a day this week, was close to ending his career.

"Luckily it was just as if someone had cut me with a razor blade," he says. "If it had gone into the joint of the knee I would probably still be in hospital now and basically they said I would have had to pack up playing."

Instead he can watch from the bench as his team try to avenge a 5-0 defeat at Stamford Bridge in last season's quarter-final. Hessenthaler walked off that day clutching Didier Deschamps' shirt for his young Chelsea-supporting son, and 11 months on the then managers, Gianluca Vialli and Peter Taylor, have gone in very different directions.

Hessenthaler has continued Taylor's good work since stepping up from player-coach in June. Gillingham are a creditable 14th in their first season in the First Division and hopeful of upsetting a side without an away win since April.

"I can't see us losing, I really can't," says Hessenthaler, who helped Watford knock the league champions Leeds out of the Coca-Cola Cup in 1992. "We have gone seven games unbeaten, there's a lot of confidence in the team and we've got to exploit their away form. We're going to make sure our tempo is good from the start and stop them playing.

"If we let them dictate the game it could be very hard for us but if we make it into a bit of a battle I believe my players can do them. It's only a small ground which will be packed with 11,000 - we could have sold it three times over - and a few of their players have probably not experienced a place like Gillingham or even heard of Gillingham."

Sheffield Wednesday and Bradford lost at Priestfield in the FA Cup last season, and although only a division divides Sunday's opponents the contrasts are enormous. Gillingham's record signing stands at £600,000, Chelsea's at £15m; the £2m Gillingham pay a year in wages must be topped by Chelsea every month.

Hessenthaler may start without his leading scorer Carl Asaba, even though the striker's move to Crystal Palace fell through yesterday, and is banking on his good friend Taylor to help him along after Leicester's 2-0 win at Chelsea in September. "We've spoken briefly," he says, "and I'll be on the phone to Pete on Friday."

Taylor signed him for Dartford and gave him his break into professional football when he was assistant manager at Watford in 1991. Hessenthaler took a wage cut to pursue that dream and now turns to Taylor for advice on tactics and dealing with players.

Keeping up with Ranieri's changes of formation could be tricky but after those years running up and down ladders in the building trade, Hessenthaler knows how fortunate he is just to be part of Sunday's match.

"I do have to pinch myself sometimes," he says. "If we had been sitting here 12 years ago and someone had said, 'You'll be managing Gillingham against Chelsea in the FA Cup,' I would have thought,no chance." Now, to the worry of his Chelsea-supporting son, he senses the best is yet to come.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Uefa raises prospect of salary caps

fields.headline: Uefa raises prospect of salary caps
fields.trailText: Football revenues cannot be stretched infinitely and national associations should consider imposing salary caps, Uefa's chief executive Gerhard Aigner said yesterday.
fields.body:
Football revenues cannot be stretched infinitely and national associations should consider imposing salary caps, Uefa's chief executive Gerhard Aigner said yesterday.

"The interest of the supporters also has its limits," Aigner said. "So, instead of forever seeking new competitions and hoped-for revenues, is it not better to concentrate on improving existing arrangements and sharing out the available revenue?

"Is it not better to attach more importance to ideas such as the fielding of homegrown players and the introduction of salary caps?"

Aigner was speaking before talks between football's world and European governing bodies, Fifa and Uefa, and the European Commission which resume in Brussels today to try to resolve the row over transfer rules, which the commission has branded illegal.

Fifa and Uefa last night finalised joint proposals calling for players to honour contracts for a minimum of three years and for a compensation system that would value players according to their commercial worth to a club as well as time spent on training, level of salary and other input into a player's development.

Chelsea are keen to take the 22-year-old defender Philippe Christanval from Monaco as part of the deal that would see Frank Leboeuf return to his homeland, according to reports in France.

Chelsea have said Leboeuf can leave if Monaco meet their asking price, believed to be £3m, and Leboeuf has confirmed that his career at Stamford Bridge is over. "I do not have a future here and it is time to move on," he said. "I want to go to Monaco and I hope a deal can be made between the two clubs. I do not want to stay at Chelsea if I'm not playing. I think I might have played my last game for the club."

Arsenal should escape expulsion from the FA Cup or losing Premier League points even if their Lithuanian striker Tomas Danilevicius is expelled from Britain for allegedly carrying a false passport.

A Football Association spokesman said that Arsenal could only be punished if it was proven they knew Danilevicius had entered the country on a false Greek passport after signing from FC Lausanne of Switzerland for an undisclosed fee. "But at the moment it's all hypothetical," he said. Danilevicius has played three games as a substitute for Arsenal since joining in December.

Tottenham have admitted an interest in Southampton's Morocco striker Hassan Kachloul, who is stalling over a new contract at the Dell.

Newcastle's goalkeeper Shay Given has withdrawn his transfer request, and Aston Villa's goalkeeper David James has agreed a new 3-year contract, 12 months longer than his current deal.

James's agent Colin Gordon said: "We shook hands on the deal last night. There are a few more technicalities to be tied up but nothing that will stop it going through.

"He has been very impressed with Juan Pablo Angel since he arrived and feels he can achieve the things he wants to in the game with Villa." Villa announced a loss before tax of £2.6m for the six months up to November 30 last year.

The Leeds manager David O'Leary has said that Rio Ferdinand's chances of playing in the Premiership game at Villa tonight are not as remote as first thought. Ferdinand looked likely to miss the game after straining tendons behind his knee while watching television.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Julian
fields.trailText: Hopefully your arrival in the South Island will have made the world seem like a better place. Auckland is just another big city and not at all representative of the rest of the country, especially the South Island, so don't be disheartened.
fields.body:
Hi Sam

Hopefully your arrival in the South Island will have made the world seem like a better place. Auckland is just another big city and not at all representative of the rest of the country, especially the South Island, so don't be disheartened.

Having been in New Zealand this time last year, I know all about the 'interesting weather' you can get (including the four days we spent stranded in Queenstown after a week of non-stop, Biblical-standard rain flooded the town and closed all the roads out), but the South Island makes it all worth it.

Shame you missed Tongariro, as it is everything it's cracked up to be, but ATNP should make up for it, being, in my humble opinion, possibly the most wonderful place on earth.

As much as I hate fellow travellers who say 'you must do this', I'm going to do so myself, so apologies now. Before you leave NZ, you really must:

1 Climb Mount Roy, which is just outside Wanaka, for views over the Remarkables, Lakes Wanaka and Hawea and the Southern Alps that will stay with you for the rest of your days (prepare well, though - it's a good three hour walk up, so take lots of water).
2 Camp (at the YHA) next to the bright blue waters of Lake Tekapo, and walk up neighbouring Mount John.
3 Stay at Hilltop in Paptowai, down in the Catlins - stunning views, lovely people (who'll take you boogie boarding if you ask nicely).
4 Take a helicopter flight round the peaks of Mts Cook & Tasman from Fox Glacier - another truly unforgettable experience.
5 Eat a pumpkin and chocolate muffin at the Christchurch Arts Centre's Boulevard Bakehouse - admittedly, not an adrenalin-related activity, but very good for the soul while the world passes by.

Hope that your South Island experience turns out to be as wonderful as ours was.

Best wishes for the rest of your travels.

fields.headline: Universities face 'swinging 60s' timebomb'
fields.trailText: Universities will be forced to charge students top-up fees to pay for better staff salaries if they are to avert a "swinging 60s' timebomb", when a generation of academics retires in 2005, MPs were told today.
fields.body:
Universities will be forced to charge students top-up fees to pay for better staff salaries if they are to avert a "swinging 60s' timebomb", when a generation of academics retires in 2005, MPs were told today.

The warning came from Sir Michael Bett, pro-chancellor of Aston University, and chairman of the committee which two years ago called for hundreds of millions of pounds to be injected into universities to improve pay and conditions for staff.

"In 2005 we are due for an exodus of teachers from higher education," Bett told the House of Commons education committee. "We are sliding down the hill at the moment but there is a crisis on the horizon." Bett said that students were put off academic careers because they could earn much more in other professions. He added that top-up fees would come if there isn't a government response to the crisis.

Professor John Beath, chairman of the Conference of Heads of University Departments of Economics, added that universities were facing a "swinging 60s' timebomb" when many academics retired in 2005.

The MPs are carrying out an inquiry into student drop out rates, which vary dramatically for academic institutions.

Yesterday, the MPs heard that more students are being thrown out of university because they can not pay their tuition fees. Professor Diana Green, vice-chancellor of Sheffield Hallam University, said that the number of students excluded for debt at the university has risen by 17 per cent since 1998, when fees were first introduced.

Next week, the committee will hear from education minister, Tessa Blackstone.

webTitle: An unusual consortium with £100m to invest

fields.headline: In fellowship
fields.standfirst: Roger Cowe  reports on an unusual consortium with £100m to invest to finance projects with real vision
fields.trailText: Roger Cowe reports on an unusual consortium with £100m to invest to finance projects with real vision
fields.body:
The Dome has gone, along with the tens of millions of pounds from the millennium commission which financed it. But the commission will leave a lasting, lottery-funded legacy - a £100m endowment fund, the interest from which will continue the millennium awards scheme.

The commission is about to hand over the cash to a curious consortium called un LTD. This is a remarkable victory for an organisation which came together last summer, but this is just the beginning of its grand ambitions. Michael Norton, chairman of Changemakers, one of the consortium partners, which works to engage young people in community affairs, says: "We believe that the potential of individuals to create change in their communities is limited only by their ideas and their energy."

The winning organisation wants to build on the experience of the millennium awards, but to go well beyond the scheme's limited aim of giving small, one-off grants to individuals to fund pet projects ranging from inventor workshops to medieval fairs.

The watchword is social enterprise, a notion which raises eyebrows in some quarters because of the suspicion that it is a euphemism for privatising public services, an excuse for cutting spending. But un LTD sees it as it was defined recently by the social investment taskforce: using conventional business disciplines, tools and entrepreneurial skills to achieve a social purpose.

It is a new twist on traditional business philanthropy, such as the social housing built in the 19th century by the Cadbury family for workers at its factory in Bournville. The modern notion of social enterprise escapes such reliance on the generosity of business owners. Instead, it is about getting community activists to use business methods, rather than vice versa. In particular, it involves thinking about investment - implying sustainable finance, rather than relying on grants which need replacing.

Most of the seven partners in the consortium have solid community credentials. They include the Scarman Trust, the School for Social Entrepreneurs, Community Action Network, and Senscot, the Scottish network for social entrepreneurs. Comic Relief makes an unlikely addition to this mix and the seventh member is Ashoka, an international organisation founded in the US in 1989. In fact, Ashoka brought together these groups - which are, in some respects, competitors.

Jeremy Oppenheim, Ashoka's UK chairman, has a direct link to the business world because his day job is as a senior management consultant at McKinsey - to many the epitome of private sector, profit-driven efficiency. Such a connection may fuel concerns about the implications of social enterprise. But Oppenheim makes clear that social entrepreneurs are pursuing public, not financial, goals. He argues that they can benefit from private sector approaches, and, to prove it, the global consultancy last year set up a not-for-profit team within the business, just as it has a pharmaceutical team and a food team.

Ashoka was founded by a former McKinsey consultant, which explains the connection. It draws a parallel between its strategy of backing social entrepreneurs with financial venture capital practices. David Cope, its chief executive, says: "Ashoka invests in outstanding individuals leading projects of direct benefit to society. They have to be innovative and have considerable potential impact."

Ashoka has not been active in this way in Britain, but there are now 1,100 such Ashoka "fellows" in 40 countries. The organisation backs them with a modest salary for two or three years while their projects get off the ground, but it places as much emphasis on the advice and support from the international network of fellows.

This model is part of how un LTD will manage the millennium awards scheme, which it describes as a "staircase approach".

The first step will broadly follow the pattern so far - small grants of up to £2,500 to individuals with good ideas for community action. The second step on the un LTD staircase will break with previous practice and offer further grants to people who have completed their projects (who become fellows) but see the scope for significant development. Up to £15,000 from the endowment interest will be available each year for about 100 such fellows. It is also intended to make more of the fellowship than in the past. The fellows have learned important lessons, and the aim is to make their experience available to new award winners.

Then un LTD aims to move beyond the commission's funding. It plans a third step of "significant" investment for the best projects. This money - the target is £100m - will come from wealthy individuals who have been dubbed "venture philanthropists". They are the new rich, the dot.com millionaires and others who helped inflate the wealth bubble during the 1990s.

The theory is that they can be just as charitable as previous generations, but they want something more than the traditional foundation. First, they want to be more involved than grant-giving bodies normally allow. Second, instead of just giving their money away they want some kind of financial return, even if that is just getting their capital back.

This is where the McKinsey connection could show its worth. Already Oppenheim has organised a few meetings, seeking to bring together these nouveaux riches with people looking for backing for their social ventures. There is another private sector analogy - the First Tuesday gatherings which helped marry internet entrepreneurs and those with money to invest in their dreams.

Oppenheim talks of "creating the next generation of community leaders" and having 10,000 "active citizens" in the fellowship at the end of five years. And, of course, he is also looking for a major change in regeneration.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Paula
fields.trailText: I have been reading and enjoying your weekly reports - they all sound very interesting and brilliant fun. I can see why you won; you're a brilliant writer. It was also good to read about your time in Nepal as I've been there myself.
fields.body:
Dear Sue,

Happy new year 2001!

You aren't missing a thing in the UK - honest. It is cold, damp and wet.

I have been reading and enjoying your weekly reports - they all sound very interesting and brilliant fun. I can see why you won; you're a brilliant writer. It was also good to read about your time in Nepal as I've been there myself, and it was all so familiar. I'm sure you could get a job as a travel writer when you return (if you do return...)

I am sure you are having some very exciting times and I look forward to reading your continuing adventures with your bear. I am sure he is great to cuddle up to in those more homesick moments.

I have never considered Malaysia, but shall have to explore it now as it does sound interesting.

Happy travelling.

fields.headline: Ken stages student conference
fields.trailText: London Mayor Ken Livingstone is to host a conference to discuss options for the future of higher and further education in London.
fields.body:
London Mayor Ken Livingstone is to host a conference to discuss options for the future of higher and further education in London.

His office said the event on February 14 was being held in the light of "the continuing funding crisis in higher and further education, rising debt and poor access to universities for those from low income backgrounds".

He has invited 200 students, lecturers and vice chancellors from colleges of higher and further education across London to an event which is likely to embarrass the government in the run-up to the general election. Labour's manifesto is expected to say little about higher education tuition fees or the growing scale of student debt.

On Friday lecturers and other university and college staff are due to demonstrate outside the offices of the university employers in London. Talks are scheduled to resume on the long-running pay dispute which has led to lecturers withholding marks from students.

Nursing students, who had expected to graduate this month, have not been able to return to hospital wards as qualified nurses. Tom Wilson, head of NATFHE's universities department said they regretted the disruption but the dispute was about understaffing and the quality of education as well as pay. The union was discussing with the Royal College of Nursing the best way of minimising disruption to Nursing students, including allowing nursing graduates to join hopsitals as care assistants until the dispute was resolved, he said.

fields.headline: Mandelson resigns
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText:
 Northern Ireland secretary quits
 Attacks media pressure
 Ex-minister to face Commons questions today
 'I want to lead a more normal life'
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the secretary of state for Northern Ireland, today announced his resignation from the government.

Mr Mandelson was summoned to No 10 to explain his involvement with the passport application of Indian tycoon Srichand Hinduja.

After meeting the prime minister, Tony Blair, Mr Mandelson said outside 10 Downing Street that he did not accept he had acted "improperly in any way" over the passport for favours row. But he said he wanted to distance himself from the "countless stories and controversies of feuds and divisions" that had surrounded him. "I want to lead a more normal life," he said.

This afternoon, Mr Mandelson took Northern Ireland questions in the Commons where he defended the government's handling of the RUC reform. But he did not expand on his decision to resign.

Northern Ireland's first minister, David Trimble, thanked Mr Mandelson for his work in the province over the past year and said: "I and many others appreciate the efforts he has done."

Tony Blair told the Commons that Northern Ireland had Mr Mandelson to thank for sustained peace in the province. Responding to an attack on Mr Mandelson by the Tory leader, William Hague, Mr Blair retorted: "He's a bigger man than many of his critics."

News of the resignation has sent shockwaves through Westminster, Northern Ireland and beyond, with Mr Mandelson saying that working on the Ulster peace process was the "greatest privilege" of his political life.

The Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, urged the government not to be distracted from the search for a solution in the province by the fallout of Mr Mandelson's resignation.

"It is a matter of public record that Peter Mandelson and Sinn Fein were in disagreement over many issues. Notwithstanding that, I wish him well for the future," he said.

Dermott Nesbitt, an Ulster Unionist minister at Stormont, said it was sad for Mr Mandelson personally, but that the political process would continue.

"We in the Ulster Unionist party want to see stability and we will work with whoever is appointed to replace him."

Mr Hinduja, whose naturalisation request set off the row, said in a statement: "We are sad to see Mr Mandelson's resignation. I wish to reiterate that I have never at any time linked our support for the faith zone of the Millennium Dome with our request to Mr Mandelson for information in 1998."

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP who asked the original parliamentary question about Mr Mandelson's involvement with the Hinduja passport application, said the resignation had been inevitable.

"He had exposed the prime minister and his colleagues in a very unhelpful way," he said.

"The government is keen to distance itself from the Tory years of sleaze and Mr Mandelson was not helping that process."

Former No 10 press officer and long-time friend of Mr Mandelson Tim Allan today said the Hartlepool MP would think "long and hard" before dropping his constituency, and also insisted the ex-Northern Ireland secretary would want to remain in public life.

But following the announcement of Mr Mandelson's resignation, the prime minister's spokesman told reporters: "I think Peter's making clear from his statement that he is clearly looking to wind down his political activity."

This is the second time that Mr Mandelson has resigned from the government. In December 1998, he quit as trade and industry secretary after the Guardian exposed a secret £373,000 loan from fellow minister Geoffrey Robinson.

webTitle: Collymore set to sign for Oviedo

fields.headline: Collymore set to sign for Oviedo
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore could make his debut for Real Oviedo on Sunday after positive talks with the club last night.
fields.byline: Sean Ingle, Mark Tallentire and Daniel Taylor
fields.body:
Stan Collymore could make his debut for Real Oviedo on Sunday after positive talks with the club last night.

Details of Collymore's existing contract at Valley Parade still need to be ironed out and are slowing the projected deal, but the Spanish club are confident that he will sign by the weekend.

Spokesman Miguel Solis said Collymore was keen and money would not be a problem to make the move happen. "We are optimistic he may even play this Sunday," he said. "We know Collymore's past history and that he has played for several clubs in England.

"Oviedo is a friendly town and the club is like a family. We are convinced he will settle down here and that above all he will score goals," he added.

There had been little interest since City announced that the 30-year-old was surplus to requirements; he could not agree terms on a move to Stuttgart and, despite a hint from Martin O'Neill that he might be given a chance at Celtic, Collymore's representatives said yesterday there had been no official approach.

It remains uncertain whether Collymore will accept Oviedo's offer, especially as he will be mindful that it may trigger Celtic into making their interest official.

Kenny Dalglish, Celtic's former director of football operations, has blamed John Barnes, the man he hired as head coach, for the club's disasters last season.

Barnes was recruited by his former Liverpool and Newcastle manager in the summer of 1999, having just retired as a player, and soon began making signings, among them the midfielder Eyal Berkovic for £5.75m and the defender Rafael Scheidt for £5m.

"It was John who signed all the players at Celtic," Dalglish said. "I don't know who was the worst although there were more bad ones than good ones.

"Obviously there was some consultation between us, but the guy who is responsible for who plays, how we played, and where and when we trained is the guy who is ultimately responsible for buying players."

Dalglish also confirmed that a row between the head coach and Mark Viduka during the 3-1 cup defeat by Inverness Caley had effectively ended Barnes's reign. He was sacked two days later, only eight months into a three-year deal.

Dalglish took control of team affairs but was sacked after O'Neill was appointed as manager last summer. Dalglish later obtained a Court of Session judgment against the club for £612,522 plus interest.

Fulham have taken Peter Moller Nielsen on loan from Real Oviedo for the rest of the season. The 28-year-old striker was a member of Denmark's 1998 World Cup squad.

fields.headline: How to deal with mosquitoes
fields.standfirst:
Last year in Zanzibar, I met a Belgian woman, who was entirely untroubled by mosquitoes thanks to an amazing battery-powered device which emitted a high-powered sound. Where can I buy one?
Helen Jacobs
fields.trailText: Last year in Zanzibar, I met a Belgian woman, who was entirely untroubled by mosquitoes thanks to an amazing battery-powered device which emitted a high-powered sound. Where can I buy one?
fields.body:
 They are made by The Edge Company, 17 Kit Street, Keene, NH 03431, US, (tel: 1 800 732 9976, www.edgeco.com). There are two types of device; one is about the size of a large wristwatch and costs $19.95; the other is like a medium size chest microphone and costs $5.95. Credit cards are OK. There is only one problem: Edge does not seem keen to send things abroad. I got mine by giving a friend's address in the States.
Michael Mann

 The device that Helen Jacobs wants is made by: Servicroma, C/Foc, 23, 08038 Barcelona, Spain (tel: 93 223 45 64, www.radarcan.com. I bought an SC-7 model for £5 in a hardware shop in Soria, Spain. It works very well and seems to run forever on a single AA battery. Some jokers in the UK are apparently trying to sell them for £20.
Aidan Rowe

webTitle: Passport row lands Mandelson in trouble

fields.headline: Passport row lands Mandelson in trouble
fields.standfirst:
There was no question of me getting any preferential treatment for anyone who wanted a British passport. After all, no application had even been made by an individual Peter Mandelson yesterday

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Downing Street was last night at odds with Peter Mandelson over the circumstances which forced senior officials to admit that Tony Blair's closest lieutenant intervened directly over a prospective British passport application by one of the wealthy Hinduja brothers - contrary to weekend assurances.
fields.byline: Michael White, and Luke Harding in Delhi
fields.body:
Downing Street was last night at odds with Peter Mandelson over the circumstances which forced senior officials to admit that Tony Blair's closest lieutenant intervened directly over a prospective British passport application by one of the wealthy Hinduja brothers - contrary to weekend assurances.

The Northern Ireland secretary went on TV last night to deny improper lobbying on behalf of Srichand Hinduja, the oldest of three brothers facing allegations of corruption in an arms scandal in their native India. The family is worth an estimated £2bn.

But in a day of shifting explanations it was confirmed that a "fleeting telephone conversation" between Mr Mandelson and the then immigration minister, Mike O'Brien, had taken place in June 1998.

It was that month that the Hinduja Foundation offered - on June 17 - to underwrite the £3m cost of the Millennium Dome's faith zone. The coincidence prompted Opposition MPs to accuse the minister of selling a passport in return for what eventually turned out to be a £1m contribution to the faith zone, formally announced in October 1998.

Last night's fresh confusion arose because Mr Mandelson's spokesman told the Observer categorically at the weekend that the minister played no direct role in Mr Hinduja's passport application and the incident came after dome funding negotiations were over.

"The [passport] matter was dealt with by [his] private secretary," said a statement - a claim repeated by Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's spokesman, on Monday.

Last night Mr Mandelson said: "There is no question of my forgetting about anything. I was not asked until today."

Asked why a Downing Street spokesman yesterday claimed he could not remember the call, Mr Mandelson said: "You will have to ask them that."

In June 1998 Mr Mandelson was the cabinet office minister in charge of making a success of the dome. He moved to the DTI the following month and was forced to resign that December when the Guardian disclosed his £374,000 home loan from Geoffrey Robinson.

According to his own version he was asked by the Hindujas - whom he had met several times - how the newly-announced change in government policy towards passport applications might affect Srichand Hinduja's chances.

"The answer was that I hadn't the foggiest idea," he told friends yesterday.

Most backbench MPs said yesterday that at this point they would have referred the inquirer to the home office - unless he or she was their own constituent. Mr Mandelson's problem is that he placed a call to Mr O'Brien. "The trouble is that Peter speaks for Tony - if he makes a call he's saying 'Tony wants this passport'," one minister said yesterday.

Mr Mandelson said yesterday: "There was no question of me getting any preferential treatment for anyone who wanted a British passport, after all no application had even been made by an individual."

He expressed no view to Mr O'Brien on Mr Hinduja's suitability either way, he said, although Hinduja sources spoke last night of getting an encouraging "steer". The tycoon applied in October 1998, just after the £1m dome gift. By the time his passport was granted in March 1999 Mr Mandelson was in disgrace. He played no further role, he insists.

A six month turn-around is three times the usual speed, experts say.

Mr Hinduja - whose brother, Gopichand, was granted British citizenship in 1997 - had applied for a UK passport in 1990, but had been turned down because he had not lived in Britain long enough.

An Indian court last week granted the brothers bail while corruption charges are investigated. But they were refused permission to leave the country.

The Tories described it as an "error of judgment" to get even slightly involved in a passport application from a non-constituent - and their party chairman, Michael Ancram, insisted there were still "very serious questions" to answer.

Downing Street and the NIO did not help their case by offering conflicting accounts of what led to yesterday's retraction at Mr Campbell's daily briefing for reporters.

The prime minister's spokesman explained: "Yesterday I repeated a line from Sunday that Peter's sole involvement was a call from his private secretary to the Home Office, which was Peter's recollection. But yesterday Peter's office was able to look at it in further detail."

The record showed Mr Mandelson's private secretary did set up a call to Mr O'Brien. Mr Mandelson suggests he instigated the trawl of the record and realised the error when he read the daily summary of Mr Campbell's briefing.

Last night sources close to the Hindujas said Downing Street's statement had not contradicted their remarks. "We asked the question [as to whether Srichand Hinduja's passport application could be resubmitted] and Peter Mandelson came back to us with a steer."

webTitle: Overhaul to student careers services planned

fields.headline: Overhaul to student careers services planned
fields.trailText: Proposals for a major overhaul to student careers services were unveiled today. A government commissioned report says that students and employers should receive the same core services from all universities. It also calls for 24-hour computer-based careers advice for students, and help for students for two years after graduating.
fields.body:
Proposals for a major overhaul to student careers services were unveiled today. A government commissioned report says that students and employers should receive the same core services from all universities. It also calls for 24-hour computer-based careers advice for students, and help for students for two years after graduating.

The review of services, led by Sir Martin Harris, the vice-chancellor of Manchester University, was announced by the government six months ago following concerns that the standard of services varied enormously across the academic sector. Education and Employment Minister Tessa Blackstone, said that university careers services were too often "a Cinderella service", offering little help to students and academics.

The report is based on one over-riding principle: where you study - and where you live after graduation - should not affect the quality of careers advice and guidance you receive.

Among some 41 proposals in the Review of Higher Education Careers Services, is that the academic sector should define the core services that every careers service should provide to students and promote best practice in relation to 'statements of entitlement' for students.

Diana Warwick, chief executive of Universities UK, welcomed the report, but highlighted the costs implied in some of its recommendations: "Some proposals entail additional costs that are not explicitly recognised by the report. For example the recommendation that calls on institutions to identify early those students who will be most in need of careers services, runs the risk of laying the heaviest costs on the institutions that are most successful in implementing the access agenda and recruit people from diverse backgrounds."

The consultation on the proposals ends on 27 April. Copies of the consultation document are available from the Department for Education and Employment at www.dfee.gov.uk/hecareersservicereview.

fields.headline: Defoe not record breaker yet
fields.trailText: Despite lots of headlines to the contrary, it appears that Bournemouth's teenage striker Jermaine Defoe is yet to break the post-war league record for scoring goals in consecutive matches.
fields.body:
Despite lots of headlines to the contrary, it appears that Bournemouth's teenage striker Jermaine Defoe is yet to break the post-war league record for scoring goals in consecutive matches.

The 19-year-old, on loan from West Ham, scored his 10th goal in 10 games last night, scoring the first in a 2-0 win for the Cherries over Cambridge. But according to the curator of the Manchester City museum, Phil Noble, Defoe now shares the post war record with former City striker Billy McAdams who scored 10 in 10 during the 1957-58 season.

A statement on the Manchester City website claims that this will "throw a spanner in the works" of many journalists who have rushed to praise Defoe this week, and the website also notes: "Billy McAdams was of course knocking them in for the Blues in Division 1. Young Jermaine Defoe has achieved his run in Division 2 ( the old Division 3)!"

Noble was tipped off about the anomaly by his dad Peter. Peter, another die-hard Blue, told Football Unlimited today: "I was there when Billy Mac scored his tenth goal. We beat Everton 6-2 and it was absolutely chucking it down. Kevin Harper also scored a hat-trick of penalties, which I think is some kind of record."

After the tip from his dad, Phil went on to check the City record books and confirm that McAdams netted 10 in a row. Asked whether he felt sorry about depriving Defoe of his moment of glory, Noble senior said: "Not at all."

webTitle: In brief: Wonder Woman a step closer to big screen

fields.headline: Wonder Woman a step closer to big screen
fields.standfirst: Plus: Bono hits back at Mel Gibson's dig at Wenders' film; Julia Roberts to tie the knot with Benjamin Bratt; British club scene movie will star top DJs
fields.trailText: Plus: Bono hits back at Mel Gibson's dig at Wenders' film; Julia Roberts to tie the knot with Benjamin Bratt; British club scene movie will star top DJs
fields.body:
 Plans to bring Wonder Woman to the big screen have come a step closer to reality now that the project's producer Joel Silver has signed Antz scribe Todd Alcott to work on the script for the film. According to Variety, Alcott has signed a six-figure deal to write about the exploits of the world's first female superhero. Although there is no word yet on who will play the lead role, the name of Sandra Bullock, who is hot again after the success of Miss Congeniality (pictured), has been mentioned more than once.

 Bono has hit back at Mel Gibson's claim that Wim Wender's Million Dollar Hotel was "as boring as a dog's arse" by claiming that the reason Gibson criticised the project was because he wasn't pleased with the role he had to play. Gibson, who played a freak with an amputated third arm in the whodunit, made the comments on a publicity tour for his latest film What Women Want. Bono told Q Magazine: "It was a thankless part. He doesn't win, he doesn't get the girl and he doesn't get to kill everybody." The U2 singer went on to say that he felt very hurt on Wenders' behalf for Gibson's comments and added: "Wim has made two, maybe more, of the top 30 films ever made. Has Mel? In the end, is it about box office over being great?" Gibson's spokesman, lan Neirob, refuted Bono's accusations, calling them "absurd."

 Julia Roberts is to wed long-time boyfriend Benjamin Bratt, according to reports this afternoon, after the Golden Globe-winning actress apparently issued an ultimatum to him to either marry her or break up. Bratt, who will be seen next in Steven Soderbergh's Traffic, apparently chose the former. A "friend" of the Erin Brockovich star claimed: "Julia is eager to start the next phase of her life - not that of movie star, but as wife and mother. She is over the moon and the happiest I've ever seen her."

 DJ Paul Oakenfold is to make his acting debut in a new film about the bar and club scene in Brixton, according to ananova. South West Nine, which will follow six characters through 24 hours in the south London suburb, is to be made by Fruit Salad Films, the company behind Human Traffic. Although it is not clear yet which role Oakenfold will play, fellow DJ Lol Hammond has also agreed to a cameo appearance.

webTitle: Unions blast McLeish's 'perverse' u-turn on elderly long-term care

fields.headline: Unions blast McLeish's 'perverse' u-turn on elderly long-term care
fields.trailText: Scottish first minister Henry McLeish today came under fire from health unions after he rejected proposals to provide free personal care for all elderly people in long-term care north of the border. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
Scottish first minister Henry McLeish today came under fire from health unions after he rejected proposals to provide free personal care for all elderly people in long-term care north of the border.

But he promised legislation to increase the numbers of people who receive free personal care, and said he would introduce within two years a new system of "needs assessment". He also announced a "development group" headed by health minister Malcolm Chisholm to look at ways of extending free provison of personal and nursing care.

Mr McLeish's decision, announced today, ends months of speculation that he would use Scotland's devolved powers to diverge from England over the provision of long-term care.

But the British Medical Association called the decision "disappointing" and accused the Scottish executive of "procrastination" over the issue.

Unison called the decision "perverse", and the Royal College of Nursing said was it was "disappointed that all personal care will not be made free".

In England, health ministers rejected the recommendations of the royal commission on long-term care that personal care - such as bathing, feeding and dressing of elderly patients - should be universally free.

Mr McLeish hinted last October when he became first minister that he wanted to "move forward" on long-term care - interpreted as a sign that Scotland would go it alone and implement the commission's recommendations.

But in recent weeks he has come under pressure from party colleagues at Westminster who were worried that a commitment to free personal care could fuel demands for parity from pensioners in England at a sensitive time before a general election.

webTitle: The likely lads for the Belfast hot seat

fields.headline: The likely lads for the Belfast hot seat
fields.standfirst: Julian Glover runs the rule over potential successors for Mandelson's Northern Ireland job
fields.trailText: Julian Glover runs the rule over potential successors for Mandelson's Northern Ireland job.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's last ministerial act was to attend Northern Ireland questions in the House of Commons. Finding his successor is now the prime minister's most urgent task. Only once the Northern Ireland secretary's empty cabinet chair is filled will Tony Blair be able to turn his mind to the rebuilding of the New Labour project.

Fortunately for Mr Blair, there are several candidates for the job. The simplest option - and the one he will probably take - is to appoint Mr Mandelson's deputy at the Northern Ireland office, Adam Ingram, currently a minister of state (Whitehall-speak for a minister just below cabinet rank).

Whether Mr Ingram - a bruiser of an MP who has spent the last couple of years coaxing the peace process to fruition - is quite the right man for the job is open to question. The prime minister may also wonder about the wisdom of appointing yet another MP with a Scottish seat to a cabinet where a Sassenach is becoming an increasingly rare sight.

One option is to appoint Mr Ingram in a caretaker's role pending a full review of the way the cabinet is made up. This change is long overdue, in the wake of devolution to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Other candidates include Dr John Reid, who has risen up the government ranks to become secretary of state for Scotland. In this post he is underemployed, and his skills could perhaps be better used to meet the challenges of implementing police reforms and decommissioning across the Irish Sea.

From Wales, Paul Murphy, currently the region's secretary of state, would be another safe choice. Less likely is Geoff Hoon - now the defence secretary - who could manage the post with ease but who would look upon it as a demotion.

But one certainty, to end: you can rule out a shock return to the frontline by Mo Mowlam, the loveable, devil-may-care former Northern Ireland minister about to take her leave from the Westminster stage. Even Mr Blair isn't that desperate - at least, not yet.

fields.headline: About www.cardiffcity.com
fields.trailText: www.cardiffcity.com
fields.body:
www.cardiffcity.com

www.cardiffcity.com is the first choice for Cardiff City on the internet.

There's everything you'd expect from a very popular website including interactive message-boards and chatrooms. The site is updated several times daily and is always alive with the open message-board.

The site has been in existence since early 1997 and is also accompanied by an active mailing list of nearly 400 users.

It has its own match reporter as well as surveying the media for reports.

Wherever you are in the world the Bluebirds are only a click away.

The site has been in existence since early 1997 and is also accompanied by an active mailing list of nearly 400 users. It has its own match reporter as well as surveying the media for reports. Wherever you are in the world the Bluebirds are only a click away.

webTitle: Serious political debate for the many not the few

fields.headline: Serious political debate for the many not the few
fields.standfirst:
Michael Jacobs, the general secretary of the Fabian Society, explains the aims of Saturday's conference

How to get tickets for the Fabian Society conference
fields.trailText:
Michael Jacobs, the general secretary of the Fabian Society, explains the aims of Saturday's conference
How to get tickets for the Fabian Society conference
fields.body:
Tony Blair has famously said that a second term Labour government would be more radical than the first. But what exactly does this mean? What would Britain look like at the end of the next parliament if Labour were re-elected? How far is this government really thinking about significant change in the economic and social structures of British society - or of the wider world? What are the key challenges it will face? These are the questions to be explored at the Fabian Society's day-long conference "Transforming Britain: Prospects for a Second Term" on Saturday 27 January at the LSE in London.

The Fabian Society's new year conference has become something of a fixture in the political calendar in recent years. More than 600 people have attended the last two events - in 1999 on globalisation, and last year on the history (and future) of the Labour party on its centenary. We are expecting more this time. There is always a good atmosphere - serious argument on important issues, open and often passionate disagreement, but never factional conflict and always a lot of fun. What marks them out is the direct engagement of ordinary members of the public - people interested in politics, some of them activists in various organisations, others just committed to the pursuit of ideas - with ministers, MPs, respected academics and leading journalists. It is a unique forum in many ways, with so many leading figures in public life addressing, being challenged by, and rubbing shoulders with, the people who really matter.

This year we have Gordon Brown, David Blunkett, Polly Toynbee, Germaine Greer, Tony Giddens, Jeremy Vine, Peter Hain, Hugo Young, Jude Kelly, Charles Secrett, Pam Giddy and many others - in fact more than 40 speakers in all, including a dozen ministers.

The subject they are discussing - how Labour might go about transforming Britain in a second term - has been the Fabian Society's focus pretty much since the government took office. It was always clear that the first term would be about foundation building, and our role is to look beyond the present. At the end of last year we launched our major report on the future of taxation and public services (Paying for Progress: A New Politics of Tax for Public Spending) - probably the key issue on which the electorate will decide at this election. We have produced a series of short pamphlets on specific policy reforms for a second term - paid parental leave, capital grants for young people, reform of private schools, for example. Many of our publications take on the big challenges of a changing world - globalisation (we have just published a stimulating new pamphlet on its impacts on foreign policy by Peter Hain), the future of democracy in a consumer age, the urgent task of environmental reconstruction.

The point about our publications and events is that they are not just for an elite at Westminster. We believe that politics and political ideas must grow out of a participative culture. The Fabian Society is Britain's only democratically constituted think tank, one you can actually join. We have around 6,000 members and more than 70 local groups around the country, as well as a thriving Young Fabian section. As this Saturday's conference will show, we are passionate about progressive political ideas - and we welcome all who share our ideals.

fields.headline: Observer celebrates scoop
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: The Observer journalist who broke the Mandelson story said he was 'sad that such a talented and clever man was forced to lie' to the press and the government. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Observer editor Roger Alton has praised the work of the paper's social affairs and politics team in breaking the Mandelson passport application story.

Following the spectacular resignation of Mr Mandelson, Mr Alton said the scoop that led to his downfall, by public affairs editor Antony Barnett, chief political correspondent Gaby Hinsliff and Asia correspondent Luke Harding, was a testament to "painstaking and diligent reporting".

"Peter Mandelson has been forced to resign today because he issued an inaccurate statement to one of our journalists via his spokesman at the weekend," said Mr Alton.

"The statement said that Mr Mandelson had made no personal representations on behalf of the Hindujas. This then became the basis for a series of incorrect public statements and press briefings by officials and ministers.

"We believe it was in the public interest that this matter was brought into the open," he continued.

Mr Barnett added that although the story was a triumph for "good, old-fashioned journalism", he was "sad that such a talented and clever man was forced to lie to us on Saturday and continued to lie to the government".

The Observer has been pursuing links between the Hinduja brothers and the funding of the Faith Zone in the Millennium Dome for some months.

Mr Barnett said that after a news story in November, he began receiving information from a number of sources who suggested that Mr Mandelson may have been among ministers who made enquiries on behalf of Mr Hinduja.

He contacted the MP Norman Baker, who tabled questions in the House, in response to which it became clear that Mr Mandelson had been involved.

But the Observer's chief political reporter, Gaby Hinsliff, was told on Saturday that Mr Mandelson had not been in personal contact with the home office.

fields.headline: Bounty, Starburst, and Drifter
fields.trailText: THE FIVER WITH NO NAME
fields.body:
THE FIVER WITH NO NAME

For the last 36 hours, Gary Charles has been missing after his £70,000 Mercedes CL500 Coupé was found abandoned in Hornchurch on Monday night. As no-one is safe in Bandit Country - ie: Essex - the Fiver Missing Persons Bureau quickly organised the biggest manhunt since the Fiver With No Name returned the Texas Seven to the slammer.

First we paid a visit to Gary Tatchell, who saw a Mercedes leased to Charles crash into a Ford Sierra on Monday night. According to Tatchell, the Sierra driver's request for insurance details was met with a twitter of "Just have the car! Just have the car!" from the Mercedes driver. When Sierra man replied, "I don't want the car, mate. I just want the insurance details!", the Mercedes driver jumped back into the car and shot off. Mighty strange behaviour which was duly noted it in our Missing Persons Bureau wipe-clean scribble pad.

Police later found the abandoned Merc with half a bottle of whisky on the front seat, and when Charles didn't show at West Ham's training ground at Chadwell Heath this morning, we knew it was time to act. So we bought some go-faster stripes and attached them to our rusting Ford Cortina. Before long, the old beauty was being smoked along the wild roads of the M25. But we had barely hit Romford when we heard Charles's solicitor announce that the player had contacted the police and is due to be questioned by officers investigating the crash. That's good news for Charles, good news for the Sierra driver - and we're pretty pleased with our Cortina as well.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NOBLE PRIZE WINNERS

It had been a good week for Jermaine Defoe. West Ham's teenage striker, on loan at Bournemouth, had had lots of nice press people coming round and asking him about his goalscoring feats, which had left him on the verge of the post-war goalscoring record in consecutive matches. Jermaine took it all in his stride, got nice compliments from his colleagues, and then went and scored his 10th goal in 10 games last night against Cambridge. He collapsed to his knees in celebration and savoured his "wonderful moment". Then some Manchester City fan had to go and take it away from him.

Or, to be precise, the curator of the MCFC museum (MC stands for "Massive Club"). A statement on City's website this morning revealed, with no small amount of glee, that "City have put a spanner in the works of a record breaking scoring run". Apparently, while "the scribes were eulogizing on their lap tops" about Defoe's strike, curator Phil Noble was verifying that Billy McAdams had done exactly the same thing for City in 1957-58. Or, alternatively, checking with his dad.

"I was there when he did it," Pete Noble told the Fiver when we rang his son's home this afternoon (Phil was at work, obviously chronicling City's recent glories isn't a full-time job). "We didn't know it was the final match. They beat Everton 6-2 in the pissing rain. Ken Barnes got a hat-trick of penalties. The Sun have already been onto us, of course." Of course. But after breaking little Jermaine's heart like that, doesn't he feel a little bit sorry for him? "Not at all. As far as we're concerned, it's Billy Mac's record." The Noble family, City through and through.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It could be a benefit for him, I suppose, as he will be able to see Hartlepool a bit more often" - Hartlepool United spokesman Paul Mullen looks on the bright side following the resignation of club president Peter Mandelson from the Government this afternoon.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CRAZY LEGS, CRAZY DEMANDS

Hassan 'Crazy Legs' Kachloul certainly is one of the most popular men in Southampton. Not only does he amuse the locals with his jocular knock-kneed gait, he also curries favour by scoring the odd goal - as well as doing his level best to get right on Leeds striker Alan Smith's tit-end. But sadly for all concerned, it looks as though the love affair between Hassan and Hampshire will soon be over.

By turning down an "extremely generous" offer from the Southampton board, the Moroccan midfielder today started a transfer tug-of-war between one of English football's "Big Five" clubs (Ipswich) and a smaller outfit who will do well to escape relegation (Spurs). "The club have pushed the boat out as far as we can within our existing pay structure but Hassan has declined the offer of a new two-year contract with us," Saints chairman Rupert Lowe said today. "We hope he changes his mind."

But although Lowe would like to keep hold of Kachloul, he was realistic enough to agree a fee with Ipswich for a player who wants £25,000-a-week and can leave for nothing at the end of the season. Sadly for George Burley, however, Hassan wasn't done with turning things down and his nose up. "The player has decided to stay at The Dell until his contract runs out with them in the summer," said Burley. "We will have a look at things again then, but I'm looking to bring new players to the club sooner rather than later." Looks like Kachloul could be the first in a long line of Southampton employees on their way to north London, then.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal sent scouts to watch Middlesbrough's Mark Schwarzer against Liverpool on Saturday, according to reports.

West Ham look set to complete the signing of Japanese defender Tsuneyasu Miyamoto from Gamba Osaka in a move that is likely to earn the club millions. Harry Redknapp admitted he has never seen Miyamoto play but with £250,000-worth of replica shirt sales already guaranteed, he's not too bothered. "We'll have enough money when we've finished with him to buy Ronaldo," he said.

Bradford are hoping to sign Hearts wing-back Gary Locke on a free transfer this week.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Stan Collymore is close to completing a move to Spanish club Real Oviedo. Oviedo spokesman Miguel Solis said: "We are optimistic he may even play this Sunday. We know Collymore's past history and that he has played for several clubs in England. Oviedo is a friendly town and the club is like a family. We are convinced he will settle down here and that above all he will score goals."

Uefa and Fifa made little progress during talks with the European Commission over changes to the transfer system today. The main stumbling block remains players' contracts: the EC are insisting that contracts between club and players should follow normal European employment law, something Uefa and Fifa are trying to limit.

FA chief executive Adam Crozier has admitted received hate mail since appointing Sven-Goran Eriksson as England coach. Crozier said: "Some of them were quite nasty but you just have to ignore it. There's not a lot I can do about being Scottish though it has only really become a talking-point since Sven was appointed."

Nigerian defender Taribo West has agreed to remain with Derby until the end of the season. "It is all in place. In principle everything is agreed and everybody is happy," manager Jim Smith admitted. "All it needs now is for Taribo to complete the forms when he is back in England on Monday."

Manchester United target Ruud van Nistelrooy is back in training and hopes to be playing again by the end of May. His agent Rodger Linse said: "Ruud is still in the process of rehabilitation - but doing well. And Manchester United are keen to know how he is doing, especially Mr Ferguson who has been very friendly."

Alan Shearer hopes to return to the Newcastle side for their match against Manchester City on February 24, following surgery on his knee.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (11.30pm) [sniff, snivel, moan]

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm, 2am) What on earth is McCaff whining about now?

The Last Word with Jimmy Hill (7pm, 11pm SS3) [drip drip drip]

You're On Sky Sports! (10.30pm, 2.30am) Oh dear! It appears he's not seeking attention this time - in fact, the poor lad's got the sniffles!

Sky Sports 2: Live Worthington Cup Football - Liverpool v Crystal Palace (7pm, 12.30am SS1) "I've got a cold that's dipped into flu, and become a cold again, and I can't shake the thing off. I've tried the whole hit with Lemsip powercaps, and Strepsils coming out of my ears."

Radio Five Live: Sport on Five (7pm) Oh dear! Well, we were doing to take you down the swings, but you'll catch your death in this weather so we'd better not.

Midweek 6-0-6 (10pm) [square-jawed howls, lanky-legged stomping, a cup of coffee is deliberately tipped over]

webTitle: Q&A: The England-Scotland divide on free personal care

fields.headline: Q&A: The England-Scotland divide on free personal care
fields.trailText:
What is the row about?
Essentially, about devolution and self-determination. The Scottish Executive (or "government" as it has suggested it might like to be called) has to decide whether to implement in full the recommendations of the Sutherland report on long-term care, in contrast to England where ministers plan only partial implementation. Breaking ranks with Westminster could be a popular move for first minister Henry McLeish and his Labour administration among Scottish voters; but it could lead to an intolerable strain on relations with his party leader Tony Blair, who is opposed to the move.
fields.body:
What is the row about?
Essentially, about devolution and self-determination. The Scottish Executive (or "government" as it has suggested it might like to be called) has to decide whether to implement in full the recommendations of the Sutherland report on long-term care, in contrast to England where ministers plan only partial implementation. Breaking ranks with Westminster could be a popular move for first minister Henry McLeish and his Labour administration among Scottish voters; but it could lead to an intolerable strain on relations with his party leader Tony Blair, who is opposed to the move.

What is the Sutherland report?
The royal commission on long-term care, to give it its proper title, was set up by the newly elected Labour government in December 1997. Headed by Sir Stewart Sutherland, vice chancellor of Edinburgh University, its report was published in March last year and recommended that all nursing care should be free, wherever it was provided, and that personal care, such as bathing, feeding and dressing, should also be free according to assessed need. The report rejected private insurance and compulsory social insurance schemes, and concluded that the estimated cost of between £800m and £1.2bn should be met by general taxation.

Why was it not implemented in full in England?
Westminster ruled out implementing the Sutherland report in full on the grounds of cost. Instead, as part of the NHS plan unveiled in July, health secretary Alan Milburn pledged to increase spending on care for older people by £1.4bn. All nursing care will be provided free by October 2001 and an extra £900m spent on home care services, a new intermediate care service, with rapid response teams to cut hospital admissions, and 5,000 rehabilitation beds for people leaving hospital.

In addition, the value of the homes of older people moving into residential and nursing homes will be disregarded from means-testing for up to three months and the capital limit for eligibility for local authority funding raised to £18,000.

But Scotland has gone its own way?
Yes and no. Initially Scotland looked set to follow England. A package of measures in response to the Sutherland report similar to that in England was announced by Scottish health minister Susan Deacon in October.

But shortly after being elected first minister, following his predecessor Donald Dewar's subsequent untimely death, Mr McLeish made the Sutherland report a key plank of his new administration, claiming he recognised people's concerns and wanted to "move forward" on it. Most interpreted this as Scotland going it alone and introducing free personal care. In November, the Scottish parliament's health and community care committee added fuel to the fire by calling for personal care to be provided on the basis of need and for the parliament to make a commitment to finding the extra funding.

Has Mr McLeish since been backtracking?
After his initital comments on long-term care, there have been numerous reports of mounting pressure on Mr McLeish from Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, who are anxious that Scotland should not have a different policy from England and Wales in the run-up to a general election. Blair is said to fear that full implementation of Sutherland in Scotland could fuel similar demands from pensioners south of the border and the spectre has been raised of a vast influx of better-off English people keen to take advantage of the possibility of free personal care in Scotland. In recent weeks, McLeish has been subtly playing down the whole issue. He has consistently denied he ever said he would implement the report in full.

Why should Scotland be any different?
Because it can, basically. The whole point of devolution is that the devolved legislatures in Scotland and Wales can allocate their spending according to local priorities and needs. It is up to the Scottish parliament to decide what it does with its annual budget of £20bn - let alone its tax-raising powers which have so far not been used - and the estimated £110m needed to introduce free personal care is not seen as a major problem.

There could also be some justification because Scotland has a far stronger tradition of publicly-provided social welfare and a higher proportion of elderly people living in poverty - in 1999 some 175,000 Scots pensioners qualified for income support because their income was too low.

The Scottish Executive working group which will look at extending the number of people who qualify for free personal care will not report for six months - conveniently after the most likely date for the next general election. Pressure has been mounting consistently from all sides to implement the report in full. But even if the cash is found, a two-tier system throughout the UK is unlikely to be acceptable politically.

The Scottish Executive (or "government" as it has suggested it might like to be called) has to decide whether to implement in full the recommendations of the Sutherland report on long-term care, in contrast to England where ministers plan only partial implementation. Breaking ranks with Westminster could be a popular move for first minister Henry McLeish and his Labour administration among Scottish voters; but it could lead to an intolerable strain on relations with his party leader Tony Blair, who is opposed to the move. Headed by Sir Stewart Sutherland, vice chancellor of Edinburgh University, its report was published in March last year and recommended that all nursing care should be free, wherever it was provided, and that personal care, such as bathing, feeding and dressing, should also be free according to assessed need. webTitle: Scientists predict stem cell trials by 2004

fields.headline: Scientists predict stem cell trials by 2004
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The first human trials of embryo stem cells as a treatment for Parkinson's disease could take place within three to five years, experts said yesterday.
fields.body:
The first human trials of embryo stem cells as a treatment for Parkinson's disease could take place within three to five years, experts said yesterday.

A vote in the House of Lords on Monday night cleared the last political hurdle to a change in the rules governing research on human embryos.

For the past 10 years, the only use permitted has been for infertility treatment and research. Now, against hotly argued opposition, and two years of examination by a procession of committees, both Commons and Lords have approved the use of embryos up to 14 days old for research into treatments for a wide range of diseases.

Stem cells are the natural source of all human tissue: a transplant of stem cells could, in theory, repair liver damage, or heart muscle, or spinal cord injury. Embryo stem cells can develop into any, or all of the 200 specialist cells in thehuman body. But the first targets are likely to be the slow, neurodegenerative diseases.

Research could begin with the collection and preservation of stem cells from up to 1,000 existing embryos, all of which must be destroyed if not used for fertility treatment. These 1,000 dishes of frozen cells would, said Richard Gardner of Oxford University, cover the range needed for safe transplantation. The hope is that injected stem cells of the correct type would migrate to the damaged organs and at least relieve symptoms.

"You would have them there in anticipation of patient needs," he said. "You wouldn't have the harrowing situation that exists at the moment of a patient having to wait for someone else to die before they have any prospect of a transplant."

Simon Best, of the Bioindustry Association, said that the first applications for experimental licences would be from researchers already focused on human need.

"Obviously, Parkinson's is a very good case. My prediction would be: the first human trials in perhaps three years," he said. "If things go very well, you may see the first small-scale commercial application seven years from now."

Austin Smith of Edinburgh University's centre for genome research said yesterday that the Lords verdict was "a decision of vision and hope" and that scientists needed to develop their knowledge and techniques as rapidly as possible.

"Our initial target will be to generate nerve cells that might be used to treat neurodegenerative conditions such as Parkinson's or Huntington's diseases. We are only at the beginning of this research, however, and I think it will be at least five years and probably somewhat longer before the first cell transplantations into humans."

Other diseases in the researchers' sights include diabetes, muscular dystrophy, multiple sclerosis, stroke and spinal cord injury.

Although much of the debate centred on so-called "therapeutic cloning", the creation of embryos from cells fertilised by transferred DNA, this is not likely to happen in the near future. "In practical terms it isn't a realistic thing for helping patients on a large scale," said Professor Gardner.

Nor is there likely to be a stampede for permission to start on research with embryos. "You have got to be highly motivated to want to do that work. The bureaucracy involved in any human embryo work, like animal work, is very dramatic," he said. "It deters all but the most committed."
