fields.headline: BBC website advertising plans condemned
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: The BBC's plans to sell advertising on a proposed international website have been condemned, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The BBC's plans to sell advertising on a soon-to-launch international website, BBCNews.com, have been branded a "clear breach of public service principles".

The British Internet Publishers Alliance has condemned the BBC developing BBCNews.com into a commercial venture that will take content from its licence fee funded services, such as BBC.co.uk.

"The content has been paid for directly by the licence fee, and they are now using it to compete directly against ITN, Reuters, the FT, the Guardian, and other British news providers who are looking to create an international business," said Rob Hersov, chairman of BIPA and ceo of Sportal.

"This could be very damaging to the these high-quality British news providers.

"If the BBC keeps setting itself these revenue targets which it claims are necessary to meet its programme-making commitments - £400m quoted in the FT today - then why does it spend these vast sums online, replicating high-quality private sector services already available?"

The plans have been mooted for more than a year but the BBC has held back from revealing details of how exactly it will structure the venture, instead insisting it was "discussing" the issue of a commercially funded international news site.

So far the BBC has refused to comment on whether a definite decision has been taken to support the international news website with advertising. A summer launch date has been suggested.

An announcement was expected next week but has been put back to "sometime in the near future".

The site will offer news to an international audience and will not be marketed to licence payers.

The BBC said it was a justified move and pointed out that it would draw even more criticism if it didn't try to make money out of foreign, non-licence fee paying audiences.

Half the visitors to BBC Online come from overseas. Although the corporation has never revealed how many people visit its sites, it pulls in an estimated 10m users a month, with an average of 200m page impressions per month.

The key issues at stake include how much content will be taken from bbc.co.uk/news, a BBC's public service funded website and who exactly within the corporation is stumping up the cash.

It is thought that BBC Worldwide has been gunning to take control of BBCNews.com for some time, in order to clear up misunderstandings and draw a boundary between public and commercial. But BBC News has been fighting to keep the website under its control.

To this end, BBC Worldwide's internet and interactive division has been developing BBC.com for some time and says it has worked out a way in which it can use technology to tell where a person is logging on from, and direct them to the relevant site.

BBC Worldwide has never denied that it would take advertising on BBC.com, which will launch later this year as an "international portal for overseas visitors to experience the BBC".

BIPA is furious that the BBC can expand at a time when budgets for internet advertising are being slashed by major media corporations.

It argues that the corporation has no right under its charter to launch BBCNews.com - and indeed BBC.com - to start competing overseas against other home-grown organisations.

BIPA has already lodged a legal complaint with the European Commission, which is currently investigation the BBC's use of state aid.

The BBC has already spent more than £150m on its public service websites, which are widely regarded as among the best in the world.

However, the Commission is said to be particularly interested in the "cross border effects" of using public funds to prop up businesses overseas. The issues of unfair competition could ultimately hinder the BBC's expansion.

The BBC secured the domain name bbcnews.com in October last year after a domain name battle against a US cybersquatter.

webTitle: Price of justice - failed by the legal system

fields.headline: Price of justice
fields.standfirst: All he wanted was the chance to rebuild his life shattered by sexual and physical abuse, but the legal system failed him.  Linda Jackson  reports on his ordeal
fields.trailText: All he wanted was the chance to rebuild his life shattered by sexual and physical abuse, but the legal system failed him. Linda Jackson reports on his ordeal
fields.body:
After 14 years of systematic sexual and physical abuse, and a further six years fighting for compensation, Zak Savio thought his ordeal was finally over. One of the most traumatised victims of Britain's worst child sex abuse scandal, he hoped to use compensation money to rebuild his life and go to college.

To his shock, however, the former resident of Bryn Alyn children's home, north Wales, has been warned he is unlikely to receive a penny of a £50,000 settlement because it has all been eaten up in legal costs totalling almost £200,000. His plight has been described as "extraordinary" by the legal services commission, formerly the legal aid board.

Savio, now 30, is one of a growing number of former children's home residents who, despite being proven abuse victims, are failing to get any money for the pain and damage they have suffered. At least six others are considering suing lawyers who, they allege, advised them to abandon compensation claims halfway through a battle for damages.

All are victims of a legal system that stands in the way of successful claims against institutions, according to child abuse solicitors who are calling for changes in the funding of legal costs in complex and drawn out cases. They also say urgent action is needed to simplify the compensation system.

Official figures suggest more than 2,000 people have begun civil proceedings for compensation for abuse they suffered in care in England and Wales. But it is thought there could eventually be as many as 15,000 potential claimants. Most, like Savio, are young men - many of whom have been pursuing claims for more than five years over abuse that happened as long as 30 years ago.

Time lags such as these cause particular problems, according to Peter Garsden, executive officer of the Association of Child Abuse Solicitors. "There are frequently difficulties in locating documents, which may be destroyed," he says. "Add to this the strict time limits, within which proceedings should be issued, and an obstructive defence which makes technical points in the hope of wearing down the claimant who is already very vulnerable."

Savio's case is a tragic example of how the system can add to the trauma suffered by abuse victims. Unable to escape the horrors that haunt him, he says he has tried to commit suicide 10 times. The last attempt was less than 12 months ago, when his solicitors told him he was "unlikely" to receive any money for a settlement they had just reached. A week later, details of the assaults he suffered, along with hundreds of other vulnerable young people at Bryn Alyn and other children's homes in north Wales, were catalogued with publication of the Waterhouse report, the biggest inquiry into child abuse in Britain.

For Savio, who grew up thinking it was normal for men to have sex with boys, it was a despair he hoped he would never know again. In 1995, there was a justice of sorts when his abuser John Allen, former head of Bryn Alyn, was jailed for six years for indecent assault of boys in his care. Twelve months later, his hopes of a fresh start rose when his solicitors, Stephens Innocent (now Finers Stephens Innocent), claimed for damages for psychological disturbance caused by neglect, maltreatment and physical and sexual abuse he suffered between the ages of four and 18 while in local authority care.

Writs were issued in 1996 against Warwickshire county council, Bryn Alyn Community Holdings and Royal Insurance, the home's insurers. All contested the claims - and the solicitors spent the next three years trawling through files for evidence. During that time, Bryn Alyn Community Holdings went into liquidation.

In July 1999, Stephens Innocent said Savio would accept a settlement of £50,000 from Warwickshire, after the authority offered to pay £30,000. The higher figure was agreed in January 2000. Around the same time, an agreement was reached with Bryn Alyn Community Holdings and Royal Insurance that Savio would discontinue the action with no order for costs except legal aid assessment.

It is understood that a separate group action against Bryn Alyn will be heard in court next month.

Savio recalls: "I was told I had to accept the settlement - otherwise my legal aid would be withdrawn and I would get nothing. I had hoped for more than £50,000. In one case that has gone to court, someone has received £180,000. All I wanted was enough money to go to college, get a flat and start my life again."

Within days of the agreement, Savio was devastated to receive a letter from Nicola Solomon, a partner at Stephens Innocent, setting out the implications of the settlement. She explained: "It is likely you will not receive more than the £1,500 in the end; in fact, it is quite likely that the whole of the £50,000 will go in legal costs".

The news tipped Savio over the edge. He cut his wrists and took an overdose. He was discovered almost dead on the beach at Brighton, where he lives. "Someone found me and I was taken to hospital," recalls Savio, who has spent the last 12 months in despair. "I have put the last five years of my life into this - all for nothing."

Solomon insists she is "very disappointed" with the outcome of Savio's claim. "It is an extraordinary situation which is very unjust to Zak," she says. However, she adds that she painted a worst-case scenario in her letter - and that she hopes to be able to secure some money for him following a court assessment of costs in June. Asked about the decision to settle, she says it was taken on counsel's advice. "We were advised that we would not get more than £50,000 overall from all three claimants - the maximum we could hope for. The decision to settle was made on that basis. "

The case has shocked the legal services commission. "It is very unusual for a damages award to end up being much less than the costs of a case," says spokesman Colin Stutt. Legal aid would have been awarded on the understanding that any damages would outweigh the cost, he explains. New rules, introduced under the Access to Justice Act, mean there are extra controls on cases expected to cost £25,000 or more, for which all costs have to be agreed in advance by the commission.

These controls should prevent a repeat of Savio's case. But Garsden, who represents 700 abuse claimants, wants major changes in the way all compensation claims are handled.

"There are all sorts of ways in which the process of compensation could be made simpler for claimants," he says. "First, the burden of proof should be on the defendant, not the claimant. Defendants would have to prove how well they looked after the claimant.

"We also need to see all records at a much earlier stage. We have had enormous difficulty getting hold of social care records. In some cases, the names of abusers have been deleted. We also need to lift the time limitation so cases aren't hurried together. Furthermore, employers should not be able to argue that they are not responsible for the abuse of their employees. Finally, costs must be proportionate to the damages recovered. At the moment, they have no bearing on the amount of damages received."

Such changes would bring small comfort to Savio, who has to be content with a £1,500 loan from his solicitors - repayable if there is money left in the settlement once the costs have been sorted.

Debbie Jones, director of Voices in Care, a charity which campaigned for 11 years for the north Wales inquiry, sums it up. "Zak has been betrayed in every stage of his life," she says. "All he wanted was justice and a quality of life. Now he is a victim again."

fields.headline: Threat of sanctions hits home
fields.standfirst: The possibility of sanctions is leading to victims of the drought trying to stockpile what little provisions they have, writes Prue Peart
fields.trailText: The lastest installment of Prue Peart'sdiary comes from Islamabad, where she reports on what the threat of sanctions will mean to both aid workers and drought victims
fields.body:
January 19, 2001
Stuart Templeton, Ockenden's relief programme manager, has been working in Herat since before Christmas, trying to implement a programme that will provide assistance to the many people who fled to the city as a result of the drought.

Today Stuart is in Islamabad while the result of the UN demand is awaited. Speaking to him, it is very difficult to see what impact the sanctions could have on the ordinary people - they already have so little and are so isolated.

Work for Ockenden has been continuing since I left in December. It is frustrating as my scheduled visit this month has had to be postponed as a result of the potential sanctions. My frustration turns to helplessness as I hear that the cloth we were waiting for while I was there has still not arrived, but everyone is hopeful it will appear soon.

In preparation for the possible sanctions Stuart does mention that people are starting to stockpile what essentials they can, but he does not think this will go on for long, after all there is not a great deal they can stockpile.

While the news on the sanctions is awaited, all non-governmental organisations offices, including Ockenden, have closed in Herat and are unable to operate as normal. I hope this will just be until next week and I will be able to look at the possibility of doing the second stage of my work, and Stuart can look to go back to Afghanistan to ensure those people most in need are given the urgent help they require.

fields.headline: M&S 'simply not good enough'
fields.trailText: Ailing Marks & Spencer took another turn for the worse yesterday as it confirmed appalling Christmas trading figures and admitted that its clothes are "simply not good enough".
fields.body:
Ailing Marks & Spencer took another turn for the worse yesterday as it confirmed appalling Christmas trading figures and admitted that its clothes are "simply not good enough".

The figures were the worst of any leading high street chain, with like-for-like sales 5.1% down in the 16 weeks to January 20 and underlying sales of general, non-food merchandise collapsing by 9.6% . It is the third year in a row that M&S sales have lurched downwards over Christmas.

Clothing, footwear and gifts were the worst peforming departments, with like-for-like sales estimated to be down 11.2%.

The group admitted that many of its new "concept stores" - on which it has pinned hopes of a turnaround - have been falling well short of expectations.

Luc Vandevelde, the chairman who two months ago promised real sales growth and a "wonderful Christmas", now says the stores needs better merchandise for there to be an about-turn.

The adult clothing ranges had "inconsistent appeal" which left M&S with too much stock to clear at marked down prices and needed "consistently better design".

Mr Vandevelde blamed previous management for many of the problems - accusing his predecessors of lacking objectivity - and blamed himself for not getting rid of them all earlier.

The former chief executive, Peter Salsbury, left only four months ago and his replacement, Roger Holmes, recruited from electrical retailer Comet, has only just started work.

Yesterday Robert Colvill - the finance director and only member of the old guard left in the boardroom - said M&S was drafting in new designers to put clothes on the racks that shoppers want to buy.

"We need to get new blood into the regime," he said. "Good goods is the only answer."

Richard Ratner, analyst at Seymour Pierce, was unimpressed. "We all know the problem is the clothing. We could have told them that."

He had little confidence that M&S was capable of delivering on its promises. "You can dress a pig up how you like, but it it is still a pig."

Mr Colvill confirmed that the experiment with concept stores - with goods grouped by lifestyle and as outfits, rather than on racks of skirts, trousers or blouses - has not been a resounding success.

M&S spent up to £4m each to refurbish 23 stores, but they performed only 4% better than comparable stores which were not revamped. Trading at some concept stores had deteriorated. "We need to get to the bottom of it," said Mr Colvill.

When Mr Vandevelde took over last year he promised a turnaround by the start of 2002. Yesterday Mr Colvill said: "Luc said he would turn it round within a two-year time frame and he stands by that. But there is no premium for us to say when the turn will come."

There were bright spots. Food sales were ahead 2.1% and home furnishings an estimated 11.4%. Gross margins rose 0.8%.

The shares climbed 5.5p to 205.5p, mainly on relief that the figures were not worse. Analysts were still urging investors to sell.

fields.headline: Reaction to the resignation
fields.trailText:
Tony Blair, prime minister
I believe that he is a bigger man than many of his critics.
fields.body:
Tony Blair, prime minister
I believe that he is a bigger man than many of his critics.

Bertie Ahern, Irish prime minister
I applaud the role he has played in the on-going implementation of the Good Friday agreement. Both the minister for foreign affairs and I have had a good and effective working relationship with Mr Mandelson during his term of office, and I wish him well in the future.

William Hague, Conservative leader
(To Mr Blair) Now you've notched up the historic achievement of being forced to sack the same minister for the same offence, twice in 25 months, do you recognise that your career-long dependency on Mr Mandelson has been a monumental error of judgment?

Charles Kennedy, Liberal Democrat leader
Peter Mandelson has made the right decision to resign. After 18 years of Conservative sleaze, the public needed the government to restore their faith in the political process.

Robin Cook, foreign secretary
I feel for him. He has a lot of talent. He has worked very hard for the Northern Ireland peace process.

David Trimble, first minister of Northern Ireland
I and many others appreciate the efforts he has done

Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein leader
It is a matter of public record that Peter Mandelson and Sinn Fein were in disagreement over many issues. Notwithstanding that, I wish him well for the future

Russell Hart, leader of the Labour group on Hartlepool council
I can understand why Mr Mandelson has taken a personal decision to resign as Northern Ireland secretary, although I am disappointed.

Cedric Wilson, leader of the anti-Good Friday agreement Northern Ireland Unionist Party
There is now a window of opportunity for the Prime Minister to replace Mr Mandelson with a Secretary of State who is prepared to listen to the views of the majority of the unionist community.

John Swinney, SNP leader
Peter Mandelson was largely responsible for creating New Labour, and personifies its untrustworthiness

David Blunkett, education secretary
I thought he was an excellent minister at the DTI and the Northern Ireland Office and I can only wish him well for the future.

fields.headline: BAT under fire from pressure group
fields.trailText:
4.40pm: An anti-smoking group has hit back against what it calls a 'sleazy' marketing initiative by BAT, writes Daniel Rogers.
Jan 24: Action urged on 'invisible' marketing
Jan 24: BAT embraces 'backdoor branding'
Jan 24: BAT lures young smokers
Read the leaked memo
Useful link: City Gorilla
fields.body:
Ash, the anti-smoking pressure group, is registering the www.citygorilla.org domain name in a strike back against what it calls a "sleazy" marketing initiative by British American Tobacco.

Ash said it will dedicate the site to exposing BAT's underhand marketing practices.

It emerged today that BAT had registered a series of City Gorilla domain names - including www.citygorilla.com - for sites providing night-life guides for young people around the globe.

A leaked memo obtained by MediaGuardian.co.uk revealed that BAT wants to use the sites - which have no obvious connection to the tobacco company - to drive young smoker to bars, clubs and restaurants outlets selling and promoting its brand.

Ash director Clive Bates said: "I have applied today to register citygorilla.org. The site will tell the truth about BAT and its covert and sleazy marketing practices."

"Hopefully when people put citygorilla into their search engine they will come across our site instead," he added.

This week BAT launched a pilot site in Poland - www.citygorilla.pl - which claims to provide an objective guide to venues in cities such as Warsaw.

A BAT spokesman responded: "Assuming Ash's registration is successful, we will watch it with interest."

fields.headline: The Mandelson I knew
fields.standfirst:
How was a man with the ear of the prime minister brought down so quickly? Peter Mandelson's erstwhile spin doctor Benjamin Wegg-Prosser on the abrupt end to his political career

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: How was a man with the ear of the prime minister brought down so quickly? Peter Mandelson's erstwhile spin doctor Benjamin Wegg-Prosser on the abrupt end to his political career
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson should not have been brought down by his own spin, but twice he has been. How has this happened? As his spin doctor for three years, I saw how he often delivered for the Labour party, but failed to look after himself.

Until he joined the cabinet in 1998, he spent 13 years trying to persuade the media and the public that his plans to modernise the Labour party were the right ones. In doing so he provided his colleagues - from Neil Kinnock and Tony Blair to Gordon Brown - with invaluable support.

Not only did he do their bidding and spinning but he took it upon himself, unwisely perhaps as it now turns out, to build relations with powerful and influential people. In doing so, he gained a strong network of contacts outside Westminster, but only a few within the House of Commons - where he was simply accused of being behind every leak or dark manoeuvre.

It was never quite as simple as that, but to his colleagues and enemies he was always the easiest target. He both relished and abhorred this reputation. You can be certain that those senior figures he served were always grateful to have him there and desperately sorry that he has gone today. It is this legacy which has left him, this afternoon, at the end of his frontline political career.

And that is the paradox of his resignation. Despite having the prime minister as his most powerful ally in Westminster, he has been unable to summon any support from his colleagues or the media. While there appears to be nothing improper in his involvement in the passport application of Srichand Hinduja, he has not been able to fight off the attacks from all sides.

What's more, while the advice which he has given his political masters over the years has been spot on, he has never had the time to develop a political persona for himself. That's left him with blind spots when he has come under pressure, as he did on Saturday, when the response given on his behalf to the Observer over the passport application was unclear.

However, despite this lack of personal political nous, it would be wrong to say that he does not have his own values. Through his relationships with senior colleagues, he managed to implement many of the things he strongly believed in. Kinnock would not have ditched unilateralism when he did without him; and Blair would not have remained as committed in principle to the euro had Mandelson not argued the case in private and public.

He will have the strength to rebuild himself, just as he did two years ago after his home loan resignation. As a friend and former colleague, I hope he keeps out of politics and builds the satisfying and fulfilling life that he deserves.

fields.headline: Events leading up to sanctions
fields.trailText:
January 19 2001
In December 2000 the UN security council gave Afghanistan's Taliban 30 days to hand over international terrorist Osama bin Laden. They were given 30 days to comply, which ends today, or face sanctions designed to ensure the militia's almost complete international isolation.
fields.body:
January 19 2001
In December 2000 the UN security council gave Afghanistan's Taliban 30 days to hand over international terrorist Osama bin Laden. They were given 30 days to comply, which ends today, or face sanctions designed to ensure the militia's almost complete international isolation.

UN secretary general Kofi Annan has said the measures will not help the UN's vital humanitarian efforts or UN-backed peace talks between the Taliban and opposition forces, which the militia has threatened to boycott.

On December 19 2000, the UN withdrew all its international staff from Afghanistan and began to return them a few days later. However, the ceiling for the number of expats that the UN will allow to be present in Afghanistan at any one time has effectively been halved since the issue of the sanctions resolution.

The International Committee of the Red Cross took the decision to keep all its staff in Afghanistan when the resolution was considered and some non-governmental organisations (NGOs), including Ockenden, adopted the same policy.

Many people are wondering if sanctions could be counter-productive and if sanctions could make the Taliban regime even more isolated from international opinion. Many humanitarian agencies are concerned sanctions could result in hostility towards the UN and NGOs. And many are still concerned that they have not been able to undertake enough work to ensure that the drought's impact is minimised to prevent famine spreading in remote areas where most people live subsistance lifestyles.

UN officials have warned that up to a million Afghans could starve to death this year if the next harvest fails and urgent international aid does not arrive.

fields.headline: Sky confident in ITV news battle
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Sky News bosses were celebrating victory in the first battle to supply ITV with its news, write Lisa O'Carroll and Jason Deans.
Jan 23: ITN slams 'ragbag rivals'

Jan 23: Rivals bid for ITV news
Dec 12: Law change threatens ITN
Nov 13: Sky in bid for ITV news
fields.body:
Sky News bosses were today quietly celebrating victory in the first battle to supply ITV with its News at Ten and other bulletins.

After enduring countless barbs about their unsuitability to supply ITV with its news, Sky News boss Nick Pollard believes they are now being taken seriously.

He said he was amused by ITN's decision to brand the consortium challenging the news firm as a "ragbag partnership crafted from desperation".

The consortium involves five TV companies including CBS, Bloomberg, Chrysalis and Ulster TV.

"ITN's reaction to the consortium's bid was very uncool. They should have said they welcome competition and said they were perfectly confident about regaining the contract. But to spit the dummy out like that was a bit silly," said Mr Pollard.

"It think they are panicking," he added.

The consortium's bid for the contract will at worst be used to hammer down the price of ITV's news when negotiations for the contract start in earnest.

It will also fuel ITV suspicions that the network is subsidising the news for Channel 4 and Channel 5.

One source said: "The ITV contract accounts for 45% of their revenue but close to 100% of their profit. Take the ITV contract out of the equation and there will be no ITN."

CBS News will use its "expertise in newsgathering and production" to help win the ITV news contract from ITN.

"This is a way for us to participate in a long-term newsgathering relationship in the UK," a CBS News spokeswoman said.

"It's an opportunity for us, along with our partners, to use our expertise in newsgathering and production and a way to raise our profile internationally," she added.

As well daily news bulletins, CBS News produces current affairs and features shows including Sixty Minutes and 48 Hours.

UTV managing director John McCann said the Northern Ireland ITV company brought its "own unique qualities to this consortium", which "formed part of our overall strategy to position the company as a broad media player".

"We have provided an award-winning news service throughout Ireland over the past 40 years - particularly in Northern Ireland, which has been one of the most difficult and controversial news areas in the world."

fields.headline: Blair backs 'courageous' Mandelson
fields.standfirst: Ex-Northern Ireland secretary 'bigger man than his critics'
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today defended former Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson in the face of attacks from William Hague, who said the affair demonstrated his "disgraceful" leadership.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today defended former Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson in the face of attacks from William Hague, who said the affair demonstrated his "disgraceful" leadership.

As Mr Mandelson looked on mournfully, Conservative leader Mr Hague said that his reappointment to the cabinet in 1999 "was a demonstration of the arrogance with which the prime minister wields his power".

Referring to Mr Blair's promises before the 1997 general election, Mr Hague said: "He said they would be purer than pure, and as in every other pledge they have failed to deliver."

The prime minister said he has ordered an inquiry into the process by which Srichand Hinduja, a wealthy Asian businessman who donated £1m to the Millennium Dome's faith zone, had obtained his citizenship. The inquiry will be headed by the former Treasury solicitor, Sir Anthony Hammond.

In the run up to an election, the last thing Tony Blair needed today was to face the House of Commons over a scandal involving the minister closest to him. Mr Blair praised the "personal courage and sense of duty" of Mr Mandelson in facing the house today for Northern Ireland questions.

"I believe he is a bigger man than many of his critics," Mr Blair said of his friend.

But his praise failed to stem the criticism, which he could counter only by saying that Mr Mandelson's performance in Northern Ireland vindicated the decision to reappoint him. Mr Mandelson last resigned in December 1998 in the wake of a scandal involving a £300,000 home loan from the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson.

Mr Mandelson had been summoned to Number 10 earlier in the day to explain his role in the Hinduja passport affair. Critics had called on Mr Mandelson to resign after he failed to disclose a phone call that he made to the Home Office on behalf of Mr Hinduja.

Mr Blair opened prime minister's question time by saying, "I accept that the reply of the Northern Ireland secretary was misleading and I accepted his resignation on that basis."

However, Mr Blair insisted that the intervention of Mr Mandelson had not tainted the work of the Home Office in awarding Mr Hinduja a British passport.

webTitle: Row over RCN's top job highlights power struggle

fields.headline: Row over RCN's top job highlights power struggle
fields.standfirst: Finding a successor to veteran Royal College of Nursing general secretary Christine Hancock that would satisfy competing factions in the college was always going to be tough, writes Patrick Butler
fields.trailText: Analysis: Finding a successor to veteran Royal College of Nursing general secretary Christine Hancock that would satisfy competing factions in the college was always going to be tough, writes Patrick Butler
fields.body:
Finding a successor to veteran Royal College of Nursing (RCN) general secretary Christine Hancock that would satisfy competing factions in the college was always going to be tough.

Ms Hancock will take up the presidency of the international conference of nurses in June, having built up a reputation as the UK's most powerful nurse, a smart operator who has given the college a high media profile and policy influence.

Her departure has activated the latent power struggle between the RCN's activist wing - who would like to see the RCN become like a trade union - and the establishment wing, who would like to see it become more like a medical royal college.

The non-shortlisting of Tom Bolger, Ms Hancock's deputy for the past 10 years, Pippa Gough, the college's policy unit head, and Jane Salvage, a nurse and journalist (and outspoken critic of the RCN under Ms Hancock), is seen as a snub to the activist wing.

But it is difficult, on the face of it, to see the shortlist as a roll call of the establishment or as a sign that the current RCN leadership is seeking to perpetuate the status quo.

A SocietyGuardian.co.uk article last November noted that Alison Kitson, the director of the RCN institute regarded as a front runner for the top job, was likely to "shock matron" with her "spiky hair and leather trousers".

An RCN insider, but hardly establishment, even if her detractors regard her as a "policy wonk" and allegedly not the most streetwise of political operators.

Ms Kitson's closest rival, according to press reports, is Beverly Malone, a black American nurse union leader and aide to former President Bill Clinton.

A glance at her track record shows high calibre political credentials, extensive experience in both clinical and academic areas, and a public profile in the US that pushed her onto an Ebony magazine list of the "100 most prominent African-Americans".

A decision on the appointment is expected in the next few days, possibly - but not necessarily - after RCN council meets in Belfast on Friday and Saturday this week.

Commenting on the today's Guardian article, an RCN spokesperson said: "After advertising in The Guardian, The Sunday Times and Nursing Standard, as well as using an executive search consultancy, a shortlist was drawn up and interviews are taking place.

"As with any employment process it is impossible to say exactly when an announcement will be made, because this will be affected by the current circumstances of the appointee."

fields.headline: A new breed of birds and bees
fields.standfirst: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.trailText: Leah Wild's IVF diary.
fields.body:
'You must have had sex then." My seven-year-old was sitting in the back of the car as I drove. We had been listening to the radio, not talking much, but she must have been mulling over her mother's big belly. She repeated the word she was so delighted with: "Dad and you must have had sex. That's how you got pregnant."

I didn't reply; I couldn't. I didn't know what to say. "Was it in the night or in the day?" I was still silent. "I bet it was in the night, so I couldn't see you."

A friend calls it the "new birds 'n' bees" - having to explain to any sibling, and then the children themselves, that conception was not in a moment of passion but in a petri dish. My daughter has just come to grips with the mechanics of the old-fashioned two-in-a-bed method and is immensely proud of her newfound knowledge, imparting it to any ignorant schoolmates and elderly aunts for its shockability value.

How can I tell her that this isn't how her very own mum and dad have gone about the baby business? That the deliciously naughty sex was not something we had indulged in to produce her twin siblings. An entirely different method was employed, where the time of day didn't matter under the glare of laboratory lights.

I miss the assisted conception unit. I have been cut loose from its care. I will never have to go into that waiting room again, flick through the messy piles of free leaflets (Mucus Hostility, Fibroids, Assisted Hatching, Adoption UK) and try to jumpstart the broken coffee machine when our appointment is running late (again).

I harbour a strange nostalgia for a time of intense longing. For a while now I have wanted to call them, on some flimsy pretext. I sent them all Christmas cards - the professor, the IVF nurse coordinator, the genetic counsellor - but, like the saddest King John, received none in return. They have done their job. Now, according to the medical profession, I'm just another pregnant woman.

But according to nearly everyone else, I am not. "How's your infertility treatment going?" asked a friend, my belly bulging between us. When will my infertility treatment become a pregnancy like anyone else's? But it is not only how others see our post-treatment progress, but how we see ourselves.

"I found it almost impossible to say that I was pregnant, it seemed too normal. I was an infertility patient, and now I was an infertility patient whose treatment had been successful," I read in the newsletter of AceBabes, a charity for a small minority - families following successful assisted conception.

AceBabes has produced an awareness-raising calendar to "show the reality of the beautiful children, rather than a statistic on a piece of paper" with photographs and footprints of children born through IVF. It makes me uncomfortable. I do not like the display of our offspring as different, defined by their experiences when a mere cluster of cells. On the long road to adult life, a few days in a lab seems of little significance unless we chose to make it so.

Perhaps we barren women are reluctant to surrender our special status. Perhaps, despite our plea that all we desire is the easy joy of parenthood others take for granted, when faced with being just another number at the antenatal clinic, it is a bit of a let-down. At my appointment with the consultant obstetrician last week, I asked if he could be at the birth, and he laughed. Why should he oversee the arrival of my children more than anyone else's? As far as he was concerned, my pregnancy was a pretty standard matter.

It was a sobering moment, which at first made me wince. How could he be so cruel? I began to argue: "It's been a long road to get this far ..." as if he should care how the milky forms hovering on the ultrasound screen came to be his prenatal patients. Who cares whether or not their parents had sex to conceive them? He clearly didn't.

At some point, I will explain to my seven-year-old how her siblings were conceived, as I will explain to them. My daughter may even find, to her great enjoyment, that the true story is more shocking to elderly aunts than her parents having sex in the dark.

But I hope it won't be shocking to anyone else. I hope they consider it no more defining of her siblings than the obstetrician did. My twins will not be Miss and Master April in the AceBabes calendar. They will just be spring babies. And I will just be what I have striven and wanted to be again for the last seven years. A parent.

webTitle: Parents: What did the Kilshaws do wrong?

fields.headline: So where did the Kilshaws really go wrong?
fields.standfirst:
Helen Carter on how the Kilshaws have struggled under the spotlight

Special report: babies for sale
<A HREF="http://www.pixunlimited.co.uk:7080/ramgen/news/politics/0123hcarter.ra">Audio: Helen Carter at the high court (1min 56)
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Helen Carter on how the Kilshaws have struggled under the spotlight.
fields.body:
Much has been written about Judith and Alan Kilshaw in the past week. They have hogged the headlines and their faces have dominated television news bulletins. One thing is clear: they do not present themselves well in interviews. The more they speak to the media, the more scorn is heaped on them and the more doubt is cast upon their credibility.

Alan is clearly an intelligent, articulate man who is able to deflect deftly any questions thrown at him. Always smartly dressed in a dark shirt and tie, he looks you straight in the eye and is able to argue his case eloquently and forcefully.

Judith, who dresses garishly, is prone to melodrama. There is a sense that she often speaks without choosing her words carefully. Alan appears keen to keep a check on her more wild-eyed, vociferous moments. Eager to maintain control at all times, he attempts to quieten her when she complains about some of the questions she is asked.

In between interviews and incandescent with rage, Judith fulminates to anyone who will listen about being barred from Buckley Royal British Legion club for dancing. He urges her to stick to the point and waves his hands in a gesture to calm her. It seems to work for a while.

However, when alone, Judith is more likely to speak her mind. At one point, during the hours after the babies were taken back by social services, she was uncompromising in her view that she was going to go back to the US and adopt two other children. It was as though she did not care about what people thought.

There is also a more vulnerable side to Judith, which rarely comes across in the many interviews she has given. At the end of a long week and surrounded by reporters in a crowded hotel bar, she appeared totally exhausted. But she was still volatile: within minutes, she stormed off after an argument with one of the journalists present. She seems very far from at ease under the constant scrutiny.

One reporter advised her to go home to her family - she nodded in agreement - but the Kilshaws did not return home until 48 hours later.

Perhaps, in the comfort of their seven-bedroom farmhouse in Buckley, north Wales, they will finally stop giving interviews and soundbites to all and sundry. Somehow, I doubt it.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Dr Andrew Wakefield's claims about adverse reactions to the MMR vaccine are fuelling further controversy. Are parents right to hesitate over the triple inoculation?
fields.trailText: The Question: Dr Andrew Wakefield's claims about adverse reactions to the MMR vaccine are fuelling further controversy. Are parents right to hesitate over the triple inoculation?
fields.body:
Peter Todd
Solicitor acting for claimants in MMR litigation

My nine-month-old son, Alexander, has had diptheria tetanus and acellular pertussis, polio, HIB and meningitis C. Today, he is going for the tuberculosis vaccine too. So I am keen on vaccines! However, when my son's invitation for the MMR jab arrives shortly, he won't be going - at least not for a couple of years. I am acting in legal claims for a number of parents who believe the vaccine has seriously injured their child. After consideration, I would say that, although there is no evidence that it does cause autism, it is a serious possibility. More research is needed.
Verdict: Wait and see

Isabella Thomas
Spokeswoman for JABS, a parents' support group

The MMR vaccine manufacturer's own leaflet warns of possible "gastro-intestinal effects" and "neurological reactions", and we have parents reporting a range of vaccine-related illness, including epilepsy, encephalitis, bowel problems, regressive autism and profound deafness. Our membership is 2,000. It is very convenient for Andrew Wakefield to be portrayed as a lone voice, but there are many other scientists who back the questions he has raised. JAB's view is that it should be suspended for further testing, and that single vaccines should be reintroduced.
Verdict: Yes

Dr Helen Bedford
Senior research fellow, Institute of Child Health

The MMR vaccine has been in use since 1972 in the US and 1982 in Scandinavia. Before it was introduced in these countries, it underwent trials to make sure it was safe and effective. By 1988, when it was introduced in the UK, we had the benefit of many years of experience which confirmed that serious side-effects were uncommon. In 1998, Dr Wakefield and colleagues suggested there might be a connection between the vaccine and both autism and bowel problems. Studies were set up to look into the possibility. They have not confirmed Dr Wakefield's suggestion.
Verdict: No

Judith Barnard
Communications director, National Autistic Society

That is a question for the medical establishment which can only be answered by more research. Given the thousands of calls about MMR to the NAS each year, parents are not convinced. A number report that autism started in their children, who had been progressing well, directly after the MMR jab, but the link cannot be proved. We are committed to immunisation and protecting children against measles, mumps and rubella but cannot advise parents either way. The government should direct its £3m into that research, not advertising campaigns.
Verdict: Jury still out

Magda Taylor
Coordinator, The Informed Parent

There is much cause for doubt about the jab, from the way that it is injected and what it is made of, to the safety of combining the three inoculations. Before the vaccine was introduced, the death rate from measles had already fallen by 95%. The colossal scale of the drugs industry is enough to make some people sceptical, and the health service so quickly and absolutely dismisses public fears that it appears to be avoiding confronting serious issues. Many people are not even told about the yellow card system to report suspected reactions to vaccines.
Verdict: Yes

Dr George Kassianos
Spokesman, Royal College of General Practitioners

There is no doubt in my mind that there is no reason to doubt the safety of the MMR jab. Yesterday's summit found that Dr Wakefield's report was riddled with inaccuracies and did not prove links between the vaccine and autism or gut problems, along with all other studies around the world on the subject. The vaccine was tested sufficiently to be granted a licence, and these licences are not granted permanently. The medical control agency demands reviews at least every five years - irrespective of how many yellow cards it may have received.
Verdict: No

fields.headline: Temper, temper
fields.standfirst: Are you suffering the terrible twos?  Richard McClure  and his son find out how to defuse the rage that grips toddlers - and exasperates parents
fields.trailText: Are you suffering the terrible twos? Richard McClure and his son find out how to defuse the rage that grips toddlers - and exasperates parents.
fields.body:
Uh-oh, here we go again. Dorothy is off on one. She is trying to tell me something but I can't understand her mumbled speech. Within a few seconds, her fists clench and her blonde curls shake with rage until her frustration explodes into an ear-splitting howl. People are looking on, embarrassed by the spectacle.

For many parents, the experience is horribly familiar. Who, after all, has not had to endure those nerve-shredding tantrums that make you yearn for the carefree days of childlessness, those public eruptions of petulance that test your patience to its limits?

Except that, in this case, Dorothy is not a temperamental toddler demanding crisps before dinner. She is a 52-year-old child psychologist with a novel, hands-on approach to "toddler-taming". Since December, Dorothy Einon, a senior lecturer in psychology at University College, London, has been running temper tantrum workshops: a pilot scheme designed to help parents struggling to cope with particularly unruly children. Among the methods she uses to restore her clients' sanity is a role-play exercise in which adults simulate their child's worst behaviour.

Presenting each parent with an abstract drawing, Dorothy asks them to describe the picture without using words. Their ensuing frustration, she believes, provides at least some understanding of their child's feelings. And Dorothy is more than happy to show how it's done.

"The aim is to hammer home just how hard it is to communicate without adequate language," she explains, a little flushed from her dramatic demonstration. "A child's inability to express its needs is a common reason for tantrums. The exercise helps parents to understand something of what their toddler is going through."

According to research, tantrums affect around 80% of children, usually those between two and four, the age when children first recognise themselves as individuals but fail to comprehend that their parents have minds and emotions separate from their own. When children, bafflingly, find that their desires don't correspond with a parent's, all hell can break loose.

Although naturally stubborn youngsters are more likely to have tantrums, even the most placid child is not immune. A recent news story revealed that six-year-old Richie Phommachanh - the spiritually aware "Golden Child" of Tibetan Buddhism - can headbang with the best of them, his path to enlightenment hindered by a tendency to throw a wobbly whenever anyone else plays with his ceremonial gong.

And which parent did not experience an intense moment of "There, but for the grace of God, go I ..." on reading recently about the fit thrown by five-year-old Anna Engstrom when she was supposed to be presenting a posy to Princess Anne. "I don't want to give it to her," shrieked Anna, to the chagrin of her mother, Jill Dale. "She's horrible." The reason for the foot-stomping sulk, it later transpired, was that Anna is a big Barbie fan and fully expected the Princess to be wearing a pink gown and tiara. Instead, she was wearing a sensible blue coat. Such are life's disappointments.

Today, however, Dorothy Einon has set her sights on two lesser mortals - my own two-year-old, Reuben, and his best friend, Lucy. Although Reuben is a tantrum novice, yet to progress beyond the basic car-seat showdowns, Lucy is a veteran. Not yet three, she has already held more street protests than Tony Benn, while her pièce-de-résistance - a high-octane fusion of pavement-pounding and knicker-shredding - draws gasps of amazement whenever it is performed.

To begin the session, Dorothy wants to know how I deal with Reuben's car-seat insurrections. Like everyone else, I tell her: with a muttering of expletives under my breath, before pinning him, Kendo Nagasaki-style, into submission. Dorothy shakes her head sympathetically. Remaining cool, calm and collected, apparently, is the correct way to proceed.

To quell the storm, Dorothy recommends removing yourself physically from the fray for a few minutes. If that is not possible, then withdraw your "emotional bond" by ignoring the child as best you can until their anger subsides. When the tantrum is over, be sure to forgive and forget. "Reassure the child of your love. Children who are quickly forgiven will stop their tantrums at an earlier age."

Even better, learn to avoid the sort of scenario likely to trigger a tantrum in the first place. Do not take your child to the supermarket when she or he is tired. Do not snatch your computer keyboard from his inquisitive fingers (as I learned this morning). Do not force her to give a bunch of flowers to Princess Anne.

Research suggests that today's parents are more concerned about tantrums than ever before. Certainly, there is renewed interest in the issue. In the documentary Living by the Book, to be shown on Channel 4 tonight, four sets of parents try to pacify their demanding darlings with the help of Toddler Taming, the no-nonsense manual written by an Australian paediatrician, Dr Christopher Green.

As the programme shows, the results prove to be mixed, perhaps not surprisingly given Green's doctrine of tough love, which tends to treat infants as if they were domestic animals and includes dishing out the occasional "light, symbolic smack".

A more forward-looking approach is being offered by Kids Unlimited, one of the UK's leading nursery chains, which is now training its staff to use sign language to improve communication with small children. Child development specialists in the US have already shown that by learning simple hand gestures - easier to form than spoken words - babies and toddlers are better able to express their needs, leading in turn to fewer freakouts (though I have a fair inkling of the hand gesture Reuben will soon be giving me).

Einon's work in the field has led to a collaboration with the BBC on a television character called Angelmouse, a cheeky-but-caring cartoon rodent designed to fill our little ones with community spirit and positive social values. Each workshop begins with a 10-minute video in which Angelmouse demonstrates his sense of civic duty by saving an elephant from drowning in a pond. Repeated viewing, it is hoped, will reduce tantrums as Angelmouse teaches children how "to more positively channel their energies".

Today, though, his saintly aspirations aren't much appreciated. After a few minutes, Reuben and Lucy seem to have dismissed him as an ingratiating do-gooder. My son starts demanding a Noddy video, featuring his preferred animated rodent, Clockwork Mouse (a charmless character entirely devoid of any instinct for civic responsibility).

"Mmm, perhaps we'll come back to Angelmouse later," Dorothy smiles weakly, as Lucy starts running around in circles.

The role-play, too, is sadly curtailed when Dorothy's faux tantrum quickly reduces Reuben to a sobbing heap. But as the session draws to a tearful close, Einon signs off with a final, persuasive warning: fail to wean your child off tantrums as a toddler and there is a strong likelihood they will continue having anger problems well into adulthood.

A vision flashes before me: Reuben, at 30, throwing Elton John-style hissy fits. The prospect is too much to bear. Angelmouse it is, then. Dorothy has another convert.

webTitle: Parents: What makes a good parent?

fields.headline: Judgment days
fields.standfirst: There is no such thing as a perfect parent - most of us settle for 'good enough'. But, asks  Joanna Moorhead, is that a concept that survives scrutiny?
fields.trailText: There is no such thing as a perfect parent - most of us settle for 'good enough'. But, asks Joanna Moorhead, is that a concept that survives scrutiny?
fields.body:
Legal proceedings over the "internet twins" Kimberley and Belinda may have only just begun, but for many people the case is open and shut. In the dock stand Alan and Judith Kilshaw. On the charge sheet: substandard parenting. And here is the evidence: item one, a dirty house. Item two, pictures of her drinking in a hotel bar at 4am. Item three, acres of television footage of the couple blabbing when they might have been better advised to say nothing.

And then there is the little matter of Judith's belief in ghosts, her inability to cradle a baby's head correctly and her tendency to histrionics. Case closed, m'lud, and I think we can all take it that the overwhelming public verdict is: guilty as charged.

Judgment is all around when you are a parent. What is happening to the Kilshaws might be particularly public, particularly unpleasant and particularly far-reaching in its consequences, but the judgment of others is an aspect of parenting we are all up against. And something we all indulge in, too, from time to time. He spends too long at work, never sees his kids; she is too pushy, doesn't let them follow their own inclinations. The misfortune of the hapless Kilshaws has been that they got the whole book thrown at them at once, but there is a sense in which we are, all of us, guilty of being less than perfect parents.

According to the pyschologist Terri Apter, the concept of the perfect parent has been dead and buried for some years: supposedly, what we buy into instead is the notion of the "good enough" parent (in the phrase borrowed from the eminent British psychoanalyst DW Winnicott).

"It used to be thought that you had to do everything just so, that if you made even one or two mistakes you could damage your child irreparably," says Apter. "But along came the idea of the 'good enough' parent, the idea that you don't have to get everything right all the time, you just have to get your child to relate to others, to be sufficiently social and able to adapt to different situations."

Which is all very well in theory, but in practice our society is riddled with anxiety that what we are doing is far from OK. "There are all these studies about whether children are being damaged by our behaviour as parents: whether we're harming them by spending too much time at work if we're a working mother, or by spanking them, or whatever," Apter says. "And it could be that a lot of these fears, which are just beneath the surface, come out when we're faced with a couple like the Kilshaws, whom we can examine and say: 'Are you suitable to be parents?'"

If judgment by our peers is bad enough, judgment by those on the receiving end of our skills (or lack of them) is both inevitable and, sometimes, searingly fierce. Deconstructing our parents' parenting abilities, examining them in minute detail and finding them wanting, is a rite of passage. When we become parents ourselves, we are often more forgiving, perhaps because as well as facing the same problems, we know we will eventually face the same scrutiny.

For a minority of parents, though, detailed scrutiny comes not as a postmortem to parenting, but as a prequel. In most cases, an individual or couple seeking to adopt a child in Britain has his or her life, or their lives, studied under the microscope in a way that few of us would find easy or comfortable to accept.

Janet, who with her partner has recently been given the go-ahead to adopt a child, admits that the six-month selection process was exhaustive and intense. "In the case of our agency, we had to give written answers to well over 100 questions - and I'm talking essays in some cases, certainly not one-word replies," she says. "It was very time-consuming, very thorough. Among other things, we were asked about our sex life, our relationships with our parents, our views on bringing up children, our financial status, our health and our views on Britain as a multiracial society.

"It was made clear to me that, were we to stand any chance of being passed as adopters, one of us would have to give up work to care for the children. I would have to stop treatment for infertility, and we would have to provide witnesses to attest to our suitability for parenting."

At one point, Janet worried that the fact that she smoked occasionally might affect the outcome of her application. "At one level, it's very tough and intrusive, and you feel you're being judged the whole time," she says. "But on the other hand, you know why it's being done - that it's for the protection of the child. And I have to say that, when you're going through it, it's less awful than you would imagine."

That is not always the view of those whose applications are turned down. Sara, who with her partner tried unsuccessfully to adopt a child from overseas, says she will never get over being rejected. "We were never told why and we never will be," she says.

"We know in our hearts that we could love and care for a child, and it seems so unfair that while others can just have baby after baby without anyone questioning their motives at all, everything about us was put under the spotlight - and, in the end, found wanting.

"It's very, very hard to walk away from that: I find it so difficult to accept that they were right, that we just weren't up to it. After all, parenting is something you learn as you go along: you get better. Only, we weren't given the chance."

What is clear is that society in general, and social workers in particular, have very different criteria by which to judge whether birth parents are doing a "good enough" job, and whether prospective adoptive parents can do the job at all. "Which is completely obvious when you consider how vulnerable adoptive children are, how they have already had a traumatic time and how they are going to have to deal with this issue of having been adopted later on in their lives," says Dirk Flower, a child psychologist.

Particularly ironic to would-be adoptive parents is that, when a very young child can no longer be cared for by a birth parent, social workers often try to elicit a stand-in from the ranks of family members who have never sought to adopt: it is as if their blood ties alone inevitably make them better-placed to parent than any amount of longing and desire - and potential competence - on the part of an unrelated couple.

"What you want to do is leave the door open, ajar a little way, so that the birth parents themselves can come back in later on and play a bigger role," explains one social worker. "What you're thinking about, all the time, is the needs of the child. That is your concern - not the needs of the parent, but the needs of the child."

Most intriguing of all, in the Kilshaw case, is that Flintshire social services evidently has serious doubts about the couple's ability to be parents to the six-month-old twin girls they adopted, but consider them adequate to care for their own two young sons. Quite why this should be the case is difficult to fathom: but in the weeks and months ahead, as the focus moves from media to courtroom, we may get something of an explanation.

webTitle: 'Internet twins' must stay with father, rules US court

fields.headline: 'Internet twins' must stay with father, rules US court
fields.trailText: The saga of the American twins "bought" by a British couple via the internet took another twist today after a US judge awarded custody to the baby girls' biological father.
fields.body:
The saga of the American twins "bought" by a British couple via the internet took another twist today after a US judge awarded custody to the baby girls' biological father.

A court in St Louis, Missouri, awarded custody of the twins to Aaron Wecker - although the order has no immediate effect, because the babies are currently in the care of a British county council.

Mr Wecker alleged in court papers that the girls' mother, Tranda Wecker, neglected them by trying to sell them over the internet.

He also accused her of "failing to report to me on the whereabouts of the children for weeks at a time, subjecting the twins to illegal activities and underhanded and shady doings", according to the St Louis Post-Dispatch newspaper.

Mr Wecker said in papers filed on Monday that Tranda Wecker's actions had "led to my twin daughters being placed in foster homes".

St Louis Circuit Judge Jack Garvey issued the custody order, which will be in force until the next court hearing, set for February 14.

Judge Garvey also prohibited Tranda Wecker - who yesterday told US TV broadcasters that she wanted the babies back - from going within 100ft of the twins.

Tranda Wecker told CBS News: "I have a job. I have family and friends that will help me take care of my children. My children miss their sisters, and I miss my girls very much."

The twins are currently with Flintshire county council foster parents in north Wales after a high court judge sitting in Birmingham decided that they should remain in council care pending research into what is best for them.

Alan and Judith Kilshaw, from Buckley, north Wales, are contesting a decision by Flintshire social services to take the babies from them.

They adopted Belinda and Kimberley after paying £8,200 to a Californian internet adoption agency.

Mr Justice Kirkwood, sitting at the high court in Birmingham, said that the Kilshaws had given the court solemn undertakings not to discuss the case or any of the arrangements for the twins with anyone unconnected with the hearing.

The twins were with a Californian couple when Tranda Wecker talked the pair into handing the babies back so she could say a final farewell.

Instead, she handed them to Mr and Mrs Kilshaw, who went through an adoption process in Arkansas.

webTitle: Hospital boss steps down after waiting list inquiry

fields.headline: Hospital boss steps down after waiting list inquiry
fields.trailText: A hospital chief executive has resigned from his post after an inquiry into allegations over waiting list figures, it emerged today.
fields.body:
A hospital chief executive has resigned from his post after an inquiry into allegations over waiting list figures, it emerged today.

South Warwickshire general hospitals NHS trust said Andrew Riley, 43, who was suspended from duty on full pay after the claims last October, had stepped down following an independent report into "administrative procedures" within the trust.

Trust chairman David Evans said in a statement that the report contained sensitive, confidential patient information and was therefore not being made public.

fields.headline: NTL to ramp up prices
fields.trailText: 4pm:Cable company NTL will increase its prices to UK customers from next month, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Cable company NTL is to phase in a series of price rises for its UK customers from next month.

Sources close to the US-listed company said the increases are in line with recent moves by BSkyB and BT.

They will cover NTL's telephone and TV packages.

Full details of the price hike will be unveiled in NTL's fourth-quarter results tomorrow.

NTL has already increased the cost of its unmetered internet access for customers on other networks from £10 to £15 a month.

The company is also expected to announce a big marketing campaign for its broadband internet service.

NTL has 2m cable TV or telephone customers in the UK - of these, 530,000 are digital subscribers.

In contrast, BSkyB boasts 4m customers while ONdigital has 1m.

Despite a debt burden of £8.8bn, NTL is highly rated by analysts.

This is because it is able to bundle digital cable, wireless services and high-speed data access into single packages.

Nonetheless, the company has delayed its £300m digital launch in Ireland and cut 1,300 UK jobs in order to conserve cash.

fields.headline: Mandelson's resignation statement
fields.standfirst:
The text of Peter Mandelson's statement in Downing Street

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: The text of Peter Mandelson's statement in Downing Street.
fields.body:
I am today resigning from the government and wish to set out the background to my decision.

I do not accept in any way that I have acted improperly in respect of any application for naturalisation as a British subject.

I do, however, accept that when my office spoke to a Sunday newspaper at the weekend, I should have been clear that it was me personally, not my official, who spoke to the Home Office minister.

As a result of that reply, incorrect information was given to the House by the culture secretary, and to the press by the prime minister's spokesman. I accept responsibility for that.

I have said to the prime minister that I wish to leave the government and he has accepted that.

I would only ask people to understand that my sole desire and motivation throughout was to emphasise that I had not thought to influence the decision on naturalisation in any way at all, merely to pass on a request for information, and the prime minister is entirely satisfied with this.

I confess in reaching my decision that there is another factor. As a reading of today's newspapers shows all too graphically, there must be more to politics than the constant media pressure and exposure that has dogged me over the last five or so years.

I want to remove myself from the countless stories of controversy, feuds and divisions, and all the rest, all the other stories that have surrounded me. I want, in other words, to lead a more normal life, both in politics and, in the future, outside. That is my decision and I hope that everyone will respect that.

Finally, it has been the greatest privilege of my political life to play a part in the peace process in Northern Ireland, something far bigger and more important than any one individual or his career.

We are so close now to a final settlement, to a complete implementation of this government's, as well as others', achievement - the Good Friday agreement. I only hope and pray that everything that we have worked for, and the parties in Northern Ireland have worked for, now comes to pass and I wish the people in Northern Ireland every success and peace in the future and I thank them for their kindness to me.

The prime minister has asked me to do Northern Ireland questions in the House this afternoon. I shall then listen to prime minister's questions and then formally I will resign from the government.

fields.body:
Arsenal's latest goalkeeping target, according to the Daily Star, is Middlesbrough's Mark Schwarzer. The paper claims that Arsene Wenger sent scouts to watch the £5m-rated 28-year-old against Liverpool on Saturday. The paper also claims that Austrian keeper Alex Manninger will be allowed to leave Highbury in the summer.

The Mirror reports that if, as expected, Tottenham's new owners Enic look to replace George Graham with Glenn Hoddle in the summer, there is a clause in the Southampton manager's contract that would allow him to leave the Dell for £750,000. Spurs paid Leeds £3m to get hold of Graham.

West Ham look set to complete the signing of Japanese defender Tsuneyasu Miyamoto from Gamba Osaka in a move that is likely to earn the club millions. Harry Redknapp told the Mirror he has never seen Miyamoto play but with £250,000-worth of replica shirt sales already guaranteed, he's not too bothered. "We'll have enough money when we've finished with him to buy Ronaldo," he said.

Ruud van Nistelrooy returned to light training with PSV Eindhoven yesterday, and told the Daily Mail how his "feeling for Manchester United is still great". He told the paper: "My first priority is to come back to my level. Then we'll see what happens. It depends on the situation, but my feeling for Manchester United is great. When I'm physically fit and feeling well, we'll see what happens."

Bradford will sign Hearts wing-back Gary Locke on a free transfer this week, reports Teamtalk.

Birmingham are set to sign Sheffield United's England under-21 midfielder Curtis Woodhouse. The Daily Mail reports that Peter Ndlovu will head in the other direction in a £1.5m player-plus-cash deal.

The Sun reports that Chelsea will announce an £18m shirt-sponsorship deal with the Emirates airline tomorrow.

Monaco's highly-rated defender Martin Djetou will leave French football in the summer and could move to England. "I don't like routine and I think it is time for me to go. My preferred destinations are England and Spain," he told Planet Football.

webTitle: 'I would not be surprised if he left politics for good'

fields.headline: 'I would not be surprised if he left politics for good'
fields.standfirst:
There's one man in Hartlepool who would be glad to see the back of his MP, as Mark Oliver reports

Fish and sympathy as minister's chips are down
Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: There's one man in Hartlepool who would be glad to see the back of his MP, as Mark Oliver reports.
fields.body:
The man who arguably has the biggest right to be pleased by Peter Mandelson's decision to resign from the government today said he had done the "correct thing" by going.

Gus Robinson, the Conservatives' prospective parliamentary candidate for Hartlepool, said: "If you are a minister and you are lying to the public, then your position is untenable and the honourable thing to do is resign."

Mr Robinson, a boxing promoter and local businessmen who employs 150 people at his construction company, said he would not be surprised if Mr Mandelson left politics for good.

"As far as him staying here, what do you think the chances are of someone like that organising their social life around Hartlepool over a prolonged period? It would be beyond belief if it happened.

"Of course, someone with his background is not going to have any real affinity with the area."

Mr Robinson attacked Mr Mandelson's record in Hartlepool which he described as "abysmal".

"Crime is rising and unemployment is rising. There were 200 policemen here when he arrived and now the figure is closer to 180."

Mr Robinson, who would have to reverse a majority of 17,000 to win the seat in the upcoming general election, claimed that Mr Mandelson and his office had not introduced any original policies in Hartlepool.

However, he did add: "If it means he will spend more time here, then that is a good thing for the area. He will no longer be able to duck out of being in Hartlepool.

"We receive a bad deal here in the north-east from government and that has to change."

fields.headline: Fish and sympathy as minister's chips are down
fields.standfirst:
Mark Oliver talks to the man behind the frier in Mandelson's constituency

'I would not be surprised if he left politics for good'
Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: As Peter Mandelson licks his wounds, he can at least console himself with the thought that locals in his Hartlepool constituency were this morning looking on the bright side of his impending resignation.
fields.body:
As Peter Mandelson licks his wounds, he can at least console himself with the thought that locals in his Hartlepool constituency were this morning looking on the bright side of his impending resignation.

"He's the classic absent MP, isn't he?" said Malcolm Foster, owner of Foster's Fish Grill, which counts the beleaguered Northern Ireland secretary as an occasional customer.

"He's not from here and he's never here," he said. At least, he added, Mr Mandelson would now "have more time for the town, which is where he should be anyway".

Mr Foster conceded that Mr Mandelson's interests were with the higher echelons of government.

"Well, maybe that's why the Labour party did so badly in the recent local council elections. There is a feeling they may be losing touch a tiny bit with their grass roots."

Mr Foster felt that there would be some local sympathy for a man often described in the Hartlepool Mail as "the esteemed politician".

"There has been an element of pride that our MP is a very high-flying cabinet member. You get the impression there is a lot of people out to get him. There only has to be a sniff of scandal and they're on him.

"I think it's all very unfortunate and I feel sorry for the man. I would not wish it on anyone to lose their job.

"This latest passport controversy seems to me to be a storm in a tea cup and I can't see that he has done anything very wrong."

Mr Foster could not confirm the truth of a famous apocryphal story about Mr Mandelson - who increased Labour's majority in Hartlepool by 8,782 votes in 1997 - once confusing mushy peas in a chip shop with guacamole.

He said: "Apparently he likes his chips. He's been in here one or two times, once getting the round of chip suppers in for nine people, including his bodyguards."

Mr Mandelson may now be providing Foster's Fish Grill with more regular patronage.

fields.headline: Government urged to stop 'invisible' marketing of cigarettes
fields.trailText:
3.45pm update: A Labour MP has called on the government to stamp out 'invisible' marketing of cigarettes, writes Daniel Rogers.
Jan 24: BAT embraces 'backdoor branding'
Jan 24: BAT lures young smokers
fields.body:
David Hinchcliffe, chairman of the House of Commons health committee has called on the government to urgently stamp out "invisible" marketing of cigarettes.

He said he was "particularly concerned" about the misuse of the internet and urged Tony Blair to set up a Tobacco Regulatory Authority to stop cigarette companies advertising their products through the back door.

He was responding to revelations today that British American Tobacco was planning to launch an unbranded series of websites encouraging users to visit venues selling their cigarettes.

"This is an excellent example of how the tobacco companies will seek to evade any advertising legislation. The government needs to anticipate their antics and set up an authority to monitor their marketing strategies," said Mr Hinchcliffe.

The Labour MP will lead the all-party committee's scrutiny of the government's Tobacco Advertising & Promotion bill in the Commons next week.

He said that a number of politicians - including MP Frank Dobson - had expressed their specific worry about the internet as a loophole in tobacco advertising during the second reading of the bill on Monday

"Increasingly the net will be used to market cigarettes to young people and even children. It's entirely consistent with the historic track record of tobacco companies to bend every code and target young people," said Mr Hinchcliffe.

A spokesman for BAT said: "We do take a responsible approach to marketing what is a unique product. If people look at BAT.com they will see that this site sets out both the dangers of smoking and our strict marketing principles.

"It even invites people to alert us to cases where they feel our marketing breaks voluntary codes."
