webTitle: Resignation upsets pot as Irish stew

fields.headline: Resignation upsets pot as Irish stew
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson's removal from Ulster threatens the balance as parties search for agreement, writes Derek Brown

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Mandelson's removal from Ulster threatens the balance as parties search for agreement, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's second resignation is a sensation in British politics. In Ireland it could be a disaster.

The peace process is finely poised between breakthrough and breakdown. It is a huge irony that the secretary of state has been obliged by his own indiscretion to leave the Northern Ireland Office, just as the latest negotiations were reaching a crescendo.

Only yesterday, Mr Mandelson was centrally involved in intensive talks in Downing Street, trying to close the remaining formidable gaps between the Northern Ireland parties.

He and prime minister Tony Blair held a six-hour series of meetings with Northern Ireland first minister David Trimble and other party leaders.

Officials of the Dublin government were also involved. The discussions focused on the interlocking issues of police reform, disarmament and the 'demilitarisation' of the province.

According to the normally reticent Sinn Fein negotiator Martin McGuinness, progress was being made "inch by inch".

The British and Irish governments were hoping next week to issue a "judgment call" on whether to continue their efforts to get the Good Friday peace deal implemented in full. But the painstaking negotiation, already clouded by the looming British general election, has now been rocked by the removal of one of the key players.

Mr Mandelson's abrupt departure is a particular body blow for Trimble's hopes of forcing the republican movement to disarm. In recent months the secretary of state had signalled a get-tough approach, by trimming police reform proposals and markedly declining to speed up British military withdrawal - which Sinn Fein demands as a condition of its own disarmament.

Other Irish parties, and the Dublin government, also have reason to regret the sudden and potentially disruptive removal of Mr Mandelson. Many will doubtless interpret it as another sign of British indifference to the peace process.

But another, more optimistic, interpretation is possible. From the start of Mr Mandelson's stint in Stormont Castle, close observers have believed that his heart was not really in the job, and that he longed to return to a higher-profile job in a Whitehall department. Although he came to Northern Ireland as a notably neutral secretary of state, his very lack of ideological commitment in Irish affairs was seen by some to make him less effective than his ebullient predecessor, Mo Mowlam.

In addition, Mr Blair has become ever more determined to play the central role in the peace process, to some extent sidelining the secretary of state. That factor is likely to become more important if, as early speculation suggests, Mr Mandelson is succeeded by the well-respected but uncharismatic Welsh secretary, Paul Murphy.

The discussions focused on the interlocking issues of police reform, disarmament and the 'demilitarisation' of the province. According to the normally reticent Sinn Fein negotiator Martin McGuinness, progress was being made "inch by inch". The British and Irish governments were hoping next week to issue a "judgment call" on whether to continue their efforts to get the Good Friday peace deal implemented in full. But the painstaking negotiation, already clouded by the looming British general election, has now been rocked by the removal of one of the key players. Mr Mandelson's abrupt departure is a particular body blow for Trimble's hopes of forcing the republican movement to disarm. In recent months the secretary of state had signalled a get-tough approach, by trimming police reform proposals and markedly declining to speed up British military withdrawal - which Sinn Fein demands as a condition of its own disarmament. Other Irish parties, and the Dublin government, also have reason to regret the sudden and potentially disruptive removal of Mr Mandelson. Many will doubtless interpret it as another sign of British indifference to the peace process. But another, more optimistic, interpretation is possible. From the start of Mr Mandelson's stint in Stormont Castle, close observers have believed that his heart was not really in the job, and that he longed to return to a higher-profile job in a Whitehall department. Although he came to Northern Ireland as a notably neutral secretary of state, his very lack of ideological commitment in Irish affairs was seen by some to make him less effective than his ebullient predecessor, Mo Mowlam. In addition, Mr Blair has become ever more determined to play the central role in the peace process, to some extent sidelining the secretary of state. That factor is likely to become more important if, as early speculation suggests, Mr Mandelson is succeeded by the well-respected but uncharismatic Welsh secretary, Paul Murphy. fields.headline: BBC tightens up cross-promotion guidelines
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: The BBC has tightened up its cross-promotion guidelines after a complaint from IPC about Eve and Star magazines, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC has tightened up its guidelines for approving the cross-promotion of its own magazines following a complaint by rival publisher IPC Media.

In future, all requests for TV promotions for BBC Worldwide titles Eve and Star on the corporation's public service TV channels will have to be approved by its controller of fair trading. However the corporation has made it plain that it will not be extending the rules to other titles such as Match of the Day or Top of the Pops magazine.

Previously, broadcasting and presentation staff on the TV channel concerned took an editorial decision on whether requests trails for BBC magazines "complement the programme and extend access to the subject matter".

Struggling BBC1 Saturday morning kids' TV show Live and Kicking has also been ordered to changing Star slot to avoid any possible confusion with the teen magazine of the same name.

The decision to revise the magazine cross-promotion guidelines was taken by the BBC's fair trading complaints committee, which is chaired by new vice-chairman Gavyn Davies.

The committee was responding to a complaint by IPC about TV trails for Worldwide magazines Eve and Star.

IPC claimed the publishing of women's title Eve and TV trails for Eve and Star, which were broadcast in August and October 2000, breached the BBC's commercial policy guidelines.

The committee dismissed both these allegations. But it ruled that: "In the case of general interest magazines like Eve and Star, in future a more substantial connection with the programme than a single article should be required to justify a trail.

"Accordingly the committee has required that further on-air trails for Eve and Star cease, and that any future requests for trails will only be granted following the prior scrutiny of the BBC controller, fair trading."

fields.headline: Tories promise housing cash
fields.trailText: The Conservatives have promised to beat the government's investment plans for affordable housing, pledging a "very substantial" increase in spending if the party returns to power. By Simon Parker
fields.body:
The Conservatives have promised to beat the government's investment plans for affordable housing, pledging a "very substantial" increase in spending if the party returns to power.

The move is part of the Tory campaign to defuse accusations that they would slash spending on key public services to pay for tax cuts. Party leader William Hague has already promised to match Labour's investment for the health service, education, law and order, transport and defence.

Today, shadow environment secretary Archie Norman added housing to that list, saying: "The next Conservative government will be committed to a very substantial increase in expenditure on housing. However, our long-term objective is to restructure the way social housing is managed in Britain to improve the quality of life for tenants and reduce the drain on taxpayers' money."

Conservative central office said the party was not yet prepared to put a figure on the increase. A spokesman said only that they would ensure total public and private investment in affordable housing was higher than it would be under a Labour government.

For the pledge to be credible, however, the Tories will have to beat the government's promise of an extra £1.6bn for social housing over the next three years, announced in last summer's spending review.

The party admitted that it would attempt to save £300m from Labour's spending plans by quickly transferring all council housing from local authorities to housing associations or tenant management schemes. Some of the planned spending increase would be used to accelerate this process.

This would make the government's planned investment in new "arm's length" council housing companies unnecessary as well as cutting back on private finance initiative projects.

Mr Norman said the transfers would also eradicate what he termed "badly managed municipal housing".

His statement came in response to a challenge from Brian Griffiths, president of the Chartered Institute of Housing.

Mr Griffiths accused the Tories of neglecting housing in their latest round of spending promises, and asked shadow ministers to "come clean" on whether they would maintain the government's level of investment.

A spokesman for the institute today commented: "The Conservatives say they will accelerate the transfer of council housing as a way of dealing with poor housing. However they make no provision for situations where tenants do not want to see their stock transferred. This proposal may not be workable. Neither is the solution to blame bad housing management."

fields.headline: Business studies how to make links with voluntary sector
fields.trailText: Business delegates at the World Economic Forum, which starts in Switzerland tomorrow, will not only be discussing the shape of the 21st century corporation but will be addressing how to engage in dialogue with non-governmental organisations (NGOs).
fields.body:
Business delegates at the World Economic Forum, which starts in Switzerland tomorrow, will not only be discussing the shape of the 21st century corporation but will be addressing how to engage in dialogue with non-governmental organisations (NGOs).

The programme states: "Constructive dialogue between business and NGOs is becoming a rarity as the two camps are increasingly at odds with each other. Many in business see NGOs as 'troublemakers' while NGOs see themselves as a 'counterweight' to corporate power."

The World Economic Forum has launched an initiative inviting representatives from major companies and NGOs to identify areas for potential dialogue. One of the sessions at the conference, called Business and NGOs: from Diatribe to Dialogue will report on progress so far.

You can participate in the proceedings by sending comments and questions via their website. Other discussions include addressing the backlash against globalisation and seizing the global digital opportunity.

The World Economic Forum started as a European economic conference 30 years ago. It has now evolved its role into one of a facilitator with ongoing projects to address global issues.

This year there will be 50 representatives of civil society including 36 people from NGOs and 11 from philanthropic foundations. They will join 1,000 top business leaders and 250 politicians from around the world.

Manny Amadi, who runs a company that brings business and social causes together, will be attending and sending an exclusive report to SocietyGuardian.co.uk.

fields.headline: Hagerty to launch ONdigital listings title
fields.trailText: 9am: Fleet Street veteran Bill Hagerty is edit a new weekly listings magazine for ONdigital called ON7, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Fleet Street veteran Bill Hagerty is to be the launch editor of a new weekly listings magazine for ONdigital called ON7.

ON7, which will go out to 1m households a week, represents a multi million-pound contract win for publisher TPD.

Mr Hagerty, a former deputy editor of the Daily Mirror and editor of the People, is contracted for the launch of the magazine, scheduled for March 3.

Since leaving the People, Mr Hagerty has been working as a theatre and film critic, as well as editing the British Midland airline's customer magazine, Voyager.

He said ON7 "would try to look at television a bit differently", adding, "We're doing some stuff that's quite tongue in cheek."

Grahame Lake, TPD managing director, the contract publisher responsible for publishing the magazine, said ON7 was revolutionising the listings market by publishing a weekly magazine to such a large market.

"I think ONdigital are doing a brave thing, and we're upping the stakes for the television listings market," he said.

ON7 will go head to head with Sky's TV listings magazine, Sky Customer Magazine, which had an audited circulation of 2.6m at the last ABCs.

Mr Lake said: "We're doing 51 issues a year at a million a shot, so we're really upping the stakes."

fields.headline: BAT embraces 'backdoor branding'
fields.trailText:
2pm update: British American Tobacco is being forced to look to the internet for 'backdoor' branding techniques to catch up with Marlboro and Camel who are already spun off into merchandising to get around advert restrictions, writes Daniel Rogers.
Jan 24: BAT lures young smokers
fields.body:
BAT has been forced to look to the internet for "backdoor" branding techniques to catch up with rivals Marlboro and Camel in this area, according to a former BAT executive.

The executive was responding to today's revelation that BAT is launching an "invisible" drive to promote cigarettes through a disguised website which will drive young consumers to clubs, bars and restaurants selling its brands.

He told MediaGuardian.co.uk: "For many years we have seen advertising for Marlboro Classics clothes and Camel Boots.

"These products boost awareness of their respective cigarette brands but BAT has failed to emulate them.

"BAT has therefore been forced to look at other ways of promoting its brands."

BAT advertises its top brands - Lucky Strike and State Express 555 - on its forumula one team, British American Racing.

However, it has failed to capitalise on the more indirect promotional techniques used by Philip Morris (owner of Marlboro) and RJ Reynolds (owner of Camel).

Three years ago, BAT opened a Benson & Hedges-branded cafe in Malaysia.

At that time, critics accused the company of trying to link tobacco with "acceptable" drugs such as coffee.

However, BAT failed to roll out the cafe concept worldwide.

The Marlboro brand undoubtedly benefits from a chain of Marlboro Classics men's clothing shops in cities around the world.

Marlboro Classics ads - which are still legal - have been criticised for resembling the famous "Marlboro cowboy" work used by the cigarette brand.

Marlboro and Camel clothing catalogues have also been mailed out to customers responding to tobacco promotions.

The government's new anti-tobacco bill, proceeding through the House of Commons, attempts to clamp down on trademark diversification or "brand stretching".

It also takes the first serious look at regulating the marketing of cigarettes on the internet.

BAT this week launched a pilot website in Poland called City Gorilla.

The intiative, which is expected to be rolled out worldwide, is ostensibly a guide to nightlife in cities.

However, BAT is using the site to drive consumers to outlets that promote its brands.

fields.headline: Farewell Mandelson, brilliant but unloved
fields.standfirst:
There is no way back now for the architect of New Labour, but few MPs will shed tears, says Nicholas Watt, political correspondent
Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: There is no way back now for the architect of New Labour, but few MPs will shed tears, says Nicholas Watt, political correspondent.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's abrupt resignation from the cabinet guarantees the end of an extraordinary political career.

One resignation, as Lady Bracknell might have said, is a misfortune, but a second is fatal.

The departure of one of the government's most high profile figures, so soon before the election, will damage Tony Blair. Some of the wiser heads around the cabinet table thought that the prime minister made a serious error of judgment when he brought his old friend back into government in 1999, less than a year after his first resignation. Such ministers will be quietly smarting today.

As the election battle intensifies, however, Mr Mandelson's departure may well pay dividends. The prime minister's ruthless wielding of the knife contrasts with John Major's dithering over troublesome ministers which allowed the sleaze tag to be attached to the Tories. Downing Street will be able to say, with some credibility, that the prime minister acted quickly when a serious question was raised about the integrity of a senior minister.

In the longer term, Mr Blair will feel the loss of one of the main architects of New Labour whose brilliant political advice is relied on in Downing Street. The prime minister is said to have remarked that if world war three broke out, the first person he would call would be Peter Mandelson.

Prime ministers are surprisingly lonely figures who yearn for reliable counselling from confidantes who will never betray them. Mr Mandelson relished this role which could never be fulfilled by New Labour's other main architect, the chancellor Gordon Brown, who still has his eye on the top job.

In the bars at Westminster Labour MPs, who have never warmed to Mr Mandelson, have been crowing over the past 24 hours. Even ministers, who live in fear of Mr Mandelson, have done little to defend him.

The Home Office minister Charles Clarke, who had his fair share of run-ins with Mr Mandelson when he was Neil Kinnock's chief of staff, made a point yesterday of only defending his department's role. "The one thing I am certain of is that the Home Office's processes in relation to this have been extremely rigorous and will continue to be," he said.

With half-hearted support like that, the die was cast.

fields.headline: RCN prizes academics above activists
fields.standfirst: The controversy over the shortlist for the Royal College of Nursing's top job is down to the RCN and its conservative culture, says Ray Rowden
fields.trailText: Comment: The controversy over the shortlist for the Royal College of Nursing's top job is down to the RCN and its conservative culture, says Ray Rowden
fields.body:
The process of replacing Royal College of Nursing (RCN) general secretary Christine Hancock, who leaves in June, is generating much debate amongst the nursing profession. The job, carrying a salary of £100,000 a year, is one of the most important in UK nursing.

The successful candidate will head what is effectively the sixth largest union in the UK, calling for management expertise of a high order and an ability to represent the college and the aspirations of members to politicians and the wider world.

Those on the shortlist are drawing wry comment from many RCN activists.

Two of the candidates are black women. A good thing too. One, Mel Chevannes, is a respected academic and heads Leicester de Montfort University's nursing faculty. The other, Beverly Malone, is a mental health expert and nurse "politico" from the US.

But Ms Chevannes has little experience at leading a major multi-million pound outfit at chief executive officer level. Ms Malone, while undoubtedly a feisty lobbyist, will be a stranger to the complex politics of both the NHS and the UK.

With some 600,000 nurses on the UKCC register, it seems amazing that we might be heading to the US to find the next general secretary for the biggest nursing union in the country. One wonders how the RCN will justify the application for a work permit if Ms Malone is offered the job. It is also questionable whether Ms Malone is eligible for the post, as she is not registered as a nurse in the UK.

The others on the list are an internal candidate, Alison Kitson, a senior RCN official with an academic background; and Pippa Bagnall, a former director of a small nursing charity, the Queen's Nursing Institute, which promotes community nursing.

Another candidate, Ron de Witt, chief executive of King's healthcare NHS trust, who is a nurse by background but has little profile in RCN activities, is understood to have withdrawn from the list.

Those not on the shortlist are also generating much comment, however. Two are chief officers of the RCN. Tom Bolger is a deputy to Ms Hancock, and Pippa Gough is head of the RCN's policy unit. Also left off the shortlist is Jane Salvage, nursing director at media group Emap Healthcare, who has written a best seller on nursing and politics, and has more than credible experience on the international nursing scene.

It does seem rich that these candidates, all of whom are up to the mark in meeting the person and job specification, are not on a shortlist.

All this raises many questions. Why does a job as crucial as this have such a thin shortlist? One might have expected to see a wider field of candidates. Why is it that two of the non-shorlisted candidates have reputations as RCN activists? What does the shortlist have to say about the current state of leadership in UK nursing?

As we go into an election, nursing and health will be key issues. Whoever wins the general election, the RCN general secretary will face many political challenges and will be a key figure in leading the profession in the post election world.

Yet it seems that a doctoral degree and academic status is more highly prized than union activism in leading the RCN.

The controversy over the appointment partly rests with the RCN itself. The upper echelons of the profession are riven with backbiting and rivalry. The college clings to a culture that is highly conservative with a small "c". The elected council which governs the RCN is somewhat lightweight, with few outstanding figures able to provide vibrant and imaginative leadership. As a group, they are, true to type, averse to risk and unimaginative.

On this occasion the RCN should think again and open up the whole appointment process. If not, members will have many more questions. Good for nursing? Good for the RCN? I think not.

 Ray Rowden is an RCN member and was a candidate in the recent election for RCN president.

Yet it seems that a doctoral degree and academic status is more highly prized than union activism in leading the RCN. The controversy over the appointment partly rests with the RCN itself. The upper echelons of the profession are riven with backbiting and rivalry. The college clings to a culture that is highly conservative with a small "c". The elected council which governs the RCN is somewhat lightweight, with few outstanding figures able to provide vibrant and imaginative leadership. As a group, they are, true to type, averse to risk and unimaginative. On this occasion the RCN should think again and open up the whole appointment process. If not, members will have many more questions. Good for nursing? Good for the RCN? I think not.  Ray Rowden is an RCN member and was a candidate in the recent election for RCN president.

fields.headline: The hands-on Hindujas
fields.standfirst:
As the passports for favours row threatens to obliterate the future of Peter Mandelson, Derek Brown looks back on his own brush with the case's key players

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: As the passports for favours row threatens to obliterate the future of Peter Mandelson, Derek Brown looks back on his own brush with the case's key players
fields.body:
The Bofors scandal was already raging when I was posted to Delhi as the Guardian's correspondent in early 1987. It was, to be honest, corrosively boring. There were acres of grey type in the Indian papers, detailing the minutiae of Swiss bank accounts and alleged illegal commission payments made through a thicket of obscure companies.

The Hindu, under its legendarily serious editor N Ram, was particularly obsessed with the story, running almost daily investigative pieces of mammoth length and impenetrability.

From time to time I felt obliged to summarise the latest state of the snail-paced investigation, particularly when it focused on the then prime minister, Rajiv Gandhi. There was also, of course, the added interest for Guardian readers of the alleged involvement of the London-connected Hinduja brothers.

The morning after one such piece appeared in the Guardian, I received a call from London. Given the time difference, it must have been made around dawn, British time. It was Gopichand Hinduja, in person, very politely pointing out some errors (as he saw it) in my short article, and warmly inviting me to contact him whenever I returned to the subject.

I'd love to say that the call was filled with menace. In fact, the tone of it was charm itself. My memory may be faulty, but I'm fairly certain he invited me to visit him next time I was in Britain.

What amazed me was that such a captain of commerce should trouble to make a personal call in response to an innocuous piece buried inside the paper. But then that's the way the Hindujas conduct all their affairs: hands-on, with no detail too small to escape their attention.

The four brothers - Srichand, Gopichand, Prakash and Ashok - inherited a commercial kingdom, and have turned it into an empire. At its core is trading and banking, but now the group is expanding fast in media and communications. It employs 20,000 people world wide.

The Hindujas have poured much of their mind-boggling wealth into philanthropic projects in India: a spanking new hospital in Bombay, an arts centre in Delhi, and a host of other good works from scholarship to sport. It is a deep irony that the oldest brother and head of the clan, Srichand, is now the subject of a sensational criminal investigation in his homeland.

Armed with his new British passport, he reluctantly agreed to return to Delhi to be questioned by the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) over its allegation that he, along with brothers Gopichand and Prakash, received US$8.3m (£5.8m) in illegal commissions from the Swedish arms company Bofors.

The money is said to have been stashed away in secret Swiss bank accounts. The brothers do not deny its existence or its provenance, but insist it has nothing to do with the Bofors deal.

In the mid-1980s, Bofors pulled off a US$1.4bn (about £1bn) contract to supply the Indian army with howitzers. Pundits and politicians have alleged from the outset that the deal was cocooned in corruption. Now, 15 years on, the truth just may be about to emerge.

Yesterday, the CBI completed a four-day interrogation of Srichand Hinduja. Today it started to question his brother Prakash, who has Swiss citizenship. Gopichand, also a British citizen, will then be questioned in his turn.

All three have been ordered to remain in India. They have submitted an appeal against that ruling. If the brothers come to trial and are convicted, they face up to seven years in prison.

fields.headline: My passport nightmare
fields.standfirst:
US national Sarah Left, who is married to a Briton and awaiting UK citizenship, laments her lack of friends in high places to speed up her application

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: 24 January, opinion: US national Sarah Left, who is married to a Briton and awaiting UK citizenship, laments her lack of friends in high places to speed up her application.
fields.body:
Like many immigrants to the UK, I am impressed by the speed with which Srichand Hinduja managed to obtain British citizenship.

I too have put in an application for British nationality. I sent it in this summer, along with my £120 fee, and I duly received a letter from the Home Office stating that they would write again and ask for more information when my application came up for consideration: at the current rate of progress, that would take 19 months, I was told. (The cheque, however, was cashed in under 19 days.)

How could anything take 19 months? And that is 19 months until they ask for more information. I have no idea how much longer it takes to process the actual application.

Mr Hinduja - a member of a family worth an estimated £2bn - was apparently able to speed up the process simply by asking Peter Mandelson how new Home Office regulations on nationality might affect them. One phone call from Mandy to the then immigration minister, Mike O'Brien, and the offer of a sponsorship to the Millennium Dome's most neglected zone, and Mr Hinduja was sorted within six months.

I too made a phone call to ask how nationality regulations will affect me; unfortunately I called the immigration and nationality directorate rather than Mandy. I was on hold for 20 minutes before giving up and using the website.

So assuming that Mr Hinduja would have qualified for British nationality with or without ministerial intervention, his £1m contribution to the Millennium Dome's faith zone probably shaved about one and a half years off the formal application process. That breaks down to about £55,555 a month.

Now, I have a few friends, and I bet I could scrape together £55K through a combination of begging, loans and remortgaging. All of which begs the question: if I made a £55,000 contribution to a favoured Labour party cause, would the current immigration minister, Barbara Roche, hand over the passport one month early?

A spokesman in Ms Roche's office informed me: "She doesn't speak to members of the public about nationality matters."

He did confirm that applications for nationality are taking about 18 or 19 months at the moment, and that I'll just have to wait.

"I'm sorry that's zero help," he apologised.

Indeed, it would appear that my problem is a lack of zeros on the end of my bank balance.

One last point: at the time the Home Office informed me that it would begin to consider my application in 19 months, it also told me not to call and bother them; phoning for information would only result in delays to everyone's application process, I was told.

So every time a minister puts in a call and puts a wealthy party donor ahead of others, it affects more than party purity. It means that every other candidate for nationality spends yet more time waiting in a 19-month-long queue for the Home Office to finally call our number.

webTitle: 'I want to lead a more normal life'

fields.headline: 'I want to lead a more normal life'
fields.standfirst:
Who said what in the 'passport for favours' row

Special report: Peter Mandelson

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Who said what in the 'passport for favours' row.
fields.body:
Saturday January 20
Peter Mandelson "To the limited extent I was involved I was always very sensitive to the proprieties. The matter was dealt with by my private secretary. At no time did I support or endorse this application for citizenship."

Sunday Jan 21
Spokesman for Northern Ireland Office "If you ignore the headline of this story and read the facts, Mr Mandelson did not assist in this passport application. He did not support or endorse any application, nor would he have considered doing so."

Spokesman for Srichand Hinduja "In the summer of 1998 Mr Hinduja asked Mr Mandelson informally if an application by him to the Home Office for British nationality would be considered. Mr Mandelson kindly came back to Mr Hinduja and confirmed he was eligible to apply, and that a formal application would be considered by the Home Office in the normal manner. Mr Mandelson had absolutely no further involvement."

Monday January 22
PM's official spokesman "This was an issue raised by the Hindujas and it was passed to the Home Office. When specifically they asked Peter to endorse or support any application he refused, perfectly properly and appropriately. He did exactly what any other minister would do, which is pass it to the relevant department, which is the Home Office. Peter did not get involved - beyond being asked to get involved, which he did not."

Tuesday January 23
PM's official spokesman "Yesterday I repeated that Peter's sole involvement was a call from his private secretary to the Home Office, which was Peter's recollection. Yesterday with offices back up and running, Peter's office was able to look at it in further detail and was able to recollect he had a call with Home Office minister Mike O'Brien in June 1998.

"Mike O'Brien has confirmed Peter Mandelson did not make representations on behalf of the brothers, or make representations on any potential application, and did not support or endorse it. The end result is precisely the same."

Mr Mandelson "There was no passport application, no discussion between me and the Home Office of the merits of giving a passport, no support or endorsement by me of any future passport application. An innocent inquiry was made in a two-minute phone conversation, facilitated by civil servants and monitored by them. That is the beginning and end of this story. The rest is innuendo."

Wednesday January 24
Home Office minister Charles Clarke "As with anything that comes along, it is far and away the best thing to tell the full story as openly as possible at the outset.

"The one think I am certain of is that the Home Office's processes in relation to this have been extremely rigorous and will continue to be."

PM's official spokesman "The prime minister has got to face the House of Commons this afternoon and there are a number of areas of fact he feels the need to pin down."

Mr Mandelson "I am today resigning from the government.

"I confess in reaching my decision that there is another factor. As a reading of today's newspapers shows all too graphically, there must be more to politics than the constant media exposure and pressure that has dogged me over the last five or so years.

"I want to lead a more normal life."

fields.headline: Ad watchdog to speed up claims
fields.trailText:
1.30pm update: The ASA has promised sweeping reforms after criticism about the length of time it takes to investigate ad complaints, writes Claire Cozens.
Jan 24: ASA rules against Red Bull
fields.body:
Advertising watchdogs today promised sweeping reforms after a protracted four-year investigation decided that a Red Bull ad had made unfounded claims.

The Advertising Standards Authority has come in for repeated criticism in the past about the length of time it takes to assess complaints about ads.

This can enable advertisers to flout the rules because, by the time an ad is banned, the campaign has already run its course.

In the time that the ASA took to ban the ads, Red Bull had already dropped the claims that the product improved concentration and endurance in favour of the new line, "Red Bull gives you wings".

An ASA spokesman said the Red Bull adjudication was exceptional because of the amount of evidence submitted by the manufacturers of the drink to support its claims.

The Red Bull Company submitted more than 20 studies to the ASA.

"Unfortunately, this kind of thing does happen from time to time and that is why we are working on speeding up our act," said the spokesman.

"But a long investigation is sometimes necessary. You can't just tell someone to stop doing something until it has been investigated properly."

He said the watchdog had been working on speeding up its adjudication process for several months.

The ASA recently began publishing its adjudications on a weekly rather than a monthly basis.

webTitle: Crozier receives hate-mail for appointing Eriksson

fields.headline: Crozier receives hate-mail for appointing Eriksson
fields.trailText: FA chief executive Adam Crozier has received hate mail since appointing Sven-Goran Eriksson as England coach.
fields.body:
FA chief executive Adam Crozier has received hate mail since appointing Sven-Goran Eriksson as England coach.

Members of far-right groups, incensed that the Scottish-born Crozier has appointed a foreign manager, have sent threatening letters and emails to the FA attacking his decision.

Crozier said: "Some of them were quite nasty but you just have to ignore it. There's not a lot I can do about being Scottish though it has only really become a talking-point since Sven was appointed.

"The really daft ones I passed on to police in case there was anything in it. Yet for each one criticising the FA decision on Sven, there was one saying we had made the right choice," he added.

Crozier has urged supporters to get behind Eriksson and support England in their bid to reach the 2002 World Cup finals.

"We have to have the courage of our convictions. We have to stick with it and get it right," he said. "There is no way either Sven or I are going to walk out if England fail to qualify for World Cup 2002.

"I can understand people saying 'we want an Englishman' because long term the FA do as well. That is why we have set Team England in place with Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren helping Sven."

fields.headline: Capital boosts revenues
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Capital Radio, home of Chris Tarrant, has admitted concern over advertising income despite reporting a boost in revenues. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Capital Radio, home of Chris Tarrant and Dr Fox, has admitted concern over advertising income despite reporting a boost in total revenues.

The fast-growing radio group said revenues from October to December last year were up 4% from the same period in 1999, but added that it was "cautious" about the current advertising market.

Earnings forecasts have been scaled back across the whole media sector due to concerns over a slowdown in advertising sales growth, and today's trading statement is likely to have a similar effect on Capital.

"We are seeing some small downgrades drifting into the advertising outlook in the first few months of 2001, and it is across the board in the sector," said Simon Baker, media analyst at SG Securities.

"After this statement there will small trimming of Capital's numbers for 2001, and that just reinforces the cautionary outlook held by some

However, the owner of Capital FM and Xfm said that the long-term picture for radio advertising was "very positive".

Radio advertising revenue grew by a staggering 50% last year, which has set the sector an impossible target for this year.

"Capital Radio is the UK's leading analogue and digital radio company and with a balanced portfolio of established and new stations we are well placed to deliver future growth," the statement said.

Capital plans to spend £3.2m on digital radio this year, and will use its digital licences to build a national network for its Xfm station.

Although Capital is up against the regulatory limit for radio station ownership, it is likely to continue growing by buying small stakes in other radio businesses.

These holdings will form the basis for takeover bids as soon as the regulations are relaxed by new communications legislation next year.

Capital's shares fell 8% to 1025p following the statement.

fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk. We'll do our best to answer them
fields.trailText: THE GREATEST EVER COMEBACK
fields.body:
THE GREATEST EVER COMEBACK

Late one Saturday afternoon in the late Fifties or early Sixties, I was listening to Sports Report on the Light Programme. The big news on that particular day was that a team losing 5-1 had recovered to win 6-5. I'm pretty sure one of the teams was Charlton. Can you tell me who they were playing? I'd also be grateful to know if I've remembered the score correctly writes Charles Wood.

One of the teams was indeed Charlton, Charles. But their Second Division home match against Huddersfield on December 21 1957 was even more incredible than you remember.

With only half an hour of the game to play, Huddersfield were 5-1 up and cruising to victory.

The scoreline made sense: defensively inept Charlton, who had been relegated the previous season after conceding 120 goals, had been playing with 10 men ever since their captain, Derek Ufton, was stretchered off after 15 minutes with a dislocated shoulder (there were no subs in those days). What followed did not.

Charlton's solitary goal at that point had been scored by Johnny Summers. But then the winger really got to work. He scored a second and, a minute later, set one up for John Ryan: 5-3. By the time the next 10 minutes were up, Summers had scored another three, bringing his personal total to a club-record five. Charlton had amazingly taken a 6-5 lead.

Huddersfield did rise from their slumber to score an equaliser. But with the last kick of the match, Summers laid on another goal for Ryan and a frankly ridiculous 7-6 victory was complete.

No team other than Huddersfield has scored six goals in a league match and still lost. What their manager Bill Shankly said in the dressing room after the game is thankfully not recorded.

HOW A DUBIOUS OFFSIDE DECISION SAVED A TACTICAL GENIUS'S LIFE

In a previous Knowledge Unlimited we explained how tactical genius Vittorio Pozzo - the man whose metodo formation helped Italy win the World Cup in 1934 and 1938 - was famously warned by Mussolini before the 1938 tournament to "win or die".

We've had an email from Arild Andersen, adding to the tale. "Italy won the cup," he writes, "but it could have been over after the first-round match, because the Norway v Italy game sports the most famous offside decision in the history of Norwegian soccer.

"Two minutes left, with the score 1-1, Norwegian left winger Arne Brustad, a Ryan Giggs-like player hailed as the best Scandinavian player of his generation, scored for Norway (he was also the man who levelled the game three minutes earlier). But the referee awarded an extremely dubious offside. This is also confirmed by several Italian sources, and in Norway it's quite popular to consider this a fascist collaboration - the ref was an Austrian.

"The match was broadcast on Norwegian radio, and on the tape a relatively quiet commentator turns into a screaming feedback wizard twice: the equaliser and the offside decision. Italy won the match 2-1 after extra time."

WHAT COUNTRY WAS SUPPOSED TO HOST THE WORLD CUP IN 1986?

"Can you settle a disagreement that I've started in my local?" asks Dan Blandford. "I set the questions for the weekly quiz and asked the following question: The 1986 Mexico World Cup was originally meant to be held in which South American country? Let me know your answer as mine was challenged by the rest of the pub!"

In 1974 Fifa awarded the 1986 World Cup to Colombia - but infrastructure and financial problems meant that by 1983 the country was struggling to meet its promises. Realising the prospects of a World Cup in Columbia were slim, Brazil, Canada, Mexico and the United States offered themselves as alternatives for the 1986 tournament.

After Colombia were forced to drop out, Brazil decided they weren't interested in World Cup 86 after all. And so Fifa, faced with three competing bids, decided in May 1983 to reject Canada and the US in favour of Mexico.

There was much outrage in the US about the decision. Henry Kissinger, the leader of the US bid, even petitioned Fifa for another chance, arguing that the 1986 tournament would revive the fading North American Soccer League (NASL). He was supported by Pele and Franz Beckenbauer - but Fifa's president Joao Havelange was singularly unimpressed.

Fifa claimed their decision was down to logistics - the US bid included venues on the east and west coast, which meant increased travelling times and weary footballers. But the real reason was that they wanted to teach US football a lesson.

In 1981, Fifa had threatened to outlaw the NASL and suspend the US Federation because the NASL had changed the offside line from halfway to 35 yards out and used a shootout to decide drawn matches. The NASL refused to back down - and even threatened legal action against Fifa. But what comes around goes around, and two years later Fifa got its revenge by rejecting Kissinger's bid. With the last hope of reviving the NASL gone, it folded before the start of the 1986 World Cup.

For more information click here.

NOT REALLY THEIR SUCCESS

Can you name an Englishman, Scotsman, Irishman and Welshman that have all played for three sides that have won the European Cup? The players do not have to have been at the club when it was won - eg: Kenny Dalglish has played for two sides in Celtic and Liverpool writes Russell Herbert.

This one reeks of the bonus round in one of Dan Blandford's pub quizzes. Nevertheless, here we go.

Your Englishman is Stan Collymore, who made friends at Nottingham Forest (winners in 1979 and 1980), Liverpool (1977, 1978, 1981, 1984) and Aston Villa (1982). Mark Hughes is your Welshman. He's turned out for Manchester United (1968 and 1999), Barcelona (1992) and Bayern Munich (1974, 1975, 1976).

The Scottish member of this clan is Alan McInally, who played for Celtic, Villa and Bayern, while Tony Cascarino completes your set, having pulled shots wide of goal at Villa, Celtic and Marseille (1993).

There are probably more. But that's enough, isn't it?

Oh, alright. David Platt's played for four European Cup winning clubs in United, Villa, Juventus (1985 and 1996) and Forest. Although obviously, like the all the other players we've mentioned, he never actually got his hands on the damn thing.

BROTHERS IN GOALS

"When was the last time that two brothers scored in the same match, either in the same team or opposite?" asks Derek Tonkin.

The last brothers to score in the same game for England were the Charltons, with Bobby and Jack both hitting the back of the net during England's 5-1 victory against Wales in November 1966. We're not sure the last time two brothers scored in the same league game, however. If anyone can help (did you see the Wallace brothers manage it?) write in and let us know.

YET MORE SPINAL TAP

We've had Derek Smalls wearing an early 80s Shrewsbury Town shirt. Smalls sporting a claret and blue baseball cap. David St Hubbins with a Wolves scarf. But the Tap footballing references still pour in.

"At the risk of flogging a dead horse," says Sam Johnstone. "I came across another footie reference in Spinal Tap.

"In the excellent companion book by Karl French there is an out-take showing David St Hubbins and Nigel Tufnel on top of a skyscraper discussing how they are 'top of the world' and comparing the Tap's current form to that of Kenny Dalglish.

"Obviously they were kidding themselves as King Kenny was, at the time of the film, by far the best player in Europe. Whereas the Tap were in Kerry Dixon's league."

CAN YOU HELP?

"Can you tell me who scored the last First Division goal of the 1991/92 season?" asks Sue Neil.

"Which club did the Egyptian goalkeeper Mustafa Mansour play for which between 1937 and 1940?" asks John Boyack. "I believe the club was a Scottish one but I'm not sure," he adds.

"My team in Norway, Odd BK, won the Cup last season; their first trophy since 1931. What is the longest gap between two domestic titles for a European club?" asks Arild Andersen.

Send your answers to the.boss@theguardian.com.

webTitle: McLeish set for elderly care u-turn

fields.headline: McLeish set for elderly care u-turn
fields.trailText: Scottish first minister Henry McLeish is today set to make a u-turn over radical proposals to give Scotland a more generous policy on long-term care for elderly people than is planned for England.
fields.body:
Scottish first minister Henry McLeish is today set to make a u-turn over radical proposals to give Scotland a more generous policy on long-term care for elderly people than is planned for England.

Mr McLeish is believed to be ready to back off from plans floated last year that he would break ranks with Westminster by implementing in full the recommendations of the Sutherland commission on long-term care.

But reports suggest that he will today avoid making such a commitment, potentially heading off a damaging row with the prime minister, Tony Blair, and party colleagues on both sides of the border.

The Sutherland report, published in March 2000, called for all nursing and personal care to be made free where needed. In England, ministers rejected the recommendations on free personal care, partly on grounds of cost.

Soon after he became first minister in October, Mr McLeish suggested the Sutherland report was a key policy of his administration and that he wanted to "move forward" on it.

But in recent weeks he has been backtracking amid fears from Westminster that such a move could fuel demands for parity from pensioners in England at a sensitive time just before a general election.

Overnight reports suggest Mr McLeish is to set up a working party - which will not report until after a May election - to consider whether, rather than when, the Sutherland report will be implemented in full.

webTitle: Last two of 'Texas Seven' surrender to police

fields.headline: Last two of 'Texas Seven' surrender to police
fields.trailText: The last two fugitives of the seven who escaped from a Texas prison surrendered peacefully to police officers in Colorado Springs, Colorado, in the early hours of this morning (11am GMT).
fields.body:
The last two fugitives of the seven who escaped from a Texas prison surrendered peacefully to police officers in Colorado Springs, Colorado, in the early hours of this morning (11am GMT).

Patrick Murphy, 39, and Donald Newbury, 38, spent Tuesday night holed up in a Holiday Inn, negotiating with law enforcement over the terms of their surrender. Hotel guests in about "six to eight rooms" near the inmates were evacuated to allow police to lay siege to the building.

Murphy and Newbury had been described as armed and extremely dangerous and had been negotiating by with the police on the telephone since 10pm local time (5am GMT) Tuesday night. The men gave themselves up after being granted a phone interview with a local television station.

"They felt they had some message that they had to say," explained a Colorado police officer on the scene. "Then they did comply with the directions given to them by officers. We are extremely excited that this ended peacefully and without injury."

Officers are now awaiting a warrant that will allow them to search the hotel room.

Murphy, who had been serving a 50-year sentence for aggravated sexual assault, and Newbury, who was serving a 99-year sentence for armed robbery, were part of a group of seven convicts that escaped from a prison in Texas on December 13.

Four of the fugitives were captured on Monday near a trailer park in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains after police were tipped by local residents. Another fugitive shot himself to death on Monday, leaving a note for relatives.

The seven were wanted for killing a policeman in Irving, Texas, in a Christmas Eve robbery at a sporting goods store, where they grabbed some weapons and cash.

Captured on Monday were George Rivas, 30, the suspected ringleader of the gang, Michael Rodriguez, 38, Joseph Garcia, 29, and Randy Halprin, 23.

The FBI said on Tuesday that it was unusual to see a group of prison escapees stay together so long.

webTitle: Houllier looks for polish, but no spit

fields.headline: Houllier looks for polish, but no spit
fields.standfirst: Follow the game with Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Gerard Houllier has warned his Liverpool players to keep their feet on the ground ahead of tonight's Worthington Cup semi-final tie with Crystal Palace ... and told Clinton Morrison not to spit in the air.
fields.body:
Gerard Houllier has warned his Liverpool players to keep their feet on the ground ahead of tonight's Worthington Cup semi-final tie with Crystal Palace ... and told Clinton Morrison not to spit in the air.

The Liverpool manager gave his homily on humility as the Reds look to overturn a 2-1 first leg deficit at Anfield tonight.

"Expectation is one thing, delivery is another", said Houllier, who is expected to recall Robbie Fowler up front alongside Emile Heskey. "We have the talent to get to the final, and I don't think their desire will be higher than ours.

'We have 90 minutes of football to put things right. As we stand, we are losing 2-1 so we shall stay humble over this. Being everybody's favourite to me means nothing, it is what we do on the field that matters.

"Let's just try to qualify for the final first. Sometimes you spit in the air and it comes back in your face."

All the metaphorical spitting has so far been done by Palace striker Morrison, who offered Michael Owen some advice on how to score after the England striker missed a host of chances during the first leg at Selhurst Park.

"There is one domain in which you really have to keep yourself out of giving lessons to others and that is football", Houllier said.

Owen will miss the second leg through injury, giving Robbie Fowler a chance to pull on a first team shirt. Houllier had declared Fowler a certain starter earlier in the week, but yesterday said Fowler would be captain "if he plays". This could just be a spot of disinformation on Houllier's part, however, and the 26-year-old is still expected to play.

Taking a leaf from Houllier's book, Palace boss Alan Smith has adopted a similarly understated approach to the game.

"I'm under no illusions," he said. "Liverpool are a great club with a fantastic set-up and there is a world of difference between them and us."

Palace will be without midfielder Hayden Mullins and key defender Fan Zhiyi, while striker Dougie Freedman is cup-tied.

"We are ahead and we are young enough," Smith said. "This will be a younger side than I have fielded all season and hopefully that enthusiasm and the way the players approach the match will be right."

Probable teams:

Liverpool - Westerveld, Babbel, Hyypia, Henchoz, Carragher, Gerrard, Hamann, Barmby, Biscan, Heskey, Fowler.

Crystal Palace - Kolinko, Smith, Frampton, Ruddock, Austin, Thomson, Black, Rodger, Forssell, Morrison, Rubins.

fields.headline: Path from denial to admission
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText:
Saturday January 20
Peter Mandelson "To the limited extent I was involved I was always very sensitive to the proprieties. The matter was dealt with by my private secretary. At no time did I support or endorse this application for citizenship."
fields.body:
Saturday January 20
Peter Mandelson "To the limited extent I was involved I was always very sensitive to the proprieties. The matter was dealt with by my private secretary. At no time did I support or endorse this application for citizenship."

Sunday January 21
Spokesman for Northern Ireland Office "If you ignore the headline of this story and read the facts, Mr Mandelson did not assist in this passport application. He did not support or endorse any application, nor would he have considered doing so."

Spokesman for Srichand Hinduja "In the summer of 1998 Mr Hinduja asked Mr Mandelson informally if an application by him to the Home Office for British nationality would be considered. Mr Mandelson kindly came back to Mr Hinduja and confirmed he was eligible to apply, and that a formal application would be considered by the Home Office in the normal manner. Mr Mandelson had absolutely no further involvement."

Monday January 22
PM's official spokesman "This was an issue raised by the Hindujas and it was passed to the Home Office. When specifically they asked Peter to endorse or support any application he refused, perfectly properly and appropriately. He did exactly what any other minister would do, which is pass it to the relevant department, which is the Home Office. Peter did not get involved - beyond being asked to get involved, which he did not."

Tuesday January 23
PM's official spokesman "Yesterday I repeated that Peter's sole involvement was a call from his private secretary to the Home Office, which was Peter's recollection. Yesterday with offices back up and running, Peter's office was able to look at it in further detail and was able to recollect he had a call with Home Office minister Mike O'Brien in June 1998.

"Mike O'Brien has confirmed Peter Mandelson did not make representations on behalf of the brothers, or make representations on any potential application, and did not support or endorse it. The end result is precisely the same."

Mr Mandelson "There was no passport application, no discussion between me and the Home Office of the merits of giving a passport, no support or endorsement by me of any future passport application. An innocent inquiry was made in a two-minute phone conversation, facilitated by civil servants and monitored by them. That is the beginning and end of this story. The rest is innuendo."

fields.headline: Minister's year of living dangerously
fields.standfirst:
Difficulty over telephone call about dome donor is seen as further hangover from period of home loan controversy
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Difficulty over telephone call about dome donor is seen as further hangover from period of home loan controversy.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire  and Luke Harding  in Delhi
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson may be grateful that the junior Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, apparently has a much better memory than his own.

While the former dome minister took time to remember phoning Mr O'Brien about a passport application from a businessman who was to fund the faith zone, Mr O'Brien could supply the details: it was a two minute call and no pressure was applied.

The Home Office was unable to find the note of the June, 1998, conversation yesterday, maintaining the missing record was a cock-up and not a conspiracy to protect the pair.

But Mr Mandelson, one of Tony Blair's closest political allies, is likely to be disappointed if he hopes that his admission will be the end of the matter as oppostion MPs demanded precise details of the call.

The Hindujas, on bail in India where corruption charges have been filed against them over alleged kickbacks from an arms deal, disclosed they were willing to pump cash into the dome on June 17.

Mr Mandelson's enemies demanded to know whether the potentially explosive call was made before or after that date.

The admission that he even spoke to Mr O'Brien, then responsible for immigration issues, followed a series of twists and turns by the Northern Ireland secretary and Downing Street that left Labour's Millbank HQ struggling yesterday to persuade Labour MPs publicly to defend the embattled minister.

Mr Mandelson has been unable to recall events in the past, most notably in December 1998 when he failed to recall whether or not (he did not) mention a £373,000 loan from Geoffrey Robinson on his Britannia building society mortgage application form.

That crisis ended in Mr Mandelson's resignation from the cabinet and the current furore is seen as another hangover from 1998, the year he lived dangerously.

The Hindjuas are Britain's wealthiest Asian family. Srichand and Gopichand hold British passports, while a third brother, Prakash, is a Swiss national.

After giving the Tories £6m, they have been courted by New Labour. Mr Mandelson attended a reception in Carlton House Terrace, near Robin Cook's official residence, shortly before the 1997 election while a year ago Tony and Cherie Blair attended a Diwali party in Alexandra Palace hosted by the brothers.

Srichand Hinduja approached Mr Mandelson after a passport application had been rejected, asking according to both whether he could take advantage of a change in immigration laws encouraging long term residents to apply.

The family had told the New Millennium Experience Company in February 1997, before Labour came to power, it was interested in financing the faith zone, and 12 months later offered to underwrite the entire cost.

June 1998 saw them announce to religious groups they would stump up as much as £3m before it emerged in the national press on October 14 that year they would hand over £1m. Six days later Srichand reapplied and by March 1999 he had his passport. Mr Mandelson maintains that he acted properly after he was approached by Srichand for advice but the information has had to be dragged out of Whitehall.

The Home Office minister, Barbara Roche, admitted in a parliamentary written reply last Thursday to terrier-like Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker that Mr Mandelson, Keith Vaz - now Europe minister - and "others" had "made inquiries" but "did not make representations that an application be granted".

On Saturday night, Mr Mandelson's office issued a statement to the Observer, which carried the story on Sunday, saying: "To the limited extent that I was involved, I was always very sensitive to the proprieties. At no time did I support or endorse this application for citizenship."

Over the weekend, telephone calls were denied and on Monday morning the prime minister's spokesman repeated the line and, when pressed for more information, the official note records that "... the PMOS [prime minister's official spokesman] said journalists could dance around the issue as much as they liked. The facts were as he had already set out." The culture secretary, Chris Smith, even repeated Mr Mandelson's original version of events on Monday afternoon during questions in the Commons; something he will be required to correct.

Then in a u-turn yesterday Downing Street admitted that it had not told the truth when Alastair Campbell confessed he had made a mistake.

Insisting it was an error, he said the full facts were not known until later Monday when civil servants dug out a record that the call was made.

"With offices back up and running after the weekend," said yesterday's No 10 note, "Mr Mandelson's office had been able to look at the records in full and had discovered that he had had a very brief telephone conversation in June 1998 with Mike O'Brien [the then immigration minister] which had been set up by their two private offices.

"Although Mr Mandelson had no recollection of the call, clearly it had taken place and he had therefore asked him [the PMOS] to make that clarification here and now. However, it did not change the material fact that he had done nothing improper."

webTitle: Big brother's family values as the boss

fields.headline: Big brother's family values as the boss
fields.standfirst:
Srichand Hinduja

Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: Profile: Srichand Hinduja
fields.body:
Standing in a courtyard filled with rubbish, Srichand Hinduja was given five words of advice last week by one of his daughters. "Don't talk to the buggers," she said.

The buggers in question were the Indian journalists who had gathered enthusiastically to report on the Hindujas' debut appearance in a court of law. But Srichand Hinduja - or SP as he is known - ignored the advice and chatted away for 10 minutes, strange behaviour for a man reputed to be a reclusive and litigious billionaire.

Of the four Hinduja brothers - he is joined by Gopichand, Prakesh, and Ashok - SP is, at 65, the oldest. He is also the most flamboyant and - as recent events have proved - the most controversial.

The rise in the Hindujas' fortunes says much about the power of collective endeavour. But it is also the story of one man. Within the firm, SP is known simply as the boss, reflecting his importance as group chairman.

Since arriving in Delhi last Thursday, SP has responded to the various setbacks that have engulfed him with phlegmatic good humour. "I never take anything as a problem," he said, after the judge investigating the corruption case against the Hindujas refused them permission to leave India. "I take things as they come. That is how I have lived my life.

"We are very relaxed because we are innocent. Why shouldn't we be relaxed?" he added.

The Hindujas have jointly been important powerbrokers in India and Britain for the past 20 years. But it has been SP's affable charm that has lured Margaret Thatcher and Tony and Cherie Blair to dinner - and which appears to have encouraged Peter Mandelson into making one phone call too many.

A conservative, teetotal vegetarian, Srichand Hinduja would prefer to be associated with his spiritual and philanthropic concerns. He has written a book, the Essence of Vedic Marriage for Success and Happiness (1996). He is a practising Hindu. (Bathing in the Ganges left one "energised," he said last week.) By billionaire standards, he lives modestly.

"Within the Asian community the Hindujas have a reputation as spiritual leaders," a source said last night. "It is only outside it they are regarded as tycoons."

webTitle: Suicide bids mar China's New Year festivities

fields.headline: Suicide bids mar China's New Year festivities
fields.trailText: China's Year of the Snake begins today, tainted by yesterday's group suicide attempt in Tiananmen Square, where five members of the banned Falun Gong sect are said to have set themselves on fire.
fields.body:
China's Year of the Snake begins today, tainted by yesterday's group suicide attempt in Tiananmen Square, where five members of the banned Falun Gong sect are said to have set themselves on fire.

Four women and one man simultaneously doused themselves in petrol early in the afternoon, the official Chinese news agency said. One of the women died and the others were taken to hospital.

Onlookers said that one man sat burning on the ground while the four women walked with their clothes alight, holding up their hands in a characteristic Falun Gong pose. A cloud of smoke rose between heaped piles of snow on the square, and film taken by a CNN crew was confiscated by the police.

The incident came after official warnings that "safeguarding social security" would be the top priority during the traditional spring festival, when the Chinese New Year is celebrated for at least a week.

The way this year's festival is celebrated in many parts of the country will be illustrative of the rapid changes Chinese society is undergoing, both for better and for worse. But the apparent Falun Gong protest also reflects the challenges of a society which is becoming harder to control.

The lifestyles of the emerging middle class now include holidays away from home, instead of the traditional family gathering.

"I'm taking my wife and daughter to Wenzhou, on the coast," said a Chinese insurance executive in Shanghai. "I'm told there are nice beaches there. It's more fun than just meeting my relatives and eating dumplings."

Domestic tourism is burgeoning, with charter planes to balmy southern China and ski packages on offer to the frozen north-east.

More than 10,000 Shanghainese have also booked overseas packages, mostly to Thailand or Hong Kong, although some go further afield to South Korea, France or the US. This is despite daunting bureaucratic formalities for international travel, such as obtaining permission from the local police, waiting 20 working days for a passport and having to deposit 5,000 yuan (£410) to guarantee their return.

Many who stay at home now prefer to eat out instead of cooking the traditional New Year's Eve meal at home; a Shanghai Daily survey showed that the city's top restaurants were fully booked yesterday evening - and some were already taking bookings for next year.

Many places offer take-away services - unthinkable in the past when families took pride in preparing their own food.

For millions of peasant migrants, however, the spring festival is celebrated with more traditional economy; it is the only chance during the year for most of them to return home to their families.

Small groups of rural workers with bundles of belongings are a frequent sight in Shanghai as they make their way through the streets to its railway and bus stations. More than 200m migrants - no one knows the exact number - are thought to be on the move, packed on to special trains and long-distance buses.

Work at the city's construction sites closes down for several weeks. "I can't find a single peasant to paint the house," complained a Shanghai landlord negotiating a lease. "I'll just have to wait till they return."

The migrants are vulnerable to scalpers whose high-priced tickets may be forged. Pickpockets, too, have a field day in the dense crowds that pack the booking halls, and among the exhausted travellers sleeping on their bundles.

In one day last week at the southern city of Guangzhou's main railway station, 130,000 passengers boarded 90 trains which left every 15 minutes for remote provinces.

Tens of thousands of other migrants waited in vain for tickets. Some will not arrive home until today - too late for New Year's Eve.

webTitle: Damilola's father attacks UK's 'lack of morality'

fields.headline: Damilola's father attacks UK's 'lack of morality'
fields.standfirst: More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: The father of the murdered schoolboy Damilola Taylor today called for a moral regeneration of Britain in memory of his 10-year-old son.
fields.body:
The father of the murdered schoolboy Damilola Taylor today called for a moral regeneration of Britain in memory of his 10-year-old son.

Richard Taylor said he was deeply hurt by the wall of silence which was surrounding Damilola's fatal stabbing in Peckham, south-east London, as he returned home from an after-school computer class last November.

Meanwhile, Damilola's mother, Gloria Taylor, has described how blood poured from her son's mouth as she embraced his body hours after his death.

Damilola's family renewed their appeal for information today following a statement from detectives earlier this week that the hunt for those responsible could be over in a matter of days if a vital witness came forward.

Mr Taylor blamed a lack of family values and moral discipline for the attack and for a subsequent "culture of hostility" which police say is preventing them from arresting the killers.

He said that moral values had broken down in the UK and, while the public had been "very kind" after Damilola's death, he regretted bringing his family to this country.

Mr Taylor said the community in Peckham was scared of giving evidence to the police, fearing reprisals from "the gangs that terrorise the area".

He said: "I am very much disappointed by this reaction from the community. I know very well that they do have information on who has carried out this heinous act.

"The parents are irresponsible people, they don't have family values and its because of this that they don't have control over their kids."

Mr Taylor told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that people who withheld information were also "criminals".

He added: "People of Nigeria are shocked that a civilised country like the UK still has things like this happening.

"We have violent acts going on in Nigeria but not the killing of a young boy like Damilola ... who was hacked down by children of no value."

In a television interview to be shown tonight, Ms Taylor wept as she spoke publicly about her ordeal for the first time since his funeral last week.

"They took me from that spot to the hospital, just about reaching the hospital as they broke the news that he was already dead ... and I couldn't believe it was him," she tells BBC1's Crimewatch UK programme.

"Then I pulled him, I pulled him and I put my head on him ... and all that came out from his lips was blood ... splashed over his face and just like a dream to me."

Mr Taylor added: "I can't imagine my son dying there, his blood was there. It was a horrifying experience for me." The programme features a reconstruction of Damilola's last-known movements built up from CCTV footage.

Fifteen people have so far been arrested in connection with the youngster's death on November 27 last year but no one has been charged.

Damilola had only been in Britain for four months, after the family had moved from Nigeria to join Mr Taylor.

Mr Taylor said a campaign in memory of Damilola would focus on deprived areas such as Peckham.

He called on the government to make "drastic changes" in policy to foster "moral values and family values" especially regarding children carrying dangerous weapons.

He said: "Parents are supposed to know that they don't have to rely on the government to bring up their children, it's their responsibility and it's on this that we are going to campaign."

 Crimewatch UK is screened on BBC1 tonight at 9.05pm.

fields.body:
The war of words between Sky and ITN escalated today with the ITV news supplier hitting out at the satellite broadcaster.

ITN today lashed out against Sky News in response to remarks made by Sky News chief Nick Pollard.

Mr Pollard accused ITN of "spitting out the dummy" when it made intemperate remarks about Sky's challenge for the £42m-a-year contract.

Mr Pollard, a former ITN executive, made his comment following the announcement that a coalition comprising Sky, CBS, Ulster TV, Chrysalis and Bloomberg was to bid for ITV news contract.

An ITN spokesman said: "We understand the ITC wrote to Sky late last year confirming Sky News was unsuitable to make a solo bid for ITV news because of Rupert Murdoch's large stake in the company.

"Sky has had to construct this coalition to technically dilute Murdoch's influence - but he's still there."

The spokesman also claimed Sky News was under pressure to win external contracts to justify its existence.

Despite growing prestige, Sky News has failed to make a profit in its 12 years of existence.

It has bid several times for terrestrial news contracts on ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5.

Last year, Sky believed it had come close to winning the contract to provide Channel 5 News.

At the time, Mr Pollard claimed Sky's bid had beaten a rival bid from ITN.

He added, however, that ITN had come back with an 11th hour deal that undercut Sky.

webTitle: Corporate world adopts voluntary sector values

fields.headline: Corporate world adopts voluntary sector values
fields.trailText: Manny Amadi, chief executive of Cause & Effect Marketing, has been chosen as a "global leader for tomorrow" by the World Economic Forum. He is one of the few people going from the UK to the annual conference in Davos, Switzerland, this week.
fields.body:
Manny Amadi, chief executive of Cause & Effect Marketing, has been chosen as a "global leader for tomorrow" by the World Economic Forum. He is one of the few people going from the UK to the annual conference in Davos, Switzerland, this week.

Mr Amadi was formerly director of development at the Prince's Trust and recently set up a small consultancy specialising in corporate social responsibility.

"The world is moving in the direction where life can't be lived in departments," he said. "Businesses are looking to acquire the values of other sectors - service from the government sector and dedication from the voluntary sector."

Last year, Mr Amadi notes that issues such as corporate social responsibility and globalisation were peripheral to the conference. "I am very excited that they are now central themes," he said.

However, he is realistic about why this has happened. "Enlightened self-interest is the driving force behind businesses taking the social agenda forward," said Mr Amadi.

In a recent global opinion survey conducted by Environics among 25,000 consumers in 23 countries found that 50% cited social responsibility as the most important factor which influenced their opinions. Two-thirds wanted companies to go beyond their traditional role and actively contribute to broader social goals.

"Businesses have realised that it is in their own long-term interests if they combine social gain with commercial advantage," added Mr Amadi.

He advises voluntary organisations that wish to engage corporate support to think of a compelling reason why the company they are targeting should be involved with their cause: "But voluntary organisations have very powerful assets of use to the business and they should not sell themselves short, there must be mutual benefit within a relationship."

The pressure is on both corporates and NGOs to be more transparent and Mr Amadi believes the internet has played a role in accelerating this trend. "Information can now be transmitted speedily around the world and labour practices in the south have not been aligned to the image companies have been projecting in the north. The information flow has helped NGOs to put pressure on companies."

However, he warns against extreme action such as the anti-globalisation demonstration dubbed the "battle of Seattle", which he says can put issues on the agenda but "might undo the points the protestors are trying to drive home, engagement is preferable as we need to build consensus".

Mr Amadi is involved in a taskforce initiated by the World Economic Forum which consists of leaders of the future. He said he thought the corporate members of the taskforce would be very competitive but was pleasantly surprised: "The future CEOs of multi-nationals are very engaged and passionate and a great hope for the future."

fields.headline: BBC bulletin narrows ratings gap
fields.trailText: 11.30am TV overnights: The gap between ITV's News at Ten and the BBC1 news closed by more than 2m viewers last night, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The ratings gap between ITV's News at Ten and the BBC1 Ten O'Clock News closed by more than 2m viewers last night.

Without a ratings leg-up from Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, News at Ten slumped by more than 2m down from from 8.1m to 5.9m, according to unofficial overnights.

By contrast BBC's Ten O'Clock News held steady at 4.4m, slightly up on Monday night's 4.3m audience.

The ratings gap between the two bulletins narrowed from 3.8m two nights ago to 1.5m, still giving News at Ten a comfortable victory.

News at Ten inherited 8.8m viewers from Peak Practice at 10pm, compared with 12.8m the previous night from Millionaire.

Overall, the Peak District GP drama had 8.4m and a 34% share, over 60 minutes from 9pm.

It was up against the concluding part of BBC1 two-part detective drama Second Sight, which shed 1m viewers between episodes, despite the backing of a newspaper ad campaign marketing the Monday and Tuesday night slots under a "Crime Double" drama banner.

The Clive Owen vehicle managed just 4.4m and an 18% share, which is believed to be one of the worst performances for a BBC1 first-run weekday drama in the past decade.

The real ratings winner last night was Channel 5 movie repeat The Rock, which aired between 9pm and 11.40pm.

The action thriller, which features Nicolas Cage and Sean Connery battling renegade US soldiers on Alcatraz, pulled in 3.4m and an 18% share.

BBC2 also enjoyed success at 9pm, with a documentary looking back 10 years to the Challenger space shuttle disaster.

Challenger had 3.4m and a 14% share.

At 10pm Channel 4 had Better Sex, a documentary series focusing on the work of Relate's psychosexual therapy service. The show drew 1.9m and an 11% share.
