fields.headline: Booker's 'nearly man' wins Whitbread
fields.standfirst: Matthew Kneale's parable of bigoted colonialism leaves judges divided
fields.trailText: Matthew Kneale's parable of bigoted colonialism leaves judges divided
fields.body:
Matthew Kneale, the "nearly man" of last year's Booker Prize, triumphed last night by winning the richer £26,000 Whitbread book of the year award. By a "microscopic margin" his 460-page novel English Passengers, a parable of bigoted 19th-century colonialism in far-flung places, beat the late Lorna Sage's barbed, highly praised and revelatory biography Bad Blood.

The decision - the most divided in the history of the Whitbread prizes - broke a four-year run of victories by poets. The last novelist to win was William Trevor, in 1994. The judges' chairman, the lyricist Tim Rice, called their task "a nightmare". He said: "I really felt that it should have been a tie between the two books but that was impossible. I had to assert the authority of my casting vote. Nearly every one in the room was incredibly enthusiastic about both books. We tried voting but when we added up first and second preferences we still had a tie. We had to go back to another long discussion."

He felt the balance was "microscopically" in favour of Kneale. "Perhaps the achievement of putting a fiction together was the slightly greater achievement."

The book was a remarkable novel, by turns comic and tragic. Its high quality came from the brilliant device of having the story told by a large cast of characters. There are several wonderful storytellers.

Lorna Sage's memoir - written while she was suffering from emphysema which killed her last week at the age of 57 only days after she had heard about winning the £3,500 prize in the Whitbread novel section - was "a very moving story about a bleak childhood, a wonderful tale of a highly intelligent child growing up in disadvantaged circumstances, blundering into things but always getting through."

Kneale defeated the bookies' favourite for the prize, Zadie Smith's novel White Teeth, already winner of the Guardian First Book Prize.

The English Passengers is an ambitious historical novel, told through inter-spliced tes timonies, about an expedition which sails to Tasmania in 1857, led by a vicar desperate to refute Darwin's theories by finding the biblical Garden of Eden. Instead, his crew of fools, racists, bigots and money grabbers plays a role in the early destruction of the island's aborigines.

The book has been praised for its vision and black comedy, but also seen as under-powered for its length and simplistic in its view of almost all whites as vile and all aborigines as innocent. Kneale, however, maintains that the near-genocide, in a terrain where no escape was possible from greedy settlers, was an exceptionally brutal scandal in the history of the British Empire.

A traveller who has visited 82 countries on six continents, he was prompted to write the novel by getting to know Aborigines in New Guinea.

Kneale has already won two literary awards, the Somerset Maughan Award for his novel Whore Banquets and the John Llellwyn Award for Sweet Thames.

fields.headline: Elstein takes consultancy job
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Former Channel 5 boss David Elstein has joined media consultancy c-quential as an adviser, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former Channel 5 chief executive David Elstein has joined media and technology consultancy c-quential as a senior adviser.

Mr Elstein will work for around two days a week at the consultancy, owned by management consultant Arthur D Little, which advises media and technology firms on business strategy.

The appointment follows speculation that Mr Elstein was in negotiations to join the BBC after he gave a talk to senior managers.

Mr Elstein, who left Channel 5 last year, is a former director of programmes at BSkyB.

webTitle: In brief: Mel Gibson admits he's "basically mad"

fields.headline: Mel Gibson admits he's "basically mad"
fields.standfirst: Plus: Matthew McConaughey buys Texas ranch; Robert Downey Jr's wife files for divorce; Courtney Love takes her boyfriend's ex-wife to court; and is it all over for Courteney Cox and David Arquette?
fields.trailText: Plus: Matthew McConaughey buys Texas ranch; Robert Downey Jr's wife files for divorce; Courtney Love takes her boyfriend's ex-wife to court; and is it all over for Courteney Cox and David Arquette?
fields.body:
 Mel Gibson (pictured) has claimed that his acting serves as a kind of "therapy" and admits that he is "basically mad". In a bizarre interview with The Radio Times, the star of The Patriot and the upcoming What Women Want describes what he refers to as his "bestial side", a manic alter ego he refers to as Bjorn. "He's got Viking horns and I imagine myself trying to bury him," Gibson calmly explains. Growing up, Gibson says he hankered to be a war reporter and be dropped into the world's trouble spots. Acting , he reckons, probably saved his life: "God takes care of the worst idiots and he's certainly taken care of me."

 Lone Star actor Matthew McConaughey is planning a return to his home state after buying a 1600-acre ranch in Irion County, West Texas. The star of U-571, Amistad, EdTV and A Time to Kill bought the property for a reported $500,000 (£341,000), after which the owners Kay and Coleta Stewart cleared out with unseemly haste - even leaving behind their dog, Purina. "They even left all the cows out there," says a bemused McConaughey. "They didn't hardly take anything with them." Could it be that they know something that the Hollywood golden boy doesn't?

 It never rains but it pours for Robert Downey Jr, whose wife filed for divorce in an LA courtroom yesterday. The recently paroled star married model-actress Deborah Falconer in 1992 but separated from her five years ago. In the suit, Falconer cites irreconcilable differences and seeks sole custody of the couple's seven-year-old son Indio. Next week Downey Jr will be back in court facing further drug charges that could land him straight back in prison.

 Courtney Love has filed charges against Lesley Barber, the former wife of current boyfriend Jim Barber. The Hole frontwoman and star of Man on the Moon claims that Ms Barber harassed her with physical threats and prank phone calls. Matters reached a head, claims Love, when Barber drove a car over her foot, causing injuries that allegedly caused her to withdraw from the John Carpenter film Ghosts of Mars. Love's attorney Martin Singer is seeking damages, medical bills and loss of earnings estimated at $1.5m (£1m).

 Rumours are currently swirling around Hollywood of a possible break-up between Courteney Cox and husband David Arquette. Supposedly outraged by Arquette's partying ways, Cox is said to have thrown him out of the house and is now demanding a divorce. The couple met while filming the Scream series and wed 18 months ago.

webTitle: More jobs to go at AOL Time Warner

fields.headline: More jobs to go at AOL Time Warner
fields.trailText: 11am: More jobs may be axed as a result of the AOL Time Warner merger, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
After the euphoria that came with the approval of the merger, AOL and Time Warner have come back to earth with a bang.

In line with promised cost savings of £680m, the internet and TV behemoth has found itself in the uncomfortable position of having to cut about 2,400 jobs - although put in context, this figure is only 3% of the newly merged AOL Time Warner.

However, a further 3,800 positions might be slashed if AOL Time Warner goes ahead with plans to sell or close its Warner Brothers retail outlets.

The divisions that will be most affected include the internet service, AOL, which is to cut 725 jobs; the publishing wing, Time, in which 400 jobs will be lost; Warner Music Group will cut 600 jobs, as will film studio New Line Cinema; and internet portal Entertaindom.com will also slash 100 jobs.

Additionally, a 100 overlapping staff in AOL and Time Warner corporate will also lose their jobs.

Last week, AOL Time Warner confirmed that it was forced into cutting 400 staff from CNN.

The only division seemingly spared staff culls were pay cable network HBO, Time Warner Cable and the WB Network.

fields.headline: T-Online posts £79m loss
fields.trailText: 11.15am: T-Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, is counting the cost of expansion, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
T-Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, is counting the cost of expanding beyond its German customer base.

The Deutsche Telekom-owned company has reached out to France, Spain and Portugal, but the start-up costs have contributed to heavy losses.

Germany and Austria provide 6.7m of T-Online's 7.9m users, leaving its expansion plans behind those of Italian rival Tiscali and Terra Lycos of Spain.

T-Online has started the fightback by snapping up Lagardere in France and Yacom in Spain, but the acquisitions pushed it into a pre-tax loss of £79m for last year, against a profit of £11.2m for 1999.

It also took a hit from the introduction of flat-rate access fees, which have slashed its revenues from internet access.

However, despite the damage to a key source of income, T-Online said group turnover rose 86% to £507m, with advertising and e-commerce revenue leaping by a mammoth 600%.

"The numbers are stronger than expected, and subscriber and advertising growth was ahead of our expectations," said Bob Kommers, internet analyst at ABN Amro.

"But there are still doubts about T-Online's management and the margin pressure on its access revenues will continue."

The European ISP sector has undergone a wave of consolidation over the past two months, with Wanadoo of France snapping up Freeserve for £1.65bn, and Tiscali pouncing on World Online and Liberty Surf.

Conspicuously, T-Online was left on the sector sidelines for much of last year after senior management upheavals paralysed the company.

"T-Online is moving very slowly, and does not have the management to move into Europe. It is mainly a German business," said Mr Kommers.

The T-Online boardroom cull, which claimed three victims including chief executive Wolfgang Keuntje, stemmed from a dispute with Deutsche Telekom about T-Online's international expansion plans.

Ron Sommer, the head of Deutsche Telekom, is still seen as the real power behind the company.

Mitsubishi has dropped Roose & Partners as its UK agency.

Fifa has appointed Michael Black to its top marketing job.

webTitle: Dillon to make directing debut with Banyan Trees

fields.headline: Dillon to make directing debut with Banyan Trees
fields.trailText: The cult star of Rumble Fish and Drugstore Cowboy is to direct and star in Beneath the Banyan Trees, a con man caper which he also co-wrote
fields.body:
Matt Dillon will juggle directing and acting roles in Beneath the Banyan Trees, a con man caper in which the actor will co-star alongside James Caan. Although Dillon directed an episode of the TV series Oz in 1999, the film will mark the actor's debut behind the camera on a feature film.

Dillon also co-wrote the script with pulp novelist Barry Gifford, the man responsible for the wild antics of both Wild at Heart and Lost Highway. Having been stalled in pre-production for nearly a year, the picture (which was originally titled City of Ghosts) has now received the green light to start shooting.

Dillon, now 36, became a youth icon in the 80s with roles in Francis Coppola's The Outsiders and Rumble Fish and an acclaimed turn in Gus Van Sant's Drugstore Cowboy. After fading out of fashion during the 90s, he turned an ailing career around with roles in the steamy noir thriller Wild Things and the Farrelly brothers' hugely popular There's Something About Mary.

Production on Beneath the Banyan Trees, which tells the tale of an insurance scammer (Dillon) on the trail of his duplicitous former partner (Caan) in the jungles of Cambodia, begins early next month.

fields.headline: Blackouts dim fairylights in Tinseltown
fields.standfirst: As most Californians brace themselves for more power cuts, some appear not to be pulling their weight at all. Duncan Campbell reports
fields.trailText: 24 January: Duncan Campbell reports on the social and political split emerging from the rolling blackouts afflicting California.
fields.body:
"On sunny days, open drapes on windows facing south and let the sun shine in. At night, close the drapes to retain indoor heat." So runs the advice being issued to Californians in the wake of the energy crisis which has led to "rolling blackouts" - the new phrase of the moment that has replaced "pregnant chads" in the news media's vocabulary. Put rather more simply, the advice is - draw your curtains in the morning and draw them shut at night.

The advice comes from Pacific Gas and Electric, one of the utility companies whose threatened bankruptcy in the wake of a failed deregulation experiment has helped to prompt the current crisis. After the first power failures last week, more are promised and so far it seems that the light at the end of the tunnel may only be a guttering candle.

So perhaps it is appropriate that the trailer for the new film about Pearl Harbour should be reminding audiences all over the state of the importance of the old wartime spirit. The lights are going out all over California and what needs to be engendered is, if not a bulldog spirit, at least a sort of beagle spirit which will help people tackle the hardships that await.

One major hardship that will have to be addressed is hinted it in the second piece of advice given so generously by PG & E: "wash only full loads in a dishwasher. If operating instructions allow, turn dishwasher off before the drying cycle and let dishes dry naturally." One way not to use so much power would, of course, be to wash the dishes by hand but clearly we have not quite reached such dire straits yet.

While all these blackouts are taken quite seriously in the Bay Area, the only signs that people in Los Angeles were heeding the warnings seemed to be that some of the fairylights that drape the palm trees in different parts of the city may have to be dimmed.

In northern California, they fume at this sort of extravagance. They recall that during the last water shortage, while northern Californians were conserving water in the best way they knew - "if it's yellow, that's mellow; if it's brown, flush it down" - the same could not be said of the southlands. There was outrage that in Bel Air in LA municipal workers had a high speed water jet using about 80 gallons to the second to get bubble gum off the sidewalks.

But there is a political dimension to all this. Even an impartial observer would have admitted that George Bush (house style now means that the W has gone to the alphabet in the sky) was smirking when the issue came up last week: he suggested that maybe all those environmental restrictions on the production of power might have to be relaxed. And Governor Gray Davis, whose political future as a possible presidential candidate may hang on this, knows that he needs to fix it and soon.

In the meantime, the best advice is the oldest: just direct your feet to the sunny side of the street.

fields.headline: ASA takes Red Bull by the horns
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The ASA has censured the makers of energy drink Red Bull over its advertising claims, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Advertising Standards Authority has censured the makers of the hugely successful energy drink Red Bull over claims that it can improve endurance and concentration.

The decision, which comes less than a week after the makers of Ribena Toothkind were told they could no longer claim that the product does not cause tooth decay, will reignite the row over food and drink makers claiming health benefits for their products.

Red Bull has been a runaway success in pubs and clubs in the UK because of its purported energy-giving qualities.

Last year more than 265m cans of the best-selling drink were sold in the UK.

Its manufacturers claim Red Bull's ingredients, which include sugar, caffeine and the amino acid taurine from which it derives its name, help to improve concentration and endurance.

But the ASA ruled that the Red Bull Company did not have enough evidence to back up the claims, which appeared in a 1997 press ad for the drink. It noted that a can of Red Bull contained only about as much caffeine as a cup of coffee.

The company will now have to consult the ASA's copy advice team before making any similar claims in future ads.

The ASA also upheld a complaint against a company that claimed to sell "natural Viagra". The manufacturers of Natura-Viga, an obvious play on the Viagra brand name, claimed in its advertising that it was "the safe natural alternative".

The ad claimed that "extensive national trials established that Natura-Viga really did have the power to enhance sexual potency".

It also featured testimonials from supposedly satisfied customers including a Mr G.C.R. of Hull, who claimed: "My wife is 23 years younger than me and I can keep her happy!"

The ASA said it had received nothing from Good Health International, the company that manufactures Natura-Viga, to substantiate its claims or prove that the testimonials were genuine.

It told the advertiser to stop using the ad and to consult its copy advice team before advertising the product again.

webTitle: Buyers still wary at slow Sundance

fields.headline: Buyers still wary at slow Sundance
fields.trailText: This year's festival of the best of independent cinema has so far failed to excite the amount of interest among film buyers that has been generated in previous years
fields.body:
In the past 48 hours a thaw has finally set in at a hitherto frozen Sundance Film Festival as film buyers began reaching for their cheque books to buy up the products on offer. The organisers believe that there is still time to turn things around, but observers remain startled by the stagnant market at this year's event. In the first four days of the festival not a single film was picked up.

Signs of a change in fortunes started when Fox Searchlight stumped up a reported $2.5m (£1.7m) for the worldwide distribution rights to Jay Chandrasekhar's Super Troopers, a free-wheeling comedy about a team of wacky cops on the Vermont/Canada border.

Later, Lion's Gate Films paid $1m (£682,000) for the North American rights to Tom DiCillo's Double Whammy (pictured). The latest film from the Sundance stalwart (the man behind Living in Oblivion and The Real Blonde) stars Dennis Leary as a New York detective, injured in the line of duty, who finds his life straightened out by Elizabeth Hurley's sexy chiropractor.

But away from these success stories, matters look less healthy. Studio executives are reported to be disappointed by the films on offer this year and are unwilling to risk large sums purchasing films which they feel lack cross-over appeal. Certainly there does not appear to be any hot property along the lines of The Blair Witch Project, which was discovered at Sundance in 1999.

webTitle: G2: Francis Wheen on Auberon Waugh

fields.headline: Bron's last laugh
fields.standfirst: Francis Wheen on the loss of a genial and generous soul and the antics of our would-be spies
fields.trailText: On the loss of a genial and generous soul and the antics of our would-be spies.
fields.body:
This afternoon, trains permitting, I shall be in Somerset attending the funeral of a man who was vilified in this newspaper last week as "effete, drunken, snobbish, sneering, racist and sexist". Auberon Waugh would have been delighted to learn that even in death he could still get a rise out of po-faced liberals.

And he would have loved the letter published the following day: "My immediate reaction on hearing of Waugh's death was to punch the air and exclaim, 'Good riddance!'" The letter-writer congratulated Polly Toynbee for putting into words "exactly how I really felt about this vile man".

Blimey. You'd hardly guess that the subject of this hysterical denunciation was the editor of a small-circulation literary magazine, a minor novelist and a humorous journalist. If that's how Guardian readers and pundits react to the death of such a figure, what on earth will they do when General Pinochet pegs out?

The anti-Waugh broadsides are at least a useful antidote to some of the extravagant obituarising elsewhere, which portrayed the old boy as a towering genius and latter-day saint. But I still find them puzzling. In the introduction to his Private Eye diaries, undoubtedly his best work, Waugh warned that "the material is entirely jocular: it contains no serious allegations whatever and everything in it is untrue".

His diaries, like those of Charles Pooter or Adrian Mole, are a comic novel. Some find it funny; some don't. Humour, it should be unnecessary to point out, is in the beholder's eye. I know people who hate Fawlty Towers, which is regarded by many others as the most hilarious sitcom of all time. But even readers who find the Diary of a Nobody wholly unamusing don't call down curses on the corpses of George and Weedon Grossmith. Why break a gadfly upon a wheel?

Ah, says Toynbee, but Waugh was not a lone and harmless irritant. He belonged to a "coterie", a sinister conspiracy of irreverent troublemakers who "spit poison at anyone vulgar enough to want to improve anything". (There is a distant echo here of Waugh's own comment many years ago about Princess Anne, "whose poisonous spittle could stop a camel in its tracks at 20 paces and blind a press photographer for life at twice the distance".)

It is quite true that Waugh mistrusted most schemes of "improvement" proposed by smooth-talking politicians on the make. He had this in common, I'd guess, with the majority of the population. He mistrusted power in all its manifestations: McDonald's and the Murdoch empire were regular targets.

If Waugh was a racist, how does one explain his passionate crusade on behalf of the Biafrans? The correct position for a racist reactionary Englishman would have been to argue that it was none of our concern if one group of Africans wished to massacre another.

If he was a caricature sexist, why did his "coterie" at Literary Review consist largely of women, many of them leftwing, vegetarian feminists? Why was he one of the earliest champions of Angela Carter? And, if he really was a poisonous bigot, why did he enjoy the enduring friendship of Paul Foot and other lifelong leftwingers?

The answer to all these questions is that Waugh was a genial and generous soul. I first discovered this when, as a 17-year-old reader of his fiction reviews, I wrote to ask for help. Having been "educated" at a philistine school, I had read almost no books at all; yet I had somehow conned my way into university to study English literature.

Could he recommend a crash course in the basic texts? The reply came by return of post. "I don't for a moment believe that you are a 17-year-old schoolboy," he wrote, clearly suspecting a practical joke. "Nevertheless, just in case you are ..." There then followed several hand-written pages of detailed and extremely helpful suggestions.

A little later, at university, I had to write an essay on "the literary influences on Evelyn Waugh". After several drinks in the student union bar one night, I obtained Bron's number from directory enquiries and rang to ask what authors his father admired. Not at all cross at having his evening interrupted by an unknown student in a phone-box, he spoke at some length about Evelyn Waugh's love of Thomas Love Peacock and Ronald Firbank. I duly put it all in my essay, citing an "interview with Auberon Waugh" as the source (and was severely marked down by my tutor, who scribbled "this is mere journalism" in the margin).

Bron Waugh was no saint, but someone capable of such kindness to an importunate young stranger was no ogre either. The monstrous persona he created for himself in the Private Eye diaries was a fictional character, invented to entertain and provoke. Not everyone laughed; but the provocation clearly worked, at least on the more cloth-eared members of the audience. Little do they realise, as they yell their insults at his unheeding coffin, that the joke's on them.

Oddballs, deadbeats and MI6 recruits

When Auberon Waugh was kicked out of Oxford university, his father advised that there were only two possible careers for him: "You must become either a schoolmaster or a spy." But young Waugh's application to join British Intelligence was sabotaged by one of the people he had cited as a referee, who told MI6 that "I wouldn't even employ Auberon Waugh as my butler".

The only surprise is that the spooks didn't hire him forthwith. Their recruitment system has always been pretty eccentric, letting in scores of deadbeats and oddballs and outright fantasists - including Richard Tomlinson, who has been described by his acquaintance David Shayler as a consummate bullshit-artist.

In an extract from his book which has already been published, and can therefore be mentioned with impunity, Tomlinson describes MI6's training procedure. He and other apprentices were dropped in the centre of Portsmouth and given an hour in which to obtain the name, address and passport number of any member of the public.

Tomlinson did it by chatting up two young women in a pub and asking if they'd like to join his crew for a sailing trip to France the following weekend. They duly wrote down all their personal details: mission accomplished. Another trainee, "Spencer", failed to return to base, having got hopelessly drunk and forgotten about his assignment.

Thus do the James Bonds of tomorrow prove themselves. But of course there's more to it than that. Thanks to the rightwing historian Andrew Roberts, a contemporary of Tomlinson at Cambridge University, we know that applicants must also sit "a series of extremely testing exams".

As Roberts revealed a couple of years ago, "some were straightforward: my spirits rose when I was asked to place, in order of precedence, viscount, duke, marquess, earl and baron." Having sailed through this test, Roberts was summoned for an interview with the MI6 doctor, who got straight down to business: "Homosexual, are you?" When Roberts said no, the doctor apologised for being so personal. "We have to ask. Silly, really, as of course no one says yes. With Oxford it's drugs, with Cambridge it's boys."

What it is with Leicester or Nottingham we shall never know, since the procedures are clearly designed to weed out provincial oiks and favour bumptious chaps who can spot a marquess at a hundred paces.

According to Roberts, it is not the fault of MI6 that Tomlinson "went progressively pottier" after leaving university, succumbing to Walter Mitty fantasies and boasting of his escapades behind enemy lines in Bosnia. Yet Roberts admits that MI6 "never discovered Richard's drug-taking habits, his promiscuity or his late-night clubbing forays around London on his motorbike; they gave him an almost unprecedented fourth year of probation". If MI6 can't be blamed for failing to notice Tomlinson's antics, who can?

This, I imagine, is why the spooks have been so desperate to prevent Tomlinson from blabbing. His book is unlikely to tell "our enemies" anything they didn't know already - but by God it might frighten the British taxpayers who have to finance this absurd circus.

Could he recommend a crash course in the basic texts? The reply came by return of post. "I don't for a moment believe that you are a 17-year-old schoolboy," he wrote, clearly suspecting a practical joke. "Nevertheless, just in case you are ..." There then followed several hand-written pages of detailed and extremely helpful suggestions. A little later, at university, I had to write an essay on "the literary influences on Evelyn Waugh". After several drinks in the student union bar one night, I obtained Bron's number from directory enquiries and rang to ask what authors his father admired. Not at all cross at having his evening interrupted by an unknown student in a phone-box, he spoke at some length about Evelyn Waugh's love of Thomas Love Peacock and Ronald Firbank. I duly put it all in my essay, citing an "interview with Auberon Waugh" as the source (and was severely marked down by my tutor, who scribbled "this is mere journalism" in the margin). Bron Waugh was no saint, but someone capable of such kindness to an importunate young stranger was no ogre either. The monstrous persona he created for himself in the Private Eye diaries was a fictional character, invented to entertain and provoke. Not everyone laughed; but the provocation clearly worked, at least on the more cloth-eared members of the audience. Little do they realise, as they yell their insults at his unheeding coffin, that the joke's on them. Oddballs, deadbeats and MI6 recruits When Auberon Waugh was kicked out of Oxford university, his father advised that there were only two possible careers for him: "You must become either a schoolmaster or a spy." But young Waugh's application to join British Intelligence was sabotaged by one of the people he had cited as a referee, who told MI6 that "I wouldn't even employ Auberon Waugh as my butler". The only surprise is that the spooks didn't hire him forthwith. Their recruitment system has always been pretty eccentric, letting in scores of deadbeats and oddballs and outright fantasists - including Richard Tomlinson, who has been described by his acquaintance David Shayler as a consummate bullshit-artist. In an extract from his book which has already been published, and can therefore be mentioned with impunity, Tomlinson describes MI6's training procedure. He and other apprentices were dropped in the centre of Portsmouth and given an hour in which to obtain the name, address and passport number of any member of the public. Tomlinson did it by chatting up two young women in a pub and asking if they'd like to join his crew for a sailing trip to France the following weekend. They duly wrote down all their personal details: mission accomplished. Another trainee, "Spencer", failed to return to base, having got hopelessly drunk and forgotten about his assignment. Thus do the James Bonds of tomorrow prove themselves. But of course there's more to it than that. Thanks to the rightwing historian Andrew Roberts, a contemporary of Tomlinson at Cambridge University, we know that applicants must also sit "a series of extremely testing exams". As Roberts revealed a couple of years ago, "some were straightforward: my spirits rose when I was asked to place, in order of precedence, viscount, duke, marquess, earl and baron." Having sailed through this test, Roberts was summoned for an interview with the MI6 doctor, who got straight down to business: "Homosexual, are you?" When Roberts said no, the doctor apologised for being so personal. "We have to ask. Silly, really, as of course no one says yes. With Oxford it's drugs, with Cambridge it's boys." What it is with Leicester or Nottingham we shall never know, since the procedures are clearly designed to weed out provincial oiks and favour bumptious chaps who can spot a marquess at a hundred paces. According to Roberts, it is not the fault of MI6 that Tomlinson "went progressively pottier" after leaving university, succumbing to Walter Mitty fantasies and boasting of his escapades behind enemy lines in Bosnia. Yet Roberts admits that MI6 "never discovered Richard's drug-taking habits, his promiscuity or his late-night clubbing forays around London on his motorbike; they gave him an almost unprecedented fourth year of probation". If MI6 can't be blamed for failing to notice Tomlinson's antics, who can? This, I imagine, is why the spooks have been so desperate to prevent Tomlinson from blabbing. His book is unlikely to tell "our enemies" anything they didn't know already - but by God it might frighten the British taxpayers who have to finance this absurd circus.

fields.headline: Charity income on the decline
fields.trailText: Charity income has fallen in real terms for the first time in 20 years, according to an unpublished report. Nicola Hill reports
fields.body:
Charity income has fallen in real terms for the first time in 20 years, according to an unpublished report.

The largest decline comes from state funding sources, which fell by £87m or 6.7% in real terms.

Research by the Charities Aid Foundation's (CAF) shows that the income of the top 500 charities has failed to keep up with inflation and has decreased in real terms of 1.7% in 1999 compared with a rise of 9% in the previous year.

Charity shops suffered competition from cut-price high street fashion stores and income dropped by 8.5% compared with an increase of 17% in the previous year.

Cathy Pharoah, head of research at CAF, said: "Voluntary sector income remains very vulnerable. Although there was progress in some areas, charity finances are held together with chewing gum."

She explained that income from statutory sources might be showing a decrease because the huge expansion in contracting out of government services had levelled out.

Ms Pharoah added: "Some of the new streams of statutory income such as SureStart, and the New Opportunities Fund might not be showing yet in charity accounts or it may be going to smaller charities."

CAF conducted the research by looking at figures from the top 500 charity annual reports. Ms Pharoah said: "Existing methods used by charities for collecting statistics on income from various sources make it difficult to track income."

The new standards of recommended practice (SORP) introduced for this financial year should make charity accounts more transparent. Despite recent criticism of charities such as NSPCC, spending on management and administration remained consistent at around 4% and fundraising and publicity costs rose by 1% in real terms, and now averages 9.3%.

On a positive note, income from gift aid rose by 29.5%. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, introduced incentives for tax-efficient giving in April 2000 so this figures signals hope for the future of charity income.

Ms Pharoah said: "The changes in the 2000 budget, potentially making all donations tax effective, could see extra revenue of between £200-£400m per annum over the next few years. This would represent an extra 4-8% rise in voluntary income and help fill the gap left by the decline in income from public sources."

Legacy income also showed growth with an average real terms rise of 10% while income from rents and investments rose by 9.4%. Richard Radcliffe, director of legacy fundraising specialists Smee and Ford, cautioned against comparing legacy income over a one-year period.

"It could be a glitch and be accounted for by the £59m left by publisher Christina Foyle. It is better to monitor legacy income over four to five years." However, he noted that there has been more legacy fundraising activity among charities in the last few years.

The top eight charities in CAF's table of top 500 fundraising charities by voluntary income remained in the same polling position between 1998 and 1999, with Oxfam attracting the most voluntary income of £169,716,000. The National Trust and Imperial Cancer Research Fund took second and third place. Aids, youth, mental health and hearing impairment charities continued to be the least supported causes.

fields.headline: BAT lures young smokers with 'devious' online scheme
fields.standfirst: Read the leaked memo
fields.trailText:
8.30am: British American Tobacco is plotting an internet campaign to drive consumers to bars where it promotes its cigarettes. By Daniel Rogers.
Read the leaked memo
fields.body:
British American Tobacco is plotting an extraordinary internet campaign to drive unwitting young consumers to bars and clubs where it promotes its cigarettes.

The worldwide initiative has been uncovered by MediaGuardian.co.uk and has been branded as "devious" and "sleazy" by the anti-smoking lobby.

According to a leaked internal memo, the tobacco giant is looking to invest £2.5m in building a new website - codenamed project Horeca - hotels, restaurants and cafes - aimed at young people world-wide.

It will be seen as a backdoor attempt by the British company to promote its "premium brands" Lucky Strike and State Express 555 to young urban smokers at a time when many countries are clamping down on tobacco advertising.

A BAT spokesman admitted that a prototype site branded City Gorilla has gone live in Poland this week. Venues promoting and selling BAT cigarettes are given a prominent position on the site.

In a plain attempt at disguising its motives, the site will not be linked to BAT or tobacco and will appear to offer independent advice on night life.

BAT is, in fact, planning to strike favourable distribution or promotional deals with outlets in return for giving them publicity on the site.

The memo, however, shows that BAT bosses are making a concerted effort to conceal their intentions to promote cigarettes in apparently "neutral" venues.

The memo states: "One perceived risk for the Horeca portal is the possible association with BAT and thus tobacco. A key success factor is developing a customer perception that the site is trendy and 'happening' Any adverse news articles from trade or consumer press may prove damaging."

"It's disgusting that BAT is trying to position itself as an arbiter of taste and cool when in fact this is a devious marketing scam. It's sleazy and dishonest commercialism posing as style." said Clive Bates, director of anti-smoking group Ash.

The BAT spokesman denied that the iniative was underhand.

"This site is not a tobacco marketing tool. We are not selling anything on it and we wouldn't because there's no guarantee the audience would be over 18," he said.

"It's also not there to persuade people to smoke. The cigarettes will be in the venues anyway and if you're going as a smoker you may smoke our brands if you like."

Promotion at the point of sale is one of brighter opportunities for tobacco marketers as many governments are becoming increasingly determined to ban cigarette advertising altogether.

Once young people are directed to bars, clubs or restaurants they can be encouraged to buy BAT cigarettes through prominent cigarette machines, "cigarette girls" and other branded techniques.

The site will also be used to collect the personal details of smokers. The data could then be used for the direct marketing of cigarettes.

This technique is known as "permission marketing" and represents another potential loophole in anti-tobacco marketing legislation.

Tobacco manufacturers argue that it is a breach of human rights to deny people the right to buy a legal product if they have given their personal permission.

BAT's project is clearly ambitious. The memo states that the aim is to attract 600,000 unique users by the end of 2001 and to achieve a top 50 rating as a Wap/mobile content provider within 12 months.

BAT believes it can build a database of 40,000 smokers by the end of year one.

fields.headline: Eurosport beats Sky Sports to US Open tennis rights
fields.trailText: 10am: Sky Sports has lost the rights to the US Open tennis tournament to Eurosport, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Sky Sports today admitted that it has lost the rights to the US Open tennis tournament. It also revealed that the rights had been won by Eurosport.

Eurosport refused to confirm that it has won the rights, claiming that the deal had yet to be inked.

But a Sky Sports spokeswoman confirmed that the rights had been lost.

Rights holder SFX is believed to have opted for Eurosport over Sky because it has carriage in Germany.

The loss of the rights to the tournament - one of the four biggest international tennis competitions - is likely to be a blow to Sky in terms of loss of sponsorship and prestige.

fields.headline: Europe debates digital content over the web
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The European Parliament meets today to thrash out a directive for distributing digital content over the internet, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The European Parliament legal affairs committee meets today to thrash out a directive for distributing digital content over the internet.

Armies of lobbyists from music companies, film companies, publishers, consumer electronics companies and broadcasters have descended on Brussels, hoping that their suggestions will be taken into account.

The objective of the Copyright Directive is to protect the activity of artists in Europe. The man charged with seeing the directive through, Enrico Boselli, has already received an avalanche of 300 suggestions.

Mr Boselli has gone on record insisting that he wants to limit any changes to the draft directive to an absolute minimum and not be stonewalled into making fundamental chances to the various stances adapted by European governments last year.

The timetable for pushing the directive through the European Parliament is tight with parliament scheduled to vote on it in mid-February.

Should the parliament stick to this deadline, European governments would rubberstamp it and ratify it at national levels in the coming months. A delay could delay implementation of the directive, which has already been three years in the making, a further three-to-four months.

The essence of the Copyright Directive is to protect rights-holders as their businesses move into the digital age, a contentious issue given the furore caused by the likes of Napster.

For the first time, it will set out the rights of European businesses involved in creating, producing, selling or broadcasting a copyright in a new digital environment.

webTitle: Baby taken to Paris for single jab

fields.headline: Baby taken to Paris for single jab
fields.standfirst: Family anger GP refused to give girl single measles vaccination
fields.trailText: A British family told last night how they took their baby girl to Paris to receive a single dose measles vaccine because they were so concerned about links between MMR and autism and Crohn's Disease.
fields.body:
A British family told last night how they took their baby girl to Paris to receive a single dose measles vaccine because they were so concerned about links between MMR and autism and Crohn's Disease.

Grandmother Tina Brightwell, 42, from Corringham, Essex, said she took granddaughter Tanith, now 3, overseas because their local GP refused to acknowledge that there were health concerns about MMR. The GP accused the family of listening to scaremongers.

After repeated arguments with their GP, Mrs Brightwell and Tanith's mother, Nina, 23, took the Eurostar and sought treatment at the Hertford hospital, near Paris. Doctors there expressed surprise that British parents were not given the choice of a single vaccine.

Charging £18, the French doctors treated Tanith, then 18 months old, with a single measles vaccine in September 1998 which the Brightwells bought over the counter at a nearby pharmacist with a prescription. Tanith later received a mumps vaccine in December 1999 as parents must wait a year after the first single injection is given. The vaccine safety campaign JABS found them a British doctor who would give the single dose on a private basis. Tanith is now awaiting the rubella jab.

Although the mumps vaccine cost £100 including a consultation, Mrs Brightwell said she was unwilling to consider MMR because of the health risks.

Since the Paris visit, the Brightwells have been inundated with calls from other parents wanting details of the French hospital.

Mrs Brightwell said: "We asked our local GP for the single measles vaccine but she said it wasn't available.

"Because of the concerns about MMR we spent six months looking for an alternative. We eventually heard about a British hospital in Paris that would do the single vaccine. By this time she was overdue so we were getting concerned.

webTitle: New bodies win access to key data in first test of strength

fields.headline: Open to observation
fields.standfirst: New bodies win access to key data in first test of strength
fields.trailText: New bodies win access to key data in first test of strength
fields.body:
The new network of "public health observatories", billed as an independent voice on health and inequality, has flexed its muscles for the first time and forced the release of official data.

The government-funded network, which operates in each of the eight NHS regions in England, was set up with ministerial approval last year. Observatories will provide the public with an accurate picture of the health and well-being of their area, flag up inequalities, provide early warning of potential problems and draw together information on new ways to improve health.

Alison Hill, who chairs the Association of Public Health Observatories and is director of the south-west observatory, has disclosed that the Office for National Statistics was refusing to hand over detailed birth and death data, citing commercial confidentiality. "This is a wonderful data set that is available to everyone in the NHS," she says. "It's a database of public health information that is not available to the general public because they [the ONS] told us that if they made it available, they would lose a lot of revenue. We went back to the chief medical officer to explain how we wanted to make this information freely available to the public. The CMO contacted them and asked them to release it. This is only information that has come from the public in the first place in terms of data about births and deaths. The public do have a right to this sort of information."

Hill guarantees that the data - which is anonymous for data protection purposes - will be available to the public. "It will be going on to our observatory websites and we are trying to think of other ways of dissemination. It's data at local authority level at the moment, but we want to get it down to electoral ward level because that is just the kind of thing people need to know."

There has been criticism that the observatories will duplicate the work of local health authorities, local government and universities. But advocates of the network counter that it is filling a gap created by the demise of the regional health authorities in 1994.

Mark Bellis, director of the north-west observatory, describes the network as a child of the information revolution. He believes that access to information will drive a 21st century public health revolution, just as sewer engineering drove the sanitation revolution of the 19th century. "It shouldn't be inferred that we are reinventing the wheel," he says. "There is an awful lot of information out there, but it's not exploited in the way that it should be at the moment."

Bellis is coordinator of a project to map the sexual health of teenagers across England. His observatory is attempting to plot levels of class A drug use and it is providing health information to private companies, local authorities, fire, police and the judiciary. "We can do health impact assessments for new firms if they want to build a new office or factory," he says. "We will help minimise pollution and disruption and tell them what they can and can't do. But we also want to maximise jobs and community benefits because, as we know, there are health gains from these sorts of things."

In London, meanwhile, observatory director Bobbie Jacobson aims to set up an ethnic minority health surveillance unit to end what she calls "the disgrace of ignorance" about progress on ethnic minority health issues across the capital.

fields.headline: Sun says sorry to Barnardo's
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Children's charity Barnardo's has forced the Sun to apologise for comments by Richard Littlejohn, writes David Brindle.
fields.body:
Barnardo's has struck a blow for all those in social care who feel that the media trivialise and distort their work.

In a settlement announced yesterday, the children's charity has forced the Sun to apologise for comments by Richard Littlejohn.

At Christmas, Mr Littlejohn - who presents himself as a scourge of political correctness - devoted part of his column to criticism of a Barnardo's education pack dealing with children abused through prostitution.

The pack has been endorsed by the Home Office, the departments of health and education and the Welsh Assembly.

Mr Littlejohn wrote that Barnardo's, "which sounds more like a wine bar than an orphanage", had distributed a pack aimed at children as young as 11 and featuring pimps, rent boys, incest, "smackheads" and prostitutes.

He also said that it included a video of a 14-year-old girl being beaten and sold for sex.

"Gary Glitter got sent down for less," Mr Littlejohn said. "Next time you're tempted to give money to Barnardo's, stop and think about how it is being spent. We were always under the impression that Dr Barnardo's existed to protect vulnerable children from sick perverts. Now, it seems, the perverts are on the payroll."

Under the settlement, the Sun has apologised for the remarks, met Barnardo's legal costs and given a donation of £5,000 to the charity. "What is most galling for us is that Mr Littlejohn's comments were made without reference to us and without him ever having seen the education pack he was writing about," said Roger Singleton, the charity's chief executive.

"We hope, in future, that he will give us the opportunity for comment."

fields.headline: IPC in talks with Perry over Loaded role
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Former acting Loaded editor John Perry is in talks with IPC about a future role at the magazine, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former acting Loaded editor John Perry is in talks with IPC management about a future role at the magazine, following the appointment of Keith Kendrick as new editor.

An IPC spokesman said that talks were continuing between Mr Perry and the managing director of IPC Music & Sport, Mike Soutar, to ensure that he stays on at the magazine.

IPC said that Mr Perry, who has edited the magazine since the departure of former editor Tim Southwell last year, had not tendered his resignation.

Mr Perry was "upset" that Mr Kendrick had been appointed as the new editor, but IPC bosses are keen to keep him on in a senior editorial role.

IPC has talked to a variety of candidates, including Mr Perry, Front editor Piers Hernu and Maxim editor-at-large Bill Borrows, about the position.

Jan 22: women's editor in with lads

fields.headline: RIM rejects fresh Newsquest bid
fields.trailText: Regional Independent Media, the newspaper group which owns the Yorkshire Post, has rejected a second approach by Newsquest. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Regional Independent Media, the newspaper group which owns the Yorkshire Post, has rejected a second approach by Newsquest, its rapidly growing competitor.

Newsquest is understood to have lodged an indicative bid with venture capital firm Candover, which owns a 50% share in RIM, shortly before Christmas. The intention is to carve up the business with a pre-arranged agreement to sell certain assets to Johnston Press and Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian newspaper.

The offer was rejected as too low earlier this month, and Candover reiterated its earlier objection, made last November, to dealing with a consortium bid.

RIM maintains that a flotation of the business is a strong likelihood. The volatility of markets and the imminent rise in newsprint costs, however, may pursuade Candover to make an early trade sale. Analysts have valued the business at around £550m.

Trade secretary Stephen Byers gave the go-ahead for bids from the trio after a mandatory three-month inquiry by the competition commission. The newspaper industry has tighter rules on ownership than others to ensure a diversity of views.

RIM is one of the few remaining independent regional newspaper publishers of any size. It was formed in February 1998 by the £360m management buyout of the regional newspaper interests of what was then United News & Media.

Candover is the largest investor in RIM. The other shareholders are Goldman Sachs and the Dutch venture capital group, Alpinvest. The group publishes 101 titles. The Yorkshire Post is one of the oldest in Britain, founded as the Leeds Intelligencer in 1754.

The regional industry is steadily consolidating and Newsquest, owned by American media group Gannett, is a leading player.

Gannett entered the UK market in 1999, when it paid £1.3bn for Newsquest. Last year it added Newscom for £444m. In the US, it publishes 74 dailies, including USA Today, and owns 22 TV stations.

fields.headline: Youth facing death after hospital injection blunder
fields.trailText: A teenager with leukaemia is in a coma facing almost certain death after doctors mistakenly injected a powerful anti-cancer drug into his spine instead of into a vein.
fields.body:
A teenager with leukaemia is in a coma facing almost certain death after doctors mistakenly injected a powerful anti-cancer drug into his spine instead of into a vein.

The blunder, which is the 14th case in Britain since 1985 - 10 of which were fatal - could lead to manslaughter charges for the doctors if the 19-year-old dies.

His parents are at his side at the Queen's medical centre, Nottingham, where the error happened. Two doctors have been suspended pending the outcome of a hospital inquiry.

The mistake usually happens because the drug, vincristine, which must only be injected into a vein, is administered with methotrexate, which goes into the spine. The packaging and data sheet for vincristine make it clear that the drug is fatal if injected into the spine.

The victims have been mainly young people and children suffering from leukaemia and other blood cancers. The few who have survived have been paralysed.

If the error is realised quickly doctors can try to "wash out" the drug, but in most cases its effects are fatal.

The teenager, who has not been named, was told what had happened before he slipped into unconsciousness a week after the injection was given on January 4.

Professor Gordon McVie, the director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said most patients have no chance of survival and die in "excruciating pain".

He added: "It is unspeakable that this should happen in this day and age. It is truly horrible. This drug should never be given by anyone other than a consultant. It should not have happened and there needs to be a major investigation into why it did."

Each time the error has occurred, the hospital concerned has overhauled procedures. But lessons have not been learned across the health service, and the same blunder has continued to occur, even in top teaching hospitals.

Where children or young adults die without dependants, any settlement is small, so the NHS has had no financial incentive to tighten up systems.

But a spokesman for the Department of Health said a new mandatory system was being set up for reporting adverse events and "near misses", including wrongly administered spinal injections.

"The aim is to ensure that no more patients die or are paralysed by maladministered spinal injections. New protective measures are due to be in place by the end of this year, he said."

A spokesman for Queen's medical centre apologised to the family, adding: "A full inquiry has been started to discover what went wrong."

webTitle: Call to involve mental health patients in service training

fields.headline: Voice of the people
fields.standfirst: Call to involve mental health patients in service training
fields.trailText: Call to involve mental health patients in service training
fields.body:
People with mental health problems should be formally involved in training all psychiatric and social care professionals, according to a report published yesterday by the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health and welcomed by the government.

The report, Users' Voices, is based on an exercise devised and carried out by recipients of mental health services who sought the views of more than 500 people, most of whom had severe long-term illness.

Diana Rose, who developed the research method and wrote the report, says it differs dramatically from other user surveys: "By employing users at the heart of research, you get different questions - about things that really matter to them. Almost all the interviewees were severely unwell on the top tier of the CPA [the care programme approach, or guidelines governing individuals' care] yet gave balanced, thoughtful and constructive views on improving services." Patient empowerment lies at the heart of the government's NHS plan, and was a priority in the 1990 NHS and Community Care Act, yet Users' Voices shows that many people still feel they are recipients of care rather than participants in the process.

About half of those interviewed for the report said they were not getting enough information about care and support services. Most did not understand the CPA, or even knew that it existed, despite the supposed involvement of users in devising their own care plan. More than half reported distressing side-effects of medication and a third said they felt over-medicated.

Rose, senior researcher at the Sainsbury Centre and herself a service user, has trained nurses, social workers and police. But she says that such involvement is fragmented and uncoordinated. "User groups persuade training managers at a local level, and then people like me get invited to speak. It's ad hoc, yet it's the only way staff ever find out what it's like to be on the receiving end of care, and what needs to change."

Cliff Prior, chief executive of the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, applauds the report and its methods. "In the world of retail, the customer is always right," he says. "In the health service, the cliche is often reversed, with the doctor in the top spot. Research undertaken by people with a mental illness gets to the heart of experiences with a sensitivity and degree of detail that other researchers usually miss."

The health department says it supports the idea of involving service users in training mental health staff, stating: "Clearly, users - who have much to contribute - are central to the provision of services and it is important to ensure they feel they have been listened to and treated as individuals."

 Users' Voices is available at £15 plus £1.50 p&p (£7.50 plus 75p for service users) from 020-7403 8790

webTitle: Row over US frontrunner for top nursing job

fields.headline: Row over US frontrunner for top nursing job
fields.trailText: A black American who led the biggest US nurses' association and served as an official in the Clinton administration has emerged as a surprise frontrunner in the race to head Britain's main nursing union.
fields.body:
A black American who led the biggest US nurses' association and served as an official in the Clinton administration has emerged as a surprise frontrunner in the race to head Britain's main nursing union.

Beverly Malone, who has been named one of the most influential African-Americans and has a formidable reputation in international nursing circles, is on a shortlist of four for the job of general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing.

Interviews for the £90,000-a-year post are taking place today and an appointment is due to be ratified this week by the college's ruling council. But the selection process has already triggered controversy.

Some activists within the college are furious that only four candidates are being interviewed and that other strong contenders, including the present assistant general secretary, have been excluded.

While her American credentials are of the highest calibre, however, many will question her grasp of British health care policy at a time of fundamental change under the government's NHS plan.

Appointment of the new general secretary has been delegated to a sub-group of the 25-strong council. It is this group which has decided not to interview all eight candidates identified by a recruitment consultancy as potential appointees.

fields.headline: Microsoft hires P&G agency for Xbox
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Microsoft has hired Procter & Gamble's PR agency to publicise the launch of its Xbox games console, writes Claire Cozens .
fields.body:
Microsoft has hired Procter & Gamble's PR agency for the publicity bonanza surrounding the launch of its Xbox games console across Europe.

The Xbox is expected to be one of the biggest ever consumer product launches, with Microsoft planning to spend almost £350m on marketing the console in Europe alone in a bid to topple Sony's Playstation from the number one slot.

And today it emerged the job of keeping the media up to date with the promotion has gone to Manning, Selvage & Lee in London.

The system will hit the streets more than a year after the arrival of Sony's Playstation 2 and the Sega Dreamcast on shop shelves.

It will be launched in the US in the autumn and in Europe early next year.

"The console is already generating an incredible amount of excitement with the public, and our job is really to work with Microsoft to develop long-term European communications strategies to harness that excitement, plus develop and implement the processes and procedures to make it all work efficiently," said Dave Bennett, who will head the account at MS&L.

MS&L, one of the UK's biggest PR agencies, will help develop the European PR strategy for the Xbox as well as working with local PR agencies such as The Red Consultancy, which has been appointed to handle consumer PR for the launch in the UK.

Microsoft is also planning a major advertising blitz to back up the European launch of the console and has reportedly appointed Bartle Bogle Hegarty to create the campaign.

webTitle: BBC1's balloon gives way to 'softer' image

fields.headline: BBC1's balloon gives way to 'softer' image
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: BBC1 is to ditch its "flying balloon" logo in favour of a "softer" image, five years after it spent £5m on the symbol.
fields.body:
BBC1 is to ditch its "flying balloon" logo in favour of a "softer" image, five years after it spent £5m on the symbol. The channel's controller, Lorraine Heggessey, said it was no longer relevant to the audience.

The marketing department has been told to rework the balloon identity, which flies over 30 British landmarks, including the Forth bridge and the Millennium Dome.

"To be honest, the balloon to me feels very slow; it goes across this majestic landscape but doesn't feel in touch with the viewers," Ms Heggessey, who took over at BBC1 in September, said yesterday.

Four weeks ago the BBC magazine Radio Times reported the balloon's popularity with viewers and invited comments on new locations for it.

The red and yellow hot air balloon was introduced in October 1997, incorporating the globe image that the BBC has used in various forms since 1963.

Ms Heggessey said yesterday she wanted to transform the "feel and tone" of BBC1. "I hate the word Auntie. Auntie suggests someone who is at least a generation older than you, a little remote, not part of your immediate family. BBC1 is starting to suffer from that image.

"The broad strategy is as much about tone and style as it is about content - to feel warmer, more modern. Now we need to emphasise the softer approach."

She said BBC1 was "not going to go all pink and fluffy".

webTitle: Murdoch aims to switch off ITN

fields.headline: Murdoch aims to switch off ITN
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB yesterday announced the formation of a powerful consortium of companies to oust ITN from the £200m contract to supply news to ITV.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB yesterday announced the formation of a powerful consortium of companies to oust ITN from the £200m contract to supply news to ITV.

The alliance includes US network CBS, financial news group Bloomberg, Chrysalis and Ulster TV - each of which will have a 20% stake in the company making the bid for the next contract.

The consortium has already fired its first salvo in a letter to the ITV Network outlining its plans. It has also made an application to industry regulators for the necessary "nominated news provider" status providing certain guarantees on the quality and resources of the proposed service.

Mr Murdoch has long envied ITN's monopoly in the free to air commercial market. BSkyB made a bid to win the last ITV contract in 1996, and more recently failed to edge ITN out of the picture at both Channel 4 and Channel 5.

A spokesman for the consortium said it was "committed to developing a proposal for ITV based on the principles of high quality journalism."

Sky News, BSkyB's award-winning 24-hour news channel, has been running for the past 11 years. CBS is the home of legendary newsman Walter Cronkite, and produces shows including Sixty Minutes.

An ITN spokesman belittled the consortium and set the tone for what is likely to be a bitter contest. "Sky has been touting around for potential partners for months," he said. "After all their efforts, they've ended up with two tiny UK broadcasters and two cost cutting American players. It's a ragbag partnership crafted from desperation.

"It is ironic that this coalition should be announced on the day that ITN beat the BBC news by a margin of two to one in the battle of the 10pm bulletins. That's not great timing on Sky's part."

The ITV bulletin returned after an absence of nearly two years with 8.1m viewers on Monday night, while BBC1's Ten O'Clock News drew an audience of some 4.3m.

BSkyB and its partners in the consortium may find it difficult to break the long relationship between ITV and ITN, which stretches back to the network's launch in 1955. An extension of Mr Murdoch's influence in British media will also have its opponents.

The existing five year contract to supply news to ITV - worth about £40m a year to ITN - comes up for renewal at the end of 2002. Shareholders in ITN have recently been pressing for an early renewal of the contract.

The five shareholders in ITN, Carlton Communica tions, Granada Media, Reuters, United Business Media and Daily Mail & General Trust, had been keen to put a new contract in place ahead of a potential stock market flotation of the business. The ITV contract accounts for about 45% of ITN's revenues.

A spokeswoman for ITV said the network would take an impartial view of awarding the next contract.

 ITN and billboard advertising group Maiden Outdoor are combining to show news and advertising on five- by three-metre screens at rail stations.

webTitle: Irvine backs plan for TV in court

fields.headline: Irvine backs plan for TV in court
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, yesterday gave his backing to a proposal to allow TV cameras to cover high profile court cases such as the Augusto Pinochet extradition hearings or the battle over whether the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary should be separated.
fields.body:
Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, yesterday gave his backing to a proposal to allow TV cameras to cover high profile court cases such as the Augusto Pinochet extradition hearings or the battle over whether the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary should be separated.

He said televising such cases might have "a valuable educative effect" by giving the public a "better understanding about the nature of the judicial system".

Lord Irvine said he would await expressions of interest from TV companies and consult the judiciary about running closed pilot schemes. The cameras would be allowed to cover only "appellant" cases, judicial reviews or cases involving legal argument between lawyers and judges in which no witnesses or juries were required.

Janet Paraskeva, chief executive of the Law Society, welcomed the proposal as being in the public interest, as long as cases involving witnesses were not included.

Giving evidence to the home affairs select committee, Lord Irvine said: "If I was satisfied that there was a demand and that we could set up pilots, I would discuss it with the higher judiciary, and I would not set my face against it."

He expressed his "hostile" attitude to televised trials since the case of the British au pair Louise Woodward in the US.

"There is a great risk that the behaviour and judgment of lawyers, witnesses and indeed the jury itself might be affected by the knowledge that they were participating in a live media event," he told MPs.

He admitted that some judges might fear that limited coverage of appellate cases could be the thin end of the wedge, creating an appetite for the televising of trials.

Support for an experiment has also come from Lord Williams, the attorney general.

The Lord Chancellor's department said pilots would have to be authorised by the court, on terms defined by it, for the purpose of considering whether the public might be better informed about the proceedings. They would not be broadcast.

Lord Irvine told MPs that "fundamental" proposals for a shake-up of security in courts were being considered after a defendant attacked the Old Bailey judge Ann Goddard. He had ordered an urgent inquiry into how three guards had failed to restrain the assailant as he leapt from the dock.

fields.headline: ONdigital joins TV listings fray
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The intensely competitive television listings magazine market faces a threat from broadcaster ONdigital, which yesterday announced plans to launch a weekly title.
fields.body:
The intensely competitive television listings magazine market faces a threat from broadcaster ONdigital, which yesterday announced plans to launch a weekly title.

The magazine will be sent to ONdigital's customer base of more than 1m households and will carry full free to air channel listings.

It replaces a monthly magazine sent to ONdigital subscribers which featured only paid-for channels.

The title, ON7, will commence publication at the beginning of March.

The TV listings market is one of the most cutthroat in publishing. IPC Media was last year forced into a price war to maintain the lead of its title What's On TV, which has a circulation of 1.7m.

The Radio Times, published by BBC Worldwide, has sales of 1.3m, while TV Times, another IPC title, has sales of around 706,000.

ON7 will be available only to ONdigital customers and will not be on sale in shops. The first four issues will be delivered free of charge, after which subscribers will be asked to pay 39p per issue.

The inclusion of listings from the BBC and ITV channels could, however, bring additional pressure to bear on publishers such as IPC. BSkyB sends customers a monthly magazine without listings.

"We couldn't carry the free to air channels like BBC1 or ITV in our monthly guide," said Gabrielle Simcocks, ONdigital's director of relationship marketing.

"Going weekly will allow us to be bang up to date with those channels, as well as with all our own channels. Three million readers from day one is an enormous market."

The magazine will be produced by the contract publishing group, TPD. IPC, in which venture capital group Cinven is the biggest shareholder, took a £7m hit to its circulation sales last year as a result of the cover price war with TV listings title TV Choice, a rival launch by Bauer.

IPC cut the price of What's On TV from 50p to 35p for three months, but succeeded in defending the title's circulation, which outsells TV Choice by 950,000 copies a week.

fields.headline: Express Manchester office faces closure
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Fears are mounting that Express Newspapers is to close its Manchester office, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Fears are mounting that Express Newspapers is to close its Manchester office in the latest round of cost cutting.

Sources say Northern & Shell is to announce that the 11 advertising sales staff based in Manchester are to be made redundant this week.

Meanwhile, reliable sources have revealed that Express Newspapers has failed to keep up to date with its rent payments.

Advertising sales staff are believed to have opted for voluntary redundancy, but an insider said: "It was made clear that they were all to be made redundant anyway."

Journalists and photographers at the office are also thought to be facing redundancy.

Express reporters Paul Gallagher and Eugene Henderson and the Star's John Mahoney are all facing job cuts, as are Express photographer Stuart Mason and freelancer Tony Fisher, a former Star staff snapper who still works regularly for the paper in the north of England.

The landlord of the office where the Express rents space also confirmed that Express Newspapers owes rent on the property.

The news follows a spate of redundancies in the Express's London headquarters, where around 30 jobs were cut at the end of last year.

The 46 staff at Express Digital Media also lost their jobs recently after the sale of the websites to an investment company which promptly put the sites into liquidation.

Express Newspapers is facing legal action from staff who are suing for redundancy and unpaid wages. They have the backing of the National Union of Journalists.

Express insiders say staff are braced for editorial job cuts in the near future.

webTitle: And finally, it's back to win ratings battle

fields.headline: And finally, it's back to win ratings battle
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: ITV's revived News at Ten yesterday emerged as the clear winner in the clash of the main TV news bulletins, attracting almost twice as many viewers as its BBC rival and prompting a war of words.
fields.body:
ITV's revived News at Ten yesterday emerged as the clear winner in the clash of the main TV news bulletins, attracting almost twice as many viewers as its BBC rival and prompting a war of words.

Britain's two main terrestrial channels went head-to-head for the first time on Monday. But the celebrations at ITN were muted by the unexpected announcement that BSkyB has entered a joint bid with the US network, CBS, for its lucrative ITV news contract.

According to unofficial figures released yesterday, 8.1m watched Sir Trevor McDonald's return to the 10pm slot on ITV, while the BBC's Peter Sissons pulled in 4.3m.

Sir Trevor was delighted with the ratings. "It is fantastic," he said.

But his BBC rival attacked ITV's scheduling tactics: the commercial network screened News at Ten directly after the hit game show Who Wants to be a Millionaire? And in a trick often used by both channels, ITV allowed Millionaire to run on a few minutes after 10pm, ensuring that any viewers who were tempted to switch to the BBC during the closing credits would have missed the opening headlines.

Sissons said: "All they [the ratings] show is that if you overrun your blockbuster crowd-puller by two minutes and run straight into the news without an ad break you will get the ratings."

He said the BBC's success would be built on solid journalism rather than ratings-grabbing trickery.

ITV's return to 10pm after two years was forced by its regulator, the Independent Television Commission, after plunging ratings. News at Ten will appear three times a week. The BBC was adamant yesterday that it would not be forced into an early retreat to the 9pm slot, which was ditched last October.

Sissons said: "All they [the ratings] show is that if you overrun your blockbuster crowd-puller by two minutes and run straight into the news without an ad break you will get the ratings." He said the BBC's success would be built on solid journalism rather than ratings-grabbing trickery. ITV's return to 10pm after two years was forced by its regulator, the Independent Television Commission, after plunging ratings. News at Ten will appear three times a week. The BBC was adamant yesterday that it would not be forced into an early retreat to the 9pm slot, which was ditched last October. Special report on the battle of the bulletins

webTitle: Advertising watchdog snaps at heels of Red Bull

fields.headline: Advertising watchdog snaps at heels of Red Bull
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It was the popular fizzy drink that promised to give you wings but now a whole host of other claims about its energy-boosting properties have been exposed as a load of Red Bull.
fields.body:
It was the popular fizzy drink that promised to give you wings but now a whole host of other claims about its energy-boosting properties have been exposed as a load of Red Bull.

The Advertising Standards Authority's 3-year inquiry into Red Bull was prompted by a rash of complaints in the spring of 1997 by customers disappointed in the manufacturer's claims that it could improve concentration, reaction time and endurance.

Independent research commissioned by the ASA found these claims to be untrue.

Red Bull, in its defence, sent the ASA lists of ingredients and the results of 20 studies into the effects of its main component, caffeine.

A spokesman for the ASA said a can of Red Bull had as much caffeine as a cup of coffee and that experts were divided over its effects.

The report said: "The advertisers had not proved that Red Bull would improve the concentration and reaction time of the vast majority of readers, irrespective of circumstances."

The same went for the company's claim of improving endurance which "had not been substantiated" by Red Bull's back-up "evidence".

The company now has to have any future claims checked by a copy advice team first.

fields.headline: Hospital machinery 'tampered with'
fields.trailText: A police inquiry into deaths at two of Britain's biggest hospitals has found that criminal damage to medical machinery may have killed a three-year-old girl and a nursery nurse.
fields.body:
A police inquiry into deaths at two of Britain's biggest hospitals has found that criminal damage to medical machinery may have killed a three-year-old girl and a nursery nurse.

Files on the two cases at Leeds general infirmary and the city's St James's hospital have been sent to the crown prosecution service.

Detective Chief Superintendent Brian Taylor, who headed the 15 month investigation, said that his team had not reached a position to press for charges against individuals. But he added: "We can find no explanation for the damage to machines in the two cases other than it was of a criminal nature."

The child victim was Nazeesh Farooq Khan of Great Horton, Bradford, who died three years ago after admission to the cancer ward at St James's. Her body was exhumed in November 1999 after re-examination of blood tests revealed surprisingly high levels of a number of chemicals.

The other case involved Katherine Hallas, 22, of West Park, Leeds, who died at the infirmary in April 1999 during a routine wisdom tooth extraction.

The investigation ruled out suspicious circumstances in 51 other incidents, including three other deaths, at the two hospitals where equipment malfunctioned unexpectedly. Mr Taylor said that no evidence had been found to back initial fears that a "serial tamperer" had been at work.
