webTitle: Manchester to take over two other regional airports

fields.headline: Manchester to take over two other regional airports
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Manchester is preparing to challenge the might of BAA, the largest airports operator, by taking over East Midlands and Bournemouth - and setting its sights on other airports.
fields.body:
Manchester is preparing to challenge the might of BAA, the largest airports operator, by taking over East Midlands and Bournemouth - and setting its sights on other airports.

The deal, which has been cleared by the environment and transport secretary, John Prescott, will help propel the airport into the big league of transport operators while making it one of the country's largest public businesses - it is owned by the 10 local authorities in the Greater Manchester area.

Encouraged by the deputy prime minister, the airport is also talking to the shadow strategic rail authority about improving rail links for its three terminals. Manchester's bid for the East Midlands and Bournemouth airports, which were put on sale last year by the National Express group, will further break the dominance of BAA, the former state-owned British Airports Authority, which operates Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted.

With concern at overcrowding in the south-east and the further expansion of the three London airports, Manchester could offer facilities, such as remote check-in from the home or at railway stations and other locations, to eliminate queuing and tempt people away from BAA.

The East Midlands airport at Castle Donington, between Leicester, Nottingham and Derby near the M1, will be de veloped as a rival to Birmingham's international airport, which has little room to expand.

Castle Donington is vying with Stansted as the country's largest freight airport, and has an £80m programme that will see the runway extended by almost a quarter. Bournemouth, too, is planning a new terminal.

Manchester's expansion plans, which will see a second runway open next month, were helped yesterday when MPs strongly criticised the dominance of London's airports.

Paul Coggins, Labour MP for Wythenshawe and Sale East, asked the Commons: "If Milan and Frankfurt, which are regional capitals, can also have international hub airports, then why not Manchester?"

fields.headline: Bubble burst on champagne scam
fields.trailText: Three champagne charlatans amassed a £2m fortune by convincing thousands of unsuspecting investors that the world's partygoers would run out of "fizz" during the millennium celebrations, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Three champagne charlatans amassed a £2m fortune by convincing thousands of unsuspecting investors that the world's partygoers would run out of "fizz" during the millennium celebrations, a court heard yesterday.

Potential investors were told they could make a killing if they bought top quality champagne, stored it in government bonded warehouses and then sold to the highest bidders at either Sotheby's or Christies just before the "biggest party" the planet had ever thrown.

Operating under the name House of Delacroix, the men duped customers into handing over large sums with carefully crafted "tosh", Southwark crown court was told.

More than 1,000 people were hoodwinked and the product turned out to be second rate and worth a fraction of the price they paid. There were no bespoke auctions and fears of a shortage proved unfounded, the court heard.

Jonathan Fisher, prosecuting, said that once the company's outlay of £450,000 had been taken into account, the three were left with a gross profit of about £2.1m.

Craig Dean of Redditch, Worcester, 35, denies one count of conspiracy to defraud between 1995 and 1998. Lee Rosser, 31, of Bournemouth, Dorset, and Julian Blee, 32, of Luton, Bedfordshire, had earlier pleaded guilty.

Mr Fisher said the men met while working for a whisky investment operation in Gibraltar during the early 1990s.

The trial continues today.

webTitle: Dangerous prisoners to be moved to new, more liberal unit

fields.headline: Dangerous prisoners to be moved to new, more liberal unit
fields.standfirst:
Special report: policing crime
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: A more liberal special unit at Wakefield prison is to be opened to hold some of the most dangerous men in Britain's prisons, after "serious flaws" were discovered in the three-year-old experimental control unit at Woodhill prison, near Milton Keynes.
fields.body:
A more liberal special unit at Wakefield prison is to be opened to hold some of the most dangerous men in Britain's prisons, after "serious flaws" were discovered in the three-year-old experimental control unit at Woodhill prison, near Milton Keynes.

The prison service announced yesterday that the "exceptional risk regime" at Wakefield, West Yorkshire, is to be opened at a cost of £500,000. It will hold such men as Charles Bronson, the notorious armed robber and hostage taker, and Robert Maudsley, nicknamed Hannibal the Cannibal for the way he murdered three fellow inmates.

An academic evaluation published yesterday of the segregation unit in Woodhill's D wing, which held up to 48 of the most dangerous and disruptive inmates, concluded that it was seriously flawed. Its system, under which prisoners had to earn incentives, often made them rebel violently against its basic principles.

"The sparseness of the regimes at Woodhill in many cases added to the prisoner's hostility," it said. The protests led to abuse of and assaults on staff and allegations of brutality against prison officers.

The chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, condemned the regime's isolation of inmates for long periods as a risk to their mental health, and questioned its legality.

Inmates at the "close supervision centre" were in their cells for up to 23 hours a day, and when they were let out they were accompanied by five prison officers in full riot gear.

The regime at Wakefield will allow prisoners televisions and computers in their cells, and they will be able to receive visits and telephone calls and have exercise daily.

The director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, said the new facility was "a long term containment of a small number of prisoners who are too dangerous or disruptive to progress, or are not capable of progressing.

"I do not expect prisoners to die there," he said. "I would expect them to move on when their dangerousness has reduced - but that would take a long time."

The Woodhill unit was opened after a decision by the previous home secretary, Michael Howard, to close the therapeutic wing of Parkhurst prison on the Isle of Wight after a breakout by four high security inmates.

The remainder of the inmates in Woodhill's unit will be distributed to a close supervision centre elsewhere in the prison and to one at Durham jail.

The director of high security prisons, Peter Atherton, said: "The prison service recognises that these segregation conditions are now quite inappropriate. We should be seeking to develop a unit which, within the restrictions that we have to maintain, is humane and meets the needs that they have.

"Normally prison officers would not wear riot gear to remove prisoners from their cells in the new unit at Wakefield."

webTitle: Bitter agent Richard Tomlinson on the run

fields.headline: Bitter agent on the run
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Richard Tomlinson has been evading the clutches of MI6 since he jumped parole in 1998 after serving six months for breaking the Official Secrets Act. He was prosecuted for sending a synopsis of his book to an Australian publisher.
fields.body:
Richard Tomlinson has been evading the clutches of MI6 since he jumped parole in 1998 after serving six months for breaking the Official Secrets Act. He was prosecuted for sending a synopsis of his book to an Australian publisher.

The previous year, MI6 gave him £25,000 and a job with the motor racing team owned by former racing driver Jackie Stewart. He says now he was unimpressed with the offer, which he was made to sign "under duress" when on the run in Spain.

He blames his sacking on an MI6 personnel officer who he calls "Poison Dwarf". His bitterness may not have been helped bythe fact that his girlfriend had died of cancer.

When he was sacked, he insisted on taking his case to an industrial tribunal. MI6 personnel officers laughed at the suggestion. Since then, the security and intelligence agencies have reluctantly agreed their officers can take grievances to a tribunal so long as genuine secrets are protected.

Paranoid

After first flying to Paris in 1998, Tomlinson moved to Switzerland, where he was friendly with local police until he was accused of putting details about MI6, including names of officers, on the internet. He moved to Germany where, he says, he was offered money to give details of alleged MI6 operations in that country. With MI6 lawyers chasing him, he went to Italy and worked in a bar in Rimini.

Tomlinson became a nervous wreck and even paranoid.Yesterday he said: "I have been hounded and hounded. They had me put under surveillance by an incompetent Italian detective agency. They told my neighbours in Rimini that I was a convicted paedophile. That made me determined to publish the book.

"They can come and arrest me if they like or just leave me alone."

webTitle: Row over US frontrunner for top nursing job

fields.headline: Row over US frontrunner for top nursing job
fields.trailText: A black American who led the biggest US nurses' association and served as an official in the Clinton administration has emerged as a surprise frontrunner in the race to head Britain's main nursing union.
fields.body:
A black American who led the biggest US nurses' association and served as an official in the Clinton administration has emerged as a surprise frontrunner in the race to head Britain's main nursing union.

Beverly Malone, who has been named one of the most influential African-Americans and has a formidable reputation in international nursing circles, is on a shortlist of four for the job of general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing.

Interviews for the £90,000-a-year post are taking place today and an appointment is due to be ratified this week by the college's ruling council. But the selection process has already triggered controversy.

Some activists within the college are furious that only four candidates are being interviewed and that other strong contenders, including the present assistant general secretary, have been excluded.

Ms Malone, who is in her early 50s, is seen as having been invited to apply for the post. She was president of the American Nurses' Association from 1996 until January last year, when she was recruited as deputy assistant secretary at the US health department, advising on policy and programme development.

While her American credentials are of the highest calibre, however, many will question her grasp of British health care policy at a time of fundamental change under the government's NHS plan.

The vacancy for RCN general secretary - the face of nursing - has been caused by the decision of Christine Hancock, who has held the post for more than 10 years, to quit to devote her time to the presidency of the International Council of Nurses.

The college has flourished under Ms Hancock and her predecessor, the late Trevor Clay. Its membership has risen to 325,000 and it recently took a hotly contested, but key, decision to extend associate membership to health care assistants, ensuring further growth.

In 1995, the college voted to scrap its no-strike rule - a move which has added enormously to its muscle without, as yet, being acted upon.

Appointment of the new general secretary has been delegated to a sub-group of the 25-strong council. It is this group which has decided not to interview all eight candidates identified by a recruitment consultancy as potential appointees.

The group initially chose five candidates for interview: Ms Malone; Pippa Bagnall, a nursing consultant and former director of the Queen's Nursing Institute, which promotes community nursing; Mel Chevannes, professor and head of the school of nursing and midwifery at De Montfort University, Leicester, and chair of the Royal Wolverhampton Hospitals NHS trust; Alison Kitson, director of the RCN Institute, the college's practice and research arm; and Ron de Witt, a nurse and chief executive of King's Healthcare trust in south London.

Mr de Witt is understood to have since withdrawn, leaving an all-women shortlist of four.

Left off the shortlist were Tom Bolger, RCN assistant general secretary who is Ms Hancock's deputy; Pippa Gough, head of the college's policy unit; and Jane Salvage, nursing director of media group Emap Healthcare.

The exclusions of Mr Bolger and Ms Salvage are causing most unrest among activists. Mr Bolger is highly popular with grassroots members and there are accusations that his past health problems - he is about to undergo a heart operation - are being used as an excuse to sideline him.

Ms Salvage is a graduate nurse who has written widely on nursing and has an international reputation. She has, however, been outspokenly critical of aspects of the RCN under Ms Hancock and has backed those calling for change and, in particular, more openness.

Of the four remaining candidates, Ms Malone and Ms Kitson are regarded as frontrunners, followed by Prof Chevannes, who like Ms Malone is black, and Ms Bagnall.

If the appointing sub-group makes a selection today, there may be dissent at the RCN council meeting in Belfast on Friday and Saturday. However, it is unclear whether any council members opposed to the choice would be able to seek to block ratification.

Ms Hancock, 57, is due to take up her international role in June. She will hold the world presidency for four years.

webTitle: 'Extinct' bat is found - only to die of cold

fields.headline: 'Extinct' bat is found - only to die of cold
fields.trailText: It was every animal loving family's dream. Hanging on a wall in their back garden one winter morning was a bat in need of help.
fields.body:
It was every animal loving family's dream. Hanging on a wall in their back garden one winter morning was a bat in need of help.

Experts pronounced the emaciated creature a surviving member of a species declared extinct in Britain 10 years ago.

But the joy of discovery for the 13-year-old boy who spotted the female mouse-eared bat at an unspecified address in Bognor Regis, Sussex, was short lived. Three days after the animal's rescue, it died.

Disappointed conservationists hope this is not the end, finally, for the rare mammal large enough to fill the palm of a man's hand. They plan to go back in the summer to establish whether others are hanging on in the face of intensive farming and the pesticides that have destroyed so many insects that make up their diet.

The location of last week's brief encounter is being secret for fear of enthusiastic amateurs disturbing other hibernating bats. Amy Coyte, chief executive of the Bat Conservation Society, told how the boy, rushing to feed chickens at the bottom of the garden, made his prized find and alerted his mother. "It was an absolutely freezing day so they brought the bat in and tried to warm it up. The boy was really excited, although it looked really ill and was really thin."

They contacted local volunteer bat workers through a website, and one came to take it home but failed to save its life. "This is a sad but incredible discovery," said Ms Coyte. "The fact the bat was found within five miles of the last known colony suggests it may be a survivor from that or another colony. We know from her worn teeth she was old. She may have lived alone for the last 10 years - but we hope that there are more somewhere in the area."

The last known colony, a few miles from Bognor, was discovered in 1969 and contained several females until 1985 when they all failed to return; it is thought they may have died in a fire in a cottage where they roosted.

There are 16 known species of bat remaining in Britain. Although they are protected by law, two are endangered, nine vulnerable and all threatened.

They contacted local volunteer bat workers through a website, and one came to take it home but failed to save its life. "This is a sad but incredible discovery," said Ms Coyte. "The fact the bat was found within five miles of the last known colony suggests it may be a survivor from that or another colony. We know from her worn teeth she was old. She may have lived alone for the last 10 years - but we hope that there are more somewhere in the area." The last known colony, a few miles from Bognor, was discovered in 1969 and contained several females until 1985 when they all failed to return; it is thought they may have died in a fire in a cottage where they roosted. There are 16 known species of bat remaining in Britain. Although they are protected by law, two are endangered, nine vulnerable and all threatened.

webTitle: MI6 recruited Russian spys, says Tomlinson

fields.headline: The rogue intelligence officer, the bogus news agency and the spies who never were
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: MI6 set up a surrogate news agency in central London as a front for recruiting Russians to spy for Britain, the rogue British intelligence officer Richard Tomlinson alleges in the controversial book which the service has been trying to ban.
fields.body:
MI6 set up a surrogate news agency in central London as a front for recruiting Russians to spy for Britain, the rogue British intelligence officer Richard Tomlinson alleges in the controversial book which the service has been trying to ban.

In what he describes as a botched and short-lived operation in 1992, the former MI6 officer claims the service wasted almost £40,000 on a futile effort to obtain Russian military secrets.

The three-month operation of the Truefax news agency resulted in not a single military secret being obtained and it was closed down, according to extracts from Tomlinson's book, The Big Breach, published in Russia yesterday.

A Russian military analyst who Tomlinson said he tried to recruit as an MI6 spy confirmed the existence of Truefax to The Guardian yesterday, disclosing that he had done some work for the phony news agency.

Tomlinson says that Truefax was established in Conduit Street in central London by him and a KGB defector in 1992 with a view to cultivating Russian journalists, obtaining military secrets, and recruiting Russian agents.

"This venture did not get us a single secret document and cost $60,000," he writes, as translated from the Russian.

After failing to publish The Big Breach on Monday as promised, Tomlinson's Moscow publisher, Sergei Korovin, yesterday told The Guardian the book, the subject of a High Court injunction obtained by MI6 against the Sunday Times last Friday, would definitely be launched this week, perhaps today.

Mr Korovin and Narodny Variant, the publishing company set up solely for the Tomlinson book project, have been leaking snippets to Komsomolskaya Pravda, the best-selling Moscow tabloid, and on to the internet, thus releasing more of its contents in to the public domain and increasing pressure on MI6 and the courts to allow the book to be issued in Britain.

Yesterday's disclosures focused on MI6 operations in Moscow around the time of the Soviet collapse in 1991-92. The MI6 Moscow residency, the renegade spy said, was made up of five operatives plus three or four technicians and half a dozen secretaries.

In spring 1992 Tomlinson says he was attached to the service's Russia section in London under a man who ordered him to recruit a Russian journalist with access to military secrets. Tomlinson was teamed with Mikhail Butkov, who defected to Britain from the KGB in Norway in 1991 and had been given a large house outside Reading, Berkshire.

The two men, given the aliases Ben Presley and Valery Ruben, set up the news agency and were quickly in touch with two dozen journalists from Moscow, Leningrad, and Kiev. Tomlinson says the most promising recruit was Pavel F, a Moscow military analyst close to President Boris Yeltsin's then defence minister, Pavel Grachev.

Over the following weeks, says Tomlinson, F received 12,000 dollars, but resisted all efforts to lure him to London and provided no secrets.

Tomlinson writes: "In the end we decided that F was simply playing with us, possibly with the participation of the Russian secret service."

Pavel Felgenhauer, a prominent Moscow journalist and military analyst, confirmed the existence of Truefax yesterday but cast doubt on Tomlinson's version of events as it applied to him. He told The Guardian he was commissioned to write an article on Russian biological warfare strategy in 1992. He says he received £400 from Truefax for two articles. He never had a telephone number for the agency but operated by fax.

Mr Felgenhauer said: "I was very closely acquainted with Grachev at that time. Truefax contacted me and I wrote one article about biological warfare. I still have it in my computer. They paid me £400. They didn't pay me 12,000 dollars. Maybe they stole it. I wrote my piece and then they disappeared. I was not connected to Russian intelligence."

Mr Felgenhauer, a ferocious critic of President Vladimir Putin and of the Russian political and military elite, added that he had learned from journalist colleagues that Truefax was a lucrative outlet. He received his £400 via an acquaintance in Paris. "They said it was a way to earn some easy bucks."

"He would have made a good agent," Tomlinson writes of Felgenhauer. "But it was hard to assess him on the phone and we invited Pavel to London. Although he eagerly accepted our fees (in all we sent him $12,000), he persistently refused to travel."

Mr Felgenhauer said: "I don't remember them inviting me to London. I never met Tomlinson or anyone from Truefax in person."

Russian intelligence yesterday denied MI6 assertions that it is behind the book's publication in Moscow and behind Mr Korovin. Last weekend MI6 alleged that Mr Korovin is connected with Russian intelligence. Boris Labusov, spokesman for the SVR foreign intelligence service, con gratulated Mr Korovin on his publishing coup and insisted that "our service has nothing to do with the publication of The Big Breach in Russia".

Korovin, who travels with a passport under the name of Kirill Tchashchin, is a Russian information technology specialist. He has set up internet press agencies. He came to Britain in 1997, and visited Switzerland in 2000 where he met Tomlinson.

An MI6 officer, identified only as AH, told the high court last week that he was acting "on behalf of Russian intelligence".

A former KGB veteran emphasised that his ex-colleagues knew nothing of the Tomlinson book and that the government press ministry which has to licence Russian publishers was also in the dark about Narodny Variant and Mr Korovin.

But Oleg Tkach, chief editor of the Olma-Press publishers, told the Kommersant newspaper that no one in Moscow publishing had heard of Narodny Variant. "Probably it is SVR agents poking around. They know everything about any scandal just starting abroad. They bought the rights from Tomlinson and set up some publishers for this."

fields.headline: Binman guilty of Beckham theft
fields.trailText: A jury yesterday found a rubbish collector guilty of handling stolen designer clothes belonging to pop singer Victoria Beckham.
fields.body:
A jury yesterday found a rubbish collector guilty of handling stolen designer clothes belonging to pop singer Victoria Beckham.

Mark Oliver, 20, of Stanwell in west London, was convicted at Isleworth crown court, west London, on two charges of handling stolen goods.

A charge of theft was dismissed.

On Monday Ms Beckham had told the court that four of her six cases were stolen after she arrived at Heathrow airport from Miami.

Oliver told the court he believed the clothes in the cases had been dumped inside bin liners on the back of his rubbish truck.

With them were items of sentimental value, and he had contacted the singer via a number available to him, that of her "nail technician", Jo.

He returned the items -including a baby book with a lock of hair from her child, Brooklyn. The court heard how the singer phoned Oliver to thank him.

She said: "I decided to call - I was just grateful somebody would give them back to me, and secondly, to see if he could get any more of my belongings back. I asked him how he had come into contact with it [her belongings], and he said he owned a dumper truck of some sort and he had found a dustbin bag in the back which he had looked into."

However, Kim Hollis, prosecuting, said that Oliver failed to return various clothes belonging to the 26-year-old star - label items by Ralph Lauren, Plein Sud and Maria Grachvogel.

Mrs Hollis said that during a telephone conversation between Oliver and Mrs Beckham, the defendant had pretended in a "farcical pantomime" to search for her possessions on a rubbish tip.

Oliver's sister, Sadie, had told the court that she had taken the entertainer's clothes unwittingly when she was looking through bin liners, which she believed were destined for a car boot sale.

Sentencing was adjourned for a date to be fixed while reports on Oliver were obtained.
Press Association

webTitle: Bishop puts faith in garden shed

fields.headline: Bishop puts faith in garden shed
fields.standfirst:
Backyard conversion creates quiet place for prayer

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Backyard conversion creates quiet place for prayer
fields.body:
In the beginning was the shed. And God said, Let there be light: and there was light (once a cable had been run from the house). And then God said, "Crumbs, it's cold in here. You need a heater."

And so the suffragan bishop of Burnley, the Right Reverend John Goddard, acquired a comfortable chapel. "Shoulder to shoulder, it can accommodate about eight people," he said. "But if 10 were to try to kneel down, it would need some synchronised movement."

The palaces of suffragan, or assistant, Anglican bishops are not grand and this one, a detached house near Burnley, had no bedroom to spare for an ecclesiastical conversion.

"When the diocese suggested this solution, I imagined it was going to be a basic kind of garden shed," Bishop Goddard said. "But if people are going to use it, health and safety regulations demand certain requirements - including heating."

The shed, measuring 12ft by 10ft and dedicated to Our Lady of Walsingham and St John, continues a Christian tradition of building in wood. It has a simple altar, a patterned rug, a crucifix from Oberammergau and icons representing saints from the churches in Bishop Goddard's previous parishes.

He uses the chapel for morning and evening prayer. "There is not much room but it is a pleasure to be able to go out of the house, where I can be embroiled by the phone and the doorbell, to a place where I can find stillness and prayer," he said. "It works extremely well. When I was in a parish, there was space in the morning and evening. That's harder to find as bishop."

Bishop Goddard said the simple wooden building also offered an atmosphere which contrasted with the permanence of a stone structure. It suggested the kind of contemplation familiar in the spirituality of early Celtic Christians, he said.

"The chapel offers an opportunity to be still, to come to know God," he added.

fields.headline: Hatfield train was 100mph too fast
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: The doomed Hatfield train was travelling at almost 100 mph above a safe speed when it crashed last October killing four people, Railtrack sources admitted last night.
fields.body:
The doomed Hatfield train was travelling at almost 100 mph above a safe speed when it crashed last October killing four people, Railtrack sources admitted last night.

They said a 20 mph speed limit should have been imposed on the line, but on the day the accident happened, the inter-city London-Leeds express was travelling at 117 mph.

Railtrack said it was still trying to discover why a speed restriction had not been imposed. It has acknowledged it had been aware that the line was in a poor condition almost 11 months before the accident.

It conceded that if a 20 mph speed restriction had been put in place, a fatal accident would have been avoided.

Vic Coleman, chief inspector of railways, said it was a "a matter of concern" that a visual inspection a week before the crash had not resulted in the cracks being seen.

Mr Coleman said speed restrictions should have been in place.

These new facts emerged yesterday as the health and safety executive published its latest report into the accident. It said a trainee driver with seven weeks' experience was at the controls. She should not have been driving the train at that speed until she had 11 weeks' training, but she was with a fully qualified instructor.

Investigators said no blame was attached to her and they were not concerned at the infringement of the rules because she was with a good instructor.

One rail expert said the scene at Hatfield was one of the worst cases of fragmentation he had seen in his 40 years' experience. When 300 pieces of the shattered track were put together, more than 50 pre-existent cracks were found.

Questioning the effectiveness of Railtrack's testing methods, the HSE said the ultrasonic testing system was "not optimised" to look at the sort of cracks which occurred at Hatfield.

The HSE rejected suggestions that it was dragging its heels on the investigation, which is now in its third month. It could not say if individual charges would be laid against staff from Railtrack or Balfour Beatty, its maintenance company responsible for the Hatfield site.

The report said cracks of a certain angle or depth "are unlikely to be detected" by Railtrack's ultrasound machine. But the line at Hatfield was in such a poor condition that it should have been visible by inspection alone. Sections of the surface metal which had broken away were up to four inches long.

Mr Coleman said all those who had seen the state of the track were "in no doubt that something should have been done about it".

HSE officials admitted later that they could not produce any further information at the moment because the case could involve criminal proceedings. It will be another month at least before the HSE and the British transport police will be able to recommend to the crown prosecution service that charges should be laid.

webTitle: Engineering eager to shrug off Cinderella role

fields.headline: Engineering eager to shrug off Cinderella role
fields.standfirst: 'Old' manufacturing could be more profitably approached as a two-speed phenomenon
fields.trailText: 'Old' manufacturing could be more profitably approached as a two-speed phenomenon
fields.body:
Transense Technologies designs sensors for monitoring tyre pressure on cars. It has 10 employees, turnover of £80,000 and a market capitalisation of £269.1m. TT Group designs and builds headlamp levelling sensors for cars. It has created a variety of innovative electronic systems for cars, mobiles phones and high speed trains. It has 11,500 employees, a turnover of £612m - but a market capitalisation of £240m.

Another example of stock market madness? A triumph of hope-based businesses over the tried and trusted companies with a long track record of profitability?

Or is it evidence of another trend within British industry? The phenomenon of a two speed economy divided between "new" companies involved in IT, electronics and optical engineering and the "old" metal bashers of car making, textiles and transport, is well established.

It will feature again in the quarterly industrial trends survey published today by the Confederation of British Industry, and was highlighted in a recent report by the Engineering Employers Federation, which showed output of electronic equipment growing by 15% last year while mechanical engineering production fell by 2.2%.

But the Transense and TT examples, and there are many others, indicate there is also a two speed trend within what the market considers "old" manufacturing.

This infuriates John Newman, the chief executive of TT Group, who is convinced he that is part of the new economy. "We are in advanced technology such as electrical components for computers and connectors for high speed trains," he insists.

Tony Wilson, the chief executive of Glynwed International, made no secret of his frustration earlier this week when he sold off the group's massive pipe manufacturing arm to concentrate on a division that produced a quarter of its profits and sales: manufacturing Aga cookers and selling them online.

Mr Wilson said he would have preferred to engage in the further consolidation of the pipe sector, where Glynwed had already become a world leader, but could not justify such a strategy to shareholders. Yet the £786m price obtained for the pipes business suggests that the company, capitalised at £533m at the end of last week, was seriously undervalued.

Other engineers have also embraced change. Over the past three years, Lord Simpson has been one of the boldest with his break-up of the massive GEC defence and aerospace empire, turning it into a much smaller hi-tech communications business under the Marconi banner.

So why the two speed trend inside a seemingly old sector? Many in the Square Mile argue that companies such as Transense or Turbo Genstar are superior to TT Group because they have potentially "killer applications" that give them a lead on the rest of the market.

One senior engineering analyst said: "It does not matter how many employees a company has; if they are heavily exposed to the commodity side of the business in a deflationary world, they are not going to attract stock market interest. Those with little intellectual property or proprietary rights are going to be subject to increasing margin pressure."

Companies such as Tomkins or even the more forward looking Invensys will continue to suffer on the stock market because they are restructuring but not quickly or deeply enough, say other analysts. They should be looking at examples like the Chloride group, which turned itself from a battery manufacturer with a price-earnings ratio of 10 to a market leader in power protection systems with a ratio of 40 within three years.

The fear in the engineering world is that the public is unaware of these distinctions and manufacturing generally has became almost a dirty word for school leavers.

It is a measure of the extent of this fear that some universities are now avoiding the word "engineering" in their course titles. Hard-pressed mechanical and civil engineering companies are being forced to pay signing-on fees in a bid to attract new talent.

At the national engineering recruitment exhibition recently held at the NEC in Birmingham - in the heart of metal bashing country - it was hard to find traditional manufacturers.

But that is fine for visitors such as Iain Best, a 23-year-old computer student at Birmingham University. He said: "I can see many traditional companies are trying to reinvent themselves. But I am interested in engineering networks, not construction, so am here for the Cisco Systems and Marconis of this world. They are more likely to provide the modern offices, nice wages and other benefits."

But I am interested in engineering networks, not construction, so am here for the Cisco Systems and Marconis of this world. They are more likely to provide the modern offices, nice wages and other benefits."

fields.headline: Reheated turkeys trotted out
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: One would have thought that this far past Christmas it was too late to reheat leftovers - but not a bit of it.
fields.body:
One would have thought that this far past Christmas it was too late to reheat leftovers - but not a bit of it.

Not one, not two, but three familiar takeover tales were given a fresh run by enterprising brokers yesterday.

First on the menu was locksmith and security services group, Chubb. Its shares rose 13.5p to 180p in heavy volume on speculation that a bid from US conglomerate Tyco International will finally arrive in the next week.

As far as anyone could tell, the tittle-tattle was based on the fact that Chubb was once part of the Williams conglomerate that once rejected an approach from Tyco.

Apparently the offer will be pitched below 265p, the level at which it started trading following its demerger from Williams in November, in order to reflect its recent profits warning. In December, Chubb lost 25% of its value in a single day after warning, rather bizarrely, that a slowdown in Australian sales after the Olympics would hit group profits.

In the meantime, buyers were busy tucking into Arriva, up 1p to 281p, on rumours that a predator was stalking the transport group.

Various names were put forward, but the one traders kept hearing was the principal finance unit of Japanese investment bank Nomura.

Some failed to be impressed, pointing out that the interest in the transport sector probably had more to do with bullish noises coming from the offices of HSBC Securities.

It seems the brokerage yesterday lifted its Arriva target price to 334p, upgraded its rating on Stagecoach, 0.5p better at 79.5p, and set a 925p price objective for National Express, which was off 9p at 870p.

The final story to be regurgitated involved property group British Land. To the surprise of absolutely nobody in the property world, the gossips were again talking about a management buyout. British Land ended 2p higher at 482p.

All this fun, however, could not disguise what had been a pretty depressing session for the London market.

The FTSE 100 ended 17.3 points adrift at 6,214.7, with the heavyweight telecoms sector doing the bulk of the damage. Vodafone fell 5.5p to 226p, BT dipped 18p to 678.5p and Cable & Wireless lost 16p to 914p - all unsettled by disappointing figures from Deutsche Telekom.

Market turnover was again weak, reaching only 1.66bn by 6.10pm last night - with many institutions prepared to do nothing until next week's meeting of the US Federal Reserve is out of the way.

Elsewhere, the FTSE TechMark technology index fell 39.57 points to 2,735.09, hit hard by losses in software and IT services sector after Sema, down 47.5p to 353.5p, delivered its second profits warning in as many months.

Misys fell 33.5p to 627p as fears about Thursday's interim figures intensified. According to market whispers, Misys could warn that it will not meet its financial targets for the second half of the year.

Psion shares were again under pressure yesterday. After Monday's 9.4% fall, they slipped 19p, or 6.35%, to 280p, affected by reports that the sale of next-generation GPRS mobile phones will not take off until next year.

Although Psion is best known for its handheld computers, its prospects depend on the success of EPOC - an operating system for next-generation mobile phones. A company named Symbian is developing EPOC, and Psion is the largest shareholder.

Not everything was going down, of course.

United Business Media topped the blue chip leaderboard, with a gain of 30p to 820p after a recommendation from Goldman Sachs.

Lower down the food chain, Imagination Technology, a designer of chips for games consoles, rose 2p to 212p on bid speculation, while retail punters piled into Business Post, up 18.5p to 240p, in hope of an offer from Federal Express.

fields.headline: Motorists spurn public transport
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The proportion of drivers who say they would make less use of their cars if public transport were to improve has fallen to an eight-year low, according to an report on motoring habits.
fields.body:
The proportion of drivers who say they would make less use of their cars if public transport were to improve has fallen to an eight-year low, according to an report on motoring habits.

The survey, undertaken before the Hatfield rail crash, found that one in five who had been willing to consider changing to public transport in 1997 now rejected the idea.

The annual report for the RAC showed the highest dependence on cars in the survey's 13-year history, with 86% saying they would find it difficult to adjust their lifestyles to being without their cars and only 36% saying they would use public transport if it was improved. This contrasted with 45% willing to switch to public transport when Labour came to power in 1997.

The findings contrasted with another survey answer: one in five decided against a planned car journey in the past three months because of worries about congestion; half opted for public transport, and the rest abandoned the journey altogether. That added up to 80m car journeys a year.

Car owners were doing slightly fewer miles each year, an average of 10,000 compared with 10,300, and changing their vehicles less often. But 72% of households had a car, 34% had two cars and 10% three cars or more. Four out of five motorists did not intend to buy a smaller car, despite the reduction in excise duty.

Nearly half the motorists questioned expected to have to pay £10 to drive into a city centre by 2010, and one in five expected it to cost £10 a day to park at the office. The RAC calculated that if this charge were imposed it would generate £16bn a year.

Seven out of 10 motorists believed that within 10 years most people working in offices would be working from home using computers, leaving rush-hour roads congestion-free. This was despite the fact there are 7m more cars on the road than in 1988.

The survey of 1,400 motorists asked about driving skills and habits, and found that large numbers admitted to dozing off at the wheel. Around 4m motorists are believed to doze off at least once a year while driving, and a hard core of 6% admitted having fallen asleep on as many as 10 or more occasions. The worst offenders were those doing more than 20,000 miles a year, with a third admitting nodding off.

Graeme Potts, the RAC managing director, said: "Anyone nodding off at the wheel is a danger, but it is particularly alarming to find such a high proportion of sleepers jeopardising themselves and other on a regular basis."

fields.headline: Eurotunnel lobbies on asylum fines
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Eurotunnel has been discreetly lobbying government to change the system under which fines are imposed on transport companies found to be carrying asylum seekers.
fields.body:
Eurotunnel has been discreetly lobbying government to change the system under which fines are imposed on transport companies found to be carrying asylum seekers.

Approaches have been made to immigration minister Barbara Roche as well as south coast MPs such as former Conservative home secretary, Michael Howard.

The initiative has been low key because the company knows it is a highly sensitive issue which prime minister Tony Blair is unlikely to tackle this side of a general election.

Eurotunnel itself is not fined under the government's Carriers Liability Act aimed at reducing the number of asylum seekers turning up at Folkestone or Dover.

But the company is concerned that traffic volumes are being held back by the financial threats imposed on its haulage customers. It is also worried about the mounting bill from its own security monitoring, which has cost it over £500,000 so far.

The Anglo-French group yesterday reported a 5% drop to £580m in operating revenues as the number of cars and coaches plummeted after the abolition of duty free sales.

But chairman Patrick Ponsolle was upbeat about the future because there had been a 35% rise in the number of trucks using the tunnel.

Last night, a Eurotunnel spokesman admitted writing to Ms Roche to ask her to look at some of the problems raised by the legislation. But he insisted: "We are not doing anything to get the fines lifted. But we do feel that immigration problems of Europe should not be left to be solved by the transport operators."

Eurotunnel admitted it was worried that fines on truck operators could be extended to rail operators. But well placed sources said the company was also pushing to have the existing law changed.

Up to 500 people a month are being found on lorries approaching the tunnel.

fields.headline: Statistics pledge broken
fields.standfirst: Whitehall demands protection from politicians
fields.trailText: Whitehall demands protection from politicians
fields.body:
Labour's commitment to taking politics out of official statistics was brought into question yesterday when ministers were accused of dragging their feet over rules designed to protect Whitehall from government interference.

Professor Denise Lievesley, president of the Royal Statistical Society, said in a letter to the head of the office for national statistics that she was gravely concerned at the continued lack of a code of practice promised by the Treasury.

She added: "If a consultation exercise on a draft code of practice for national statistics is not launched in the very near future, this government will have reneged on its commitment to create an independent statistical service."

Labour came to power in 1997 promising to establish a truly independent statistical service after accusing the Tories of repeatedly changing the basis on which the unemployment figures were calculated to make them look better.

A watchdog, the statistics commission, was established last year, and Len Cook made the first national statistician.

The society is concerned that without a code, pressure can be brought to bear on civil servants to publish figures when it is convenient for ministers. Prof Lievesley said last week the Home Office was trailing crime figures and the week before the Department of Health trailed waiting list figures before publication.

Last night, Mr Cook said the code could not be rushed. "We must create something which will stand the test of time when judged not only by the UK public, but also by our European partners and the wider international community."

webTitle: SFI to sell table dancing venues

fields.headline: SFI to sell table dancing venues
fields.trailText: SFI Group, the high street bar and restaurant operator, yesterday revealed it was in talks to sell For Your Eyes Only, its chain of table dancing venues.
fields.body:
SFI Group, the high street bar and restaurant operator, yesterday revealed it was in talks to sell For Your Eyes Only, its chain of table dancing venues.

The company, which enjoyed a bumper Christmas period with sales up 111% to £15m, said it was time to sell the chain because it did not fit in with the rest of its business.

Tony Hill, the executive chairman, said the chain only contributed a small amount to the group and needed a lot of work to take it forward.

Analysts predict that the four venues, which are based in London, Bournemouth and South-hampton, could fetch up to £8m. "The move should be applauded," said Nigel Popham, of Teather & Greenwood. "There were quite a few people that weren't comfortable and didn't want to invest in the company because of it."

SFI, whose portfolio includes the Litten Tree and Bar Med brands, delighted the City with pretax profits above most expectations at £6.2m for the 24 weeks to November 18, up from £3.1m last year.

The turnover, which increased 91% to £45.3m, was helped by the performance of the Slug & Lettuce and Break for the Border chains, bought last summer for £32m and £4.7m respectively.

"The results and outlook are extremely positive," said one analyst. Last night the share price edged up 1.5p to 222.5p, well ahead of its 165p year's low but still off its 295p high, prompting speculation it could be a takeover target or even taken private.

Mr Hill said the share price was not essential, as the group was not after acquisitions, but he would still like reassurance. Earnings per share have increased 76% to 7.9p, and the proposed interim dividend is up 10% to 0.8p.

fields.headline: Profitability crushed at Deutsche Telekom
fields.trailText: Telecoms stocks were hit by disappointing results yesterday from Deutsche Telekom, Europe's second largest provider, after figures showed that its profitability had been crushed through high spending on new third-generation mobile phone services.
fields.body:
Telecoms stocks were hit by disappointing results yesterday from Deutsche Telekom, Europe's second largest provider, after figures showed that its profitability had been crushed through high spending on new third-generation mobile phone services.

While net income leapt from €1.25bn(£800m) to €7.4bn during the 12 months to December - boosted by the sale of the group's cable businesses - the company, which owns British mobile telephone operator One2One and Voicestream in the United States, recorded losses of €1bn in the last three months of 2000.

The figures reflect a €450m interest and accounting charge to cover the cost of UMTS licences across Europe and the group's acquisition spree over the past year.

With investors in Paris and London weighing up the prospects for the forthcoming €65bn flotation of Orange by France Telecom, nerves were further stretched by a slump in the value of mobile handset manufacturer Nokia, whose shares fell 4% ahead of year-end results next Tuesday.

The Finnish firm, which has already issued a profits warning, has been hit by downgrades by investment banks such as Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein in London, which has slapped a "sell" recommendation on the company.

The knock-on effect saw shares in Scandinavian rival Ericsson fall 3%, while Dutch carrier KPN, which plans to float its own mobile division later this year, lost more than 5%.

Europe's mobile leader, Vodafone, was forced to issue a formal denial of reports that it was slowing the roll-out of General Packet Radio Service technology - an intermediate step before the full high-speed mobile internet service promised by UMTS.

"You put all these things together and you end up scrambling trying to find some good, upbeat stories," said one City analyst. "You feel like the grim reaper."

Sector analysts are bracing themselves for further bad news today, when Deustche Telekom's 82%-owned internet division, T-Online - which has seen several executive departures of late - reports what are expected to be losses of up to €70m.

Yesterday, Deutsche Telekom executives stressed that group sales had jumped 15% to €41bn overall, despite heavy acquisitions, and that the number of its mobile customers globally had almost doubled to 31m during the year.

An Italian court is expected to confirm today that it has upheld an appeal by telecoms group Blu against a government request to retain a €2.1bn deposit paid by the firm to take part in an auction of UMTS phone licences. The decision could save the BT-backed Blu from paying an amount estimated to be equivalent to its entire value.

webTitle: Business: What's hot and what's not

fields.headline: What's hot and what's not
fields.standfirst: Vandevelde's volte face
fields.trailText: Vandevelde's volte face
fields.body:
So, at long last, Luc Vandevelde has discovered what British shoppers have known for three years - that Marks and Spencer's clothes are "simply not good enough".

Yet it is quite a volte face. Only a couple of months ago, Mr Vandevelde had tremendous optimism about his merchandise. He believed it would generate real sales growth and a "wonderful Christmas" for the retailer.

Now that M&S's endless rails of dull jumpers, bland officewear and horrendous pyjamas have once again been left dangling on their hangers, Mr Vandevelde took the predictable route of blaming the previous management.

But the about-turn in his opinion is a perfect illustration of the present M&S board's shortcomings. With no fashion or design talent on the board, how should they know what is hot and what is not?

Yesterday, M&S reckoned they had a few positives to report. Footfall increased over Christmas, they said. How much? Well, they can't actually say because they don't really measure it. But they have some "electronic indicators" which suggest there has been a "marginal" increase. Not much to boast about there, then.

Then there are the margin improvements, with M&S pointing to an improvement of about 0.8%. Big deal, said some analysts. The supply chain changes could have generated three times that.

And M&S's problems do not begin and end with the merchandise. Its concept stores, which were supposed to bring such dramatic improvements, have grossly underperformed. Some are worse now than before they had expensive refits.

Other stores have juggled their floor layouts and put cosmetics inside the front door, in the style of a traditional department store. M&S might want to sell us more make-up, but brand names dominate the market and shoppers don't want to trip over own-label face cream on the way in.

M&S also has just too much space - maybe not too many stores, but too big.

Then there is the competition. First, it was the new breed of discounters, more recently it has been the huge reductions on offer at C&A as it shut down its UK operations and at Bhs, ahead of its relaunch later this year.

The new look Bhs, with former Debenhams chief Terry Green at the helm, and the new management at Arcadia are likely to cause more problems this year.

In reality it will be autumn of this year before Mr Vandevelde - and the design team he is recruiting - has to take responsibility for a clothing range, as M&S's spring ranges, put together by a team Mr Vandevelde has now decided is not good enough, are already on their way.

There is no reason that a stock has to recover. There is no reason to believe that M&S is not in long term decline. There is no reason to believe that Mr Vandevelde will deliver his promised turnaround - he has, after all, already promised it twice in the last six months.

Marks & Spencer shares are a sell.

New asset

Don Cruickshank, the battered chairman of the London Stock Exchange, has certainly broken with tradition at the venerable institution. Not only is Clara Furse, his new chief executive, a relative unknown in the tight-knit equity broking community, she is also, to state the obvious, a woman.

In fact, Ms Furse is one of only three females to have ever made it on to the board of the 200-year-old exchange.

What is more, she has never sold a share in her life. She has a cosmopolitan background and speaks five languages, and manages the upbringing of three children to boot.

Clearly, Ms Furse is no "little Englander". She also comes with a reputation for taking tough decisions, and sat on the board of the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange during its bleakest hours in the late 1990s.

We should know pretty quickly whether all this will enable the new chief executive to survive longer, and with more dignity, than so many of her predecessors.

But what a relief to have the job filled at last - a relief which manifested itself yesterday in an apparent outbreak of peace between London's bulge bracket investment banks and the scores of small stockbroking firms which still have control over the votes over the LSE's future.

Quite a few older stockbrokers in the Square Mile have spent a good portion of the past decade and a half complaining about the "tail wagging the dog" - a reference to the fact that, over the years, prices on the traditional cash market have been increasingly set by trading on the derivatives markets.

Now a futures and options expert is running the show, we should pre-empt financial bookmakers IG Index and offer our own spread on Ms Furse's survival. The book is now open at 24-26 months.

But they have some "electronic indicators" which suggest there has been a "marginal" increase. Not much to boast about there, then. Then there are the margin improvements, with M&S pointing to an improvement of about 0.8%. Big deal, said some analysts. The supply chain changes could have generated three times that. And M&S's problems do not begin and end with the merchandise. Its concept stores, which were supposed to bring such dramatic improvements, have grossly underperformed. Some are worse now than before they had expensive refits. Other stores have juggled their floor layouts and put cosmetics inside the front door, in the style of a traditional department store. M&S might want to sell us more make-up, but brand names dominate the market and shoppers don't want to trip over own-label face cream on the way in. M&S also has just too much space - maybe not too many stores, but too big. Then there is the competition. First, it was the new breed of discounters, more recently it has been the huge reductions on offer at C&A as it shut down its UK operations and at Bhs, ahead of its relaunch later this year. The new look Bhs, with former Debenhams chief Terry Green at the helm, and the new management at Arcadia are likely to cause more problems this year. In reality it will be autumn of this year before Mr Vandevelde - and the design team he is recruiting - has to take responsibility for a clothing range, as M&S's spring ranges, put together by a team Mr Vandevelde has now decided is not good enough, are already on their way. There is no reason that a stock has to recover. There is no reason to believe that M&S is not in long term decline. There is no reason to believe that Mr Vandevelde will deliver his promised turnaround - he has, after all, already promised it twice in the last six months. Marks & Spencer shares are a sell. New asset Don Cruickshank, the battered chairman of the London Stock Exchange, has certainly broken with tradition at the venerable institution. Not only is Clara Furse, his new chief executive, a relative unknown in the tight-knit equity broking community, she is also, to state the obvious, a woman. In fact, Ms Furse is one of only three females to have ever made it on to the board of the 200-year-old exchange. What is more, she has never sold a share in her life. She has a cosmopolitan background and speaks five languages, and manages the upbringing of three children to boot. Clearly, Ms Furse is no "little Englander". She also comes with a reputation for taking tough decisions, and sat on the board of the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange during its bleakest hours in the late 1990s. We should know pretty quickly whether all this will enable the new chief executive to survive longer, and with more dignity, than so many of her predecessors. But what a relief to have the job filled at last - a relief which manifested itself yesterday in an apparent outbreak of peace between London's bulge bracket investment banks and the scores of small stockbroking firms which still have control over the votes over the LSE's future. Quite a few older stockbrokers in the Square Mile have spent a good portion of the past decade and a half complaining about the "tail wagging the dog" - a reference to the fact that, over the years, prices on the traditional cash market have been increasingly set by trading on the derivatives markets. Now a futures and options expert is running the show, we should pre-empt financial bookmakers IG Index and offer our own spread on Ms Furse's survival. The book is now open at 24-26 months.

fields.headline: LVMH sees bags of demand
fields.trailText: Expensive handbags are rarely an impulse buy, except for the seriously rich, but luxury goods group LVMH believes demand for some of its new lines is so strong it has had to draw up waiting lists.
fields.body:
Expensive handbags are rarely an impulse buy, except for the seriously rich, but luxury goods group LVMH believes demand for some of its new lines is so strong it has had to draw up waiting lists.

The latest products, Monogram Vernis and Epi pastel, met with "an exceptional reception" according to the company. Overall demand for the group's Louis Vuitton luggage range could not be met entirely in the fourth quarter and sales growth had to be restricted to 19%. More capacity is being brought on stream.

The strong performance from luxury luggage saw sales up 37% on the year helping the group to clock up a 35% increase in turnover to €11.6bn (£7.4bn). Operating profit, to be announced later, is likely to be up by more than 25%.

The wines and spirits operation, which includes names like Moët & Chandon, Veuve Clicquot and Hennessy, was up 4%, thanks largely to a fourth quarter surge in sales.

Fragrances and cosmetics -where brands span Christian Dior's J'adore to Urban Decay - were up by just over a fifth. The watch and jewellery division set up in 1999 produced sales of €614m.

webTitle: Menzies to dump loss-making Early Learning Centre

fields.headline: Menzies to dump loss-making Early Learning Centre
fields.trailText: John Menzies yesterday confirmed it is to sell its loss making Early Learning Centre children's chain within 18 months.
fields.body:
John Menzies yesterday confirmed it is to sell its loss making Early Learning Centre children's chain within 18 months.

The company would not put a price on the business but Menzies is believed to be unwilling to sell for less than its asset value of £30m. The ELC management is known to be interested in a buyout.

Martyn Smith, finance director at John Menzies, said: "We will sell it sometime within the next 12 to 18 months. It will be back in profit this year."

Like-for-like sales for ELC rose 3%. Including new concessions in 14 Debenhams stores, sales were up by 6% to £69.5m. The business also saw an increase in sales through mail order and its internet site, which it says should reach profitability this year.

Losses for ELC were reduced from £6.4m to £5.5m in the six months to November.

The news of the proposed sale, part of the company's strategy to dispose of non-core seasonal businesses and to move into aviation and distribution, came as John Menzies reported a half-year loss of £8.2m compared to a profit of £7.8m. This included an exceptional charge of £23.9m re lated to the decision to sell its THE music business to management and close down its THE Games distributor.

In its final contribution to the company's results, THE turned in an improved sales performance, up by £41.5m to £71.8m thanks to the Pokemon phenomenon. Menzies is shutting THE Games at the end of next month when its contract with Pokemon owner Nintendo ends.

"THE Games' results were outstanding and the timing of our exit from this business has allowed us to maximise its profits at the peak of the Pokemon phenomenon," the company said. Menzies' total turnover rose 6% to £630.9m, with two-thirds coming from the distribution of magazines and newspapers to shops.

The group also said it has moved further into the airport ground handling business. John Menzies acquired Ogden Ground Services at the end of November for $118m (£80.27m), as part of its move into less seasonal businesses.

Analysts yesterday said the results were in line with expectations. One said: "John Menzies should be a more stable business now."

Its shares rose 7p to 428p. The board raised the interim dividend by 10% to 5.5p per share.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Mercury Rising | Alien 3 | Buffalo 66
fields.body:
Mercury Rising
(Harold Becker, 1998)
10pm, Sky Premier

An autistic boy unwittingly cracks a top secret service code, causing cynical government agent Alec Baldwin to call in the hitmen. So, as Ghostbusters would put it, who you gonna call? Bruce Willis, of course. His FBI man is washed up, over the hill and down the other side, but still able to turn the tables on the smart young goons in a formulaic but efficient drama from the director of Sea Of Love.

Alien 3
(David Fincher, 1992)
10.10pm, Sky Cinema

Once more into those dark tunnels for Sigourney Weaver in this gloomy chapter in the great SF horror saga. Her battle-weary Ripley crashlands on a planet colonised by convicts. Her surrogate family, and with them hope are dead, but one creature is very much alive and stirring in her belly. Her shaven head is like preparation for execution, but she rises to the final challenge: 'atta girl, Ripley.

Buffalo 66
(Vincent Gallo, 1997)
11.55pm, Sky Premier

Gallo's Billy, straight from jail, goes home to Buffalo, NY, and kidnaps Christina Ricci's Layla so she can pretend to be his wife in a meeting with his feckless parents (Ben Gazzara, Anjelica Huston): and so one of the most touching of screen romances is born. Gallo's directorial debut, with its sadly faded and poignant imagery, is also fresh, funny and utterly individual.

The Green Ray
(Eric Rohmer, 1986)
11.30pm, FilmFour

It's summer, but a sad time for Parisian secretary Delphine (Marie Rivière): she visits Cherbourg, the mountains and the coast, but nothing can stir her from her acute ennui. Then along comes Jacques (Vincent Gauthier), and suddenly the sun is shining again (the green ray being the diffracted light of the sunset, which is said to bestow insight on lovers). A film of transcendent beauty and wisdom from Rohmer, so perfectly performed and crafted it's hard to believe it was entirely improvised.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: And so to bed
fields.trailText: Better Sex | Challenger | Jungle Janes
fields.body:
Beside a church spire and under a cerulean sky, Janet was on a desensitising weekend. An aspiring sex therapist for Relate, she had just started her 30 months of training. Judging from the glimpse Better Sex (Channel 4) gave us, this mainly involved writing rude names for ladyparts and menbits on a white board, participating in role plays about premature ejaculation ("It's all over in a flash," a man said softly. "Sometimes less than that," offered his partner), and watching films of a real couple doing it.

As a porno piano plonked away on the soundtrack, a lithe young woman got all orgasmic thanks to a man with a beard. (At least, I think it was a beard.) "I was relieved when they came," Janet confessed.

Having been suitably desensitised to sex and its discussion, Janet then ventured to Cardiff where Gareth, a leonine sex therapist, was in the process of helping Petula and Chris. Their 30-year marriage had run into difficulties after news of investigations into sexual abuse in Welsh care homes had triggered Petula's memories of her own abuse as a child.

This is when Better Sex turned rather serious and joking seemed out of place.

Pained, awkward and courageous, Petula told how, as a lonely five-year-old, she had enjoyed the abuse and the attention inflicted upon her. She told Gareth she now found sexual contact unbearable while Chris, lost and overwhelmed in an understated male way, choked on the words as he explained how Petula cringed when he touched her.

Tackling Petula's sedimentary layers of guilt and confusion, and Chris's bewilderment, Gareth demonstrated the sensitivity and skill to which Janet aspired. His handling of their problems led to the couple slowly getting to know each other again and re-establishing intimate relations.

A moving, interesting documentary, Better Sex was also badly weighted and frustrating. Petula and Chris's complex and compelling story simply overpowered Janet's and, in the end, her progress seemed almost like a footnote. Initially a main player, Janet was too quickly relegated to the benches, giving Better Sex a slightly disappointing conclusion.

Fifteen years ago in another blue sky, forking plumes of white smoke signalled the destruction of the space shuttle Challenger and the death of its crew. Six astronauts and the teacher Christa McAuliffe perished - quite unnecessarily - as the excellent Challenger (BBC2) recounted.

Combining a tragic human interest story - that of McAuliffe - with a meticulous scientific approach to the engineering problems that caused the disaster, and a knowledge of the political and institutional machinations at Nasa that contributed to the tragedy, this was an exquisite epic. An instance of the American dream gone nightmarishly wrong, Challenger was like Arthur Miller with rockets.

The documentary was extensive, charting the disaster from the moment engineer Roger Boisjoly realised the danger posed by seals not sealing in the cold, which could - and did - lead to 500,000 gallons of unstable fuel igniting and blowing up the shuttle. We saw the retrospectively perverse popularity contest in which McAuliffe won her place. And we watched, as millions of Americans including McAuliffe's family and pupils did in 1986, a tiny flame appearing on the rockets and, quick as a flash, consuming the shuttle.

Building the tension as surely as it built a convincing argument, Challenger was quite literally spine-tingling. Amongst those interviewed were a Nasa official who still sought to justify his decisions, and the engineers who had opposed the launch. The latter men - Boisjoly included - seemed a whole lot more troubled by the accident than the Nasa man who did nothing. After all these years, he was still chuckling as Christa McAuliffe's mother's eyes filled with tears while she talked about her dear daughter.

Perhaps rocket science isn't all it's cracked up to be.

Major Ken Hames (retired) may not be quite as eloquent as Sartre, but when he observed that it's not the mountains or the rock faces that are the biggest obstacles for the Jungle Janes (Channel 4), he was spot on. As the Castaways and the Big Brother housemates know - hell is other people.

webTitle: Ulster army base attacked as talks falter

fields.headline: Ulster army base attacked as talks falter
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Dissident republicans were blamed for a mortar bomb attack on a Derry army base yesterday heightening tension as Tony Blair met Northern Ireland leaders at Downing Street in efforts to break the peace process deadlock.
fields.body:
Dissident republicans were blamed for a mortar bomb attack on a Derry army base yesterday heightening tension as Tony Blair met Northern Ireland leaders at Downing Street in efforts to break the peace process deadlock.

The RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, and Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, condemned the bomb, which was fired from a van into Ebrington base in the mainly Protestant Waterside area, but failed to explode. Scrawled on the launching plate of the barrack-buster bomb was an abusive message directed at Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams signed PO Neill, the name more normally put to Provisional IRA statements.

A passerby suffered minor leg injuries, and about 300 families had to leave their homes while the bomb was defused.

There was no sign of breakthrough in talks aimed at resolving disputes over policing, demilitarisation and paramilitary disarmament. Unionists insisted that security should not be scaled down while dissidents were so active.

The Derry attack, the second on Ebrington in 10 months, came a day after a 100lb booby trap tripwire bomb was defused behind a police station in nearby Claudy.

Last week police and soldiers foiled the planting of 1,100lb of explosives near Armagh, and RUC officers in Cookstown, Co Tyrone, had a lucky escape when a blast bomb was hurled at their patrol car.

Mr Mandelson said the attacks should spur politicians to redouble their attempts to reach agreement. Mr Adams, the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble, and the Social Democratic and Labour party leader John Hume, had separate talks with Mr Blair yesterday.

Nationalists and republicans said legislation on police reform had watered down Chris Patten's recommendations too much, but Sinn Fein claimed that talks were "inching forward", especially on policing. Mr Trimble, however, who left after only an hour, said republicans were shirking their commitments on decommissioning, and all sides must support police.

He is under pressure from hardliners in his party to quit power-sharing with Sinn Fein unless the IRA makes substantial progress toward disarmament. The looming general election could see the process shelved if a comprehensive deal is not worked out soon.

There was evidence of growing disillusion in the unionist community when a third of the Ulster Democratic party, which represents the largest loyalist paramilitary group, the Ulster Defence Association, said they could no longer support the Good Friday agreement. But the UDP leader, Gary McMichael, insisted that the split was amicable and that the UDA ceasefire was not under threat.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What teenagers are watching on TV
fields.trailText: What teenagers are watching on TV.
fields.body:
Rebecca Moody, 16: "I'm trying to get my mum and dad to get E4 digital so I can watch Ali G and Friends, and I think Buffy is on there too. I want to see the Paramount Channel anyway, and MTV. They won't let us get it at the moment, because they say we'd watch too much TV. Well that's the point! It keeps me out of the pub, anyway. I like the 4 Music slot but it doen't have enough rap and nu-metal. Top Of The Pops? No, full of shit S Club 7."

Francesca Harp, 17: "My brother's got a video camera and he's trying to make open-access programmes about music in Hounslow. I get to present the shows. Do I want to be a presenter? Yeah. I like people like Davina McCall and Daisy Donovan, I think they're really good. I'm not going to be nice when I'm on TV, though, I'm going to be [adopts American accent] The Bitch On The Box! Wooh! Yeah, I'm going to go on telly and be really nasty to everyone. In particular? Jamie from EastEnders. I hate him."

Dee Imani, 15: "I think TV's all right, it has its moments, but I don't watch that much of it. I don't have my own TV, I prefer working on the computer and emailing people, chatrooms. I think it's a lot better for your mind, really. I can get to speak to people who like hip-hop all over the world."

Dan Bearman, 17: "I watch the 4 Later stuff, some of it, because I'm an insomniac. I watch the football and sometimes Later with Jools Holland, if anything good's on, Beck or something. I used to spend a lot of time watching all the archaeological programmes. I know all about excavations."

Grace Ford, 14: "I watch Pet Rescue when I come home from school because I like the animals. I watch Top Of The Pops and Cold Feet and Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? Have I ever seen Harry Enfeld's teenagers? Yes, and I'm exactly like that! I burnt half the kitchen down once, almost, when I did oven chips in the middle of the night. And I had a tantrum and left for two days. I used to be awful...."

 Sian Pattenden spoke to teenagers in south-west London.

fields.headline: No: 1807
fields.standfirst: Rupert Thompson
fields.trailText: Rupert Thompson
fields.body:
Age: Bespectacled throwback to 1930s gay heyday of Auden 'n' Isherwood. Even takes retro style to logical conclusion of being coloured sepia, judging by photo in Independent. (Actually he is 34.)

Occupation: Has just taken over at helm of World of Interiors. He succeeds Min Hogg, the snooty doyenne of bleeding-edge soft furnishings reportage who edited the soigne Condé Nast glossy for a very long time.

How long a time? Since around 1893, it's believed.

So he's set to become Britain's answer to Martha Stewart? More or less. Sales are sliding, and he has to recapture flush young trendies who found Hogg's mag too "impenetrable" and "stale" and defected to Wallpaper*.

What's the plan? He wants "to do things in a different way" and make "every page work hard". Text and pictures are "equally important", apparently.

Zzzzzzzzzzzzz. Sorry, nodded off there. Surely there's something interesting about him? Not really. He lives with Alan Bennett, if that kind of celeb trivia floats your boat.

Good God, the nation's teddybear! But I thought Bennett was in a committed yet platonic relationship with Thora Hird, based on a shared penchant for Earl Grey and macaroons? Just a media myth, started by Spitting Image and perpetuated by Dead Ringers.

But he did say that being asked if he was gay was like asking a man crossing a desert if he preferred Badoit or Perrier? That was then, this is now. Like Philip Larkin, he's managed to put across an image of curmudgeonly celibacy while scoring regularly as a sexagenarian. Before Thomas there was "A", a lass from his native Yorkshire.

Are Rupert and Alan officially an item? Only very discreetly: Bennett refers to Thomas as "R" in a diary chronicling 2000 in the latest London Review of Books.

And? It seems he didn't say anything worth recording all year.

Not to be confused with: David Starkey, Terence Davies, Rupert Everett, Tyler Brûlé.
