webTitle: Delroy Lindo: The battle over my good name

fields.headline: The battle over my good name
fields.standfirst:
As soon as a police report finds in my favour, poisonous leaks begin

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: As soon as a police report finds in my favour, poisonous leaks begin.
fields.body:
On July 5 last year the Metropolitan Police Authority came into being in London. Two days later it announced an inquiry, to be conducted by the Met, to investigate police harassment of my wife Sonia and I.

The harassment has in fact gone back more than 20 years, ever since Winston Silcott and I highlighted policing problems on the Broadwater Farm estate in north London. However in the past four years, action against us has intensified.

In that time I have been charged and cleared of 17 offences, ranging from public order to assault. Sonia has been charged and cleared of two offences.

The incident which led to the launch of the inquiry was my latest arrest. I had been observing a police officer cutting the numberplate off someone's car, an act which I know from bitter experience is illegal because a police officer had previously done that to me. In the course of my five-hour detention in a cell at Tottenham police station, I discovered I had been arrested for sucking my teeth, not an offence (but something which, incidentally, I had not done).

During the course of my arrest, a call was made to Lee Jasper, equality and policing adviser at the Greater London Assembly, who complained to Scotland Yard. After that I was hurriedly released without charge and the inquiry was born.

Despite our fear and suspicion of the police, I welcomed the inquiry which was conducted by a team of Met officers and headed by Deputy Assistant Commissioner Tarique Ghaffur. I have nothing but praise for the way he and other senior police officers conducted their investigation.

We were kept informed throughout and the process of their investigation has been transparent. We know from a series of media leaks that the findings are damning - harassment because of negative stereotyping of me and my family. More than 93 intelligence reports were held about us, some using racist or derogatory language although we were not prominent suspects for anything. And there were three unlawful arrests.

A dirty tricks campaign against us began in earnest once the findings became known. I have a spent conviction for rape from 20 years ago. I always protested my innocence of this crime, there was never any forensic or corroborating evidence and even my alleged victim's family gave evidence supporting my innocence.

Because of my profile on the Broadwater Farm estate, urging residents to oppose police harassment, I was a police target and I believe that framing me on this charge was the start of all the subsequent incidents. Indeed the inquiry report states that my previous spent conviction was a key factor in the police harassment.

Does this mean that anyone with a conviction, valid or not, is not entitled to just treatment by the police ever again? And do the police consider themselves exempt from the provisions of the 1984 Rehabilitation of Offenders Act? It wasn't long before the Daily Mail dredged up my conviction, neatly juxtaposing it with two facts (that had only been disclosed to Assistant Commissioner Mike Todd and Chief Superintendent Chris Cerroni in a highly confidential meeting at Scotland Yard), namely that I was seeking £1m in damages from the Met and that I had five civil actions planned against the Met, not all of them yet lodged with the courts.

More sinister leaks to other rightwing newspapers followed, involving some gross fabrications. We discovered that Met solicitors defending the civil action we have launched had access to the inquiry report as long ago as December 7, long before we knew of its contents. The leaks have also helped to obscure some important wider issues. While the inquiry's aim was not to attribute blame to individual officers, the officers who carried out three unlawful arrests must be addressed in a separate inquiry. To date I have had no undertaking from the Met that this will be the case.

Despite everything we have been through in recent years at the hands of the police, my family and I do not harbour hatred and bitterness against them and cooperated 100% with the inquiry.

However the dirty tricks campaign, which is aimed at both undermining the legitimacy of our grievances and the extent of our civil action, makes me believe that the Met may not be capable of moving forwards.

The inquiry was launched to try to make progress and restore trust. I believe the malicious leaks reveal a battle going on between the reactionaries and the progressives at the very top of the Met.

If the adversarial stance between some elements of the police against the black community is allowed to fester unchecked, then all of us will be the poorer for it.

 Delroy Lindo lives in north London.

webTitle: Minister tells industry to protect children using chat rooms

fields.headline: Minister tells industry to protect children using chat rooms
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: New ways to stop internet chat rooms being used by child sex abusers to meet and "groom" children are being considered, the Home Office minister, Lord Bassam, said yesterday.
fields.body:
New ways to stop internet chat rooms being used by child sex abusers to meet and "groom" children are being considered, the Home Office minister, Lord Bassam, said yesterday.

Measures include the improved supervision of chat rooms and "hotlines" so that children could make an official report when they felt they had been the target of an "inappropriate" approach.

The proposals follow talks between the internet industry, police and the government. Addressing an Internet Watch Foundation seminar yesterday, Lord Bassam said that there was a difficulty in outlawing the early stages of contact between a potential abuser and a child.

"Initial exchanges between a child and a potential abuser online might amount to no more than harmless chat about pop-groups or football, but may be more serious and a prelude to a meeting prior to abuse.

"It has been suggested that, in these circumstances, the intentions or motives of the person seeking to become involved with the child should be taken into account. This is something we need to think carefully about. We have to be careful to avoid the creation of 'thought crime'," said Lord Bassam.

It is expected that the in ternet industry will be asked to adopt the safeguards.

Ruth Dixon, deputy chief executive of the Internet Watch Foundation, said she hoped internet service providers would ensure there was proper supervision of chat services aimed at children.

The annual report of the IWF published yesterday showed that it received more than 8,000 tip-offs last year about illegal or offensive material. This was more than double the number in the previous year.

The IWF was set up by the internet industry in 1996 to combat criminal content on the web. It advises British internet service providers to remove access to sites that contain illegal material - usually child pornography but also extreme forms of adult pornography and racist material.

Last year 7,681 of the items on which the IWF hotline received complaints were judged to be potentially illegal, and UK internet service providers were asked to take down 2,498 items from their servers.

Only 121 of these items were found to have originated in Britain. The figure for the number of items removed from British internet servers was smaller than in 1999 when more than 10,000 items were removed after being reported by the IWF.

The IWF said that the fall was a sign of the success of its operation and those of the police in arresting British paedophiles active in chat rooms. Many of the complaints it was receiving had shifted from these chat rooms to websites originating in eastern Europe.

Special report on free speech on the net

webTitle: Israel suspends talks after new killings

fields.headline: Israel suspends talks after new killings
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel withdrew its delegation from peace talks with the Palestinians yesterday after two Israeli restaurant owners were killed in the West Bank by Palestinian gunmen.
fields.body:
Israel withdrew its delegation from peace talks with the Palestinians yesterday after two Israeli restaurant owners were killed in the West Bank by Palestinian gunmen.

Only two days after the talks started in Taba, on the Red Sea, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, recalled his team for "consultations". It was unclear how long the suspension would last.

Some progress had been reported at the negotiations when the news that the bodies of two Israelis had been found emerged. Israeli security officials said the two were eating in a restaurant in the West Bank town of Tulkarem when masked gunmen entered, forced them out and shot them. Their bodies were found near the Nur Shams refugee camp outside the town.

A Palestinian negotiator, Ahmed Qureia, condemned the killings. It was unclear whether the murders were political or the result of some other dispute.

In Taba, both sides were reported to have presented maps to illustrate positions on border issues and control over parts of Jerusalem.

At a school in Tel Aviv, meanwhile, Mr Barak spoke of possible "joint management" of Jerusalem's contested Old City. But with Israel's prime ministerial election on February 6, he insisted that Judaism's holiest sites would be under Israeli sovereignty.

The Israeli foreign minister, Shlomo Ben-Ami, told army radio: "I think the chance [of a peace breakthrough] is not very high, due to limited time and the weight of the subject."

webTitle: G2: Can death metal music kill?

fields.headline: 'He asked if I'd be down for sacrificing a virgin. I said, whatever'
fields.standfirst: Their lyrics celebrate 'gleaming blades' and 'flowing blood' but no one could take the death-metal band Slayer seriously, could they? David and Lisanne Pahler do. They believe the group inspired three teenagers to kill their daughter. And they think they can prove it.  Michael Ellison  reports
fields.trailText: Their lyrics celebrate 'gleaming blades' and 'flowing blood' but no one could take the death-metal band Slayer seriously, could they? David and Lisanne Pahler do. They believe the group inspired three teenagers to kill their daughter. And they think they can prove it. Michael Ellison reports.
fields.body:
Even in a nation where 12 schoolchildren a day are killed by guns, the death of Elyse Pahler stood out from the welter of cold statistics. The adventurous 15-year-old Californian thought she was sneaking into a eucalyptus grove to share a marijuana joint with three boys: but they had other intentions.

First they choked her with a belt; then they took turns with a hunting knife to slash and stab her more than a dozen times; and as she fell to the ground, praying and crying out for her mother, the three friends stamped their feet on the back of her neck.

Not long afterwards, according to a lawsuit, Joseph Fiorella, 14, Jacob Delashmutt, 16, and Royce Casey, 16, returned to where Elyse had bled to death and had sex with her corpse.

That was five years ago in San Luis Obispo and now her killers are serving sentences of 25 years to life. They were problem kids who devoted most of their leisure time to marijuana, methamphetamine and LSD, but they had something else swirling around in their heads. This was death-metal music, and specifically the records made by Slayer, the veteran pioneers of thrash from Huntington Beach, California.

The band's lyrics might be taken to have a risible, cartoonish, flavour about them. Try these from Kill Again:

Homicidal maniac

Trapped in mortal solitude

Lift the gleaming blade

Slice her flesh to shreds

Watch the blood flow free.

While there are those who regard these words as a vehicle for no more genuine menace than a Robbie Williams video, 53-year-old David Pahler and his wife Lisanne, 43, are not among them. They believe that Slayer's paens to serial killers and necrophilia contributed to their daughter's death and are suing the band and the companies that have distributed their music.

"This case isn't about art," says David Pahler. "It's about marketing. Slayer and others in the industry have developed sophisticated strategies to sell death metal music to adolescent boys. They don't care whether the violent, mysogynistic message in these lyrics causes children to do harmful things. They couldn't care less what their fans did to our daughter. All they care about is money."

For their part, Slayer are not talking about the case. But two years ago Paul Bostaph, the drummer, said: "They're trying to blame the whole thing on us. That's such nonsense. If you're gonna do something stupid like that, you should get in trouble for it." He supported Slayer's case by observing that the killers had not done their homework properly: they had failed to follow the rituals of necrophilia sacrifice set out in the songs.

The Pahlers are simply the latest bereaved parents to try to hold accountable purveyors of popular, and not so popular, culture for the deaths of their children.

Their predecessors include the parents of a 19-year-old who commited suicide after listening to the music of Ozzy Osbourne and the families of children shot in a Kentucky schoolyard who tried to sue the makers of video games. Both cases foundered in the path of the first amendment to the US constitution, which guarantees freedom of expression.

The shock-rocker Marilyn Manson, too, was a convenient lightning rod after the Columbine school massacre in Denver, Colorado, nearly two years ago when the fact that the teenage killers were members of a Trenchcoat Mafia appealed to the demand for instant answers.

But the California lawsuit is different. Here the lawyers for the Pahlers hope to body-swerve the first amendment by relying on the argument that the companies sold materials harmful to minors in the knowledge that the music's violent creed was simply a tool to sell records. The firm handling the case is Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, who persuaded a court case that the RJ Reynolds Tobacco Co had marketed the Joe Camel character to children.

"The distribution and marketing of this obscene and harmful material to adolescent males constituted aiding and abetting of the criminal acts described in this complaint," says the lawsuit. "None of the vicious crimes committed against Elyse Marie Pahler would have occurred without the intentional marketing strategy of the death-metal band Slayer."

Attorneys for the band and the music companies - including Def Jam Music, Columbia Records, Sony Music Entertainment and American Recordings - say that Slayer's work is ring-fenced by the right to free speech enshrined in the constitution.

No one can be sure that this guarantee is worth what it was. Next month at the Grammys it will become known whether the music industry has found a way to avoid giving one of four awards to the confrontational rapper Eminem, variously hailed as a bigot and the most vital young artist in America or anywhere else.

No sooner had he been nominated than there was a foretaste of the ructions to follow, whether he wins or not. "We're not really endorsing him," said Michael Greene, head of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. "There are very few people in this organisation who wouldn't agree that Eminem's record is probably the most repugnant album of the year. However, the craft around it ... it's a remarkable recording."

Eminem, born Marshall Mathers, says that his lyrics are not meant to be taken literally, any more than Slayer wish to be certified as necrophilia salesmen. "We're part-evil," says Slayer singer Tom Araya. "If we were really evil, we would be doing everything we're writing about."

Naturally, this distinction does not impress David Pahler. "What are we talking about here? We have children ending their lives because the lyrics say they're worthless. It's about money. That's the driving force. I can't imagine the adults in the band, in the distribution end, really think this so-called music or the lyrics are good." His wife Lisanne says: "They have families of their own. Where's their conscience?"

Advocates of the first amendment believe that the Slayer case could be a turning point and are not over-confident about the outcome. "We're kidding ourselves if we don't think the cultural climate affects judges and their decisions," says Peter Eliasberg, of the American Civil Liberties Union. "We're getting to the point, if we let these cases go forward, that someone can say [the blaxploitation movie] Shaft glorifies vigilantism. There is a really serious danger to decide to not make a movie or not write a book."

That danger, as he perceives it, was not diminished by a report last week from the US surgeon general's office that identified a "scientific link between graphically violent television programming and increased aggression in children." The paper, commissioned by the White House after the Columbine shootings, says: "Research to date justifies sustained efforts to curb the adverse effects of media violence on youths. Although our knowledge is incomplete, it is sufficient to develop a coherent public health approach to violence prevention that builds upon what is known, even as more research is under way."

The surgeon-general's finding followed a study last autumn by the federal trade commission which concluded that Hollywood is marketing violent movies to children.

Perhaps the starkest if not the best evidence, though, comes not via august government bodies, but rather from Elyse's killers.

Delashmutt, now a 21-year-old, says: "It was harmless at first. We used to smoke weed, play guitar, kick it. I was just into heavy-metal music." But Fiorello had taken his hobby further. "It gets inside your head," he told a police counsellor a year after the girl's death. "It's almost embarrassing that I was so influenced by the music. The music started to influence the way I looked at things."

Delashmutt says that one day Fiorella asked "if I'd be down for sacrificing a, whatever, a virgin. I didn't take it seriously. I said 'whatever' ".

Slayer are in Canada this week, working on the record they hope will become the sixth gold disc by the outfit who have awarded themselves the title of "the world's most grisly band".

Other than their back catalogue of collections such as Seasons in the Abyss, Reign in Blood and Diabolus in Musica, fans have had only the band's contribution to the soundtrack for Wes Craven's Dracula 2000 to tide them over lately.

"They're the nicest people," says Chris Ferrara, their long-serving publicist. "It's a matter of opinion how you take in the music, but I think it's fiction, period. They're nice, conservative people, believe it or not."

Devil's own: the music of death
Caroline Sullivan

Birmingham hard rockers Judas Priest, whose releases include the album Killing Machine, were sued over a 1985 suicide pact made by two Nevada schoolboys. One survived, and he and the other boy's parents charged that a 1978 album contained hidden messages. The words "Do it" allegedly can be heard when the record is played backwards, and the letters S U I (for "suicide") are in the sleeve artwork. The case was dismissed after evidence that the boys had grown up in "violent and depressed" surroundings.

Marilyn Manson, who is also known as Antichrist Superstar and the God of Fuck, was blamed by the media for the 1999 Columbine High massacre in which students Dylan Klebold and Eric Harris killed 13 classmates and a teacher. Despite a suicide note left by the pair that said, "Don't blame anyone else for our actions. This is the way we want to go out," Manson's ghoulish image and self-confessed Satanism were thought to have inspired them.

It emerged that they were not fans, but not before Manson was approached by "every media organisation in America" for his reaction. He said the shootings were "horrendous and sad, but they got what they wanted - fame"

Tennessee teenagers Damien Echols, Jessie Misskelley and Jason Baldwin were accused of killing three younger boys. The platinum-selling California thrash-metal act Metallica were implicated when lyrics were found in Echols' diary. The teenagers were found guilty despite lack of evidence.

Heavy metal veteran Ozzy Osbourne has been sued by the parents of three American teenagers who committed suicide after listening to his records. In 1984 a teenage boy shot himself while listening to the song Suicide Solution, which allegedly contained the line "I tell you to end your life." The case was dismissed when it was proved the line was "I tell you to enjoy life."

In 1986, 16-year-old Michael Waller killed himself after telling his father that Osbourne had "the solution". In 1988 a 17-year-old killed himself in his car. An Osbourne live album with tracks such as Shot in the Dark and Road to Nowhere was found in his stereo. Both cases were thrown out of court.

All they care about is money." For their part, Slayer are not talking about the case. But two years ago Paul Bostaph, the drummer, said: "They're trying to blame the whole thing on us. That's such nonsense. If you're gonna do something stupid like that, you should get in trouble for it." He supported Slayer's case by observing that the killers had not done their homework properly: they had failed to follow the rituals of necrophilia sacrifice set out in the songs. The Pahlers are simply the latest bereaved parents to try to hold accountable purveyors of popular, and not so popular, culture for the deaths of their children. Their predecessors include the parents of a 19-year-old who commited suicide after listening to the music of Ozzy Osbourne and the families of children shot in a Kentucky schoolyard who tried to sue the makers of video games. Both cases foundered in the path of the first amendment to the US constitution, which guarantees freedom of expression. The shock-rocker Marilyn Manson, too, was a convenient lightning rod after the Columbine school massacre in Denver, Colorado, nearly two years ago when the fact that the teenage killers were members of a Trenchcoat Mafia appealed to the demand for instant answers. But the California lawsuit is different. Here the lawyers for the Pahlers hope to body-swerve the first amendment by relying on the argument that the companies sold materials harmful to minors in the knowledge that the music's violent creed was simply a tool to sell records. The firm handling the case is Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, who persuaded a court case that the RJ Reynolds Tobacco Co had marketed the Joe Camel character to children. "The distribution and marketing of this obscene and harmful material to adolescent males constituted aiding and abetting of the criminal acts described in this complaint," says the lawsuit. "None of the vicious crimes committed against Elyse Marie Pahler would have occurred without the intentional marketing strategy of the death-metal band Slayer." Attorneys for the band and the music companies - including Def Jam Music, Columbia Records, Sony Music Entertainment and American Recordings - say that Slayer's work is ring-fenced by the right to free speech enshrined in the constitution. No one can be sure that this guarantee is worth what it was. Next month at the Grammys it will become known whether the music industry has found a way to avoid giving one of four awards to the confrontational rapper Eminem, variously hailed as a bigot and the most vital young artist in America or anywhere else. No sooner had he been nominated than there was a foretaste of the ructions to follow, whether he wins or not. "We're not really endorsing him," said Michael Greene, head of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. "There are very few people in this organisation who wouldn't agree that Eminem's record is probably the most repugnant album of the year. However, the craft around it ... it's a remarkable recording." Eminem, born Marshall Mathers, says that his lyrics are not meant to be taken literally, any more than Slayer wish to be certified as necrophilia salesmen. "We're part-evil," says Slayer singer Tom Araya. "If we were really evil, we would be doing everything we're writing about." Naturally, this distinction does not impress David Pahler. "What are we talking about here? We have children ending their lives because the lyrics say they're worthless. It's about money. That's the driving force. I can't imagine the adults in the band, in the distribution end, really think this so-called music or the lyrics are good." His wife Lisanne says: "They have families of their own. Where's their conscience?" Advocates of the first amendment believe that the Slayer case could be a turning point and are not over-confident about the outcome. "We're kidding ourselves if we don't think the cultural climate affects judges and their decisions," says Peter Eliasberg, of the American Civil Liberties Union. "We're getting to the point, if we let these cases go forward, that someone can say [the blaxploitation movie] Shaft glorifies vigilantism. There is a really serious danger to decide to not make a movie or not write a book." That danger, as he perceives it, was not diminished by a report last week from the US surgeon general's office that identified a "scientific link between graphically violent television programming and increased aggression in children." The paper, commissioned by the White House after the Columbine shootings, says: "Research to date justifies sustained efforts to curb the adverse effects of media violence on youths. Although our knowledge is incomplete, it is sufficient to develop a coherent public health approach to violence prevention that builds upon what is known, even as more research is under way." The surgeon-general's finding followed a study last autumn by the federal trade commission which concluded that Hollywood is marketing violent movies to children. Perhaps the starkest if not the best evidence, though, comes not via august government bodies, but rather from Elyse's killers. Delashmutt, now a 21-year-old, says: "It was harmless at first. We used to smoke weed, play guitar, kick it. I was just into heavy-metal music." But Fiorello had taken his hobby further. "It gets inside your head," he told a police counsellor a year after the girl's death. "It's almost embarrassing that I was so influenced by the music. The music started to influence the way I looked at things." Delashmutt says that one day Fiorella asked "if I'd be down for sacrificing a, whatever, a virgin. I didn't take it seriously. I said 'whatever' ". Slayer are in Canada this week, working on the record they hope will become the sixth gold disc by the outfit who have awarded themselves the title of "the world's most grisly band". Other than their back catalogue of collections such as Seasons in the Abyss, Reign in Blood and Diabolus in Musica, fans have had only the band's contribution to the soundtrack for Wes Craven's Dracula 2000 to tide them over lately. "They're the nicest people," says Chris Ferrara, their long-serving publicist. "It's a matter of opinion how you take in the music, but I think it's fiction, period. They're nice, conservative people, believe it or not." Devil's own: the music of death Caroline Sullivan Birmingham hard rockers Judas Priest, whose releases include the album Killing Machine, were sued over a 1985 suicide pact made by two Nevada schoolboys. One survived, and he and the other boy's parents charged that a 1978 album contained hidden messages. The words "Do it" allegedly can be heard when the record is played backwards, and the letters S U I (for "suicide") are in the sleeve artwork. The case was dismissed after evidence that the boys had grown up in "violent and depressed" surroundings. Marilyn Manson, who is also known as Antichrist Superstar and the God of Fuck, was blamed by the media for the 1999 Columbine High massacre in which students Dylan Klebold and Eric Harris killed 13 classmates and a teacher. Despite a suicide note left by the pair that said, "Don't blame anyone else for our actions. This is the way we want to go out," Manson's ghoulish image and self-confessed Satanism were thought to have inspired them. It emerged that they were not fans, but not before Manson was approached by "every media organisation in America" for his reaction. He said the shootings were "horrendous and sad, but they got what they wanted - fame" Tennessee teenagers Damien Echols, Jessie Misskelley and Jason Baldwin were accused of killing three younger boys. The platinum-selling California thrash-metal act Metallica were implicated when lyrics were found in Echols' diary. The teenagers were found guilty despite lack of evidence. Heavy metal veteran Ozzy Osbourne has been sued by the parents of three American teenagers who committed suicide after listening to his records. In 1984 a teenage boy shot himself while listening to the song Suicide Solution, which allegedly contained the line "I tell you to end your life." The case was dismissed when it was proved the line was "I tell you to enjoy life." In 1986, 16-year-old Michael Waller killed himself after telling his father that Osbourne had "the solution". In 1988 a 17-year-old killed himself in his car. An Osbourne live album with tracks such as Shot in the Dark and Road to Nowhere was found in his stereo. Both cases were thrown out of court.

fields.headline: Europe struggles to coordinate immigration
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Spain's controversial new immigration laws may herald a tougher approach in Europe as individual governments and the EU struggle to formulate more coherent policies.
fields.body:
Spain's controversial new immigration laws may herald a tougher approach in Europe as individual governments and the EU struggle to formulate more coherent policies.

The EU estimates that 500,000 illegal immigrants arrived last year, up from an estimated 40,000 in 1993.

Everywhere the issue poses serious questions about human rights and racism, and whether national social and employ ment strategies are coordinated with immigration policies.

With ageing populations, plummeting birthrates and high pension costs, EU governments recognise that the old policies aimed at zero immigration are no longer an answer. All, however, face problems if they move to forge common policies. It is a highly charged issue: in Italy, Austria, France and Belgium, immigrants serve as a way for rightwing extremists to exploit concerns about the erosion of national identity and rising welfare burdens.

Protests erupted in Germany when the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, announced a plan to recruit information technology specialists from India.

In Britain the talk is now of immigration management instead of immigration control, but still the government refuses to join the EU's Schengen system of passport-free travel.

In Brussels, the EU's headquarters, the strategy is to seek alternatives to policies that compel people to risk illegal entry. EU members are being asked to issue reports on immigration policy - with the numbers of third-country nationals and where they work - and on future policy intentions.

Ministers are to discuss progress when they meet in Sweden next month.

"These issues can no longer be dealt with on a purely national basis," one official said. "They really have to be handled on a European level. But this is not an area where it is easy to set common standards, like you can with plugs or microwaves."

webTitle: New technology creates a 'larger rift between rich and poor'

fields.headline: New technology creates a 'larger rift between rich and poor'
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Large areas of the world have missed out on the information revolution, threatening to widen the gap between rich and poor unless governments take urgent action to bridge the digital divide, a report warns today.
fields.body:
Large areas of the world have missed out on the information revolution, threatening to widen the gap between rich and poor unless governments take urgent action to bridge the digital divide, a report warns today.

In its annual World Employment Report*, the International Labour Organisation says information and communications technology (ICT) has created jobs and spurred growth in industrialised countries but has yet to fully penetrate the developing world.

Even within countries in which it has made a difference, there is a "digital gender divide", with men tending to occupy the better paid hi-tech jobs and women stuck in low level positions.

"The ICT revolution offers genuine potential, but also raises the risk that a significant portion of the world will lose out," said Juan Somavia, ILO director general.

"Let us strip out the hype. What is left? What's left is its effects on peoples' lives, wherever they live. We need to promote policies and develop institutions which let everybody benefit. And it won't happen on its own."

The report says that despite an improving global employment situation, there are still some 160m people officially unemployed at the beginning of 2001 - 20m more than before the onset of the Asian financial crisis in 1997 - while many millions more suffer from underemployment.

While unemployment in OECD countries has declined sharply from the double digit figures of the mid-90s, about 500m workers in the developing world are still unable to earn enough to keep their families above the poverty line, at $1a day.

With some economists forecasting a recession in the US, the ILO says the prospects for the future depend very much on whether the present global expansion can be maintained.

It expects growth to carry on reducing unemployment, but urges government to adopt the right policies to ensure the benefits of ICT are spread more evenly. These include investing in skills; giving women more opportunity; lowering telecoms costs through more competition; using ICT to improve health care, education and other social services; and focusing on basic education before "digital literacy".

*World Employment Report 2001 - Life at work in the information economy; International Labour Office; telephone 020 7828 6401

webTitle: Bonelli resignation fails to save Sema from mauling

fields.headline: Bonelli resignation fails to save Sema from mauling
fields.trailText: Sema, the troubled Anglo-French IT services group, lurched deeper into crisis yesterday after a second profits warning in two months prompted a further sell-off of its depressed shares.
fields.body:
Sema, the troubled Anglo-French IT services group, lurched deeper into crisis yesterday after a second profits warning in two months prompted a further sell-off of its depressed shares.

A surprise statement that revenues for the second half of 2000 would be below expectations and that further explanation would not be provided until February 20 left analysts and investors furious.

Even confirmation that the much criticised chief executive, Pierre Bonelli, is preparing to step down could not stem a 12% fall in Sema shares, which closed off 47.5p at 353.5p, valuing them at one sixth of the level they traded at less than a year ago.

"A second profits warning in two months does little for the company's credibility," said WestLB Panmure analyst Finlay Thomson.

Instead of the 30% profits growth seen in the previous three years, profits for 2000 are likely to come in flat, at £90-95m, Sema said.

The company hopes that growth will climb by 12% in the following year - although analysts are increasingly doubtful of the company's ability to deliver.

"Until several strategic and operational issues are resolved, I wouldn't want to own the stock," said another analyst.

At the core of Sema's problems remains its controversial £3.3bn summer acquisition of LHS, an American mobile phone billing firm, which was widely seen as the reason behind Mr Bonelli's decision to step down.

He will eventually be replaced by a new chief operating officer - once someone of suitable calibre can be found to fill the post.

Analysts blamed LHS for "contaminating" Sema's previously strong telecoms division, which now faces a restructuring. This could result in some skilled staff deciding to leave the firm.

The division's poor perfor mance forced Sema to warn about falling profits in November, and triggered a 44% slump in Sema's share price.

A week previously LHS's founder and a Sema non-executive, Hartmut Lademacher, had sold £24m worth of Sema shares, breaching stock exchange rules. Outraged investors forced him to resign shortly afterwards.

Several large shareholders in Sema - including France Telecom, BNP Paribas and fund manager Fidelity - are thought to have added their weight to calls for Mr Bonelli and Mr Lademacher to go.

Other shareholders, angry at the way in which the LHS acquisition has destroyed the value of their holdings, are thought to be considering legal action against Sema.

The decline in the Sema share price saw it lose its position in the FTSE 100 at the last quarterly review.

Some sector watchers believe Sema is now a takeover target, with Cap Gemini Ernst & Young being touted as a potential bidder.

The alternative telecoms provider, Dataflex, issued a profits warning yesterday only days after highly placed company sources were attempting to talk up the performance of the company.

Shares fell 37% to 97.5p after the company said turnover and profit in the second half were expected to be "significantly lower than recent market expectations".

First half pretax profit was up 276% at £7.6m.

The slump could force the company to abandon its plans for consolidation in the sector, and it could itself become a takeover target instead.

webTitle: Dreamcast heads for defeat in console wars

fields.headline: Dreamcast heads for defeat in console wars
fields.standfirst: Sega agrees to make game software for rivals Sony and Microsoft
fields.trailText: Sonic the Hedgehog is about to be squashed by the PlayStation2 juggernaut, according to reports in Tokyo yesterday.
fields.body:
Sonic the Hedgehog is about to be squashed by the PlayStation2 juggernaut, according to reports in Tokyo yesterday.

Sega, which is the company behind Sonic and the Dreamcast console, is said to have agreed to make software for its rivals, Sony and Microsoft, in a deal that may represent the first white flag in the video game console war.

After losing more than two-thirds of its value in the past year, Sega's share price surged more than 18% following the report, which investors took as a sign that the firm would scale down or abandon its loss-making Dreamcast operation.

According to the Jiji newswire, Sega will announce a business plan this month to provide software for the PlayStation2, made by Sony, and possibly for XBox, which will be launched by Microsoft in the autumn.

Such a move would raise questions about the future of the Dreamcast, which has failed to meet consumer and business expectations since its launch in 1999 as the world's first 128-bit, internet compatible console.

The fate of the Dreamcast depended on how much of a head start it could get against market leader Sony - which has more marketing muscle, greater technological expertise and deeper pockets.

But despite deep price cuts and a multibillion-pound global marketing campaign - including sponsorship of premier league football team Arsenal - sales of the console have fallen more than 1m short of projections.

Since the debut of the PlayStation2 last year, Sega has been bleeding money trying to keep its console alive.

Last year, Sega lost more than £200m - its third year in the red. Analysts expect the financial damage to be even greater this year.

The situation is likely to worsen after October, when two new, powerful competitors will enter the already crowded market.

As well as Microsoft's XBox, Nintendo is planning to launch a new console, the GameCube, which will be compatible with its Gameboy handset.

Rumours have been circulating around Tokyo for months that Sega will either be bought up by a rival - Nintendo is said to have put in an offer - or be forced to re-invent itself as a purely software operation.

The latter would play to Sega's strengths. The company has 800 of the world's top game creators - more than Sony or Nintendo - and they have produced a string of hit games and characters, such as Sonic the Hedgehog, that rivals would love to offer on their systems.

Sega would not comment on yesterday's reports, but in the past the company has insisted that even if it provided games for rival consoles it would never abandon its own hardware business.

Sony refused to confirm that such an agreement had been reached, but a spokesman said a deal would have many advantages.

"This is a welcome move for PlayStation2.

"Sega has excellent software technology and a pool of popular game software."

webTitle: Rage on hold but it's game over for Barrysworld

fields.headline: Rage on hold but it's game over for Barrysworld
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The troubled computer games sector slipped further into the doldrums yesterday when publisher Rage said profits would be lower than expected and an online gaming site, Barrysworld, called in liquidators.
fields.body:
The troubled computer games sector slipped further into the doldrums yesterday when publisher Rage said profits would be lower than expected and an online gaming site, Barrysworld, called in liquidators.

Rage shares slipped 1.75p to a year's low of 10p after admitting delays to the launch of Sony's PlayStation2 had affected sales and the development of five new games would be stopped because they were unlikely to be mass sellers. Wild Wild Racing, a game published to coincide with the launch of PS2, was particularly badly hit by the delay.

Chief executive Paul Finnegan and chairman Thomas Roberts demonstrated their faith in the company's ability to recover with the purchase of 360,000 shares. "We're feel ing the pain at the moment but it will get better as the new consoles hit the shops," Mr Finnegan said. "We're probably at the bottom of what is likely to be the greatest cycle this industry has seen. Rage's plan has not changed.

"We will continue to take greater control of our destiny by publishing and not just developing games. Taking this opportunity to clear out the games that looked like they weren't shaping up makes a great deal of sense."

Optimism that the sector will recover appeared not to be shared by the principal backer of Barrysworld, venture capital group 3i. It has decided to pull the plug on the four-year-old firm, which allows gamers to play against each other on the internet. All 35 staff will lose their jobs.

"Those that have tried to survive on the funding from dial-up call revenue and/or advertising are dead or in their death throes - this market has collapsed," said Ade Brownlow, chief executive of Barrysworld. "It is simply not feasible to run gaming services with a long-term future on this model." Insolvency specialists Fischer Partners have been brought in and the site, which claims to have attracted more than 300,000 players, will shut on February 5.

Online gaming is seen as the future of the industry, with Datamonitor believing the sub-sector could be worth $6bn by 2004. Operators are struggling to make a profit from it while internet access speeds remain slow. Interactive television and mobile phones are considered more likely platforms for long-term success of online gaming.

fields.headline: Yesterday in parliament
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Liberal democrat peers. Lord Rodgers and his party led opposition to procedural changes that supporters said would allow peers living far from London to get away early on Wednesday nights. Opponents feared it would reduce attendance for debates and effectively put the house on a three day week. Tory leader Lord Strathclyde joked that it was the first Liberal victory in the Lords for nearly 100 years.

Today

Commons : Northern Ireland questions . PM's questions. Opposition debates on manufacturing job losses, and government's "failure" to deliver its public health agenda.

Lords: Debates on recent constitutional developments, disadvantaged young men, the coroner service, and multi-faith Britain.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Minister pleads for Corus jobs
fields.body:
Minister pleads for Corus jobs

Steel firm Corus is in the mood for making a "ruthless" commercial decision about the future of the company, a government minister said last night after making a last-minute plea aimed at saving jobs.

A frantic round of talks failed to secure any denial from the company that it plans to axe several thousand jobs, mainly in Wales and northern England.

Welsh first minister Rhodri Morgan said that his meeting with Corus chairman Sir Brian Moffat had not been very fruitful, but he pledged to continue lobbying until the announcement is made. Sir Brian told him a final decision on job losses had not been made, fuelling speculation that the announcement will be made next week.

Manchester Metro deal

Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian, yesterday announced a deal with Daily Mail & General Trust to produce a Manchester version of the free London Metro paper.

Editorial will come from DMGT's Associated Newspapers, while GMG will handle publishing, printing and distribution.

GMG, which is licensing the title to Associated, publishes the Manchester Evening News and 30 weekly papers in the area.

Metro has also been launched in Birmingham, Newcastle, Leeds, Sheffield, Glasgow and Edinburgh.

Aeroflot hopes to fly green flag

Aeroflot announced yesterday that it is in talks on buying a stake in budget carrier Virgin Express Ireland that could open up new European routes to the Russian company.

The European Union's open skies agreement allows EU-licensed carriers to fly to any European destination if the route generates sufficient traffic and airport space is available.

Former BoS governor dies

Sir Alistair Grant, governor chairman of the Bank of Scotland until May 1999, died on Monday night after a long battle with illness. Sir Alistair, a core member of Scotland's business community, was also deputy chairman of Scottish & Newcastle, the brewery group.

He stepped down as governor of the BoS due to poor health in May 1999 and moved down from chairman to deputy chairman of Scottish & Newcastle in July 2000.

Ship firm drops Cammell order

The Italian company in dispute with Cammell Laird over an extension to the cruise ship Costa Classica cancelled the order yesterday, increasing fears for the Birkenhead shipyard on Merseyside.

The company, Costa Crociere, said it had little choice but to terminate the £51m deal with Cammell, claiming there was no chance that the yard would be capable of completing the contract to Costa's satisfaction.

Union leaders expressed outrage and observers said the situation raised questions about the yard's ability to survive. The yard had been due to start the work when the ship turned round en route to England in November.

webTitle: Chemistry set to work in Munich

fields.headline: Chemistry set to work in Munich
fields.trailText: The Chemistry, a London networking forum for entrepreneurs and venture capital investors, is bucking the trend surrounding technology start-ups by today making its first foray into Europe.
fields.body:
The Chemistry, a London networking forum for entrepreneurs and venture capital investors, is bucking the trend surrounding technology start-ups by today making its first foray into Europe.

The launch in Munich is the first step in the company's planned European expansion this year. The Chemistry plans to move to Paris, Madrid, Milan and cities in Scandinavia.

"It is going to be a pan-European network in the cities where the venture capitalists are, and we are going to increase our number of partners," said Mark Simon, the group's founder and chief executive.

The Chemistry, which was founded just over a year ago and had its first event in London in December 1999, claims to be the thriving, upper class version of First Tuesday, the networking group.

"Its like a Groucho club for venture capitalists and entrepreneurs," said Mr Simon.

The forum for networking, training and matchmaking in Munich will, claims The Chemistry, be the "only place for German entrepreneurs to meet with investors".

"We believe Munich's thriving venture capital community is the perfect environment for The Chemistry and is at the right stage of its development for us to make the greatest difference," Mr Simon insisted.

The firm brings together what it claims are "top-notch" venture capitalists with vetted start-ups and "serial entrepreneurs" at its invitation-only events where, The Chemistry says, there is a one-to-one ratio of investor to entrepreneur.

The Chemistry, which holds monthly events at the Imagination gallery in London, puts on training sessions for start-ups - what it calls a "bootcamp" - and a clinic where start-ups are matched to investors and advisers.

Unlike First Tuesday, the networking group that has an estimated 100,000 members internationally but is struggling because of funding problems, Mr Simon says The Chemistry is going strong.

"It is more popular than ever. We have between 170 and 240 people at our events each month. It is always very busy. New entrepreneurs come along every time."

The Chemistry generates revenues from partners such as Oracle, Cable & Wireless, and WestLB Panmure, which pay for brand association and access to the community. The company, which is profitable and employs nine people, has 10 partners at present and revenues of £1.5m a year.

First Tuesday 's owner, the Israeli incubator Yazam, is experiencing financial difficulties. Members of the First Tuesday network were last night waiting to find out whether their offer to buy back the organisation from Yazam would be accepted.

Susan Kisch, who runs Zurich's First Tuesday, and her north of England equivalent Adam Sherlock have offered a small sum to take First Tuesday off troubled Yazam's hands.

About 10 other parties are thought to have expressed an interest in buying the networking group, but selling it to its members is likely to be the cleanest and easiest option.

fields.headline: We must save the dome for sport and rock concerts
fields.standfirst:
The Legacy bid takes this architectural wonder away from us forever
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The Legacy bid takes this architectural wonder away from us forever.
fields.body:
In the early morning rush-hour yesterday not one other soul stepped off the train at Greenwich North: this architectural wonder of a new tube station was empty. Under a wide, windswept sky the dome's great peninsula on the Thames lies deserted. Richard Rogers's iridescent jellyfish hovers there as dazzling as ever with its jutting yellow masts, a famous London landmark now. Forget its hollow contents - at night with the lights playing on the roof, it was as romantic and magical a sight as any in the capital. From the air foreigners arriving lean over and point to it in delighted recognition.

But there are now only two weeks left before the government sells it off at a knock down price to the first company willing to take it off its hands fast. The dome is synonymous with disaster. Misfortune, miscalculation, mediocrity and mistake marked its miserable life so far. What government wouldn't want to be rid of it before an election? Even now, further revelation of the Mandelson/Hinduja connection rips another hole in the dome's reputation: the raising of £1m for the abysmal faith zone returns to haunt the place. The National Audit Office looms, scrutinising everything that was done and not done as lottery millions poured in month after month last year.

Robert Bourne's Legacy bid itself is tainted by a fat donation given by him to Labour party funds and a big birthday party thrown for Peter Mandelson. The place is a haunted political graveyard. No wonder they are eager to privatise it quick. But that would be the last and worst mistake of all.

After Nomura pulled out of its plan to keep the dome as a public theme park, Robert Bourne and his Legacy consortium seemed to be all that was left. So they got "preferred bidder" status, allowing them to continue negotiating without competition. Their bid is for a "hi-tech business park", which means filling the dome with modern offices. Their spokesman speaks of "major IT companies, professional services, lawyers, accountants and academic institutions" who have expressed an interest in moving in. Some of them will have technology on display for members of the public interested in viewing their products. Otherwise it will be closed, a private space for ever.

Once sold off, there will never again be a chance to keep this beautiful building on the one of the most dramatic London sites as a public leisure, exhibition and entertainment centre. It has - at great cost - the best transport links, including the river. The leisure industry, say the economists, is the future. London has no other space like it, desperately short of good concert venues compared with every other European capital. The dismal dinge of Wembley Arena, Earls Court or Olympia can't begin to compete with either the glamour or ease of access of the dome. Pop and mega-classical concertgoers, along with sports fans, have always had to suffer miserable journeys and horrible conditions. Here, already paid for by us, is a place with every comfort and facility. Don't let them sell it off.

PY Gerbeau, until last week the dome's ebullient chief executive, thinks it can be saved. He had to stay silent until his contract ended, but by then Legacy had its peculiar "preferred bidder" status: his case may never be put. He has a major financial institution backing him, he has done the sums - and he knows the costings well. The government is full of praise for the way he stemmed the haemorrhage of money from the dome in the final months.

But will they listen - or will they hasten to be rid of it to Legacy? PY plans to run it as a visitor attraction in the day with the present contents enhanced: in the evenings it will be a concert and sports venue. He will build a hotel and conference centre and use the land around the dome as a village of themed restaurants and attractions - no housing or offices. He claims he will get 3m visitors a year and make a profit after two years. He will even offer the government more money than Legacy's timid £50m up front and £100m later. But he needs the attractions inside - especially the dazzling body zone sculpture (one of the few things of beauty). However, along with other key zones, the body will be demolished in two weeks. Will the government stay its hand and consider the PY bid?

The government is now legally bound not to even speak with other bidders. It says it must consider whether Legacy is the best value. But how is that judged without considering alternatives, and above all the public interest? The public has punted up the cash and must have an interest in keeping this great national asset for their own pleasure: £150m is peanuts compared with the near £1bn already spent, when the dome could be secured as a public amenity for ever.

The key to all this is property value. Hotly though they deny it, there is a canny suspicion that the Legacy bid will end up as a property deal. The invaluable land around the dome will be developed, the "hi-tech" park within may never quite materialise, never quite find all these tenants it promises. Unused, the dome would dilapidate until someone someday makes a fortune out of the land it stands on. Like the non-development of Battersea power station up-river, glittering promises from developers are not always all they seem. But even if Legacy does all it says, it still shuts down a public place.

Gerbeau's scheme also buys the site, but at least he keeps it as a public space (sale conditions should insist on that in perpetuity). Better still, PY would be quite happy to rent the dome for a fixed number of years which keeps open the option of returning it to public ownership at some future date - if ever an Olympic or World Cup bid required it. The land around is so valuable some could be sold off to create a trust fund for the dome's future. There are much more imaginative ways of saving the dome than selling it off in a hurry to Legacy. By now that will also be the worst political option, the one most likely to dog the government at the election: added to the breath of sleaze will be a grotesque mishandling of a priceless public asset.

Politicians always lag behind the public mood, out of fashion, fighting old battles instead of facing future challenges. This government's 90s mindset still wrestles with clause 4 versus privatisation - dead ducks both. Money is poured into Railtrack in exchange for nothing at all, as if afraid that buying back shares in it is socialism incarnate. They are still trying to sell off the tube and air traffic control against passionate public opposition. Now they want to sell off one of the finest heritage sites in London, just as the Tories very nearly sold off half the National Gallery - saved only by Sainsburys. Mrs Thatcher left behind no monuments but despite its accursed first year, Tony Blair might live to be proud of this one yet.

webTitle: Pupils to be steered into vocational path at 14

fields.headline: Pupils to be steered into vocational path at 14
fields.standfirst:
Pupils to be steered into vocational path at 14
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Labour is planning an ambitious second-term transformation of Britain's secondary schools which will give 14-year-olds the option of a vocational path and will aim to "customise" qualifications to meet the needs of each pupil - and the economy.
fields.body:
Labour is planning an ambitious second-term transformation of Britain's secondary schools which will give 14-year-olds the option of a vocational path and will aim to "customise" qualifications to meet the needs of each pupil - and the economy.

As Tony Blair shifts the focus of his declared number one priority from primary to secondary education, the government is intent on overhauling the GCSE system in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, will today promise a big expansion of vocational GCSEs, which are being introduced in 2002 in an effort to address skills shortages. They could lead to foundation apprenticeships for 16-18 year olds and on to post-18 modern apprenticeships.

Ministers are introducing a "complete reshaping of training programmes for young people", a source close to Mr Blunkett said last night. "For the first time in British education we will have a coherent system of vocational study so schools don't see it as something that is second best."

In Labour's manifesto, state schools will be urged to let their brightest students take GCSEs at 15 - giving them time to take more A-levels, AS levels and the new "world class" advanced extension awards. A key theme of the manifesto will be to raise the achievement of pupils at all levels who "coast" because their work is not demanding enough.

Labour is also likely to be accused of attempting to engineer a "two-tier" qualifications system at 14, by allowing pupils to take a vocational route and ignore traditional subjects.

But ministers argue that it does the reverse, moving away from the emphasis on academic qualifications, which already alienates many youngsters. Instead they will be offered a choice, where some students would take solely traditional GCSEs, some would take a mixture of academic and vocational GCSEs, and some would take all vocational GCSEs with the exception of English, maths and science.

One senior official said last night that the government was determined to rid students of the notion they could follow just two routes: one to higher education, or one to work.

Many educationists recognise the flaws in the current system but unions are likely to complain about further pressure on already overworked staff.

Currently, students can take up to 14 intermediate vocational GNVQ qualifications. But small employers in particular have been reluctant to recognise them and they still suffer from the stigma of being less demanding than GCSEs. In pilot schemes, about 50,000 youngsters are already taking work-related study programmes from aged 14. Vocational A-levels began last September in the new post-16 curriculum.

Some schools already do offer a mixture of vocational and academic qualifications, and set GCSEs early for some pupils. But with government weight behind it, the practice could be extended to most and perhaps all state schools.

Ministers have heard arguments from David Hargreaves, head of the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority (QCA), that the academic GCSE turns off many students. And some schools have complained that it is not demanding enough for its brightest pupils.

Labour has already announced plans to introduce national tests in the basics for students at 14, following on from the tests at 7 and 11 in primary schools. The QCA is developing computer-based problem-solving tests for the brightest pupils at 9 and 13, part of a "suite" of demanding tests alongside the advanced extension awards. It will put pressure on youngsters in the academic "dip" between 11 and 14, whose academic performance stagnates and sometimes gets worse.

Labour's election manifesto will extend the themes of excellence through diversity and targeted money. Another key plank of the manifesto, the excellence in cities programme, which will cover 1,000 secondary schools by September, gives itself glowing praise in a government report published today. The rise in the proportion of those achieving five good GCSEs at 16 was almost double the national average in excellence in cities areas.

The government claims that statistics on exam results released yesterday also disproves the case of those who argue that GCSEs are being debased by "grade inflation". Black and Indian students, and students from working class backgrounds, saw their GCSE results rise by nearly three times the national average between 1997 and 1999.

fields.headline: Germany woos Blair on EU
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Germany is to make a determined push to resolve the future shape of Europe in a series of consultations with Britain, starting today when the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, arrives in London.
fields.byline: John Hooper in Berlin and Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Germany is to make a determined push to resolve the future shape of Europe in a series of consultations with Britain, starting today when the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, arrives in London.

With the Franco-German axis - until now, the driving force behind European integration - visibly fractured, Berlin is exploring new patterns of alliance within the European Union.

Mr Fischer's visit is sensitive because he has emerged as a prime target for British Euro-sceptics after making an unashamed case for European federalism last year.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, is to fly to Berlin for a dinner with the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, on Monday. Officials in Berlin said last night that the get-together had been prompted by the crisis in relations with Paris.

French and German leaders are to discuss their divergent views at an emergency summit meeting on January 31, in Strasbourg. Their relations have been strained since the Nice summit in December that left them at loggerheads over the pace of integration.

Government sources in Berlin said that, ahead of that potentially tricky encounter, Mr Schröder was hoping to find common ground with Mr Blair.

fields.headline: Pompous made perfect by Cook, Maude and Vaz
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Foreign Office questions are covered in a haze of pomposity which simply couldn't exist if MPs were talking about domestic affairs.
fields.body:
Turkey, Israel, Greece, Palestine, Colombia, Cuba, Sierra Leone, Iran, Poland, France, Sweden, North Korea, Western Sahara, South Africa, Tibet, Zimbabwe, Congo, Denmark, China, Iraq and the United States - just some of the countries MPs felt obliged to sound off about yesterday during questions to the foreign secretary.

The empire may be no more, but if every nation into which our legislators felt they had a duty to stick their noses were coloured pink on the map, it would look like a curtain swag selected by Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen.

The result is that Foreign Office questions are covered in a haze of pomposity which simply couldn't exist if MPs were talking about domestic affairs. When members are telling foreigners what to do, their voices become deeper and more orotund, their cadences more measured, their style becomes that of a Victorian housemaster explaining to some wretched youth why he must be thrashed.

When Robin Cook faces his Tory opposite number, Francis Maude, the effect is even more dramatic - like watching sumo wrestling in slow motion. The grandees circle each other slowly, watching their footwork, hoping to grasp the other and suddenly inflict the crucial hold.

For example, after a long discussion on the Middle East, in which it was agreed that everyone should try to get along and stop killing each other, Mr Maude rose to ask if the foreign secretary acknowledged - please take a deep breath here - "that Britain, with its record of support for Israel and its long history of involvement with Arab states, is uniquely well-placed to exert influence. So why is it that people on all sides in the region now feel that Britain is failing to live up to its historic role?"

Really? On the West Bank, do stone-throwing youths ask when the British tommies will return? Do Israeli hardliners secretly wish that Peter Hain would arrive like a deus ex machina and fulfil Britain's historic role?

But Mr Maude had not finished. It turned out that he wasn't actually talking about the Middle East at all. "If he understood a bit better what Britain has been, he might understand a bit better what Britain can be, and the role it has to play as a confident and independent country in the world!"

In other words, this was an elegy for a lost nation, hence an attack on the EU which, as we all know, is taking away our sausages, imperial measures, army and historic role. (And replacing our historic rolls with baguettes, ciabatta and inedible pumpernickel.)

But when it comes to pompous, nobody can touch Robin Cook. Mr Cook, who in private is a cheery, affable soul, does pompous-plus - pompous with added spinach, pomposity which makes Sir Peter Tatchell sound like Norman Wisdom.

"I would congratulate the House, until now, for we have had a sober, non-partisan discussion of a real issue. I do think it is deplorable that it should be rounded off by an opposition front bench seeking to turn it to party political advantage.

"I. Do. Not. Propose to respond in the tone or in the style of the opposition spokesman. All he has done is to demonstrate that he is unfit ever to hold the office of Foreign Secretary!"

Mr Maude was left, totally out-pompoused, panting for breath on the mat.

Later we heard from Mr Keith Vaz, a minister so pompous that if you squeezed him, pomposity would shoot out like pus from a zit.

At one point he had to refer to the mass slaughter of Armenians by Turks in the last century. "It was a sad event, a sensitive event in the history of Armenia," he averred.

And the Holocaust was a "sensitive" event in the history of the Jews, I suppose.

webTitle: Tories forced to drop key spending claim

fields.headline: Tories forced to drop key spending claim
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague's tax and spending plans suffered a new blow last night when it emerged that the Tory leader has been forced to abandon a claim that Labour is over-spending by the equivalent of £600 for every taxpayer in Britain.
fields.body:
William Hague's tax and spending plans suffered a new blow last night when it emerged that the Tory leader has been forced to abandon a claim that Labour is over-spending by the equivalent of £600 for every taxpayer in Britain. As the battle over tax and spending intensified yesterday, the Tory leadership admitted that the figure was overblown and had been quietly shelved.

In an attempt to whet the public's appetite for tax cuts during last July's government spending round, the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, claimed that Gordon Brown's spending plans had spiralled out of control to the tune of £600 per taxpayer. This works out at £16bn.

Labour yesterday distributed a copy of a Portillo press release from last July, which unveiled the £600 figure, in an attempt to show that the Tories will impose £16bn of cuts in public services - double the amount pledged by Mr Hague. The Tories, who are determined to rebut Labour's warn ings of swingeing cuts, were forced last night to concede that they no longer stood by the £600 claim. A spokesman said: "That figure was an illustrative figure used at that time [in July]."

The spokesman said that Mr Portillo had come up with his original claim when he was planning to cut £16bn from public services. However, this has been trimmed back to £8bn over the past few months because Mr Portillo has decided that the cuts should be phased in.

Under his plans, a Tory government would stick to Labour's spending plans for its first year in office. The cuts would be introduced on a phased basis in the second year, with the full £8bn of cuts being introduced by the third year. "We will plot a path," one source said. "We will not try to rip up public spending immediately."

The Tories' admission last night added to the sense that the leadership has worked out its tax and spending plans in a haphazard way. Labour accused the Tories of drawing up its plans on the back of the envelope after Mr Hague was forced to double the number of areas in which he would ringfence Labour's spending plans.

However, the Tories will hope that their decision to abandon their claim on the government's increased tax burden will severely undermine Labour's claim that their cuts will amount to £16bn. "By scrabbling around in the wastepaper bin picking out old press releases shows how Labour have mucked this one up," one Tory source said. "They rushed out the £16bn figure and now it does not stand up."

Labour stuck to its guns yesterday as it unveiled a nationwide poster campaign which claims that the Tories will be forced to impose cuts on schools and hospitals - areas supposedly ringfenced - to meet their £16bn of cuts. Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, said: "However much they try to deny and evade the simple fact is that the only way they can make their figures add up is to make massive cuts to public spending."

webTitle: Internet twins to stay in care

fields.headline: Internet twins to stay in care
fields.standfirst:
Judge orders Kilshaws not to discuss case as court gathers information

Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The internet twins at the centre of a complex custody battle will remain in temporary foster care, a judge ruled yesterday during a hearing held in private.
fields.body:
The internet twins at the centre of a complex custody battle will remain in temporary foster care, a judge ruled yesterday during a hearing held in private.

Sitting at Birmingham high court, Mr Justice Kirkwood succeeded in effectively silencing Alan and Judith Kilshaw, the adoptive parents from north Wales who have been in the public eye for eight days.

The judge received a solemn undertaking from the couple during the short hearing that they would not discuss any of the arrangements for the twins with anyone not involved with the court. He said if anyone was foolish enough to publish information relating to the hearing, they would be in contempt.

On their way into court, the Kilshaws had been as vocal as ever. Mrs Kilshaw, 47, said: "We are going to go for it. I am not giving up. We are fighting for everybody that has had children taken off them by social services. British people should listen to me and my husband and help us and support us."

Her husband, Alan, 45, added that he would be happy for the children to be made wards of court.

More than four hours later, after promising not to discuss the case, the couple left the building.

"No comment," said Mrs Kilshaw, as she was followed by a scrum of journalists, photographers and camera crews. She was heckled by passersby who called her a witch, following reports at the weekend that she had dabbled in witchcraft.

The judge ruled that the six-month-old baby girls should be the subject of an interim care order and remain under the care of the court. But they were not made wards of court.

Mr Justice Kirkwood said: "It is not just English law that I have to consider, but the position also in one, two or perhaps three states of the United States of America.

"In human terms, there are obviously various conflicting interests and claims. I am sure that everybody understands that the court's task is to do its best to find the right solution for the twins. It is their welfare that really matters in all of this."

He said it had become perfectly clear that to get the right solution some calm, responsible research was needed. He said he had asked the official solicitor to assist the court, because he would be able to participate in the necessary research in Britain and the US with entire impartiality.

"I do not intend to allow this research to take a very long time," he said. "We must make haste but we must do so carefully and conscientiously.

"While that is being done, it is absolutely imperative that the twins, who are presently being well looked after, are left in peace."

He said the social workers, the people looking after the babies, and the lawyers should be left to do their jobs.

The judge's ruling replaces the emergency protection order obtained by Flintshire county council last Thursday.

The twins were taken into care by police and social services late last Thursday and placed with temporary foster parents while the Kilshaws were staying at a hotel in Mold.

The Kilshaws had urged the local authority to allow the babies to stay with them while their future was decided.

The couple bought the six-month-old twin girls from a Californian baby-broker in December last year and adopted them in Arkansas.

Yesterday it emerged from the Legal Services Commission that the Kilshaws would automatically be entitled to legal aid to pay for their costs because of the nature of the proceedings. No legal aid application had been received.

 Bailiffs arrived at Mr Kilshaw's home in Buckley, north Wales, yesterday to repossess a touring caravan, alleging the finance had not been kept up. At the same time a speeding charge against him was adjourned in his absence at Flintshire magistrates' court. Mr Kilshaw is alleged to have driven at 46mph in a 30mph zone on the A 541 at Mold.

More net news

fields.headline: Fur protesters sabotage Chanel website
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Anti-fur protesters hacked into Chanel's website yesterday and accused the French fashion house's designers of being murderers.
fields.body:
Anti-fur protesters hacked into Chanel's website yesterday and accused the French fashion house's designers of being murderers.

Shortly before the morning showing in Paris where Chanel unveiled its spring-summer collection on the catwalk, gory images of animals were posted on its website by campaigners.

"We had a hacker," a Chanel spokeswoman said. "We closed the site and are going to conduct an investigation."

There was no fur on display on the catwalk when the Chanel show was opened by the designer Karl Lagerfeld. At the launch of Christian Dior's collection in Paris on Monday, fur accessories by the British designer John Galliano were on view. Guests including the actress Liv Tyler, French news reader Claire Chazal and Heini Al Fayed, wife of the Harrod's owner, saw items including racoon hats and fox fur stoles.

France has more hunters than any other EU country and Britain's agonising over whether to ban fox hunting is regarded with puzzlement.

webTitle: Mona Lisa gets salon with a view at Louvre

fields.headline: Mona Lisa gets salon with a view at Louvre
fields.trailText: Maybe it will make her smile properly for once. The Mona Lisa is finally to get a room of her own. As part of a £15m expansion and restoration of the Louvre in Paris, the room in which Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece hangs will be divided in two, making it easier to see the painting.
fields.body:
Maybe it will make her smile properly for once. The Mona Lisa is finally to get a room of her own. As part of a £15m expansion and restoration of the Louvre in Paris, the room in which Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece hangs will be divided in two, making it easier to see the painting.

The project announced yesterday by the Louvre's head, Pierre Rosenberg, is good news, too, for fans of Venetian Renaissance paintings. For years they have had to crane to glimpse their favourite canvasses through dense crowds of tourists gawping at the Mona Lisa.

From 2003 onwards, when redesign work at the museum is due to be complete, such neglected Venetian works as Veronese's The Marriage at Cana will have a room to themselves.

The gallery of ancient Greek sculptures that houses the Venus de Milo will be spruced up, too. But the biggest single work of restoration will be on the dilapidated Apollo gallery, the model for Louis XIV's Hall of Mirrors at Versailles.

The museum's rather feeble display of British paintings -including works by Constable, Turner, Gainsborough and Reynolds - is also to be expanded and air conditioned.

The revamp is more modest than the Louvre overhaul of the 1980s under François Mitterrand. But it still poses big logistical problems, notably how to keep the museum fully functioning while the work is done. There were 6.1m visitors to the Louvre last year.

fields.headline: Quick jabs
fields.trailText: As the parent of a child with autism, I believe the money allocated to the government's campaign aimed at restoring our faith in the MMR vaccine (£3m advert drive to promote MMR jabs, January 23) would be better spent on research into discovering the causes of autism.
fields.body:
As the parent of a child with autism, I believe the money allocated to the government's campaign aimed at restoring our faith in the MMR vaccine (£3m advert drive to promote MMR jabs, January 23) would be better spent on research into discovering the causes of autism.

Once these are fully understood there will be no room for doubt.
Owen Spencer-Thomas
Chair, East Anglian Autistic Support Trust
ors22@cam.ac.uk

Before coming to a decision about MMR, parents might consider that I was left with an untreatable disease called chorea after catching measles as a child and have spent more of the past 29 years on the dole than in work.
Mike Taylor
Stockton-on-Tees, Cleveland
miketaylor8@yahoo.com
