webTitle: Letters: We are all getting older

fields.headline: We are all getting older
fields.trailText: While we welcome government action on skills shortages (Britain 'in crisis' on skills and filling jobs, January 22), and recognise immigration can contribute a short-term solution, we remain concerned at the consistent failure to firmly link skills shortages with changing UK demographics.
fields.body:
While we welcome government action on skills shortages (Britain 'in crisis' on skills and filling jobs, January 22), and recognise immigration can contribute a short-term solution, we remain concerned at the consistent failure to firmly link skills shortages with changing UK demographics. An ageing population means there will be fewer people coming into the workplace and it is imperative that we invest in workers over the age of 45, who by 2010 will represent 40% of the UK's population.

Recent research by us found only 7% of those aged between 55 and pension age are getting any job-related training - critical in maintaining skills levels - compared with 23% of employed people over 25. Our members are benefiting from recruit ing and training employees of all ages within their organisations, and until all UK employers address ageist attitudes we have little hope of effectively increasing participation and plugging the skills shortage gap.
Sam Mercer
Employers Forum on Age
mercers@ace.org.uk

Having been trained and educated until there are qualifications coming out of my ears, I know I'm not the only skilled but unemployed person feeling frustrated by this talk of a skills shortage. Our lack of recent experience does not equal a lack of ability, and those of us who are over 40 are not senile. We have the tools; just give us the jobs.
G Robinson
Bolton
shelley666@cwctv.net

Our members are benefiting from recruit ing and training employees of all ages within their organisations, and until all UK employers address ageist attitudes we have little hope of effectively increasing participation and plugging the skills shortage gap. Sam Mercer Employers Forum on Age mercers@ace.org.uk Having been trained and educated until there are qualifications coming out of my ears, I know I'm not the only skilled but unemployed person feeling frustrated by this talk of a skills shortage. webTitle: Kostunica snubs UN call to seize Milosevic

fields.headline: Kostunica snubs UN call to seize Milosevic
fields.standfirst:
War crimes prosecutor in frosty talks with president

Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: The UN chief war crimes prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, ran into a cool and unbending response yesterday when she met the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, for the first time to demand the arrest of his predecessor, Slobodan Milosevic.
fields.body:
The UN chief war crimes prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, ran into a cool and unbending response yesterday when she met the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, for the first time to demand the arrest of his predecessor, Slobodan Milosevic.

Plans for a joint appearance before the media after their hour-long meeting were cancelled, and Mrs Del Ponte left his office in silence. Her spokeswoman later said she would speak at a press conference tomorrow at the end of her three-day visit.

A written statement from Mr Kostunica's mentioned "differences" and said the president had insisted that new Yugoslav laws would be needed before Belgrade could fully cooperate with the Hague war crimes tribunal, a stance rejected by Mrs Del Ponte. He also complained that "mostly Serbs" had been indicted, and accused the tribunal of wanting to impose "collective guilt on all Serbs". The prosecutor rejected those assessments, the statement added.

Mr Kostunica had initially refused to see the Swiss lawyer but changed his mind last week after protests from several of his government members. After his three-month honeymoon with western governments, which have lifted sanctions and renewed some aid to Yugoslavia since Mr Milosevic's downfall, the encounter with Mrs Del Ponte was meant to be his chance to give something back.

Although Mr Kostunica has repeatedly refused to accept the tribunal's jurisdiction, it was hoped that he would gradually change his tune under international pressure - and with the knowledge that the flow of aid could depend on it.

Yugoslavia was accepted into the UN last autumn. But Mr Kostunica justified his agreement last week to see the prosecutor by saying he would urge her to act against the west for its attack on his country and Nato's use of depleted uranium last year.

Zoran Djinjic, the new prime minister, is more aware of the need to seem flexible. Mr Milosevic ought to be arrested and tried for corruption in Belgrade to show that action was being taken, he said, while "we should keep an open ear to what the world is saying".

Mrs Del Ponte's spokeswoman told reporters before the meeting that as well as a dozen publicly indicted suspects still at liberty in Serbia, she was ready to give Mr Kostunica at least one name on a list of secret indictees if he showed a willingness to act. But afterwards, she said that if necessary the list would be handed to the minister of justice instead.

Such "sealed" indictments are used to snare defendants by surprise.

Turning up the pressure ahead of the talks, the war crimes tribunal ordered Yugoslavia to freeze the remaining financial assets of Mr Milosevic. Yugoslav central bank officials have accused the Milosevic regime of stealing more than £2.7bn and taking it out of the country in bags of cash marked "citizens' savings".

Mrs Del Ponte refuses to say just how much money Mr Milosevic may have left behind in Yugoslavia. In November, she told the UN that "it was a huge, huge amount of money that was stolen [from] the Serb population".

A statement from the tribunal said the warrant for Mr Milosevic's arrest was reissued on Monday by an Australian judge on the tribunal, David Hunt. It directs Belgrade to discover if the ousted president still has assets in Yugoslavia and, if so, to freeze them until he is taken into custody.

Judge Hunt also ordered the publication of an indictment against Zeljko Raznatovic, the paramilitary known as Arkan who was assassinated last January. Officials said that the indictment would be made public in the next day or two.

The Belgrade media have been feverishly speculating about the identities of the "secret" indictees. Top of their list is Borislav Pelevic, Arkan's sub-commander of the socalled Tigers in the Croatian war. He now heads the Serbian Unity party which won 14 seats in the Serb parliament.

A world-class kickboxer and vice-president of the world kickboxing federation, he runs a department in a sports college and calls himself "professor". He rejects all suggestions that he committed war crimes.

"I'm very proud of my role as a Tiger. We were the most disciplined part of the army. General Michael Rose, who commanded UN forces, said the Tigers were the best unit and always first into battle, although we did not have heavy weapons." For those two reasons, he said, they were not able to commit war crimes.

"I don't understand why anyone would indict me. The only reason could be because my party has just got into parliament. I stopped fighting in 1993, when I was wounded, so why were they waiting eight years?"he asked.

Like many other Serbs, "Professor Pelevic" would prefer to see Mr Milosevic stand trial in Serbia - not at the Hague - and face charges of corruption and abuse of power, not for war crimes.

Some ministers in Mr Kostunica's government have hinted that a trial for corruption might start in Belgrade this year. Goran Svilanovic, the federal foreign minister, has canvassed the idea of holding a war crimes trial for Mr Milo sevic in Belgrade with the Hague. Some European diplomats seem willing to consider this, but Washington insists on the Hague as the only venue.

US President George Bush has to certify by April whether Yugoslavia is "cooperating" or it will forfeit American aid.

Mrs Del Ponte has stated that trials away from the Hague are impossible. In any case it would be unfair on those already convicted. "I don't think we should make an exclusion for Milosevic," she said.

Some 15 of the 25 publicly indicted Serbs still at large are thought to be living in Serbia. Some, such as the Serbian president, Milan Milutinovic, make no effort to hide.

He was seen on television on Monday night meeting the leaders of all four parliamentary factions before nominating Mr Kostunica's main ally, Mr Djindjic, as Serbia's new prime minister.

webTitle: Letters: What about those fathers of 56?

fields.headline: What about those fathers of 56?
fields.trailText: Many grandparents look after their grandchildren to facilitate working mothers like Sally Weale, who admitted to arriving at work in the morning exhausted (Grey area, G2, January 23).
fields.body:
Many grandparents look after their grandchildren to facilitate working mothers like Sally Weale, who admitted to arriving at work in the morning exhausted (Grey area, G2, January 23). Women in their fifties may have more time, less exhaustion, more experience and more patience to look after the offspring of their own progeny. Why not, then, give birth in the sixth decade?

As a former midwife, I know many "menopausal" babies that were born to women well into their fifties. So why the fuss?
Sandra Kernohan
Poole, Dorset
home@kernohan.u-net.com

I don't recall anyone making such a fuss when Michael Douglas became a dad last year, aged 56. Nor when an elderly Les Dawson sired a child, only to die soon after, thus cruelly denying the "fruit of his worn-out loins" child the opportunity to know her father. Ageing fathers never receive the opprobrium showered on older mothers. Teenage mothers receive the same treatment.

If it's wrong for women to attempt parenthood in their teens or their fifties, then it's wrong for men too.
Laura Marcus
Leek, Staffs
Lawls@compuserve.com

Dea Birkett is wrong. (Cloning is good, January 23). IVF is not "a legitimate way of treating infertility", it is a frequently questionable (and unsuccessful) means of circumventing the socially constructed "problem" of childlessness, and in cases such as those of the Bezants and Buttles, a way of procuring a pregnancy in circumstances which must fall far short of prioritising the interests of the ensuing children.

Before us at present we have not only the Kilshaws, who believe that their desires place them above the law on adoption, but certain IVF practitioners who, encouraged by a toothless regulator, regard their practice as so unfailingly benign that it should be subject to virtually no constraint.

Current laudable measures to engender a more child-friendly society will not be helped by giving the green light to inappropriately child-obsessed individuals.
Root Cartwright
Chairman, British Organisation of Non-Parents
root.cartwright@btinternet.com

fields.trailText: In a Media Guardian diary item about a film-making workshop held for BBC Panorama staff, page 5, January 22, we suggested that reporters John Ware, Jane Corbin and Tom Mangold were compelled to attend after initially refusing to go. In fact attendance was voluntary: John Ware went, Jane Corbin was on assignment and Tom Mangold was preparing to travel abroad. Sorry, we got it wrong.
fields.body:
In a Media Guardian diary item about a film-making workshop held for BBC Panorama staff, page 5, January 22, we suggested that reporters John Ware, Jane Corbin and Tom Mangold were compelled to attend after initially refusing to go. In fact attendance was voluntary: John Ware went, Jane Corbin was on assignment and Tom Mangold was preparing to travel abroad. Sorry, we got it wrong.

All three photographs, of works by Caravaggio and Carracci, accompanying an article about The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 exhibition at the Royal Academy, G2, page 12, yesterday, were accidentally reversed.

An article about fertility treatment for older women, Grey area, G2, page 2, yesterday, said the policy of the Bourn Hall clinic, near Cambridge, was not to treat women "much over the age of about 59". We should have said 49.

Bridlington migrated north in a piece about coastal towns, Sleepy resort where developers might dispel the gloom, page 6, January 20. We placed it between Scarborough and Whitby, when in fact it lies south of Scarborough.

fields.headline: Turning up the heat
fields.trailText: The Guardian has drawn attention once again to the environmental threat of global warming (Warming could be worst in 10,000 years, January 23).
fields.body:
The Guardian has drawn attention once again to the environmental threat of global warming (Warming could be worst in 10,000 years, January 23). To control and reduce the threat requires that the planet as a whole balances its use of fossil fuel as a source of energy with the ability of the planet to safely absorb the byproducts.

Solar energy provides about 1,000 times as much energy as the fossil energy used at present and 170 times as much as would be required to maintain all at the same level of consumption as the developed nations.

The sensible way is to introduce a UN-managed world wide levy, at source, on the extraction of primary energy products. A levy of 10p per kilowatt-hour would result in fossil energy costing six times as much as renewable forms of energy. The market would then ensure massive research and development of renewable sources. As fossil fuel use is gradually switched to renewable use, the levy would be increased to make replacement even more financially attractive and to conserve the diminishing fossil stocks.

This international income, disbursed by the UN, would allow each nation to abolish all forms of taxation which increase the cost of labour. With tax barriers removed, each nation's economy would be able to benefit from the release of the ingenuity and creativity of its own citizens.

Of course it won't happen because it requires cooperation between nations and leaders. As one-time US presidential contender Adlai Stevenson said, "the human race is very good at reading the writing on the wall - but only when its back is right up against it".
Owen Ephraim
Chelmsford
owenephram@onetel.net.uk

webTitle: Leader: What's Hague done to the Thatcherite credo?

fields.headline: Heretic Hague
fields.standfirst:
What happened to the Thatcherite credo?

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The disciples of Margaret Thatcher, that diminished but still significant army, must be deeply unhappy today. The heretics, in their terms, have seized the control room and are taking apart the sacred legacy.
fields.body:
The disciples of Margaret Thatcher, that diminished but still significant army, must be deeply unhappy today. The heretics, in their terms, have seized the control room and are taking apart the sacred legacy. It was bad enough when William Hague and his colleagues pledged themselves to accept Labour spending targets for health and education.

But now that promise has been extended, to cover law and order, transport and defence. Labour has set the agenda: the principal party of opposition is dutifully following suit.

Mr Hague maintains that none of this will imperil the £8m spending cuts he plans to allow for the tax cuts for which he thinks the nation is slavering. But the question which the Conservatives have always asked, with some success, about Labour - where is the money to come from? - has now reared up in front of their leader.

And the answers so far supplied - the privatisation of Channel 4 and a war on waste, fraud and bureaucracy - will fool very few. Aspiring governments all the way back, it sometimes seems, to Ethelred the Unready have promised money-saving assaults on waste, fraud and bureaucracy. None has ever delivered. Nor would Mr Hague.

But for Thatcherite believers the offence is much worse. The mantra they used to chant, in private if not always in public, throughout their years of hegemony - private provision good, public provision bad - is now, it seems, to be silenced. And why? Clearly, because the Conservatives are growing as scared of spending cuts as Labour used to be of higher taxation. The conviction is growing that when voters told pollsters time and again that they would rather have better funded public services than cuts in taxation, they really meant it. Perhaps now the Labour leadership, which has for so long been so feebly defensive about championing public service and public investment, will gain courage from this turn of events.

And if the Conservative press turns nasty, Mr Hague can console himself with a thought from the latest of many memos written by Labour's polling guru, Philip Gould, and later leaked to the newspapers. "Follow the voters rather than the media" Mr Gould counselled after talks last spring with the former Clinton aide Doug Sosnik.

Other extracts from the wisdom of Sosnik included a reminder that no political leader could expect to win every day. There would be bad days, bad weeks: best use them as evidence of the PM's resolve and proof that what mattered was the leader's own agenda, not the media's. That sits oddly with the advice offered by Mr Gould in an earlier memo, drawing on talks with another Clinton associate, Dick Morris, which emphasised that every day is election day in modern politics and that days must not pass without Mr Blair controlling the news. But the wisdom of Sosnik is a big improvement on that. It means that you don't kowtow to the Mail and the Sun: you take them on.

Yet even this new formulation is dubious. Put the public before the media certainly: but "follow the voters" is dangerous advice for a leader. Had Tony Blair fallen for that, he would not have stood up as he rightly and courageously did to the agitation last autumn for cuts in the tax on petrol.

People who go into politics - as many do - intent on making the world a better place need the courage to propose solutions which may not yet be in demand by public opinion - even though if rightly handled they may come to be so in time. Labour too often abdicated that role in the 1997 election campaign. It must not do so again.

fields.headline: Mugabe stars at Kabila burial
fields.trailText: The Democratic Republic of Congo's assassinated president, Laurent Kabila, was buried in the capital Kinshasa yesterday with his closest African bedfellows in politics and war in attendance.
fields.body:
The Democratic Republic of Congo's assassinated president, Laurent Kabila, was buried in the capital Kinshasa yesterday with his closest African bedfellows in politics and war in attendance.

Whipped up by state propaganda, several hundred thousand people crowded the gates of the "people's palace" government hall where the dead dictator lay in state.

A delirious uproar greeted Kabila's staunchest ally, President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe. As he walked up the palace steps, groups dressed in cloth imprinted with Kabila's portrait chanted his name.

Either side of Mr Mugabe came the presidents of Angola and Namibia, also allies in a war that in two and a half years has displaced more than 2m people and split Congo.

Though Kabila was the man who in 1997 ousted the longtime dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, he was not mourned immediately after he was shot last week by an alleged lone bodyguard.

People blamed him for impoverishing the huge central African country by waging war against rebels backed by Rwanda and Uganda. Mr Mugabe also stands accused at home of wasting Zimbabwe's resources on the war.

But since Monday, when Kabila's body was flown back from his southern homeland, the state machine has worked up a wave of nationalism and xenophobia among Kinshasa's poverty-stricken people.

"We will kill the white assassins!" chanted the hordes outside the palace, acting out a mock lynching for the motorcades of western diplomats. The mix of arrivals also included representatives from Iran, Cuba, Sudan and Libya.

The apparently smooth takeover of Kabila's son Joseph, 31, who was recently under house arrest accused of plotting a coup, has raised suspicions of a conspiracy. But yesterday Congolese society was on parade for the funeral, tribes men's drums competing with at least three military bands. The new president, a slight man, greeted the dignitaries impassively. Briefly he embraced Mr Mugabe. Zimbabwean and Angolan soldiers surrounded them, machine guns pointed at diplomats who sat sweating in black garb.

"We need the Angolan soldiers at this time," said a Congolese adjutant, Fidel Mombatu. "The new president prefers them because they give better protection. He is not sure about all Congolese."

Gaetan Kakudji, the interior minister who many analysts see as the political kingmaker, brought the funeral mass to a close. "Kabila put together a process of democratisation which was going to end in fair and transparent elections, but that was brutally ended by this aggression," he claimed.

The crowds were kept well back by Angolan and Zimbabwean troops in armoured vehicles before Joseph Kabila left for the national palace where his father was interred.
fields.bodyText: The Democratic Republic of Congo's assassinated president, Laurent Kabila, was buried in the capital Kinshasa yesterday with his closest African bedfellows in politics and war in attendance. Whipped up by state propaganda, several hundred thousand people crowded the gates of the "people's palace" government hall where the dead dictator lay in state. A delirious uproar greeted Kabila's staunchest ally, President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe. As he walked up the palace steps, groups dressed in cloth imprinted with Kabila's portrait chanted his name. Either side of Mr Mugabe came the presidents of Angola and Namibia, also allies in a war that in two and a half years has displaced more than 2m people and split Congo. Though Kabila was the man who in 1997 ousted the longtime dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, he was not mourned immediately after he was shot last week by an alleged lone bodyguard. People blamed him for impoverishing the huge central African country by waging war against rebels backed by Rwanda and Uganda. Mr Mugabe also stands accused at home of wasting Zimbabwe's resources on the war. But since Monday, when Kabila's body was flown back from his southern homeland, the state machine has worked up a wave of nationalism and xenophobia among Kinshasa's poverty-stricken people. "We will kill the white assassins!" chanted the hordes outside the palace, acting out a mock lynching for the motorcades of western diplomats. The mix of arrivals also included representatives from Iran, Cuba, Sudan and Libya. The apparently smooth takeover of Kabila's son Joseph, 31, who was recently under house arrest accused of plotting a coup, has raised suspicions of a conspiracy. But yesterday Congolese society was on parade for the funeral, tribes men's drums competing with at least three military bands. The new president, a slight man, greeted the dignitaries impassively. Briefly he embraced Mr Mugabe. Zimbabwean and Angolan soldiers surrounded them, machine guns pointed at diplomats who sat sweating in black garb. webTitle: Letters: Don't cram air passengers in

fields.headline: Don't cram them in
fields.trailText: To advise passengers of exercises and precautions to take to minimise deep vein thrombosis in the absence of public acknowledgement of the role of seat design and placement appears to place the onus of prevention solely upon the passenger (The cramped skies, January 14).
fields.body:
To advise passengers of exercises and precautions to take to minimise deep vein thrombosis in the absence of public acknowledgement of the role of seat design and placement appears to place the onus of prevention solely upon the passenger (The cramped skies, January 14).

Seat design and manufacture is undertaken by the aircraft manufacturers; the placement of these seats within the aircraft is undertaken by the airlines. The causal contribution to DVT of sitting in a relatively fixed cramped position, in a non height-adjustable seat; being unable to fully stretch the legs and having pressure on the underside of the thigh, compromising return flow to the heart, cannot be denied.

The seating needs to be redesigned in terms of both actual seat design and seat spacing, and should comply to accepted ergonomic standards. The standards should be set by an independent body. Ideally, the passageways need to be increased in width, as do the seats themselves.

Airlines will need to forego the steerage class mentality of maximising bums on seats and recognise that they have a liability under duty of care and appropriate country of origin legislation. In the UK, it would be interesting to use the occupational health and safety legislation to prosecute an airline based upon: the application of ergonomic principles to the design of the average seat being offered to the economy-class passenger; the airline's duty of care.

Passengers will need to accept that these changes will require an increase in fares - fewer passengers mean higher fares.
Dennis Lewis-Enright
Sydney
lewisenright@ozemail.com.au

webTitle: Leader: Soon most Britons will be on the net

fields.headline: Legions of loggers-on
fields.standfirst:
Soon most Britons will be on the net

More net news
fields.trailText: Dot.com businesses may be falling like ninepins, but Britain's love affair with the internet is not cooling down. Our ICM poll today shows that 49% of people now have internet access.
fields.body:
Dot.com businesses may be falling like ninepins, but Britain's love affair with the internet is not cooling down. Our ICM poll today shows that 49% of people now have internet access (up 12% on the year). Some 63% of us use mobile phones and no less than 43% are sending text messages from their phones.

Over three quarters of 18- to 24-year-olds use text messaging. It is not clear exactly what they are messaging each other about - but it is a safe bet they are not discussing prime minister's question time.

What we are observing among dot.com failures is the natural attrition rate of new companies, magnified by the fact that no one has yet worked out a successful business plan for making profits out of consumers on the web. At the moment, the founding "free-to-all" principles of the world wide web are still triumphing over the commercial forces.

The only companies making real money out of the web are those laying down the infrastructure or selling to other compa nies. The consumer's ability to click off to somewhere cheaper has made the internet a hard place to make an honest buck - a factor that has helped to bring inflation down all over the world.

The only worry about the ICM figures is the danger of a digital divide. But the fact that the rich (73%) are far more likely to have web access than the poor (21%) does not mean the divide is here to stay. All new technologies -radio, television, video recorders - tend to be bought first by the rich before mass production and falling prices makes them affordable to the poor.

The fact that the take-up rate for the net is much faster than previous technologies among rich and poor is encouraging. Personal computers, though falling sharply in price, are too expensive for poorer people - who may find television or the mobile phone an easier route to mass net access. The worrying digital divide is not within rich countries but between rich and poor nations. That is widening all the time.

fields.headline: The fallibility of science
fields.trailText: Hywel Williams is misguided in his attack on the infallibility of science (Comment, January 23).  As any scientist will tell you, few, if any, scientific "truths" are universal: each has its own domain of applicability, from quantum physics to genetics.
fields.body:
Hywel Williams is misguided in his attack on the infallibility of science (Comment, January 23). Every scientist is aware of the limitations of his craft: how could it be otherwise in a profession where each step of progress requires the consignment of another man's work (and often one's own) to the dustbin? As any scientist will tell you, few, if any, scientific "truths" are universal: each has its own domain of applicability, from quantum physics to genetics.

However, this is not to say that scientific truth is relative in an intellectual sense. I disagree with Williams's contention that Werner von Braun's ability to build rockets for both Adolf Hitler and John F Kennedy demonstrates that science is more interested in serving its master than the truth: on the contrary, it shows that scientific results are independent of their political environment.

Rather than attacking scientists for providing politicians with false certainties, Williams should attack politicians for misrepresenting scientific research. Fallible science is of no use to politicians operating under the harsh light of the media: John Gummer could hardly have asked everyone to wait five years for biologists to fully assess the risks of BSE. Instead, as politicians are wont, Mr Gummer used the myth of scientific truth to evade responsibility for his own decision. It is this debasement of the scientific endeavour that is dangerous, both to the general public and to science itself.

Scientists are not blameless in this matter. When politicians proclaimed that there was no scientific evidence of danger from BSE, depleted uranium, or genetically modified food, where were the scientific voices patiently explaining that a lack of evidence - as opposed to positive evidence that something is safe - is no grounds for complacency?

When politicians ignored mainstream scientific opinion on global warming for maverick beliefs that suited their purpose, where was the flood of newspaper articles giving detailed rebuttals of their claims? Or perhaps the reason for the lack of informed public debate about such matters as BSE and DU is that the media, too, finds it easier to sell clear-cut "scientific" truths than the messy uncertainties of ongoing scientific research. Jonathan Dawid
Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, US
dawid@fas.harvard.edu

Science is objective in that it delivers real solutions to real problems, but Hywel Williams has hardly revealed any great conspiracy by pointing out that there is a subjective element in deciding which questions to ask and which problems to solve; it was a political decision to invest in putting someone on the moon rather than eradicating malaria.

Science is not about absolute certainty - it is about finding a route through uncertainty. If politicians understood this better, scientific advice would be better used.
Dr Peter Cotgreave
Director, Save British Science Society
peter.cotgreave@ucl.ac.uk

I have become accustomed to any development with the possibility of adverse biological effects being ascribed to "scientists". Anything, on the other hand, with even the most tenuous prospect of benefit is thanks to "doctors".

So I was not surprised to find Hywel Williams bracketing scientists with politicians and witch-burners. What did surprise me was the ingenuity with which he handled the uncomfortable facts about Harold Shipman. It seems that this former GP and sometime murderer was a "scientist" all along!
Dr Brian Jordan
Huddersfield, West Yorkshire
b-jordan@lineone.net

webTitle: Leader: The killing will not subdue Chechnya

fields.headline: This war cannot succeed
fields.standfirst:
The killing will not subdue Chechnya

Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: A halt to Vladimir Putin's criminal war against the Chechen people is long overdue. Even the Russian president cannot any longer pretend that his policy of suppression and annihilation is working.
fields.body:
A halt to Vladimir Putin's criminal war against the Chechen people is long overdue. Even the Russian president cannot any longer pretend that his policy of suppression and annihilation is working.

Unofficial estimates suggest that 6,500 Russian serviceman have died and at least 20,000 have been injured in "anti-terrorist" operations that began 16 months ago. Civilian casualties are in the uncounted tens of thousands. Chechnya and its cities have been laid waste; basic human rights are being flouted on a tragic scale. Killings, disappearances, torture and extortion by Russia's ill-disciplined, ill-led soldiers have become routine, as a new Human Rights Watch report makes clear.

Mr Putin has imposed pro-Moscow puppet administrators and talks of reconstruction aid. But such self-serving gestures ignore the reality on the ground, where destruction goes on unchecked. The secessionists led by Chechnya's elected president, Aslan Maskhadov, although much reduced, fight on guerrilla-style and show not the slightest sign of giving up. Thus does Mr Putin reap the harvest of hatred that his murderous blitzkrieg has sowed.

Mr Putin's decision to place the main KGB successor agency, the FSB, in charge in Chechnya, and to withdraw some troops, may mean that the indiscriminate army bombardments of civilian areas that usually follow Chechen attacks will in time be reduced.

But it also means a switch of tactics towards what Mr Putin's spokesman calls "neutralisation and elimination" - in other words, state-sponsored terrorism and assassination. Yet more than that, Mr Putin's decree is a silent admission of defeat.

His presidential campaign vow to subjugate Chechnya remains unfulfilled. He can insist until he is red in the face that the war is now just a mopping-up operation. The truth is that his clumsy use of brute force has proved to be a disaster for all concerned and is the shame of all Russia.

It is time for this pointless carnage to end. Mr Maskhadov says he is prepared to talk. The EU and the Osce, vapidly, and the Council of Europe, more energetically, support a negotiated settlement. The Russian people appear weary of Putin's war.

So are ordinary Chechens, whose unrelenting suffering should sting the conscience of all who would do business with Mr Putin (including our own Tony Blair). Russia's leader should stop shooting, start talking, and prove he is not just a thug in a sharp suit.

webTitle: Ws take a walk at the White House

fields.headline: Ws take a walk at the White House
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Hundreds of members of George Bush's incoming staff have stumbled upon the Democrats' real legacy this week. When many of Bill Clinton's team left their offices at the weekend they took the W keys from their computer keyboards.
fields.body:
Hundreds of members of George Bush's incoming staff have stumbled upon the Democrats' real legacy this week. When many of Bill Clinton's team left their offices at the weekend they took the W keys from their computer keyboards.

When their Republican replacements arrived, they discovered that they had been made the victims of an extensive practical joke. In office after office, keyboards are missing their Ws, and many of the lost keys are turning up in strange places.

"There are dozens, if not hundreds of keyboards with these missing keys," a White House spokesman told the Washington Post yesterday. "In some cases the W has simply been marked out, but the most prevalent example is the key being removed."

The missing Ws are being discovered in all sorts of odd places, such as taped to the top of door frames. Others have turned up in hard-to-get-at nooks and crannies.

Mr Bush, whose middle name is Walker, made a big deal out of his middle initial during campaign rallies, often holding up the middle three fingers of his hand to form a W. He is often popularly referred to as "Dubya".

The W keys have been pocketed from offices throughout the White House and in the neighbouring old executive office building where most of the presidential and vice-presidential staff work.

"It has the technical and computer support people very busy," said the unidentified spokesman. "They already have quite a lot to do. I don't believe they expected to be coping with this as well."

Few members of the ancien regime were able to cast any light on the lost Ws yesterday.

Mr Clinton's former adviser, Sidney Blumenthal, always a prime suspect among Republicans where the political black arts are involved, professed innocence. "I only read about it in the paper," he claimed.

Al Gore's press spokesman, Chris Lehane, said: "The White House did not have many reasons to use the letter W over the last couple of years; it's possible they just fell off because of sheer atrophy."

webTitle: Dracula abbey's secrets saved from sea

fields.headline: Dracula abbey's secrets saved from sea
fields.trailText: The secrets of a church that changed the course of British history were saved from the sea yesterday, after a delicate excavation on top of cliffs too dangerous for archaeologists to tread.
fields.body:
The secrets of a church that changed the course of British history were saved from the sea yesterday, after a delicate excavation on top of cliffs too dangerous for archaeologists to tread.

An adapted mechanical digger with a five-metre arm scraped back topsoil above the North Sea at Whitby, north Yorkshire, where chunks of the graveyard of the Anglo Saxon abbey have been toppling on to the beach 150ft below.

Notorious as the fictional setting for Count Dracula's landfall in Britain, the abbey was host to the Synod of Whitby in 664, which committed England to the Roman rather than Celtic Christian church.

Sections of an 8th-century cross and traces of royal burials have already been salvaged from a 12-metre strip closed to the public since sections slid into the sea.

"We've just got a tiny window of time to retrieve what could be vital clues about our past," said Peter "Buz" Busby, head of English Heritage's emergency dig on the clifftop. "If we had left this dig any longer an awful lot of history could have fallen into the North sea and into oblivion."

Jagged cracks in the grass come close to two nameless graves marked with skulls and crossbones, often linked to Bram Stoker's account of Dracula racing up the 199 steps to the abbey, drinking a girl's blood and then hiding in a suicide victim's grave. The two tombs are actually those of unknown pirates, another part of the port's heritage that the excavation hopes to save.

Tonnes of earth rescued by the digger will be sifted by English Heritage archaeologists, who spotted traces of medieval and possibly Anglo Saxon detritus in the first bucketloads.

Mr Busby said: "Whitby Abbey is one of the most important archaeological sites in the north, but it's also a famous puzzle. Everywhere we dig we find signs of a large-scale urban complex dating to the Anglo Saxon period, but contemporaries like Bede offer us only tantalising glimpses of what might have been here."

The graveyard is thought to be the resting place of St Hilda, a powerful figure in the 7th century, and the shepherd boy, Caedmon, whose Song of Creation is one of the earliest poems in English.

English Heritage also hopes for finds connected to King Oswy of Northumbria, a Celtic Christian who was fed up that he and his Roman Christian wife had different dates for Easter and the year's biggest feast at court.

Results of the "remote digging" method at Whitby will be applied at other erosion threatened sites. The dig is the first trial of strategies to deal with erosion and rising sea levels recommended in an English Heritage strategy paper.

fields.headline: Chicken and embryo
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: I have been thinking about stem cell research. It seems that roughly 2,000 years after the birth of Jesus, bishops still have a say in political affairs.
fields.body:
Firstly, let me apologise for not writing about Auberon Waugh. I know how much readers enjoy a glimpse into the lives of columnists and how it brightens your drab days to see us write about one another.

Instead I have been thinking about stem cell research. It seems that roughly 2,000 years after the birth of Jesus, bishops still have a say in political affairs. You might say their role is nominal, just as it is often said that the monarchy has no real power - other than to cruise the world at our expense insulting foreigners in our name, and generally clouding our thinking with trivia about their longevity or inability to use a bath correctly.

True, churches do not have the power they once enjoyed. Women don't get burnt for having a third nipple, although they do get jailed for not having a TV licence. But when society considers matters of ethics, it is deemed important for the views of "faith communities" to be solicited. Somehow, people who believe in a deity are still attributed with more, or at least special, moral authority.

Indeed, some parents send children to religious schools on the grounds that it will "teach them right from wrong", as though we who don't believe in God have no guiding principles whatsoever. In fact, there is little in the scriptures that is directly useful in modifying children's behaviour. Moses does not descend from the mountain saying: "If you can't be sensible with that Golden Calf, I'm going to put it away until you're older."

This is not to say that religious people have nothing important to say. I'm merely suggesting that ideas about justice, kindness, humility or the right to life are not exclusive to people who believe in God. And governments are quite selective in who gets to pontificate about ethics. I don't see Robin Cook running the ethical dimension to foreign policy past the Quakers for closer inspection.

If one campaigns around human rights issues, one will inevitably find oneself campaigning alongside a number of brave, practical, good humoured and angry people who are religious. And if a religious person is vigorously opposing racism, corporate greed and miscarriages of justice, they are hugely preferable to reactionary atheists. It can be dispiriting when they speak of prayer, but no more so than when a person says: "What sign are you?" or "I've got this crystal..."

How much their faith informs their politics is hard to say. I dare say there's the odd British Aerospace executive who has a blinding revelation and discovers from God that the arms trade is morally repugnant, but if he can't work it out for himself he is wilfully dim. On the other hand, people who have generally humane and just ideas frequently select the better bits of their chosen creed while being somewhat embarrassed about the bits that involve minor offenders being stoned to death and women being forced to menstruate outdoors.

But when people seem to be driven primarily by an acceptance of what purports to be holy law, we are usually in trouble. We hear cries of horror at the thought of a sheep grown from a single cell, from people who are quite sanguine about the idea of a woman grown from a single rib. We hear protests about the welfare of the unborn from people who wouldn't give the born the time of day.

An embryo is not a person. It is perhaps more fully developed than George Bush, but it's no more difficult to create. It is a living thing, as is a sperm. I always feel rather sorry for all those brave little tadpole-like fellows that don't get to score with the egg. I'm being flippant. An embryo can actually grow into a person, if a woman is prepared to incubate it or, in the future, if a lab technician will do so. But it is not a person.

Some people are squeamish about IVF. Admittedly, it sounds like a loyalist organisation, but it does not literally mean babies born in laboratories, except where there is a chronic bed shortage. Some people wonder where we're going with all this reproductive technology and embryo research. Jehovah's Witnesses wonder where we're going with all these blood transfusions.

If deists have something distinctive to say about abortion or the use of embryos to find medical cures, it is because of their belief in the soul. Some people have such faith in the soul that they see no value in earthly life at all, although most hedge their bets. I don't know whether the soul is supposed to be complete at conception or whether it develops with age, a 25-year-old having as much as Otis Redding and an embryo as much as Craig David. But I do know that life isn't perfect, that an embryo is a very primitive form of it and that people's lives are more important. If God disagrees, I say, come again.

fields.headline: Surgeon's work under scrutiny
fields.trailText: Hospital managers yesterday promised to review every operation carried out by a pioneering surgeon suspended after complaints about her work.
fields.body:
Hospital managers yesterday promised to review every operation carried out by a pioneering surgeon suspended after complaints about her work.

Consultant Briony Ackroyd was among the first in Britain to offer breast cancer victims a combined mastectomy and reconstruction operation.

The tissue used often came from the abdomen, offering the patient a "tummy tuck".

She was suspended from Walsgrave hospital in Coventry last February, following complaints about her procedures.

Hospital managers confirmed yesterday that they had referred Miss Ackroyd, 52, to the General Medical Council, the medical profession's disciplinary body.

Thirty cases of possible malpractice are being investigated by the GMC.

Walsgrave hospital's chief executive, David Loughton, said that all Miss Ackroyd's cases over her six years at the hospital would be reviewed.

"We are working as quickly as we can to resolve this matter both for the hospital and patients concerned and for Miss Ackroyd's sake.

"It is fair to say we are looking at all cases Miss Ackroyd has undertaken while employed since 1995."

Critics say the consultant's complication rate was too high and that her patients were not fully informed of the risks.

Her supporters say they were comforted by her unconventional approach - which included visiting patients at home - and claim that she is the victim of a predominantly male medical establishment.

Former patients have set up the Briony Ackroyd Support Group, which has collected more than 4,000 signatures calling for the surgeon's reinstatement, and more than 100 former patients have agreed to testify on her behalf at any GMC hearing.

Local GPs are also backing her and at least one has agreed to speak for her at the GMC.

However, the daughter of a former patient is calling for her to be struck off the medical register for life.

Debra Butler blames Miss Ackroyd for persuading her mother, Janet Nixon, to have a breast reconstruction operation, during which she suffered a stroke that left her partially paralysed.

The reconstruction also became infected and five further operations were needed to repair the damage.

Mrs Nixon, 57, was paid £51,000 in an out of court compensation settlement before her death in June last year.

She received the compensation after obtaining an opinion from an independent expert which was harshly critical of Miss Ackroyd's work.

In a statement to Mrs Nixon's solicitor, a consultant plastic surgeon, Christopher Ward, said that she had not been properly warned of the risks and would probably not have agreed to the surgical procedure if she had been.

He said that although the breast removal was successful, in other areas of her treatment the standard of care fell below what was expected of surgeons taking on that particular operation.

A GMC spokesman said it had had "discussions with the hospital about this doctor" after the hospital contacted it.

Miss Ackroyd was referred to the GMC but no date for a hearing had yet been set, the spokesman added.

fields.headline: Amnesty for finds from shipwrecks
fields.trailText: An amnesty to encourage people to hand over finds from shipwrecks was launched yesterday by the maritime and coastguard agency.
fields.body:
An amnesty to encourage people to hand over finds from shipwrecks was launched yesterday by the maritime and coastguard agency.

People who have munitions found at sea or on the shore, perhaps displayed in homes or clubs, were also urged to hand the items over.

The amnesty, until April 24, allows people in possession of anything classed as wreck material - such as ships' equipment, coins and bundles of wood - to set the record straight, and to avoid prosecution.

All items must be reported to the receiver of wreck, Veronica Robbins, who said: "Divers are attracted to bright and shiny objects.

"Items being used as ornaments could be unstable, and this offers an opportunity for them to be brought into the public domain and dealt with."

Old shells and other ammunition and firearms are sought. Police reinforced the message that they could be dangerous.

Detective Inspector Alan Stevens, of the Ministry of Defence police, said there was evidence that "certain people, certain clubs have bits of ordnance on display which have never been checked for safety."

Finders of wreck material must complete a form and return it to the receiver.

Important historical or archaeological finds are often placed in museums.

Ms Robbins said Guernsey, Alderney, Sark and the Isle of Man were launching similar amnesties.

Press Association

webTitle: Police pay £25,000 to CS sprayed man

fields.headline: Police pay £25,000 to CS sprayed man
fields.trailText: A police force was criticised yesterday for the "trigger-happy" use of CS spray after a man temporarily blinded by the device was awarded £25,000 in damages.
fields.body:
A police force was criticised yesterday for the "trigger-happy" use of CS spray after a man temporarily blinded by the device was awarded £25,000 in damages.

Officers from Merseyside police sprayed Wayne Fudge, 30, of Halewood, after they responded to a report of loud noise at a house party in Bebington, Wirral, in June 1998.

Mr Fudge was charged with assaulting a police officer but was acquitted at Liverpool crown court in January 1999.

He sued Merseyside police for assault, wrongful arrest, false imprisonment and malicious prosecution, and on Monday a jury at Liverpool county court ruled in his favour.

His solicitor, Rex Makin, said yesterday that police had "overreacted and blinded" Mr Fudge. "This is a case of the improper use of the gas of trigger-happy policemen using CS gas." He said the £25,000 damages had been agreed after the trial.

In a statement, Merseyside police said: "The force contested the claim following legal advice. However, in light of findings, all aspects of the case will be reviewed."

A spokeswoman said: "All officers receive a complete package of training, which includes the use of CS spray. Merseyside police is committed to improving the use of CS spray, and this is an issue we are taking extremely seriously.

"Figures show a 59.5% decrease in the number of complaints relating to the use of CS spray from 1998 to 1999."

Press Association

webTitle: Weather change offers hope to Galapagos

fields.headline: Weather change offers hope to Galapagos
fields.trailText: Black surf broke over the semi-submerged wreck of the stricken oil tanker Jessica as we approached. Small motorboats bobbed up and down in the waves, dancing to the tune of the tide amid the scramble to avert a major ecological disaster from a 250,000-gallon oil spill just off the coast of the Galapagos islands.
fields.byline: Jo Tuckman on San Cristobal island
fields.body:
Black surf broke over the semi-submerged wreck of the stricken oil tanker Jessica as we approached. Small motorboats bobbed up and down in the waves, dancing to the tune of the tide amid the scramble to avert a major ecological disaster from a 250,000-gallon oil spill just off the coast of the Galapagos islands.

The young locals who manned the boats were scooping up diesel from the water, while sturdier vessels carried officials spraying chemicals to disperse the spill, or sizing up the conditions for refloating the ship.

Amid all the activity, the only thing not moving was the Jessica itself. The tanker has been stuck on a reef for a week since it ran aground less than a mile from the shore of the island of San Cristobal.

For several days the ship was merely a blot on the horizon of this volcanic island chain bursting with life, 600 miles from Ecuador in the middle of the Pacific. But then the ship tanks cracked and 180,000 gallons of diesel and 80 gallons of bunker fuel began to leak out, menacing the complex ecosystem supporting the species that inspired Charles Darwin's theory of evolution.

On Monday the Ecuadorean government declared a state of emergency, but yesterday the environment minister, Rodolfo Rendon, said that the spilled diesel had shifted direction "toward the northwest, which is an open zone where there are no major islands".

Oil reached Santa Fe Island, 37 miles west of San Cristobal, and pelicans have been found coated with oil, sea lions irritated by toxins and large numbers of dead sea urchins washed up on the shore, but the oil has now begun to move away from the island.

"We're not out of the woods yet, but in general we expect the ecosystem to recover," said Robert Bensted-Smith, the Shropshire-born director of the Charles Darwin research centre on the archipelago.

Dr Bensted-Smith thanks the heavens for the escape. The wind and the currents were kind and pushed the spill out to sea, so that it was dispersed into streaks of oily film visible from the air as you fly into the tiny islands.

Sunshine helped to evaporate much of the diesel, and the fact that the leak was relatively slow allowed for most of the thicker, more dangerous fuel to mix with the diesel and flow away more easily.

So while praising the "huge local effort", and thanking the authorities and the US experts, the British biologist is sure that if the Galapagos is in fact safe from disaster it will be because "the major part of what we had was luck".

He had been particularly concerned about the lava gulls. There are only a few hundred of these in the world and all of them are on the Galapagos. Any damage to their colonies could have been devastating.

The gulls now appear safe, Dr Bensted-Smith said, but other species are still vulnerable, including the marine iguanas which may eat contaminated algae, the sea lions whose pups are particularly at risk, and the pelicans and blue-footed boobies which live around the shore. Not to mention that while most of the Jessica's tanks have now expelled their oil into the sea, there is still some left that could wash ashore in concentrated form if the favourable climatic conditions do not hold up.

And that issue was at the top of the agenda at the daily midday coordinating meeting at the Ecuadorean base on the island, within sight of both the wreck and a smattering of sea lions basking in the sun in the bay by the pier.

The navy and Galapagos reserve authorities want to pull the Jessica far out to sea to sink it, burying the remaining danger, and the evidence of its catastrophic potential. But US coast guard commander Edwin Stanton is not so sure that this is a good idea, as the reef is deep, the water above it shallow and the swells large.

He would prefer to tip the vessel level and pump out the 17,000 gallons thought to remain in one of the ship's 10 tanks, and then wait until the sea calms before trying any thing more dramatic. "The biggest risk now is that we wreck another ship trying to save this one, or that someone dies doing it," he said.

There have been reports that the Ecuadorean government had waited until the last minute to start the clean-up operation because of concerns about the cost of the operation, expected to run to about half a million dollars. Now they are being more assertive about calling for aid.

"Ecuador is a very poor country and the Galapagos is patrimony of humanity, and the world is happy that the Galapagos exists. So now is the time for the world to do something to ensure it remains," said Ramiro Morejon, chief of operations of the reserve.

webTitle: Double murder halts peace talks in Egypt

fields.headline: Double murder halts peace talks in Egypt
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel withdrew its delegation from peace talks with the Palestinians yesterday after two Israeli restaurant owners were killed in the West Bank by Palestinian gunmen.
fields.body:
Israel withdrew its delegation from peace talks with the Palestinians yesterday after two Israeli restaurant owners were killed in the West Bank by Palestinian gunmen.

Only two days after the talks started in Taba, on the Red Sea, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, recalled his team for "consultations". It was unclear how long the suspension would last. The cabinet is to meet today to decide whether the talks should go ahead.

Some progress had been reported at the negotiations when the news emerged that the bodies had been found.

Israeli security officials said the two victims were eating in a restaurant in the town of Tulkarem, in the West Bank about 25 miles north-east of Tel Aviv, when masked gunmen entered, forced them outside and shot them.

Their bodies were found later near the Nur Shams refugee camp outside the town.

A Palestinian negotiator, Ahmed Qureia, condemned the killings, the motive for which remained unclear.

In the past, Israel has suspended peace efforts in reaction to killings. Last week contacts were broken after an Israeli youth was shot dead in the West Bank; talks were also halted earlier this month when a Jewish settler was shot in Gaza.

In Taba, both sides were reported to have presented maps to illustrate their positions on border issues and control of parts of Jerusalem.

At a school in Tel Aviv, meanwhile, Mr Barak referred to the possibility of "joint management" for Jerusalem's contested Old City. But with Israel's prime ministerial election due on February 6, he insisted that Judaism's holiest sites will remain under Israeli sovereignty.

His comments immediately drew fire from the Palestinian authorities.

As ever, hope for a breakthrough in Taba remained guarded. The Israeli foreign minister, Shlomo Ben-Ami, told army radio yesterday: "I think the chance [of a peace breakthrough] is not very high, due to limited time and the weight of the subject."

The Israeli foreign minister, Shlomo Ben-Ami, told army radio yesterday: "I think the chance [of a peace breakthrough] is not very high, due to limited time and the weight of the subject."

webTitle: Hague overturns Tory bar on front line women

fields.headline: Hague overturns Tory bar on front line women
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Tories were in disarray yesterday after William Hague declared that women should be allowed to fight in the military front line, an idea previously dismissed by his chief defence spokesman as "political correctness gone mad".
fields.body:
The Tories were in disarray yesterday after William Hague declared that women should be allowed to fight in the military front line, an idea previously dismissed by his chief defence spokesman as "political correctness gone mad".

During a question and answer session with students, Mr Hague contradicted the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, when he voiced support for a woman who said that she wanted to join the RAF.

"I am pretty pragmatic about this," Mr Hague said when asked by a woman for his views about women serving in the military. "I don't say that women can never fight in the front line. I think in general that women should be welcomed into the ranks of the armed forces and let's hope that that's going to be the attitude over the next few years. Let's hope that you, as an RAF recruit will be able to be in the frontline if you want to."

His remarks to an audience of A-level students in London were in sharp contrast to Mr Duncan Smith's strong opposition to moves to allow women to serve in the frontline.

At last year's Tory conference Mr Duncan Smith flatly rejected suggestions by the government that women should be allowed to fight in the frontline, saying: "The suggestion of women on the front line is PC gone mad."

Central office insisted last night that there was no difference between Mr Hague and Mr Duncan Smith, one of the most rightwing members of the shadow cabinet and a favourite of Margaret Thatcher.

A spokesman said that Mr Hague was talking about the RAF in which women already served in the front line. In his conference speech Mr Duncan Smith was referring to the army.

The spokesman attempted to clarify Mr Hague's remarks by saying that a future Tory government would be neutral on the issue and would leave a final decision to the military.

"Any decision over whether women should serve on the front line can only be taken by the military themselves, on grounds of military operational effectiveness," the spokesman said. "It is not an issue for politicians to decide. We believe that the Labour government are pushing the military to make decisions, against their better judgment, for politically correct reasons."

However, there was little doubt last night that Mr Hague's remarks had exposed serious differences between the Tory leader and Mr Duncan Smith over a contentious area of defence policy. Mr Duncan Smith is one of the shadow cabinet's leading traditionalists, who is often at odds on social issues with Tory modernisers.

Amid the confusion over their defence policy, the Tories managed to land a punch against the government yesterday when they proved that a minister misled MPs over a military matter.

George Foulkes, the international development minister, told MPs on January 15 when he said that the West Indies guard ship could not help the victims of the El Salvador earthquake because it was "helping us in another emergency".

However, the defence minister, John Spellar, said yesterday in a parliamentary written answer that the ship was currently in Portsmouth.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: I wouldn't take too much notice of this, but we like to carry the odd Tory story for balance and there's a moderate chance this one may be true.
fields.body:
 I wouldn't take too much notice of this, but we like to carry the odd Tory story for balance and there's a moderate chance this one may be true. It concerns the rumbling feud between the anti-Hague axis of Polly Portillo and Francis Maude, and Hague's ultra-loyal press chief, Amanda Platell.

Just before Christmas, rumours of tension drove Mr Maude on to the World At One to be asked if he'd been to see his leader about the whispering campaign against him and Polly. This Mr Maude declined to deny, but we gather that in fact he had gone much further, actually demanding of Hague that Miss Platell be fired. Hague's response was of the school of: "If she goes, I go", so Maude and Polly must put up with the sniping a little longer, contenting themselves with the small spate of "Platell will go after election" stories that concluded these queeny and deliciously irrelevant exchanges.

 Hackles climb at the BBC over a perceived grubby Dykian approach to taking on ITN at 10pm. On Monday, having at one stage planned to spoil its rival's interview with Mr Hague by reporting as fact on the 6 O'Clock News mere rumours of what he would say (these people who run stories unchecked, they sully us all), the Beeb then began its 10pm show by interviewing the crazy Kenyan student who almost destroyed that BA 747. This tabloid lurch was a tremendous ratings success: by overruning Who Wants To Be A Millionaire by two minutes, ITV murdered BBC1 anyway. Poor show.

 At Millbank, that lovably daffy good time girl Margaret McDonagh continues to show a sure touch. She writes to branch parties on a particular area of expertise - the openness and transparency of party procedures. "OMOV at local level", one section is headlined.

"The selection of candidates for local government, parliamentary, Scottish, Welsh and regional seats are made," she declares, "by one man, one vote (OMOV)." Hardly in the vanguard of feminist thinking, but unusually honest: Labour historians believe that once there was something called "one member, one vote", but that was in the dark ages before the advent of Mr Tony Blair.

 Bungling pornographer Richard Desmond's promise to "spend what it takes" to turn the Express titles around still baffles staff, who wonder if this is a reference to catering. The canteen is to be remodelled to include a sushi bar and an expanded salad bar. To pay for this improvement (designed to cater for the increase in celebrity traffic the star-struck Desmond craves) sacrifices must be made, of course, and here this appears to be the luxury item of paper.

Yesterday staff in London, while considering rumours of a bailiff invasion of the Manchester office over several months backpayments for supplies of paper, revelled in the exquisite drama of being down to their last day's supply of A3 and A4. Ah well, so long as there are California rolls, who needs proof pages anyway?

 Concern mounts, meanwhile, over alopecian Sun editor David Yelland, whose memory was so tragically ruined when the doors of a New York subway train clamped shut on his wig. In adducing the appeal court's Bruce Grobbelaar verdict as a vindication of outstanding journalism, David forgets the savage criticism of his paper peppered through the judgments. "The manner in which the Sun carried out its investigation appears to have been amateurish, to say the least," is one example from Lord Justice Simon Brown. David will have forgotten all this by the second line of the next item, so we'd better repeat it often in the hope that it sinks in.

 In an exciting development, the Diary has registered the internet name www.buyababy.co.uk - amazing value, at £27.03, for so promising a business opportunity. Further details soon.

webTitle: Comment: Disclosing contents of spy memoirs

fields.headline: What's in that book
fields.standfirst:
Richard Norton-Taylor discloses the contents of some spy memoirs which remain officially suppressed

Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Richard Norton-Taylor discloses the contents of some spy memoirs which remain officially suppressed.
fields.body:
After days of tantalising dripfeeds to Russian newspapers (in an operation of which the most experienced publicist would be proud), The Big Breach, by Richard Tomlinson, the former MI6 officer, will be officially launched, we are promised, in Moscow this week.

The Guardian can outline today, however, just what other major "secrets" are contained in Tomlinson's book, alongside his account of the farcically unsuccessful Truefax news agency. Readers can then decide whether the book publication this week actually matters very much, for all this material is already in the public domain in one way or another - as well as being in foreign hands. Nothing big remains to come out.

The Big Breach describes how Tomlinson was approached, in time honoured fashion, by a tutor at Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge, a typical MI6 talent spotter. He was himself classic MI6 material - an enthusiastic member of the university's air squadron, fit, adventurous and with a first class degree in aeronautical engineering.

Initially, he demurred and accepted a scholarship at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He then passed a rigorous test to become a member of the territorial SAS. In 1991 he remade contact with MI6 and made a favourable impression at its "front office" in Carlton Gardens off the Mall in central London.

Tomlinson passed Ionec - the Intelligence Officers New Entry Course - with flying colours. He recounts how recruits were trained at Fort Monckton, an old naval fort near Portsmouth. They were dropped in the centre of the city and given an hour to obtain the name, profession, and passport number of a member of the public. He persuaded a couple of nurses he befriended in a pub to crew a yacht he was delivering to France. The nurses provided him with all their personal details. He says a fellow MI6 trainee, pretending to be a French student, made a bet with his intended target, insisting all British passport numbers ended with 666. The target proved him wrong. The MI6 recruit lost the bet but achieved his objective.

Tomlinson was quickly assigned to highly sensitive operations. He describes how eight years ago, as the cold war was ending, he was sent to Moscow posing as an industrialist under the name Andrew Huntley. He was told to meet his Russian contact, codenamed SOU, at a Financial Times conference on doing business with Russia, held at Moscow's Hotel Metropole. His mission, apparently successful, was to "to exfiltrate" SOU's notebooks - believed to contain details about the performance of a new Russian missile system. He was also involved in purloining intelligence about armoured cars.

Later in 1992 Tomlinson was sent to Bosnia posing as a journalist, complete with a forged National Union of Journalists membership card. His initial contact was a Serb, who was hoped to have access to senior army commanders.

On Balkan business, Tomlinson met Harold Elletson, then Conservative MP for Blackpool South and a long-term MI6 contact - (the rule that MI6 should not "run" MPs was waived by the then prime minister, John Major). Elletson, says Tomlinson, was an upright figure who was concerned about John Kennedy, a Tory party candidate and British citizen from a Serb family who changed his name from Gvozdenovic. Kennedy was a strong supporter of the Bosnian Serbs under the indicted war criminal Radovan Karadzic and was a channel through which Serbian money was being offered to Conservative funds.

MI6 did its best to sweep the potential scandal under the carpet. Tomlinson alleges he was told to destroy his report, which would normally have been circulated throughout MI6 and instead Sir John McColl, head of MI6, quietly warned Sir Robin (now Lord) Butler, the cabinet secretary. Robin Cook, shadow foreign secretary at the time, later raised the issue, telling MPs: "No wonder MI6 was worried."

One role Tomlinson alleges MI6 officers were asked to undertake while in Bosnia was to write articles under pseudonyms. As the Guardian reported in 1998, articles written by an MI6 officer under a false name were at that time published in the Spectator magazine.

The articles, which included bitter attacks on British journalists, including the BBC correspondent Kate Adie, were written with a Sarajevo dateline under the name of Kenneth Roberts, during the civil war in Bosnia. The Spectator said at the end of the articles that the author's name "has been changed at his request". It did not say that the writer was an MI6 officer. The officer has already been publicly identified as Keith Craig.

These MI6 articles appeared to be part of an attempt to influence public opinion during the Bosnian crisis by suggesting atrocities were being carried out by all sides - and not just Bosnian Serb troops.

Finally, in 1994, in what turned out to be his last sensitive operation, Tomlinson was assigned to MI6's counter- proliferation department (responsible for disrupting attempts by "rogue" states such as Iraq and Iran to acquire nuclear, chemical, and biological weapons). Iran, whose troops had been attacked by chemical weapons in the Iran-Iraq war of the 80s, was suspected of trying to procure chemical weapons for itself.

In an elaborate operation involving agents from the CIA, Mossad, the Dutch and Polish intelligence agencies as well as MI6, Tomlinson was asked to pose as a businessman knowledgeable about chemicals and approach the Iranians.

The facts, which apparently originated from Tomlinson himself, have already surfaced in the Israeli press. The operation involved an undercover Iranian intelligence officer based in Vienna and known as Tehrani. He in turn was involved with Nahoum Manbar, a shadowy Israeli businessman with links to Mossad; an English woman, Joyce Kiddie, known to MI6; and a company called Bari Trading. MI6 tasked Tomlinson, working under cover, to contact Kiddie, who was known to Manbar, who in turn was known to Tehrani.

Manbar had been a long-term informant for the Israeli internal security service, Shin Bet. According to Kiddie, Manbar had in fact been using his Iranian contacts in attempt to discover the whereabouts of Ron Arad, an Israeli pilot taken prisoner in southern Lebanon in 1986. It is unclear whether MI6, perplexed by Mossad's apparent indifference to its scheme, succeeded in sabotaging the alleged Iranian procurement programme. Tomlinson appears to have been dismissed by MI6 in the midst of this murky operation.

Tomlinson makes a stream of other major allegations which have already come out. He says that MI6 had a spy, code-named Orcadia, in the German Bundesbank as part of an operation, called Jetstream, responsible for economic espionage. He also makes claims, less plausibly, that MI6 officers plotted to assassinate Slobodan Milosevic, and, even less plausibly, that MI6 had a role in Princess Diana's death. He claims, too, that Nelson Mandela was an MI6 agent. He was involved in the release of the names of MI6 officers on to the internet.

MI6 is certain to have long ago undertaken a damage limitation exercise, assuming the worst as soon as Tomlinson made clear he was not going to keep quiet after his sacking six years ago, a sacking he blames on a personal feud with his line manager. MI6 has said he was not a "team player". They have chased and harassed him around Europe. Tomlinson has now responded with his last throw of the dice. But - except in terms of MI6's plummeting prestige as an agency that, above all, can keep its secrets - it may not matter.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Shipman patient unlawfully killed
fields.body:
Shipman patient unlawfully killed

A coroner yesterday recorded a verdict of unlawful killing on another patient of killer GP Harold Shipman. Nellie Mullen, 77, had complained of feeling mildly ill on the morning of her death on May 2, 1993. Soon after Shipman arrived at her flat in Hyde, Greater Manchester, she died from what he said was a heart attack.

Train worker pushed on track

A platform worker suffered head injuries when he was pushed on to an electrified track by a passenger after telling him to move away from a departing train. The rail worker, in his 30s, was seeing off a train at Bromley South station.

Cash boost for child services

Forty councils across England shared £80m in the first allocation from the government's £380m Children's Fund. The councils will get between £1.5m and £2m to provide parenting courses, after-school activities, counselling and support groups for lone parents.

Increase for air traffic control

National Air Traffic Services is to increase recruitment of trainee air traffic controllers by 50% each year. Nats, which is soon to be part-privatised, said the increase followed concern that controllers' workloads were becoming dangerously heavy.

Potency pills ad will not stand up

The Advertising Standards Authority ordered the makers of Natura-Viga to drop claims that its herbal alternative to Viagra would boost "sexual performance, vigour and vitality." It questioned whether testimonials from "satisfied" customers were genuine.

Explicit posters offend women

Most women are easily embarrassed and even offended by sexually explicit billboard adverts, according to a survey. Two thirds of women asked thought advertisers went too far in using sex to sell products.

Flood alerts in west and south

With more rain expected, a flood warning was issued yesterday for the Dart from Dartmeet to Totnes, Devon. Elsewhere, in parts of southern, south-west and eastern England, flood watches were in force.

Police asked to raid school

Three teenage boys were arrested yesterday in school for possession of cannabis. Pool school and community college, near Redruth in Cornwall, took the unusual step of inviting police on to the premises after being told drugs might be being used.

Suicide wrote out rap lyrics

Upset by taunts over his sexuality, David Hurcombe, 17, wrote out lyrics by US rapper Eminem before jumping under a train in September, an inquest at Teignmouth in Devon heard. Verdict: suicide.

Radio centenary transmission

At 4.30pm yesterday the Lizard radio station in Cornwall received a morse signal from the Isle of Wight. It marked the centenary of the first long-distance wireless transmission, by Guglielmo Marconi, and restoration of the world's oldest radio station by the National Trust.

Incriminating evidence

Jayne Williams, 25, and Dean Baker, 24, were each jailed for five years yesterday at Merthyr crown court after admitting supplying heroin. The prosecution produced transcripts of mobile phone text messages, eg: "I have run out of bags. Don't tell anyone to ring me now OK babe - and I think the CID just drove round the car park."
