webTitle: Britons grasp net and mobile phones

fields.headline: Britons grasp net and mobile phones
fields.standfirst:
Poll shows high speed take-up of technological revolution, with 43% now communicating via text messages

More net news
fields.trailText: Britain is enthusiastically embracing the "techno" revolution at an astonishing pace with the rapid spread of the internet outstripped only by the explosion in the use of mobile phones, according to this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll.
fields.body:
Britain is enthusiastically embracing the "techno" revolution at an astonishing pace with the rapid spread of the internet outstripped only by the explosion in the use of mobile phones, according to this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll.

The survey showed that in the last 12 months the internet had become a true mass medium in Britain with nearly half all adults now enjoying on line access at home or at work. In two years internet access had risen from 29% of all adults in January 1999 to 49% now, confirming that the internet was growing at a far faster pace than any previous technological advance, including radio and television. The spread of the internet was accelerating. The 8 percentage point rise in adults online in 1999 was followed by a 12 percentage point increase last year.

But the ICM poll showed that even this impressive record was being outstripped by the spread of the mobile phone. Some 63% of all adults said that they now used a mobile phone to make and receive calls.

The real success story has been the explosion in the use of mobile phones to send and receive text messages. Some 43% of the entire adult population said they used a mobile to send and receive text messages. This rose to an astonishing 76% of all 18 to 24 year olds who said they used text messaging.

It was not just a teenage thing either. Among those up to the age of 35, 68% said they used the service. Over 35, and the figures started to drop sharply with only 41% of the middle aged using text messages and 10% of the over 65s.

But while the poll revealed the extent of the explosion in the use of all this new technology it also confirmed that there was still a disturbing "e-gap" developing between the young and old, the rich and poor, and the north and south. It also showed that half the population was worried about the health hazards of mobile phones. One in four owners of modern video recorders admitted they did not know how to set its "videoplus" facility to record a programme while they were out of the house.

The ICM survey showed that the rapid growth of internet use had been matched by the rise of multichannel television. Some 45% of homes - about 9m - now subscribed to Sky, Ondigital or cable television. The fact that the 11% of homes with Ondigital now also faced the choice of accessing the in ternet via their television rather than through a personal computer started to raise the prospects of "convergence" in the digital age.

The great marketing flop has been the Wap phone, which gives access to the net via your mobile. Only 4% of the population said they used a Wap phone.

There remained a big gap in terms of who had access to all this new technology. When it came to those who were online the rich and more affluent were much more likely to be on the net (73%) compared with the poor and unemployed, of whom only 21% had access. Fifty-four per cent of men and 44% of women said they had access to the net. Sixty three per cent of those under 35 were on the web but only 13% of the over 65s.

Forty three per cent of northerners were hooked up, compared with 54% in the south. When ICM asked how enthusiastic adults were about it all, 68% said they "very" or "fairly" enthusiastic. Only 30% said they were not enthusiastic.

As could be expected, the younger generation and men rather than women tended to be more excited but even 54% of the over 65s said they were happy to embrace these new developments.

One of the greatest worries is the possible health hazards of mobile phones which nearly half the population said they are concerned about. When ICM asked if they were worried enough to put them off buying a mobile phone or to use their existing phone less, some 21% said it had affected their behaviour.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,004 adults aged over 18 by telephone from January 19-21. Interviews were conducted across the country and results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Deal near on free arts entry

fields.headline: Deal near on free arts entry
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, and the culture secretary, Chris Smith, look set to agree a deal within weeks that will scrap admission charges to museums and art galleries.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, and the culture secretary, Chris Smith, look set to agree a deal within weeks that will scrap admission charges to museums and art galleries.

The Treasury and Department of Culture, Media and Sport have been negotiating for six months on how to fulfill the government's commitment to free access. A deal is expected as early as the the March 6 budget.

Ministers have been held up by tax rules, whereby museums that charge can reclaim VAT because they are a business, but those free of charge must pay the tax. While free admission would cost an estimated £23m a year, the real cost would come from writing off this VAT - possibly more than £100m a year.

One solution, advocated by Chris Smith, would be for the 17 museums affected to be grouped with the BBC, ITN and local authorities, which are deemed not to be businesses and are allowed to reclaim VAT.

webTitle: Chilean judge quizzes Pinochet on abuses

fields.headline: Chilean judge quizzes Pinochet on abuses
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet
fields.trailText: In his first appearance before a Chilean judge yesterday, Augusto Pinochet was interrogated by Juan Guzman, who is investigating charges that the former dictator ordered the death and disappearance of at least 74 political prisoners.
fields.body:
In his first appearance before a Chilean judge yesterday, Augusto Pinochet was interrogated by Juan Guzman, who is investigating charges that the former dictator ordered the death and disappearance of at least 74 political prisoners.

The questioning began at Gen Pinochet's Santiago residence, where a group of about 30 Pinochet supporters held placards reading: "Always remembered, never forgotten".

Judge Guzman is seeking answers from Gen Pinochet about a travelling hit squad known as the "caravan of death", and the former dictator's relationship with the Dina secret police, responsible for the more notorious torture and execution sessions. Due to 85-year-old Gen Pinochet's poor health, the interrogation may last for several days.

In December, Judge Guzman ordered the arraignment of Gen Pinochet, but that order was annulled when the supreme court ruled that he should first be questioned. Following yesterday's questioning, Judge Guzman acquired legal authority to issue a new arraignment - and arrest order - against the former head of state.

The questioning comes more than three years after Chilean courts began to inves tigate the dictator's role in the estimated 3,200 murders committed by security forces during his 1973-1990 military rule.

Gen Pinochet had avoided the questioning for months, first through legal appeals and ultimately by ignoring court ordered medical tests. Ricardo Izurieta, commander in chief of the army, finally convinced him to abide by the supreme court ruling and submit to the medical tests and then to the interrogation.

The state of Gen Pinochet's health has been a source of controversy following an article in an online newspaper, www.elmostrador.cl , which uncovered discrepancies in the medical report ordered by the courts. After extensive tests, a team of eight specialists signed a final report at the beginning of January. But they later altered their diagnosis from "mild to moderate" dementia to "moderate".

Luis Fornazzari,a medical specialist representing relatives of the those killed during Gen Pinochet's rule, claims that there was a campaign to exaggerate his illnesses.

"If Pinochet has the same motivations that he had with us during the four mornings and four afternoons of exams, "udge Guzman is going to find a lucid and cooperative person and is not going to have any problems communicating," Mr Fornazzari said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Paris | Japan | Estrada | Dumas
fields.body:
Papon's appeal to be hurried

The European court of human rights in Strasbourg yesterday decided to speed up its hearing of a 90-year-old French war criminal's attempt to be released from prison.

The appeal of Maurice Papon, who has served nearly three years of a 10-year jail sentence for his role in deporting 1,500 Jews from France to Nazi death camps, may be heard in the next six to nine months, the court said. Stuart Jeffries, Paris

Third Japanese minister quits

The prime minister of Japan, Yoshiro Mori, lost his top economic planner to a corruption scandal yesterday, further reducing his party's record-low approval ratings ahead of crucial elections.

Fukushiro Nukaga, minister for the economy, indus try and information technology, became the third cabinet minister to resign in disgrace since Mr Mori took over in April. Elections are due in six months. AP, Tokyo

Travel ban for reeling Estrada

Philippine authorities blocked the disgraced ex-president, Joseph Estrada, from leaving the country yesterday and froze bank accounts, some under his known aliases, while they investigate claims that he plundered the economy.

The moves came amid rumours of coup plots by Estrada sympathisers, and as the army placed a 5,500-man strike force on alert in the capital. Reuters, Manila

Dumas comes under fire

A one-time director of the French oil company Elf yesterday accused the former foreign minister, Roland Dumas, of demanding that his mistress be hired by the company.

Mr Dumas, who faces a five-year jail sentence, is charged along with Christine Deviers-Joncour and five other senior Elf officials with complicity in the misuse of company funds. Stuart Jeffries, Paris

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Celtic Connections | The Disease Detectives
fields.body:
One of Britain's largest folk festivals (it pulled in 85,000 punters last year) has so far received very meagre national air time. Could it be because, unlike Cambridge and Sidmouth, it takes place in Scotland? However, it's time to kiss and make up when Celtic Connections (8.0pm, Radio 2) gets the first of two major transmissions from its various venues around Glasgow. Mike Harding acts as compere for an eclectic mixture of performers from the Scottish folk scene, including Kate Rusby.

In the series commemorating the Victorian age, Jolyon Jenkins looks at the work of 19th century epidemiologists struggling to enhance medical understanding that was still in its infancy. In The Disease Detectives (9.0pm, Radio 4), he recalls the work of Dr John Snow, who tracked down the source of the Soho cholera outbreak of 1854. Jenkins finds that the accepted version of the investigation is not quite the way things unfolded.

fields.headline: The right buff
fields.standfirst: When Victoria Beckham's luggage disappeared it wasn't the police who found out where it was, but her "nail technician". Her what? Hadley Freeman on the new style surgeons
fields.trailText: When Victoria Beckham's luggage disappeared it wasn't the police who found out where it was, but her "nail technician". Her what? Hadley Freeman on the new style surgeons.
fields.body:
The lawsuit over Victoria Beckham's missing luggage has given us a better insight into the Posh life than any celebrity interview ever could. She travels with 11 pieces of baggage ("most of my luggage was Louis Vuitton"), her bikini top is by Maria Grachvogel, her denim jacket is a Ralph Lauren. To top it all off, the alleged thief made contact with Beckham through her "nail technician".

Yet while some balked and puzzled at the term "nail technician", to many women (and some men), this is the most normal part of such life of luxury. Like skinny double caffe lattes and text messaging, nail bars have become part of the daily urban landscape in Britain over the past two or three years. Those without much interest in French manicures and nail transfers could easily have missed them, but so-called nail bars (beauty salons for your hands) are now thriving on British high streets.

Nail technicians, however, are no common-or-garden manicurists. They are the surgeons of the manicuring world. If you want false nails, nail extensions, nail piercings, nail transfers, nail infills, nail art or nail airbrushing, find yourself a nail technician.

"Basically, a manicurist works with the natural nail but a nail technician is someone who works with false nails," explains Joanne King, beauty manager at the Aveda Salon in Harvey Nichols, London. "They apply false nails, extensions and infills, and can make art on the false nails, such as designs and piercings."

Sceptics might be surprised to hear this fad is not exclusive to the under eights. "One woman came in who was well into her 60s and she had a coffee-bean stud pierced through the tip of her nail," says King. "But then, she did have mad hair."

Nails Inc, in South Molton Street, London, offers nail art in any design you could ever desire, all for £25. "The most memorable request was the Louis Vuitton logo for a fashion shoot!" says manager, Emma Knowles. You can also have nail transfers, designed by the uber-trendy Jade Jagger, applied for £10.

Visitors to their salon have included Jennifer Lopez for an acrylic infill (£30), the Spice Girls for manicures (presumably in the pre-nail technician days for Victoria) and Jane MacDonald, singer from the docudrama Cruise. That list says it all - the ultra glam such as La Lopez have nail extensions, but so do the common folk.

This nail obsession has drifted from America - or New York, to be precise. In uptown Manhattan, there have been nail bars on every street for the past 10 years, offering 30-minute manicures for $7. Having a manicure is as normal and easy as stopping off at the supermarket on your way home from work. And nails are taken very, very seriously. In New York, manicurists should be registered with the Council of Nail Technicians, which requires passing a test. As yet, there is no such stipulation in the UK, but nail technicians do have to go through several months of training.

"Lots of American tourists were coming here and wanting to get their nails done while they were visiting Britain, so that created a demand in this country for nail bars," says King.

Also, the arrival of glamorous American television programmes in this country, such as Friends and Sex in the City, has also whetted some British appetites for similar high-maintenance lifestyles - and manicures and nail technicians are part of that (along with personal trainers, weekly body scrubs, visits to the nutritionist ...) "Having your nails done, and having amazing designs on them, is no longer seen as just a treat," says Knowles.

Chris Rhoda, an office manager for an investment capital company, first had nail extensions applied a year ago and now goes for infills every three to four weeks.

"I used to break my nails all the time, and really manky nails look so awful. They can ruin a fabulous outfit. Now nail bars are just so handy - you go, you chat, you have your nails done. It is totally worth the time and money."

Just 10 years ago to have a manicure summoned up images of Ivana Trump and elderly ladies with blue rinses. They belonged to the glamorised 80s universe of Dynasty, and were the province of older women with plenty of time and big baubles on their hands. For those under the age of 60, to have a manicure was unimaginably pretentious.

The late Florence Griffith Joyner, the Olympic runner, showed the world how downright sexy improbable talons looked on a young confident woman when she won three gold medals in 1988, but it wasn't until the rise of mass-market hip hop in the late 90s that the fad took off. Singers Li'l Kim, Missy Elliot and Destiny's Child, who appeal to both sexes of all ages, all sport fabulously ridiculous nails.

Ruth Drake, 26, who works for a music PR company, agrees. She had long false nails applied before going to Miami last year. "I wanted to look bling-bling [extravagant]. I used to think that long, fake nails looked really tacky but then I thought they looked really cool."

All the examples cited above are black. Are extravagant nails more common for black women than white?

"Yes, absolutely," agrees Lannah Nguyen, manageress of Las Vegas Nails in Holborn. "Most of my clients who want piercings and stuff are young black girls. I think it's because black women tend to be more colourful, whereas white women are often more conservative. But the trend is definitely growing in the white community now." The look is, as Drake says, "ghetto fabulous" - that extravagant look mocked by Ali G, now rendered fashionable thanks to singers such as Lopez and Puff Daddy. The rise of nail technicians reflects this, as well as aspirations to the Sex in the City manicure lifestyle.

How typical of Victoria Beckham to help turn the once-irredeemably tacky into something that will always be associated with posh.

Nail polish: the technician's craft

Nail art: the general term for attention-grabbing art on nails. This could be images applied to individual nails, such as faces, sunsets, palm trees, etc, patterns (such as stripes, polka dots, etc), or unusual colour patterns.

Airbrushing: paint comes out of a tube filled with compressed air. This allows the technician to create intricate and miniature images on nails.

Piercing: a tiny drill pierces a hole through the tip of the false nail and a nail ring can then dangle through it.

Transfers: an image applied to your nail, like a sticker.

Nail extensions: acrylic or occasionally fibre glass, gel or another material, is affixed to the tip of your nail to make it appear longer.

Nail enhancements: known to you and me as false nails. These generally come in gel, fibre glass and acrylic. They can last forever, but you will need frequent infills to fill in the base of your nail when the growth of your real nail underneath pushes up the false nail.

Nail infills: see above.

How typical of Victoria Beckham to help turn the once-irredeemably tacky into something that will always be associated with posh. Nail polish: the technician's craft Nail art: the general term for attention-grabbing art on nails. This could be images applied to individual nails, such as faces, sunsets, palm trees, etc, patterns (such as stripes, polka dots, etc), or unusual colour patterns. Airbrushing: paint comes out of a tube filled with compressed air. This allows the technician to create intricate and miniature images on nails. Piercing: a tiny drill pierces a hole through the tip of the false nail and a nail ring can then dangle through it. Transfers: an image applied to your nail, like a sticker. Nail extensions: acrylic or occasionally fibre glass, gel or another material, is affixed to the tip of your nail to make it appear longer. Nail enhancements: known to you and me as false nails. These generally come in gel, fibre glass and acrylic. They can last forever, but you will need frequent infills to fill in the base of your nail when the growth of your real nail underneath pushes up the false nail. Nail infills: see above.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
Woke this morning to fresh snow. It was driving down, wet and almost blizzard-like for a short while but non-committal, a transitory dollop. Nevertheless, it was enough to cover the ground and drift a foot deep into field corners on top of the Edge.

Having somehow managed to injure my ankle, walking became a quite different experience. When each step has a price it makes you appreciate things normally taken for granted. This winter has been full of lessons like that. From torrential rain and flooding we have moved into a cold snap which also seems to be lasting forever.

Our weather-memory is incredibly short. Whatever Nature is throwing at us seems to have always been. Two weeks of hard frost have got right into the bones of the earth. We have not experienced a winter like this since the 1980s. Birds are desperate for food. Little groups of long-tailed tits flick around; their hunger overcoming their nervousness. Robins follow, keeping an eye on all the foragers in case they turn up something. Wrens rummage through the ivy.

Blackbirds meet in circles on the snow, heads up as if smelling out the horizons of the weather. Rooks are busy in their nesting trees. When skies were clear, buzzards and ravens sliced their calls through the cold air, challenging the world. In the snow they're glowering somewhere in the high branches.

A thaw began but did not reach the frozen ground and only turned the snow to slush. Tomorrow it will seem that the world was always slush - a formless ungraspable empire. Winter will play with us this way because we've forgotten our respect for it.

webTitle: TV and Radio: The Adam and Joe show

fields.headline: Making history
fields.standfirst: When Adam and Joe, aka  Adam Buxton and  Joe Cornish, were asked to make a fourth series of their cult show, they knew they were in for tricky times. Here, with the help of those closest to them, they reveal the inside story
fields.trailText: When Adam and Joe, aka Adam Buxton and Joe Cornish, were asked to make a fourth series of their cult show, they knew they were in for tricky times. Here, with the help of those closest to them, they reveal the inside story.
fields.body:
A dam Buxton ("Adam"): After our third series back in 1999 we'd become frustrated with the limitations of the show and decided that it was time to brainstorm new formats that would break us into the mainstream.

Joe Cornish ("Joe"): One idea we had was a spoof quiz show where two teams of celebrities answered surreal questions. In one round we had this big stuffed dog called ROOF! who was lowered from the ceiling, and the contestants had to shout ROOF! ROOF! as he came down. Instead of saying "correct" or "incorrect" we were going to use made up words like "Peetootoo" and "Fajoolies". In the end it fell through because Channel 4 thought it was "too similar" to Shooting Stars, but I don't recall Vic and Bob saying "Peetootoo" or "Fajoolies".

Adam Buxton: Another idea was Adam & Joe's Very Good Time, where we went on holiday and stayed in expensive hotels and someone filmed us. It would have been different from other holiday programmes because it wouldn't have had all those factual bits, just long sequences of swimming and sunbathing and reading. The geniuses at Channel 4 shafted that one at quite an early stage. By that time we were thinking, well, what the hell do you want then?

Joe Cornish: Instead the channel suggested we do a fourth series of The Adam & Joe Show, which I was against because I really felt we'd exhausted the whole home-made, bedroom thing. But then I had lunch with Billie Piper and Chris at the Ivy and Billie said "Why don't you do another series, but like, change a couple of bits so it's like, the same but a tiny bit different? That's what I do with my records."

Billie (Because We Want To): I don't remember saying that, but I might have done. I mean I'm nearly 19 now, you know? I don't really talk that way any more. It sounds more like something Lolly would say.

Lolly (My Radio Rocks, MICKEY): I felt the programme needed to consolidate it's media satire elements and focus on appealing to the core 16-24 demographic. So I put Adam & Joe in touch with Lowrie Turner from Shopping City.

Lowrie Turner (Shopping City): I thought the show had lost touch with real people's lives. What it desperately needed was some kind of live segment set in a public space, involving real people in fast moving con sumer tests and lifestyle features. Look, I can fit a tyre in my mouth!

Joe Cornish: What Lowrie brought to the table was a huge amount of experience of making TV in shopping centres.

Adam Buxton: We tried Lowrie's ideas and came up with a segment called "People Place", which was a big success and really gave us the boost we needed to crack the rest of the series. We came up with the idea of Ken Korda doing South Bank Show style profiles of artists like Handy Andy and Jenny Powell, then a couple of lame West Country video pranksters called The Media Chaos Collective who make crap guerilla TV, and a version of The 1900 House called The 1980s House. But we still had to decide what to do with my father Nigel, who played our youth reporter Baaaddad.

Nigel Buxton ("Baaaddad"): I'd been at a low ebb since we finished the previous series as I'd had several projects fall through. I was particularly excited about a sitcom spin-off from the McCain's commercial called Daddy Or Chips? but it never happened. So when the gig as Baaaddad became available again, I went for it. I'm told my Macintyre Undercover style investigative reports are the strongest thing in the show. That's why they're always at the end, where they won't throw the rest of the programme into the shade.

Joe Cornish: The day before we started shooting, we did something that's become kind of a tradition on our shows. We gathered our entire production team together and screened Greystoke: The Legend Of Tarzan twice. When I say screened, I mean we watched it on the screen of a television. It's a way of inspiring the crew, reminding them what we're aiming for, what's possible in this business.

Adam Buxton: Did it all work? Is the series any good? Who knows, I mean at this stage it's hard to see the wood from the trees, we're just so close to the material, we can't tell. We sent tapes to Billie and she watched half of the first show and said she didn't really understand it but thought it looked as if it was quite funny. Lolly hasn't had a chance to watch them yet because she's very busy and Lowrie Turner said she only really watches documentaries but had we seen something called Trigger Happy TV? Apparently it's amazing.

webTitle: G2: The debate around Holocaust Memorial Day

fields.headline: Myth and memory
fields.standfirst: Britain's first Holocaust Memorial Day is on Saturday - but why has such a laudable event stirred up anger and protest? Because it provokes an uneasy reading of our history, says  David Cesarani
fields.trailText: Britain's first Holocaust Memorial Day is on Saturday - but why has such a laudable event stirred up anger and protest? Because it provokes an uneasy reading of our history, says David Cesarani.
fields.body:
In the 1994 BBC Reith lectures, the writer and critic Marina Warner observed that arguing about the past has become "a vital part of being a member of society, an ordinary but important act of citizenship, a factor in establishing the idea of a home as a place where you would like to belong, and might be allowed to stay". The current row over Holocaust Memorial Day exemplifies the tangled relationship between history and home.

Britain's first Holocaust Memorial Day, on Saturday, will be marked by a ceremony in London attended by political and religious leaders and broadcast live by the BBC. Similar gatherings will be held around the country and schools will hold special assemblies and classes inspired by the day's message: Remembering Genocides. Lessons for the Future.

At first sight this would seem laudable, but the event has been denounced as irrelevant and hypocritical from the left and the right. Representatives of the Armenian community have condemned the day for apparently excluding the slaughter of Armenians by the Turks in 1915-16. They have accused the government of colluding in the denial of the Armenian genocide in order to avoid offending Turkey.

These are serious charges. However, there is more at stake than arguments about the "uniqueness" of the Holocaust or the pathos of the government's "ethical" foreign policy. Those who condemn the event entirely, or merely criticise its "exclusivity", are prone to moral and political myopia.

They are so mired in either universalism or particularism that they have failed to notice that Holocaust Memorial Day is a step towards realising the vision in the Parekh report on the future of multi-ethnic Britain. This development in itself has to be appreciated in the context of global changes which presage the emergence of a new international morality.

None of this occurs to adversaries such as the Observer columnist Nick Cohen, who take their cue from antagonists of the so-called Holocaust industry. They deny that the Holocaust is relevant to Britain and ridicule the idea that it has lessons for today. If the government is serious, why is it locking up asylum seekers and selling arms to regimes with poor records on human rights?

Isn't the Holocaust actually being used to avoid engagement with contemporary atrocities by requiring them to meet an impossible standard before they merit intervention? From the other extreme, the Daily Telegraph has declared that "a special day to commemorate the Nazis' six million Jewish victims was a bad idea in the first place".

Using it to push ideas of political toleration, ethnic inclusivity, and cultural diversity "is to belittle the enormity of what happened, to help bolster New Labour's spurious claim that Britain is riddled with racism". The day "does not deserve wide public support". When the bien penseuses of the left concur with the Daily Telegraph in loathing something, you know it has to be right.

Apart from the fact that Britain was embroiled in the fate of the Jews between 1933 and 1945, Nazi racial-biological policies perpetrated a crime against humanity. Humanity does not stop at the white cliffs of Dover. The day was never intended to be just about Jewish suffering: it will highlight onslaughts against a range of other populations in Nazi Europe and afterwards, including Cambodia, Bosnia, and Rwanda.

There are sound reasons why the day made Nazi atrocities a springboard for examining genocides after 1945. The Nazi assault on the Jews differed from anything that had preceded it. That was why in 1943 Rafael Lemkin invented the concept of genocide: to define something new. The choice of subsequent cases can be debated endlessly, but it is puerile to insist that because the selection is imperfect no one should benefit.

The Holocaust was a dormant subject until the 70s, but before that there was not much interest in previous genocides either. A general shift in the ethical and cultural climate is responsible for concern about the victims of the past. According to Elazar Barkan, author of The Guilt of Nations, "a new international morality" has gradually fallen into place since the 50s.

It began with West Germany's admission of responsibility for Nazi crimes and making reparations to the victims. It was accelerated in the United States when, as part of the 60s Great Society policy, the administration heeded the legacy of slavery and racism, and instigated social policies to correct their effects.

Suddenly the memories harboured by survivors of persecution were no longer a private affair: it was recognised as part of their identity as members of a group. Moreover, this group had a right to claim compensation. Diaspora groups used the democratic process to mobilise and pursue their claims.

Because collective memory is now accepted as integral to personal and group identity, perceptions of history and their ramifications must be accommodated in a pluralistic society. In his 2000 report for the Runnymede Trust, The Future of Multi-Ethnic Britain, Lord (Bhikhu) Parekh contended that to achieve such a goal it would be necessary to retell Britain's "national story".

This entails challenging the myth of Britain as unified and uniform from time immemorial until the arrival of those pesky immigrants. It means questioning the "civic and secular character" of liberal constitutionalism and religious toleration by recognising that they are "embedded in particular cultural values and traditions" with an ethnic hue. Above all, it requires disrupting the simplistic glorification of Empire and recognising the ambiguous impact of British expansionism which was, after all, ultimately responsible for most post-1945 immigration.

Whereas Remembrance Day each November was harnessed to the myth of a doughty island race defending democracy and toleration, Holocaust Memorial Day provokes a queasy reading of British history: a tale of half-hearted opposition to fascism, the mean-spirited treatment of refugees, and prevarication in the face of persecution, later genocide. It begs questions about Britain's role in recent international crises and the treatment of asylum seekers. Yet it can also give those who have found refuge in this country a sense that their scarred memory has become part of our national heritage.

Of course, the day is not perfect. But it will take place annually and it is appropriate if it remains contested ground. Unlike the monolithic remembrance of Britain's mythic past, it defies monopoly. By remembering genocides we are acknowledging the way that past catastrophes have helped to create a multi-ethnic Britain. By confronting the history of intolerance we can help to forge a society in which such things will not recur and the once persecuted can, at last, feel at home.

 David Cesarani is professor of modern Jewish history at Southampton University and a member of the Holocaust Memorial Day steering group. This article reflects his personal views.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge.
fields.body:
Following the horribly public unravelling of her marriage to Richard Gere, who could begrudge Ur-supermodel Cindy Crawford her moment of domestic bliss among the genteel brownstones of New York's Upper East Side? The answer, sadly for Crawford, is her downstairs neighbours John and Marina French, currently claiming that their day-to-day existence is being disturbed by the aural overspill of the model's life, as heard through their mutual wall space.

So disturbed, in fact, that the Frenches filed a lawsuit against Crawford and husband Rande Gerber late last week, protesting at the regularity with which they're obliged to listen to their illustrious neighbour's phone ringing, front door slamming, toilet flushing and platform heels clattering. According to their suit, the Frenches' problems began when Crawford and Gerber renovated the floors and ceilings of their seventh-floor apartment back in the autumn of 1998, a procedure which stripped the place of its evidently all-too-vital sound-proofing.

Although the suit alleges Crawford and spouse have "ignored" their various complaints, the Frenches are selflessly not seeking damages - simply the loss in the value of their property they claim is a direct result of Crawford's incessant racket.

Meanwhile, the long-standing tradition of America's Trekkies stalking and harassing female cast members of the sci-fi franchise took a battering last Thursday, as over-zealous fanboy Marlon Pahtakhan was sent to trial on charges of harassing actress Jeri Ryan (alias Star Trek Voyager's Cyborgian pin-up Seven of Nine).

Having been arrested last November for "wilfully, maliciously and repeatedly" pursuing Ryan, Pahtakhan was dispatched to trial by LA Superior Court Judge Alan Ellis on Thursday, with his arraignment scheduled for this time next week. In the meantime, he's being held in custody in lieu of $405,000 bail.

webTitle: Arts: Arthir Smith's a quick one

fields.headline: A quick one
fields.trailText: Arthur Smith: Going on tour is a tiring business even if, like me, you play only two dates. My European University Towns Tour 2001 has left me exhausted and without socks.
fields.body:
Going on tour is a tiring business even if, like me, you play only two dates. My European University Towns Tour 2001 has left me exhausted and without socks. My first gig was speaking in a debate at the Cambridge Union on "Satire is the lowest form of wit". Oxford gets Michael Jackson, Cambridge gets me.

You have dinner before the event with posh young people in dinner jackets, one of whom says grace in Latin. Then you "process" into the debating hall and the president of the union ascends to a wooden throne. One wonders what the satirist should make of this. He would probably be entirely at home, since, when satire had its afternoon in the sun in the 1960s, most of its practitioners were from Cambridge.

TW3 is remembered fondly by older TV executives, but it never changed anything. Its presenter, David Frost, soon embarked on his long and successful journey up the backside of the establishment. But then, I am the voiceover on the Oxo ad. I'm on the gravy train. Who am I to lecture undergraduates on this subject?

The second date of my tour took me to Tübingen in southern Germany. Although I have received no monies from the local tourist board I am happy to declare that Tübingen is a charming little town with a nice river and an atmosphere both studious and lively. German theatre is much better funded than British. The Landestheater has 120 staff, three auditoriums, 30 plays in repertory and an excellent bar. One of the plays was my own effort, Live Bed Show, translated into German.

I speak no German so I underwent the curious experience of understanding both nothing and everything. I learnt that the German for "one-night stand" is "one-night stand". The cast had rehearsed for a luxurious six weeks and it showed. It was imaginatively staged and acted with such sexy verve that I came over very smug. Not to be missed if you are in the Stuttgart area. I note that I have succeeded in giving my own play a good review. Is that satire?

But then, I am the voiceover on the Oxo ad. I'm on the gravy train. Who am I to lecture undergraduates on this subject? The second date of my tour took me to Tübingen in southern Germany. Although I have received no monies from the local tourist board I am happy to declare that Tübingen is a charming little town with a nice river and an atmosphere both studious and lively. German theatre is much better funded than British. The Landestheater has 120 staff, three auditoriums, 30 plays in repertory and an excellent bar. One of the plays was my own effort, Live Bed Show, translated into German. I speak no German so I underwent the curious experience of understanding both nothing and everything. I learnt that the German for "one-night stand" is "one-night stand". The cast had rehearsed for a luxurious six weeks and it showed. It was imaginatively staged and acted with such sexy verve that I came over very smug. Not to be missed if you are in the Stuttgart area. I note that I have succeeded in giving my own play a good review. Is that satire?

fields.headline: Christopher Dearnley
fields.standfirst: He rebuilt the great organ of St Paul's cathedral and brought its majesty to millions
fields.trailText: He rebuilt the great organ of St Paul's cathedral and brought its majesty to millions.
fields.body:
Christopher Dearnley, who has died in Australia aged 70, served the cause of cathedral music in two hemispheres with great distinction for half a century. As organist and director of music at St Paul's cathedral from 1968-90, he masterminded the music for many state occasions: the thanksgiving service for the Queen's silver jubilee in 1977, the wedding of the Prince and Princess of Wales in 1981 and the Falklands war thanksgiving service in 1982.

Born in Wolverhampton, the third son of an Anglican clergyman, Dearnley was educated at Cranleigh school and Worcester College, Oxford, where he held an organ scholarship from 1948-52. He read theology jointly with music for his BA degree and, in his fourth year, took the degree of B Mus.

This academic grounding stood him in good stead. He produced two books: The Treasury Of English Church Music (Volume III) and English Church Music, 1650-1750, the definitive work on the period, which includes thorough research into the history of the Chapels Royal. In addition, he edited anthems and services, and sat on the editorial board of the New English Hymnal.

After leaving Oxford, Dearnley did his national service in the RAF at Melksham. As the base was near Salisbury, he made contact with the cathedral organist, Douglas Guest, who invited him to play for some services; this led to his appointment as assistant organist.

In 1957, he succeeded Guest, and began a fruitful 11-year tenure, living in the shadow of the tallest spire in England and master of the cathedral's wonderful "Father" Willis organ. Dearnley seized the opportunities; together with Alwyn Surplice and John Birch, the organists of Winchester and Chichester, he worked to revive the Southern Cathedrals Festival and set it on course to become the premier festival of liturgical music in the world.

He introduced instrumental teaching for the choristers to enhance their musical education, something he believed in very strongly. One of the music teachers who responded to his advertisement, Bridget Wateridge, later became his wife and bore him three sons and a daughter. This meant that when he was appointed to St Paul's in 1968, he became the first occupant of the organist's house in Amen Court for more than a century with young children .

The contrast between the plain early English Gothic of Salisbury and the Renaissance splendour and vast acoustic of St Paul's could not be greater. Always forward-looking, Dearnley, who was still only 38, made a positive virtue of the change and enthused his family for the excitements of London, especially the Thames, where he led them on explorations of the shore.

In his new post, he had a dynamic influence, introducing the European tradition of orchestral masses by Mozart, Haydn and Schubert as settings for the Sunday Eucharist. He drove through the rebuilding and enlargement of the cathedral organ, which included a new division over the great west doors featuring a full chorus of horizontally-mounted royal trumpet pipes. Although inaugurated to great effect, they have startled royalty on many occasions, and are now banned when Prince Philip is underneath.

International celebrity organ recitals were given, as well as choral concerts, which drew large audiences. A brilliant recitalist himself, Dearnley was always keen to seize opportunities to make the instrument more accessible, taking part in organ galas at the Royal Albert Hall and Alexandra Palace.

Together with Barry Rose, his sub-organist, he made many superb choral and organ recordings. Always pragmatic, he found things worked best when he played the organ and Rose conducted, so he re-designated him master of the choir, thereby releasing himself from directing at services, and was thus able to provide splendid accompaniments. Choral services were enriched; broadcasts of evensong were electrifying. His last recital in England was a virtuoso performance last June, on the magnificent organ he helped to create.

Dearnley joined the Friends of Cathedral Music (FCM) in 1965, becoming its chairman in 1971. For 19 years, he led a team of dedicated volunteers, who all shared his determination to overcome the many threats to the tradition, by attracting bequests and making grants. During this per- iod, FCM grew tenfold in funds and membership.

Dearnley and his wife emigrated to Australia in 1990, ostensibly to live quieter lives as naturists, and for Dearnley to concentrate on teaching. In the event, after his first post at Christ Church, St Laurence, in Sydney, he was head-hunted by one cathedral after another to direct their music: Hobart, Perth, Sydney and Newcastle, plus the University of Melbourne. He is survived by his wife and children.

fields.headline: The rise of little voice
fields.standfirst: At the age of 44 the soprano Barbara Bonney is determined not to become a 'grown-up' opera singer.  Charlotte Higgins  investigates
fields.trailText: At the age of 44 the soprano Barbara Bonney is determined not to become a 'grown-up' opera singer. Charlotte Higgins investigates.
fields.body:
There are some musicians who hold the world and its grubby realities at arm's length. The American soprano Barbara Bonney is not one of them. She is worldly - in her chic sweater and slim leather skirt she could be an off-duty merchant banker.

She is polished - there are an impressive eight shelves of Chanel and Bobbi Brown in the bathroom of her London house. She is also a realist. "I'm not like a pretty prom queen," she says. "I am not blessed with a sensational voice, as a prom queen is blessed with fantastic looks, and so doesn't have to work at her personality since everyone is going to fall at her feet anyway.

"Because I don't have the greatest voice on earth, I have to make up for it with other qualities, like being nice to my colleagues, like being on time, like being generous ..." She ticks these off with all the efficiency of a management consultant.

Bonney is not being entirely fair to herself. Born in New Jersey in 1956, she has become one of the great sopranos of her generation - a lieder singer of rare intelligence and powerful expressiveness, and an opera performer whose favoured roles, such as Sophie in Der Rosenkavalier, Susanna in The Marriage of Figaro, and Pamina in The Magic Flute, have garnered her huge praise and devoted fans.

She is a light-voiced soprano, not possessed of the sort of sound suited to big, swooning roles in Verdi or Puccini. "I sing opera mainly by Strauss and Mozart because they are intellectually challenging," she says. "In Italian opera, it's all about big emotions and having this gorgeous instrument to play with. I love opera, but I know my own limitations. Some days I wish I had a big voice to throw around but I don't. I just have to make do with what I've got."

The idea of "what I've got" is important to Bonney, as it must be to all singers. Singing is not like playing the cello or flute. You can't throw your voice away if you tire of it, or buy a better one. You can't even see it. "This is why teaching singing is so abstract," she says. "This is why singers' voices tend to be so much part of their personalities. And that's why singers are all so crazy and vulnerable."

For a crazy, vulnerable singer she seems remarkably at peace with her voice. Last month the BBC televised two masterclasses Bonney gave to aspiring young singers. Teaching is close to her heart; after her performing career winds up in perhaps 10 years' time she plans to devote herself to passing on her accumulated wisdom.

Her funny, informal, inspirational classes tended towards one major theme - that the students should find "their own" voices. "Try to sing with your 12-year-old voice," she said more than once. It worked like magic and the young singers would produce a fresher, less manufactured, less affected sound.

"When they do that their voices become something people recognise as being unique and true - and it's also something they can sustain," explains Bonney. "You can't sustain something that's not part of you. You can't say, 'I want to have a voice like Maria Callas's' unless you have a voice like Maria Callas's."

Does Bonney herself sing with her 12-year-old voice? "I have the same voice I started out with. It's got a little bigger, a little more mature, but basically I sing the same way now as I did when I was in 10th grade in high school. Lots of people see this as a failure, they say I should be a 'grown-up' opera singer. But this is something I have striven not to do. There's something meaningless to me about people who just sing with a big loud voice."

Bonney likes an intellectual challenge. When she sings lieder, the words of the songs are as important to her as the music. She learns the poetry by heart first. Only then do the notes come. She prefers to sing in languages she speaks, including German (after a stint at the University of New Hampshire, she went to Salzburg to continue her studies) and Swedish (she lived in Sweden for seven years while she was married to baritone Hakan Hagegard, from whom she is now divorced).

It is rare for her to sing in her native tongue, which is why recording her new disc of 16th- and 17th-century English songs has given her so much pleasure. She enjoys the rawness and ribaldry of the poems, by Sir Philip Sidney and John Dryden, amongothers. "We used to be really sexy naturally," she says. "But we are no longer physically free. That's what this music tells us. That's why this music is important."

Bonney makes no secret of the fact that, in general, she feels more at home on the concert platform as a lieder singer than on a theatre stage. She likes to be able to make eye contact with the audience - impossible if you're in an opera, where the audience is a black shape somewhere out beyond the orchestra pit.

This is also about control. She likes to be out there just with her pianist - that way she can run things. "Lieder singing is exhilarating because you can really feel you have changed someone's life, or your own life," she says. "In opera it is the genre people get excited about - the theatre, the spectacle."

Though opera does have its moments. She talks about singing Sophie in Der Rosenkavalier, one of her signature roles. The character is a naive, innocent girl who has a passionate love scene, culminating in a kiss with Octavian, the Rosenkavalier - a male part sung by a woman. "It's not that I have this butch attitude and women turn me on," says Bonney, "but there is something uniquely exciting about being on stage in front of 5,000 people with opera glasses as this tall, slender, mezzo soprano grabs you, looks deep into your eyes and kisses you on the mouth.

"I'll never forget when Anne Howells did that to me at Covent Garden. It was strangely thrilling. I think that's what the composers wanted. We all know what men feel about women getting together. Strauss was a real buttoned-up bourgeois, and I'm sure it was his way of letting out his fantasies."

Bonney has something of a following among men of a certain age, and regularly receives rather overheated reviews that praise her blonde good looks as much as her fine voice. What does she think about that?

"I'm not going to knock being a girl," she says. "Being a soprano is a wonderful position of female power. Because you know what? No man can ever take my job away from me." As she says this, ripples of silvery laughter exit into the incense-scented atmosphere of her front room. And her laughter sounds like a song.

 Barbara Bonney performs tonight at the Wigmore Hall, London W1 (020-7935 2141). Fairest Isle, her disc of early English songs, is out on Decca.

fields.headline: Dodgy wigs, extravagant costumes, over-the-top speeches? You'd never get away with that on stage ...
fields.standfirst: John Mortimer on the drama of the court case
fields.trailText: John Mortimer on the drama of the court case.
fields.body:
'We are not a theatre," a crusty, ill-tempered old hanging judge used to say, rapping his pencil on the desk to emphasise his remoteness from showbusiness and to still the slightest murmur of laughter in court.

Those were the days when I was a nervous, young, white-wigged barrister. Years later, at the end of a lengthy fraud trial, I congratulated the jury for their patience in sitting through what was undoubtedly the most boring case ever heard in the Old Bailey. In one of the better judicial put-downs a more tolerable judge started his summing up with: "Members of the jury. It may come as a surprise to you to know that the sole purpose of the criminal law of England is not to entertain Mr Mortimer ..."

Were these legal authorities right? Are trials not a form of public entertainment: a sell-out, for instance, when the late lamented George Carman was starring in a sensational libel action, and a depressing lack of bums on seats during a lengthy VAT trail in Snaresbrook?

Having spent a good deal of my life either appearing in real trials or writing trial scenes for drama, and now having written a theatre play about crime and judgment, I have to wonder how near to the theatre the Old Bailey is. The two worlds collided most neatly and satisfactorily for me during the OJ Simpson trial.

One of the defending lawyers got up and said to Judge Ito: "I think, your honour, that we are, as Mr Rumpole would say, in danger of getting a case of premature adjudication," which is something that Rumpole does say. Legal truth and legal fiction seemed to have become satisfactorily mixed.

There is, of course, one factor that distinguishes the Old Bailey from the West Yorkshire Playhouse. No one leaves the theatre to start a sentence of life imprisonment. But there is a good deal of acting down at the Bailey. Habitual criminals are playing cheerful and hopefully lovable Cockney characters, barristers are acting charming and sensible men of the world, and judges are still imitating Felix Aylmer in old movies and rehearsing lines like: "What are the Beatles?"

Work in court, as in the theatre, starts by dressing up. QCs' tail coats and waistcoats have now been reduced to one-piece "monkey jackets", which, under a silk gown, give merely the appearance of a tail coat - another theatrical trick. In front of the mirrors winged collars are clamped on, white bands tied, wigs adjusted.

The legal taste for strange costumes can be exaggerated. I once defended a man accused of murder, who was brought up from the cells on the first day of the Old Bailey session. He was met with the sight of a City dignitary wearing a hat like a fur muff and carrying a sword, another in a three-cornered hat with black ostrich feathers and a judge sniffing a nosegay designed to ward off the stench of Newgate prison, which had been pulled down at the beginning of the century.

My client cried out, "The day of judgment is at hand!" and had to be removed to a criminal lunatic asylum. In this case it may be thought that the legal love of theatre had gone too far; but it must be remembered that professional criminals don't want to be sent down by judges casually dressed in T-shirts and trainers. They like to get justice done in the full monty, so to speak.

Once you are properly dressed, wigged and gowned, how much is appearing in court like acting in a play?

In some ways the language is even more archaic and the meanings more deeply hidden than in the theatre, particularly when addressing judges. "If I may humbly submit to your lordship," means, "Shut up, you old fart, and listen to me," and, "Your lordship puts the point far better than I can," means, "Well done, dickhead, you've got it at last." Performing to a jury does entail, however, the use of simple, direct language and can be greatly assisted by theatrical technique.

My father, an accomplished courtroom advocate, once appeared for a well-known comedian who congratulated him on his timing. From then on my father became very keen on timing and always used to count up to 10 in silence before asking the first question. This, he said, unnerved hostile witnesses and made them think you were planning a devastating attack. In my early days I tried the same technique, and was instantly told to get on with it by the judge and not to keep everyone waiting while I stood in silent prayer.

Edward Marshall Hall, perhaps the greatest criminal defender, was always preceded into court by three clerks, one carrying a pile of clean handkerchiefs, the next with a carafe of water and the third bearing an air cushion. If the prosecution evidence was impressive he would blow his nose, a loud and terrible trumpet, on the handkerchiefs; if it got more dangerous he would knock over the carafe of water; if it looked like becoming fatal he would slowly and deliberately blow up the air cushion, and so attract the jury's undivided attention.

Marshall Hall's acting technique was old fashioned, but wonderfully effective. He would end his final speech by holding out his arms to represent the scales of justice. "Evenly balanced, until you put in one side that small feather, the presumption of innocence. And then" - and here one arm sank - "the scales come down on the side of the defence." On one occasion the judge, a merciless dramatic critic, told the jury that he was always pleased when Marshall Hall came to his scales of justice act, "Because that means his speech is almost over."

All the same, some of Marshall Hall's theatrical moments were admirable. He defended a terrified young prostitute accused of murder. "Look at her, members of the jury." He pointed to the miserable girl in the dock. "God never gave her a chance! Will you?" I never went as far as Marshall Hall, only daring to chew Polo mints moderately loudly during a prosecutor's opening speech.

But there are, it seems to me, legitimate uses of theatrical techniques in courtrooms. Opening a case to a jury you have to tell a story in a way that holds the audience's attention, using pauses and suspense to keep them listening. You should never lose your temper, but there are moments when you can act anger and outrage, either at the prosecution or, in extreme cases, if you decide to ditch a particularly hostile judge.

As the result of my pretended anger in a case in Singapore the prosecutor asked for time off so he could recover from my attack, probably with bed rest and counselling. The Chinese judge thought this was absolutely pathetic and we won the case. Simulated anger, however, should be used only in extreme cases and simulated weeping never.

So how does all this affect courtroom drama? Real trials, which go at the speed of a judge's note, are too slow to be reproduced on stage, and the activity in court - the constant coming and going, whispering, telephoning by the clerk of the court, covert doing of crosswords during boring stretches - is never seen on television. But writing a play that deals with matters of justice, I am on familiar ground.

The jury, now called the audience, has to be asked to perform an act of the imagination, either in picturing the scene of a real crime or accepting that the actors are real people. One weapon open to the courtroom advocate is not available in the theatre. You can, in extreme cases, bore a judge into submission.

You can go on until he is in real danger of missing the last train to Godalming. Bore an audience for five minutes and you've lost them for an hour. There is no place for boredom in the theatre, which is what makes plays more enjoyable than trials. Also, they don't last nearly so long.

 Naked Justice by John Mortimer is at the West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds (0113- 213 7700), from Friday until February 24.

Habitual criminals are playing cheerful and hopefully lovable Cockney characters, barristers are acting charming and sensible men of the world, and judges are still imitating Felix Aylmer in old movies and rehearsing lines like: "What are the Beatles?" Work in court, as in the theatre, starts by dressing up. QCs' tail coats and waistcoats have now been reduced to one-piece "monkey jackets", which, under a silk gown, give merely the appearance of a tail coat - another theatrical trick. In front of the mirrors winged collars are clamped on, white bands tied, wigs adjusted. The legal taste for strange costumes can be exaggerated. I once defended a man accused of murder, who was brought up from the cells on the first day of the Old Bailey session. He was met with the sight of a City dignitary wearing a hat like a fur muff and carrying a sword, another in a three-cornered hat with black ostrich feathers and a judge sniffing a nosegay designed to ward off the stench of Newgate prison, which had been pulled down at the beginning of the century. My client cried out, "The day of judgment is at hand!" and had to be removed to a criminal lunatic asylum. In this case it may be thought that the legal love of theatre had gone too far; but it must be remembered that professional criminals don't want to be sent down by judges casually dressed in T-shirts and trainers. They like to get justice done in the full monty, so to speak. Once you are properly dressed, wigged and gowned, how much is appearing in court like acting in a play? In some ways the language is even more archaic and the meanings more deeply hidden than in the theatre, particularly when addressing judges. "If I may humbly submit to your lordship," means, "Shut up, you old fart, and listen to me," and, "Your lordship puts the point far better than I can," means, "Well done, dickhead, you've got it at last." Performing to a jury does entail, however, the use of simple, direct language and can be greatly assisted by theatrical technique. My father, an accomplished courtroom advocate, once appeared for a well-known comedian who congratulated him on his timing. From then on my father became very keen on timing and always used to count up to 10 in silence before asking the first question. This, he said, unnerved hostile witnesses and made them think you were planning a devastating attack. In my early days I tried the same technique, and was instantly told to get on with it by the judge and not to keep everyone waiting while I stood in silent prayer. Edward Marshall Hall, perhaps the greatest criminal defender, was always preceded into court by three clerks, one carrying a pile of clean handkerchiefs, the next with a carafe of water and the third bearing an air cushion. If the prosecution evidence was impressive he would blow his nose, a loud and terrible trumpet, on the handkerchiefs; if it got more dangerous he would knock over the carafe of water; if it looked like becoming fatal he would slowly and deliberately blow up the air cushion, and so attract the jury's undivided attention. Marshall Hall's acting technique was old fashioned, but wonderfully effective. He would end his final speech by holding out his arms to represent the scales of justice. "Evenly balanced, until you put in one side that small feather, the presumption of innocence. And then" - and here one arm sank - "the scales come down on the side of the defence." On one occasion the judge, a merciless dramatic critic, told the jury that he was always pleased when Marshall Hall came to his scales of justice act, "Because that means his speech is almost over." All the same, some of Marshall Hall's theatrical moments were admirable. He defended a terrified young prostitute accused of murder. "Look at her, members of the jury." He pointed to the miserable girl in the dock. "God never gave her a chance! Will you?" I never went as far as Marshall Hall, only daring to chew Polo mints moderately loudly during a prosecutor's opening speech. But there are, it seems to me, legitimate uses of theatrical techniques in courtrooms. Opening a case to a jury you have to tell a story in a way that holds the audience's attention, using pauses and suspense to keep them listening. You should never lose your temper, but there are moments when you can act anger and outrage, either at the prosecution or, in extreme cases, if you decide to ditch a particularly hostile judge. As the result of my pretended anger in a case in Singapore the prosecutor asked for time off so he could recover from my attack, probably with bed rest and counselling. The Chinese judge thought this was absolutely pathetic and we won the case. Simulated anger, however, should be used only in extreme cases and simulated weeping never. So how does all this affect courtroom drama? Real trials, which go at the speed of a judge's note, are too slow to be reproduced on stage, and the activity in court - the constant coming and going, whispering, telephoning by the clerk of the court, covert doing of crosswords during boring stretches - is never seen on television. But writing a play that deals with matters of justice, I am on familiar ground. The jury, now called the audience, has to be asked to perform an act of the imagination, either in picturing the scene of a real crime or accepting that the actors are real people. One weapon open to the courtroom advocate is not available in the theatre. You can, in extreme cases, bore a judge into submission. You can go on until he is in real danger of missing the last train to Godalming. Bore an audience for five minutes and you've lost them for an hour. There is no place for boredom in the theatre, which is what makes plays more enjoyable than trials. Also, they don't last nearly so long.  Naked Justice by John Mortimer is at the West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds (0113- 213 7700), from Friday until February 24.

webTitle: Arts: Danny Leigh meets musician Steve Malkmus

fields.headline: 'I rock like a beast'
fields.standfirst: Steve Malkmus had carved himself a nice cosy niche as the frontman of indie band Pavement. Why did he pack it all in? He talks to  Danny Leigh
fields.trailText: Steve Malkmus had carved himself a nice cosy niche as the frontman of indie band Pavement. Why did he pack it all in? He talks to Danny Leigh.
fields.body:
Ultimately it wasn't money or musical differences, fist fights or drug habits. It wasn't any of the rock cliches that caused Steve Malkmus to call time on Pavement, the languid indie rock band he had led for 10 years, and launch a solo career. It was, at least in part, down to male grooming products.

But then Pavement, masters of tangent-happy melodies and arcane wordplay, were not your typical rock group. And the strangely professorial Malkmus was never your typical rock star. Sipping tea and cadging cigarettes on "promotional vacation" from his home in Portland, Oregon, he ambles through the chronology that climaxed with his imminent solo album.

No, there were no bloody ruckuses in rehearsal rooms, just "a lot of good old-fashioned passive-aggressiveness". No, there was no earth-shattering epiphany, just "the recollection I'd been saying 'OK gents, it's over' before every tour since the mid-1990s." In his laconic, laissez-faire kind of way, Malkmus simply walked early last year, and Pavement simply ended.

"But by then," he says, "everyone had their own lives going on all across the States. There'd been this ... diaspora. So it was a question of coldly measuring the problems of getting everyone together against the benefits of what we ended up with." He smiles, almost guiltily. "Plus I just couldn't imagine going to another photo session with all of us there. I know that sounds vain, but I just couldn't see it, standing there at seven in the morning, smelling other people's aftershave."

Was it really that bad?

"Yeah. I mean, no. Not really. But the aftershave thing stuck with me."

Aftershave and diaspora: going by the pained look on his face, you could not find better reasons to fly the nest. Yet there are two strange things about Malkmus's bid for sweet-scented freedom. The first is its timing. Because, while Pavement failed to crack the mainstream in either Britain or the US - and, more importantly, failed to look as if they wanted to - theirs was a comfortable niche.

Warmly supported by a loyal fanbase ever since 1992's debut Slanted and Enchanted, they were, by the end, a minor institution. They even had the occasional hit: the caustic Cut Your Hair, the singalong Stereo. Mention this and Malkmus shrugs.

"Oh, but 10 years is a huge amount of time for any band, let alone a band like ours. And when you're realistic about what's going on creatively, there's only a certain amount you can do before it becomes a nostalgia deal. It's like, does the world need another U2 song? Not really." He bites his lip for a second. "Although then you could say, 'Well, do we need another song by me? Not really.' But I guess if you do feel the need to ... it's a horrible way to say it, but to express yourself creatively , then you can at least try these little acts of subterfuge."

The other strange thing is the album itself, which sounds smart, witty and endearingly angular. In short, exactly like Pavement. That's fine for those with a yen for witty, angular guitar rock, but anyone expecting a bold artistic departure is in for a disappointment.

Another shrug. "You know, I had tunes that I'd done in my house that I wanted to get out of my system. I mean, I can be arrogant and say, 'Yeah, it's a great album - pick it up.' But it's still just basic All Tomorrow's Parties indie-rock. I don't know, hopefully there'll be enough people out there who think it's good, rather than just, 'Oh, put that dog out of its misery.' Although there are people that think that. Some of my friends included."

As you may have guessed, Malkmus isn't big on the hard sell, or on keeping up with the latest trend ("It's supposed to be the kind of record you hear on the jukebox"). That, too, was Pavement in a nutshell: never quite ironic, never quite sincere, reliably on the sidelines of every passing trend.

As Nirvana raged through the early 1990s, so Pavement turned cleaner, and prettier; then came the chirruping inanity of Britpop, pushing them squarely to the margins (even if Blur's Damon Albarn later claimed them as an influence). And, more recently, with the professionally tortured likes of Radiohead vying for sales with the bovine rap-metal of Limp Bizkit et al, Malkmus still couldn't be further from the zeitgeist.

"Well, I've always been a sucker for the contrarian impulse," he drawls, before claiming he'd like nothing more than "people joining in harmony to my songs, like a Coke commercial." Really? "Um, yeah. It's just other people do that stuff better than me. I don't know, I have trouble with the anthem. I mean, I can emote, but it's hard for me to feel too much universal camaraderie. Whatever pulse it is people pick up with someone like Radiohead, I don't have it."

Not that the man or his music are cold exactly; just perennially semi-detached, ill at ease with the arrested development of most rock musicians. "I was never into hanging out backstage with the boys and the beers." There's a word for Malkmus that marks him out from his peer group: intelligent. "But I'm kind of loath to play on that," he says. "I mean, I'm not too enthused about being The Smart Guy Who Plays Guitar."

With his dry, vaguely patrician demeanour, Malkmus just doesn't seem born to rock. "But I'd play tough-guy boogie if I could," he insists. "I don't know, the thing is if you're middle-class in America, you don't have that same fire in your belly. So just the idea of not having a shitty day job is great. And I mean, I'm in my early 30s now, so if I wanted to be a doctor, I'd have to go to medical school for seven years and everything."

He isn't joking. But that's good: it's rare to find a rock musician who can imagine a life beyond shifting units and getting tinnitus. How about writing? Highly literate, he must know he's closer in lots of ways to novelists such as Dave Eggers and David Foster Wallace than to Bono and Kid Rock?

"Yeah. Writing's something I think about. It'd be nice to take a crack at it in my 40s. But what I would say about Wallace and Eggers is - could they go out and front a band like I do? I mean, I can rock when I want to. I rock like a beast." And then he leans forward. "Shall we get some more tea?"

 The album Stephen Malkmus is out on Domino on February 12.

fields.headline: Ian Taylor
fields.standfirst: Sociologist pioneering radical approaches to the study of crime, sport and popular culture
fields.trailText: Sociologist pioneering radical approaches to the study of crime, sport and popular culture.
fields.body:
Professor Ian Taylor, who has died of cancer, aged 56, was a founder member of the National Deviancy Symposium, that irreverent, anarchistic bunch of sociologists who got together in the late 1960s, rehearsing many of the themes and controversies later to be associated with postmodernism, and revolutionising criminology out of recognition.

In 1973, he co-authored The New Criminology, which remains in print; in 1981, while a lecturer at Sheffield University, he published Law And Order: Arguments For Socialism, which forcefully argued the need for parties of the left to take seriously the problems of crime, prefiguring much of the present shift in policy and debate.

Taylor was a key figure in the politically-committed sociology that emerged in the 1960s. Radicalised, like so many of his generation, by the political flux of the time, he worked prolifically in the fields of criminology, politics, urban studies, sport and popular culture. He was a polymath, writing on a wide array of subjects, including soccer hooliganism, gun control, the Hillsborough disaster, glam rock and money laundering.

His recent work included an article and a consultancy on the Italian village planned in Manchester, and his last piece, written from his hospital bed for the Times Literary Supplement, was about Canadian populism and the so-called "common sense revolution".

In the 1980s, while working as a professor at Carleton University in Canada, Taylor began to develop a criminology which rooted the problem of crime within the wider political economy, a position that became the hallmark of his later work. But his interests were not solely theoretical. Following the Dunblane massacre, he became active, both politically and as a researcher, in the campaign to control gun ownership, which made him the target of attack. Numerous packages, containing bullets, used syringes and decaying meat, arrived at his address, and the police eventually arrested an irate gun enthusiast.

Taylor's latest book, to my mind the best, is Crime In Context (1999). In it, he traces not only how market societies generate crime, but how crime itself can be seen as operating as a market place. Critically acclaimed, it was awarded the American Society of Criminology's prestigious Michael J Hindelang award.

Taylor was born in Sheffield and educated at Durham and Cambridge universities, returning to Durham to complete his PhD. His first job was at the University of Bradford, but he spent a considerable part of his working life in Canada and Australia. It was in Canada that he met his wife Ruth Jamieson, with whom he had two much-loved daughters, Jean and Anna.

His relationship with Ruth was to be a great intellectual partnership: they influenced and supported each other's work, and together wrote on areas as diverse as masculine protest in the de-industrialised cities of present-day Britain and the trafficking of humans across European borders.

Taylor's years in Canada were happy, but he missed the sport and the politics of home. I remember visiting him in Ottawa; there was an airmailed New Statesman on the table, a video of Match Of The Day playing on the television. He returned to England in 1989 and took up the chair of sociology at the University of Salford. His book, A Tale Of Two Cities, written in this period with his research team, about Manchester and Sheffield, is a classic documentation of the shape and direction of urban anxieties at the end of the 20th century.

But it was on Europe that Taylor's major research focused. An ardent European, he revelled in the multiplicity of cultures and the juxtaposition of difference as much as he extolled the great achievements of the welfare states of northern Europe. He was, all his life, a committed socialist; the iniquities of Thatcherism and the antics of New Labour only served to confirm these beliefs.

In 1998, Taylor returned to the University of Durham as principal of Van Mildert College, a position in which he took great pastoral delight and satisfaction. Throughout his career, he travelled widely and enjoyed himself thoroughly. He enthused about meeting Pele at the 1970 World Cup in Mexico and, two decades later, having tea with Eric Cantona.

He was a perpetual optimist, as befits a lifelong supporter of Sheffield Wednesday. I remember him taking me and my eldest son, Jesse, to Old Trafford to watch Wednesday play the home team. He insisted that the best view was from behind the Manchester United goal. There he sat, doggedly refusing the stewards' requests to remove his Wednesday scarf and cheering every time his team approached the United goal. Jesse described the experience as surreal, and I have never been so frightened in my life.

But that was Ian, one man in 10,000, sticking to his beliefs, enthusiastic about the game, critical in his judgments - a flair that characterised him throughout his life.

His wife and children survive him.
