fields.headline: Henck Arron
fields.standfirst: Banker who won independence for Suriname
fields.trailText: Banker who won independence for Suriname.
fields.body:
Henck Arron, who has died aged 64, was the former prime minister of Suriname, a slab of Amazonian jungle and coastal swamp on the northeast shoulder of South America. He was also one of that dwindling band of politicians who led their countries to independence in the latter half of the 20th century.

In Arron's case, the colonists were the Dutch, who were not sorry to see the back of the territory. They won sovereignty over Suriname in 1667, at the same time as they lost New York; even though it became the world's biggest producer of bauxite, it proved to be poor compensation.

The colonial authorities established a plantation economy based on African slavery, which the Netherlands was the last European nation to abolish. The freed slaves were later replaced by indentured labourers, first from India, then from Indonesia, producing an ethnic jigsaw puzzle which complicated the post-independence task of unification.

Two-thirds of the population, of less than 500,000, is split between the majority Africans and Hindustanis, while the Javanese make up about 15%. Maroons - the descendants of escaped slaves, known in Suriname as "Bush Negroes" - constitute around 10%, and the native Amerindians 2.5%.

Political affiliation has historically been based mainly on race; Arron's loyalty was to the Creole (Afro-Surinamese) National party of Suriname (NPS), which he joined in 1961. Born in the capital, Paramaribo, he obtained a banking degree in the Netherlands, and worked for the Amsterdamse Bank before returning to Suriname. In 1963, he was elected to parliament.

Arron took over the NPS leadership in 1970, remaining its chairman for 23 years. He led the party to victory in the 1973 elections and, as prime minister, opened independence talks with the Dutch government, even though the idea was unpopular with the electorate and had not been mentioned in his manifesto.

The NPS was influenced by Caribbean black power ideas, and the conservative Progressive Reform party (VHP), mainly identified with the Indian community, feared a re-run of events in neighbouring Guyana, where independence from Britain had been followed by authoritarian Afro-Guyanese rule. There were even fears of civil war in Suriname. But the Arron/NPS line prevailed; the VHP reconciled itself to independence, and the prime minister took the credit for a substantial aid package agreed with the Hague.

Independence was not, however, an unalloyed blessing; politics degenerated further into ethnic polarisation and corruption, with the NPS using Dutch aid money for partisan purposes. Its leaders were accused of fraud in the 1977 elections, in which Arron won a further term, and the discontent was such that a large chunk of the population fled to the Netherlands.

So when some army NCOs, led by Master-Sergeant Desi Bouterse, overthrew the government in 1980, there were few protests. The soldiers, veterans of the Dutch army, resented the fact that they were not allowed to belong to a union. They had not originally intended to seize power; "We wanted a union and we got a nation," one of them remarked.

It was Arron himself who had insisted, despite Dutch reluctance, that Suriname needed an army. "He was rather vain," said a foreign businessman who knew him. "He wanted a guard of honour at the airport when he came home from overseas trips."

So, paradoxically, in 1980 Arron was accused of corruption and jailed by the very military he had created. He bore the ill-treatment and humiliation with courage; the charges did not stick, he was released in 1981, and, a year later, became managing director of the Surinaamse Volkskredietbank.

Under Bouterse, conditions went from bad to worse. The Netherlands cut off aid in protest at his execution of 15 civilian opponents in 1982, and, in 1986, a Maroon insurgency broke out, led by former Bouterse bodyguard Ronnie Brunswijk. When the military were eventually compelled, under pressure from abroad, to hand back power in 1987, Arron - who had resumed the NPS leadership in 1985, when the army relaxed a ban on political activity - became vice-president and prime minister of a coalition government.

On Christmas Eve 1990, in the so-called "telephone coup", Bouterse's men again told the civilian government to pack its bags. This time, formal military rule was more rapidly ended, although Bouterse remains immensely influential and wealthy. Arron, meanwhile, had retired from politics. fields.bodyText: Henck Arron, who has died aged 64, was the former prime minister of Suriname, a slab of Amazonian jungle and coastal swamp on the northeast shoulder of South America. He was also one of that dwindling band of politicians who led their countries to independence in the latter half of the 20th century. In Arron's case, the colonists were the Dutch, who were not sorry to see the back of the territory. They won sovereignty over Suriname in 1667, at the same time as they lost New York; even though it became the world's biggest producer of bauxite, it proved to be poor compensation. The colonial authorities established a plantation economy based on African slavery, which the Netherlands was the last European nation to abolish. The freed slaves were later replaced by indentured labourers, first from India, then from Indonesia, producing an ethnic jigsaw puzzle which complicated the post-independence task of unification. Two-thirds of the population, of less than 500,000, is split between the majority Africans and Hindustanis, while the Javanese make up about 15%. Maroons - the descendants of escaped slaves, known in Suriname as "Bush Negroes" - constitute around 10%, and the native Amerindians 2.5%. Political affiliation has historically been based mainly on race; Arron's loyalty was to the Creole (Afro-Surinamese) National party of Suriname (NPS), which he joined in 1961. Born in the capital, Paramaribo, he obtained a banking degree in the Netherlands, and worked for the Amsterdamse Bank before returning to Suriname. In 1963, he was elected to parliament. Arron took over the NPS leadership in 1970, remaining its chairman for 23 years. He led the party to victory in the 1973 elections and, as prime minister, opened independence talks with the Dutch government, even though the idea was unpopular with the electorate and had not been mentioned in his manifesto. The NPS was influenced by Caribbean black power ideas, and the conservative Progressive Reform party (VHP), mainly identified with the Indian community, feared a re-run of events in neighbouring Guyana, where independence from Britain had been followed by authoritarian Afro-Guyanese rule. There were even fears of civil war in Suriname. But the Arron/NPS line prevailed; the VHP reconciled itself to independence, and the prime minister took the credit for a substantial aid package agreed with the Hague. Independence was not, however, an unalloyed blessing; politics degenerated further into ethnic polarisation and corruption, with the NPS using Dutch aid money for partisan purposes. Its leaders were accused of fraud in the 1977 elections, in which Arron won a further term, and the discontent was such that a large chunk of the population fled to the Netherlands. So when some army NCOs, led by Master-Sergeant Desi Bouterse, overthrew the government in 1980, there were few protests. The soldiers, veterans of the Dutch army, resented the fact that they were not allowed to belong to a union. They had not originally intended to seize power; "We wanted a union and we got a nation," one of them remarked. It was Arron himself who had insisted, despite Dutch reluctance, that Suriname needed an army. "He was rather vain," said a foreign businessman who knew him. "He wanted a guard of honour at the airport when he came home from overseas trips." So, paradoxically, in 1980 Arron was accused of corruption and jailed by the very military he had created. fields.headline: Migrants try to fight expulsion
fields.trailText: Immigrants from Morocco, sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America and Pakistan staged sit-ins and protests across Spain yesterday against a law that could, if the authorities press on with enforcement, lead to the expulsion of 60,000 or more people who entered the country illegally.
fields.body:
Immigrants from Morocco, sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America and Pakistan staged sit-ins and protests across Spain yesterday against a law that could, if the authorities press on with enforcement, lead to the expulsion of 60,000 or more people who entered the country illegally.

As the stringent rules came into force yesterday, thousands of unregistered foreigners queued at government offices in a last-minute bid to get work and residency papers allowing them to stay.

The conservative Spanish prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, has pledged to tackle the rise in illegal immigration following last year's race riots in the south-eastern town of El Ejido, near Almeria. "To give the same rights to both legal and illegal immigrants, that is something unthinkable," Mr Aznar has warned.

Hundreds of clandestinos, paying up to £1,000 a head, cross the busy shipping lanes of the Straitof Gibraltar every week. Many drown when their overladen vessels capsize or are involved in collisions.

Those who make it from Morocco head for northern cities such as Barcelona or for the south-eastern vegetable and fruit farms which rely on cheap labour.

There are tens of thousands of Ecuadorians working on farms in Murcia, Lorca and Almeria. Chanting "We are not illegals, we are people", they staged protests across the region. Some wore white bands demanding papers to normalise their status, others called for the right to work.

In Barcelona, 300 immigrants, mainly Pakistanis and a few Bangladeshis and Senegalese, locked themselves inside the Santa Maria Pi church in the old city and announced plans to stage a hunger strike. "Papers for All," their banners declared.

In the Spanish-run north African enclave of Melilla, hundreds of Pakistanis who had arrived via north Africa, joined in the demonstrations.

More than 60,000 people whose residency or work permit applications were turned down last year now face deportation. They include immigrants from as far afield as China, Argentina, Mauritania Ukraine and Nigeria. As well as streamlining procedures to expel illegal immigrants, the new law curbs their rights to join in protests and strikes.

No one knows how many foreign workers will be affected by tightening the rules. One charity suggested yesterday that there could be as many as 300,000 illegal immigrants in Spain.

The cost of detaining and subsequently deporting those deemed illegal is expected to be high - one estimate suggests it will cost £300,000 simply to repatriate the 4,426 Ecuadorians whose applications have already been denied.

Mr Aznar admits that Spain needs foreign workers, but the rate of arrivals has disconcerted many Spaniards despite only around 2% of the official population hailing from abroad: in Germany, as many as 12% were born abroad.

webTitle: Stop stifling debate, critics warn government

fields.headline: Stop stifling debate, critics warn government
fields.standfirst: £3m advertising campaign could backfire as support grows for rebel doctor's views on links with autism
fields.trailText: The government's £3m campaign to persuade parents to take their children for MMR vaccination looked as though it could backfire yesterday, as critics argued that the government was out to stifle debate over controversial claims that it could be linked to autism.
fields.body:
The government's £3m campaign to persuade parents to take their children for MMR vaccination looked as though it could backfire yesterday, as critics argued that the government was out to stifle debate over controversial claims that it could be linked to autism.

"Government money should be spent on the vital research needed to answer the questions raised about MMR and autism, not advertising," said the National Autistic Society (NAS). "These hollow advertising campaigns only serve to patronise parents and raise their suspicions.

"The NAS is aware that there have been a number of high quality research proposals which have been submitted to the various research funding bodies, including the Medical Research Council, and have been turned down. There is no doubt that public confidence in MMR is falling. Advertising campaigns do not provide answers. Proper research does. The government should think again about its priorities."

The Department of Health is to blitz parents, GPs, practice nurses and health visitors with leaflets and videos, as well as funding four weeks of national television adverts, but it was clear yesterday that the groups of scientists from the Royal Free hospital medical school in London who believe there may be a link between the MMR, bowel disease and autism will not give up and go away. Andrew Wakefield, the consultant gastroenterologist who has been at the centre of the row, is believed to have further research projects in the pipeline.

Dr Wakefield's supporters say he is under heavy pressure from the medical establishment and unable to speak out freely in defence of his views, but that he will not give up his hypothesis, in spite of the weight of evidence against him advanced by the Department of Health. He has become the champion of the parents who have arrived at the Royal Free in increasing numbers, worried that their children's autism may be caused by the MMR vaccination. His original study group was 12. He now says he has 170 in which the majority of parents have documentary evidence that the symptoms first showed after the jab.

The hostility of the Department of Health, which has tended to write off his concerns as "bad science", has only served to make him more determined to look after the interests of those parents and their children, say his supporters.

Positions are hardening. In an interview at the weekend, Dr Wakefield said the government's insistence that study after study had proved the MMR was safe was "not an honest appraisal of the science and it relegates the scientific issues to the bottom of the barrel in favour of winning a propaganda war."

Yesterday Scott Montgomery, an epidemiologist who co-authored the latest piece of work which looks at the safety data from the trials of the combined MMR vaccine before it was licensed in the UK in 1988, said the government would not reassure the public by dismissing their concerns. "People are always suspicious when they think they can hear the cogs of the propaganda machine in motion," he said.

He and others who work with Dr Wakefield believe there may be adverse events or side effects of the vaccination that take time to show themselves. "What we are concerned about is delayed events, events that occur some time after vaccination, and insidious events like autism which doesn't have a day when it obviously starts - it creeps up and it is hard to pinpoint the time when that starts exactly."

They argued in their paper in the medical journal Adverse Drug Reactions that the children given MMR in clinical trials were only followed up for a maximum of 28 days, not long enough for any possible problems in the gut or autism to be detected. The Department of Health said this was factually incorrect, as some trials were followed up for six to nine weeks. Dr Wakefield's supporters counter that any such trials are not in the public domain because the drug companies have claimed they are commercially confidential.

There have been further bitter exchanges over a 10-year study of the side effects of MMR in Finland, which the De partment of Health claimed proved that there was no possible link to autism. Dr Montgomery and others have dismissed the study as a passive surveillance exercise, saying autism would not be picked up because none of the doctors reporting side-effects was aware of the possibility.

Yesterday Elizabeth Miller, epidemiologist and head of the immunisation service of the Public Health Laboratory Service, defended the Finnish study. "It is not fair for Wakefield to dismiss it as a passive surveillance system," she said. Clinicians were specifically asked to report any chronic disease that set in after the jab. In Dr Wakefield's original study of 12 children published in the Lancet in 1998, the average onset of autism was given as 6.3 days after the injection. "Cases of autism in association with bowel disease would certainly have been detected," she said.

But Dr Wakefield and his inflammatory bowel diseases study group at the Royal Free believe they are piecing together a jigsaw. His original study found inflammation of the bowel in autistic children. Yet to be published is a study in Dublin, which is said to have found measles RNA, which could only have been produced by the measles virus, in the gut of autistic children and not in the gut of others without autism.

The next piece of the jigsaw is work suggesting that toxic chemicals which get into the gut in our food can pass through it if the gut is damaged by inflammatory disease. The Norwegian scientist Kalle Reichelt in the 1980s found an excess of opioid peptides, which occur naturally in bread, milk and other foods, in the central nervous system of autistic children.

Paul Shattock, director of the Autism Research Unit at Sunderland University, says that changing the diets of autistic children by removing glutens, for instance, can bring about improvements. "We're slowly producing evidence that what parents have said for years about diet is true," he said. But his unit finds it hard to get funding to carry out research on the scale and to a standard that the medical establishment would accept.

"Our work is considered flaky," he said. "It is not popular with the medical establishment. The medical establishment is trained to treat diseases by giving drugs and patients are trained to ask for drugs."

He backs Dr Wakefield's theory on toxins passing through the gut to the brain, although he says more research is needed before we can identify the MMR as the cause of the disease in the gut that makes it possible.

Dr Miller, of the PHLS, says the diet theory is one of many in the treatment of autism. "There is a plethora of other hypotheses that children may be improved by certain regimes. It is right and proper that work should be done to find the cause of this condition, but the work must be amenable to others to test it."

She rests on the epidemiological case against Dr Wakefield. In the PHLS study in North Thames, every child with autism - around 500 - was reviewed. The rate of those with autism who had been given the MMR and among those who had not been vaccinated was the same.

webTitle: Under-funded help for  children triumphs against the odds

fields.headline: Small triumphs
fields.standfirst: Mike George on the success of an under-funded approach to helping children with behavioural and learning problems
fields.trailText: Mike George on the success of an under-funded approach to helping children with behavioural and learning problems
fields.body:
A new scheme for pre-school children and their parents is getting under way in Plymouth, with the aim of helping parents of young children with severe behavioural difficulties to change not only their children's behaviour, but also their own.

The idea of equipping young children with the learning and behavioural skills necessary to get a good start in school obviously goes down well with the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE).

But while the Plymouth scheme operates in the local education action zone, and is done in collaboration with educational psychologists, nursery and playschool staff, its work is heavily based on the home visiting model for pre-school children known as "portage". And although the DfEE acknowledges portage in its curriculum guidance for pre-schoolers, portage services, as a general rule, receive very little official or public attention.

Portage, which derives its name from its origins in the US state of Wisconsin, aims to support the development of play, communication, relationships, learning and participation of young children within the family. The focus of the work is on children who have learning disabilities, physical disabilities or communication difficulties, or other substantial and complex needs. Portage workers are often teachers, health visitors and nurses who have undergone specialist training to equip them to work alongside parents, offering practical help and ideas to encourage a child's emerging skills and to address problematic situations.

About 140 portage services are registered with the National Portage Association (NPA), which celebrates its 25th anniversary this year. Last year, some 5,500 young children received regular home visits, while more were assisted by staff in the context of places like playgroups and nursery classes in schools.

Nobody, including the DfEE, really knows how many children (and their often desperate parents) could benefit from the proven successes of these services.

The 1987 disability surveys by the former Office of Population, Censuses and Surveys, which remain the most recent large-scale source of information, suggested that some 77,000 under-fives had problems with intellectual functioning, communication or behaviour. However, what is clear is that there are not enough portage services, and that most of them do not have sufficient or sufficiently secure financial resources to meet the level of need. "Waiting lists are horrendous in some parts of the country," says Rosemary Gardener, who collates the NPA's statistics.

Similarly, there appears to be a lack of clarity about where portage fits into pre-school support, because the schemes are sometimes based within education authorities' early years services and sometimes bracketed with psychology, special education or education learning support services. Some are managed by health agencies; some by joint education and health bodies; others by mainly voluntary management teams, which sometimes include parents.

However, there does seem little doubt that the portage model works for most. Alison and Ian, from Kent, are adamant that the service has been crucial in encouraging and supporting their five-year-old daughter Sandra - and them - to the point where she entered mainstream schooling a few weeks ago.

Sandra - not her real name, because her parents do not want her to suffer from being regarded as "special" - was premature and, as result of oxygen deprivation, had severe difficulties. Luckily, says Alison, their local service was able to intervene when Sandra was very young. The couple believe that others, who are on considerable waiting lists or who have had difficulty in getting their child referred, may as a result find that portage is not able to achieve quite so much.

"The worker, in her weekly visits, provided us with all sorts of multi-sensory play things to help Sandra," says Alison. "But even more importantly they gave her, and us, a framework within which we could all help her to focus and coordinate, then to start to learn language skills, to improve her perceptual skills and cognitive abilities.

"The key to it was the identification of lots of small positive steps, so that something could nearly always be achieved during or between each visit. The approach was also invaluable because it covered the whole family - taking into account, for example, our initial feelings of mourning for the healthy child we would have liked.

"But we quickly moved on to teaching her in a positive way. Obviously, it was very wearing sometimes, but we always knew that the service was there to support and encourage us. I'm sure that without it our daughter would not have been able to go to school as she has."

Annie McGee, manager of pre-school services for special needs for Plymouth council, explains that this portage model has proved itself relevant to the needs of young children, and their parents, where challenging behaviour is not necessarily associated with learning or physical disabilities. "This is partly because many disabled children can exhibit difficult behavioural problems which portage work routinely addresses anyway, and the partnership with the parent is always seen as the key to success or failure," she says.

The expansion of the portage service into the field of behavioural difficulties in Plymouth occurred after an approach by Martin Herbert, emeritus professor at Exeter University, and clinical psychologist colleagues who had been piloting programmes for parents with "difficult" young children. Herbert, who has written several books on the assessment and treatment of childhood disorders, recognised that portage provided an ideal basis for this work. As a consequence, the Plymouth portage childwise parenting project was started, and is now building up to a full caseload.

Diane Davis, a senior portage worker on the project, says: "We use portage as the basis, but we've also been trained to work with parents, using an ABC behaviour management programme - where A means that we examine the antecedents, or the factors and parental behaviour which leads to difficult behaviour; where B means that we look at the type of behaviour exhibited; and where C means the consequences, or what does a parent do about it and what effects that has on the child.

"In the same way as portage, we start with a full assessment to see if we can help, then develop a profile both of the parent and the child and start work with the parents to create ways of breaking negative cycles and rewarding positive behaviour. Again, it's all based on taking small steps.

"But, unlike portage, we work on the basis of a 12-week programme, through which we help parents to set out and attain achievable goals, whereas the usual commitment in portage is to provide whatever support is needed until a child reaches school age."

This new initiative appears to have worked well, but as McGee points out, the parlous state of many portage services means that few are likely to be able develop their work in this direction - and some are struggling even to keep their main portage work going.

With the mishmash of funding, and obvious confusions over which services they should operate under, education and health officials might be well advised to engage in some joined-up thinking and come up with a plan for the development of portage. For this small, under-funded service seems to offer a lot for a little.

The approach was also invaluable because it covered the whole family - taking into account, for example, our initial feelings of mourning for the healthy child we would have liked. "But we quickly moved on to teaching her in a positive way. Obviously, it was very wearing sometimes, but we always knew that the service was there to support and encourage us. I'm sure that without it our daughter would not have been able to go to school as she has." Annie McGee, manager of pre-school services for special needs for Plymouth council, explains that this portage model has proved itself relevant to the needs of young children, and their parents, where challenging behaviour is not necessarily associated with learning or physical disabilities. "This is partly because many disabled children can exhibit difficult behavioural problems which portage work routinely addresses anyway, and the partnership with the parent is always seen as the key to success or failure," she says. Herbert, who has written several books on the assessment and treatment of childhood disorders, recognised that portage provided an ideal basis for this work. As a consequence, the Plymouth portage childwise parenting project was started, and is now building up to a full caseload. Diane Davis, a senior portage worker on the project, says: "We use portage as the basis, but we've also been trained to work with parents, using an ABC behaviour management programme - where A means that we examine the antecedents, or the factors and parental behaviour which leads to difficult behaviour; where B means that we look at the type of behaviour exhibited; and where C means the consequences, or what does a parent do about it and what effects that has on the child. "In the same way as portage, we start with a full assessment to see if we can help, then develop a profile both of the parent and the child and start work with the parents to create ways of breaking negative cycles and rewarding positive behaviour. Again, it's all based on taking small steps. "But, unlike portage, we work on the basis of a 12-week programme, through which we help parents to set out and attain achievable goals, whereas the usual commitment in portage is to provide whatever support is needed until a child reaches school age." This new initiative appears to have worked well, but as McGee points out, the parlous state of many portage services means that few are likely to be able develop their work in this direction - and some are struggling even to keep their main portage work going. With the mishmash of funding, and obvious confusions over which services they should operate under, education and health officials might be well advised to engage in some joined-up thinking and come up with a plan for the development of portage. For this small, under-funded service seems to offer a lot for a little.

fields.trailText: Watt stamina
fields.body:
Watt stamina A 25-watt bulb installed 70 years ago in the gents' toilet at an electrical shop in Ipswich, Suffolk, has finally burnt out.
News North West, 9.1.01 (Gillian Oakes, Cheadle)

Cross response School crossing patrol staff in the South Hams area of Devon have been given voice data recorders to keep a catalogue of motorists who abuse them or fail to stop.
Western Morning News, 5.1.01 (Nicola Neale, Sidmouth)

Film noir A woman who spent two years compiling video evidence of late-night drug dealing and prostitution outside her home in Walsall, West Midlands, has been awarded funding to turn it into a short film.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 2.1.01 (Simon Briggs, Bearwood)

Metro North East, 3.1.01 (Heather Gould, Newcastle upon Tyne)

Fir exchange Residents in Rye, East Sussex, have been asked to donate their old Christmas trees to help stop erosion of dunes caused by visitors to Camber Sands.
Shoreham Herald, 5.1.01 (Gilly Sweet, Shoreham-by-Sea)

False hope Workers concerned for their safety while laying cable on a stretch of road between Yatton Keynell and Castle Combe, Wiltshire, have set up a mannequin dummy with a reflective jacket on to try to get motorists to slow down.
Wiltshire Times, 5.1.01 (D Maguire, Westbury)

Moved to tears A man from Thornaby-on-Tees divorced his wife because he claimed that she rearranged the furniture every day.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 18.12.00 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Tinky-Vinky? An 18-month-old toddler from Workington, Cumbria, has started speaking German after being mistakenly given a Teletubby toy programmed in that language.
Metro, 4.1.01 (J Mohamed, Ilford)

Flushing smile Staff at a sewage works near Bradford, Yorkshire, set up an ID parade of false teeth they had found after a woman phoned to say she had lost her new set down the toilet.
Express and Star, 19.1.00 (David Smith, Stourbridge)

Tay and empathy Anglers on the River Tay in Scotland are being offered free lager and sweatshirts if they return salmon to the water or donate them to a restocking scheme.
East Anglian Daily Times, 29.12.00 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Stable incomers A couple who were told they do not have planning permission for the luxury bungalow they were having built near Aberystwyth, west Wales, have moved horses into it and applied to turn it into stables.
Western Mail, 10.1.01 (Alexander Welsh, Llanidloes)

Convenient answer Villagers determined not to lose their sub-post office in Shilton, Warwickshire, have raised enough money to re-open the service in a former public toilet.
Coventry Evening Telegraph, 5.1.01 (John Forster, Daventry)

Rough and tumble The owners of a chain of launderettes in Tenby, west Wales, have stopped late-night opening after schoolboys were discovered playing games of dare in the tumble driers.
Western Daily Press, 3.1.01 (Francis Harvey, Exeter)

Glasgow Herald, 28.12.00 (Alison Prince, Whiting Bay)

webTitle: Profile: David Fleming, innovative director of Tyne and Wear museums

fields.headline: His story in the making
fields.standfirst: David Fleming, innovative director of Tyne and Wear museums
fields.trailText: David Fleming, innovative director of Tyne and Wear museums
fields.body:
Whenever the directorship of a national museum falls vacant, speculation over who will fill it rarely focuses on any nominee from the world of local authority museums. National jobs tend to go to senior figures in other nationals, to high-flyers from overseas or to those with a track record in running complex institutions in the corporate world.

If there is a glass ceiling preventing those who have built up their expertise in the council-run sector from transferring to the more glamorous national scene, then the man thought most likely to smash through it is David Fleming, director of Tyne and Wear museums and current president of the Museums Association. Fleming, a 47-year-old Yorkshireman, has dramatically raised the profile of Tyne and Wear in almost 10 years as boss. In particular, his championing of social inclusion as an essential museum function has helped change the thinking on what a museum's role should be.

"I see museums as being in the service of society, not just as the preservers of a collection of objects," he says. "I do believe Tyne and Wear has set the new agenda in the past few years and has helped people reassess what museums can do. We are relatively poorly funded, but money doesn't become a huge barrier to this kind of work because social inclusion is quite simply a fundamental issue. Lack of money is often used as an excuse in the cultural sector, but lack of commitment in the first place is often a much bigger problem."

Social inclusion does not detract from a museum's curatorial role, he insists. "People who say that don't know what they're talking about, quite frankly. Social inclusion has been happening for years, but with this government we have finally got support for it. It's scaremongering to say it puts the objects at risk."

Fleming's roots are in working-class Leeds. He studied history at Leeds University, following it with a PhD in urban history at Leicester, and entered museums as a researcher after a disappointing spell in teaching.

"I was interested in adult education as a historian and taught Workers' Educational Association classes for a while, but found myself teaching middle-class housewives," he says. "It was the same with the Open University - I was introducing educated people to more study, whereas I was looking for people who had been denied educational opportunity, as that was my family background. I felt that museums were a particularly accessible source of education for people who had had a traditional working-class education - that is, they'd left school young."

It was at Hull in 1985, where he helped establish a social history museum in a former grammar school building, that his ideas took hold. "The idea of looking at community history was a novelty in universities and museums at that time, but my research had been edging towards those areas and there were a few people coming through at the same time as me who were interested in that kind of thing. With the grammar school, there was the opportunity to create a people's history of Hull and to design a place that would appeal to excluded audiences."

As director at Tyne and Wear, he now controls more than 200 staff in 10 museums and galleries, which together attract 1.2m visitors a year. His first change, on taking up the post in 1991, was to devote more resources to education, with education staff given the responsibility of setting up positive action and access programmes.

One of his boldest moves was to rename Newcastle's Museum of Science and Engineering as the Discovery Museum - "much less anal in terms of describing what it's about", as he puts it. The Discovery's annual visitor figures have since risen from 40,000 to 250,000.

Fleming is one of only two museum service bosses in local authorities in England to retain the title of director and the executive independence that goes with it. Many believe that is a sign of how highly he is regarded by the five authorities that make up Tyne and Wear.

He says the absorption of museums into heritage or leisure divisions in other authorities is a mark of how their status in local government has declined over the years, partly as a result of restructuring but also, he thinks, because museums under-sell themselves. One of the aims of the Group for Large Local Authority Museums, which he helped found, is to promote the work of these unsung services.

His relationship with the Department for Culture, Media and Sport is also strong. A funding quirk means the department contributes some £1m to the Tyne and Wear budget, but Fleming also offers strong backing for culture secretary Chris Smith. Interestingly, Fleming still sees himself as a socialist - "to me it means identifying local needs and doing something about them" - so the synergy with New Labour is not total and, as president of the Museums Association, he represents a broad church - not only local authority museums, but independents too.

After a decade in Newcastle, the logical promotion for Fleming now would be to one of those prestigious national jobs. He just missed out on the directorship of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, but the forthcoming vacancy for director at the National Museums and Galleries on Merseyside is reckoned by many to have his name on it.

"There's a view that running big national museums is more difficult than running a local authority service like Tyne and Wear," he says. "But it's not a view that I share."

webTitle: Are sick NHS staff being scared into work?

fields.headline: Cold chills
fields.standfirst: Turning up ill to look after sick people isn't a sensible idea, but is a new system of assessing days off scaring NHS staff into work?
fields.trailText: Turning up ill to look after sick people isn't a sensible idea, but is a new system of assessing days off scaring NHS staff into work?
fields.body:
You are a healthcare professional working with elderly people. You really have no business being at work because your throat is sore and inflamed, you feel febrile and have a cough. In short, you are going down with something which is, at best, a cold - but may be flu.

Exposure to the illness would be potentially lethal for your frail patients, but sick leave could result in you facing a formal occupational health or disciplinary hearing. You are on the horns of a dilemma already facing many health workers this winter, but one which will soon face many more.

If it is surprising to learn that people responsible for the care of other people's health are behaving in a way that exposes their patients and clients to an increased risk, then it is wholly unexpected to find the institutions they work for pursuing a policy that can lead to such risk.

There is, however, an absence control model that achieves precisely this end. Its users currently include several NHS trusts, but it is shortly expected to be employed throughout the service. It is, moreover, a model whose provenance is unknown; one for which no empirical research has been published; and one which even the university whose name it bears knows of only anecdotally.

This is the "Bradford factor", a system for differentiating longer, infrequent staff absences from those which are more frequent, but of shorter duration. The assumption behind it is that high frequency, short duration absences are more problematic in certain types of organisation, are symptomatic of different problems and require separate identification in order to be addressed.

Used strategically, to compare departments or groups of professionals or even whole workforces, Bradford is theoretically presumed to identify problems within management itself, or in the body of the workforce, before they become insurmountable. In practice, though, it is widely deployed at a tactical or individual level by departmental or human resources managers, for whom it can acquire a talismanic resonance.

This is certainly how the system is perceived by some staff at Wakefield and Pontefract Community Health trust, in West Yorkshire. The trust requires that care staff who have suffered a viral infection should be symptom-free for four days before they return to work. The requirement is widely ignored by staff who frequently fail even to take time off to recover from the symptoms. They fear the effect of such absences on their Bradford profiles.

A person having a few days off, to recover from a cold, might very well find themselves sending their Bradford score through the roof. They might consequently find themselves incurring the attention of their human resources or occupational health department, for whom a particular Bradford score triggers further action, perhaps disciplinary. Understandably, then, some staff members tend not to go sick in the first place.

The trust's director of human resources, Alan Davis, is adamant that no action is taken purely on the basis of an adverse Bradford score and that it is merely a management information tool. He says: "Bradford is not an absolute measure. It is one of a number of indicators used by us to provide managers with an understanding of absence among their staff. It is not intended to be a trigger for particular courses of action."

Davis is surprised to hear that staff are suspicious and fearful of the technique. He believes that their unions are happy with its use and recognise that the trust has paid great attention to occupational health matters.

"If someone has a particular health concern, they can take it to our confidential staff counselling service, which operates on a self-referral basis, or they can discuss matters with their manager," he says. "We also put great efforts into rehabilitation of members of staff from long-term sickness."

Like many, Davis thinks the system originated at Bradford University. "One of my staff came across it while doing some research and it appeared to be credited to the university," he says. "We have now been using it for about four years."

In one recent case, a care assistant at the Wakefield trust, who had been absent sick on six occasions for a total of five weeks in a rolling year, registering a Bradford score of 900, was interviewed by two members of management and subsequently received a letter. Headed "Absenteeism/sickness absence", the letter's tone is unmistakable. After recording the specifics of the interview, it reads: "I must point out that while I am sympathetic with your difficulties... if there is no improvement in your attendance, consideration will be given to your suitability to continue in your present employment."

According to Mary Maguire, spokeswoman for public services union Unison, the union's national negotiators are unaware of the Bradford factor. But she says: "Unison accepts that in any organisation there are going to be one or two lead-swingers, but line managers should be able to identify those. We feel that, in a civilised society, we should take steps to find out remedial rather than punitive steps to resolve sickness issues."

Bradford is implicitly discriminatory, she says. "By focusing on short-term absence, it is bound to discriminate against women and older workers. By coercing people to come back to work when ill, it is creating a situation in which sick workers are treating sick patients."

Geoff Helliwell, an occupational health physician and medical director of WellWork, a consultancy, identifies this as a distinct problem in its own right. "People who are actually ill attending work, because they feel obliged to do so, is a form of 'presenteeism'," he says. "It is bad for their own long-term health, bad for those they work with and bad, ultimately, for the organisation. It can arise out of misinformed use of absence scoring such as the Bradford factor."

Helliwell also feels that, as a means of reducing sickness absence, Bradford is wrongly focused. "An organisation seeking to reduce its sickness absence ought to be focusing on the long-term rate of absence," he says. "It has a choice: it can spend all its time, using tools like Bradford and running around after absences of one week or less, which form 35% of all spells of absence, or it can focus on the 3.9% of spells of four weeks or more which cause 48% of time lost."

Mike O'Donnell, also an occupational health doctor, is broadly a supporter of Bradford. He feels that short-term absenteeism is a problem that needs addressing and which, if unremedied, leads to long-term absence. But he agrees that the disciplinary overtones attached to some uses of Bradford are counter-productive.

"Bradford is an analysis tool; it should not be used as a disciplinary one and occupational health departments should not be used as enforcers," says O'Donnell, of Medical and Industrial Services, another consultancy. "However, short-term absence is a problem and as it may be one which relates to subsequent long-term absence, Bradford scores are of use in predicting this, as well as in highlighting managerial problems."

Helliwell recommends that organisations using Bradford to focus on short-term absence rates should ask themselves what has happened to their overall rates as a result. Neither Davis, nor his staff at Wakefield, were able to provide figures for changes to short-term, long-term or overall absence in the four years they have been using the system.

"Bradford is an analysis tool; it should not be used as a disciplinary one and occupational health departments should not be used as enforcers," says O'Donnell, of Medical and Industrial Services, another consultancy. "However, short-term absence is a problem and as it may be one which relates to subsequent long-term absence, Bradford scores are of use in predicting this, as well as in highlighting managerial problems." Helliwell recommends that organisations using Bradford to focus on short-term absence rates should ask themselves what has happened to their overall rates as a result. Neither Davis, nor his staff at Wakefield, were able to provide figures for changes to short-term, long-term or overall absence in the four years they have been using the system.

webTitle: Conservation threatened by progress as Southampton plans port expansion

fields.headline: Bay in the dock
fields.standfirst: Conservation threatened by progress as Southampton plans port expansion
fields.trailText: Conservation threatened by progress as Southampton plans port expansion
fields.body:
Associated British Ports, the company which operates many of Britain's ports, sees Southampton as the jewel in its crown. In 1998, the docks handled 6% of all British port trade, 850,000 container units, more than 35m tonnes of cargo and 50% of the UK's trade with the far east. More than 500,000 new cars pass over the quayside every year - around 70% of them for export.

Now ABP want to expand the port to cater for the new, larger container ships and an important plank in this major expansion is a controversial proposal to build a huge new container terminal just opposite at Dibden Bay.

The bay is a nature conservation area of international repute with four European, national and local designations intended to protect it, including the EU Birds Habitat directive. Its open grazing supports a high number of rare grass and over-wintering waders.

The site for ABP's container terminal also adjoins the New Forest, one of the most important heathlands in the UK and home to many rare plants, birds and animals. The area is of international significance for its woodlarks, Dartford warblers and nightjars. The New Forest, once William the Conqueror's hunting preserve and now one of England's biggest tourist attractions, was even shortlisted by the government for consideration as a world heritage site.

But ABP, which has owned the land for several decades, is adamant that it needs to be developed. The port, if approved by government after a public inquiry later this year, will include 1.3 miles of quayside and 500 acres of marshalling yards.

Dr Caroline Lucas, Green MEP for the south-east, has asked EU environment commissioner Margot Wallstrom to intervene to protect Dibden Bay. "There is considerable evidence", says Lucas, "that despite the claimed need for increased port facilities, ABP has been releasing land at Southampton port for commercial and residential development. Much of this development is not related to harbour business but has been driven by the company's desire to capitalise on rising land values".

A spokesman for ABP says: "Some years ago our parent company sold some land for development that was not suitable for port use. The port is busier than ever now. Everything we have is being used as intensively as possible. We urgently need more land."

A major focus of concern for local residents would be the inevitable increase in port-related traffic congestion and pollution if the planned expansion is approved. ABP acknowledges that two-thirds of containers would come by road or rail rather than via sea routes. Port access to Dibden Bay would also increase pressure on the local trunk road, which is already snarled up at peak times.

ABP offered at one stage to contribute to Hampshire county council's existing plans to upgrade the road. It remains an open question how the council will square Dibden Bay development with its obligations under the Road Traffic Reduction Act (Local Targets), which requires local authorities to limit - then reverse - the growth of local road traffic levels.

ABP says: "We've studied the traffic implications for five years and we're proposing light rail developments and other environmentally sensitive solutions. We think 35% of all the cargo handled by the port will go straight out again by boat."

However, environmental concerns may ultimately be outweighed by the growing dependence of the regional - and national - economy on Southampton's port.

"The continuing success of the Port of Southampton means we're nearing the time when Dibden Bay will be needed to support the growth in the UK's international trade," adds ABP.

ABP says that the new port would create 3,000 jobs, but a third of these will probably be in one-off construction work, and it is unclear whether the rest would be long-term. The trend in ports is to increase automation. Last year ABP announced 150 job losses at their other ports.

The lines appear to have been set for a long-drawn out public inquiry, probably starting in the autumn. A broad coalition, including local residents, Friends of the Earth and the Green Party, is now mobilising support to oppose the port expansion.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: A damned cheek
fields.body:
A damned cheek

Tony Blair gets a whack over the knuckles in a letter from professor Martin Hall, president of the World Archaeological Congress, over his support for the Ilisu dam in Turkey which the PM is "minded" to back with £200m of taxpayers' money, even though it would drown a city and 46 ancient villages. Hall says: "It raises fundamental issues concerning the human rights of the large and overwhelmingly Kurdish populations scheduled to be moved from their homes - specifically their rights with regard to cultural heritage. The severing of people from the materials through which they understand their past has demonstrable traumatic effects." Just in case Tony misses the point (as he has so far), the professor has sent copies to Stephen Byers at the DTI, Richard Caborn, the unreconstructed trade minister, John Prescott, environment, Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, Chris Smith at culture, and the boys at the export credit guarantee department. Watch this space for a reply.

Nick nick...

So Nick Raysnford MP, perhaps the least "green" environment minister since the late Nicholas Ridley, did indeed urge MPs to vote down plans to give energy efficiency advice to home-buyers - as predicted here last week. Dear Nick. This does not look good. Indeed, following your spectacular delaying of improvements to the energy efficiency building regulations, it looks spooky. Was it really you who won Tony Blair's support for Balfour Beatty's building of the Ilisu dam?

Secret out on the net

Good to see the biotech industry keeping up the pressure on politicians and global bodies. All the top chaps spent yesterday at the House of Commons presenting their case on animal testing and intellectual property to MPs and select committee members. Meanwhile, the CEOs of the world's 13 largest GM companies - including Monsanto, Aventis, Dow, Cargill and DuPont - have been secretly meeting James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank. The bank, it seems, is looking at whether there is a role for it to play in assisting agribusiness programmes in the developing world which the CEOs apparently presented as "the second green revolution." Heard that one before. Incidentally, the only reason anyone got to know about the meeting was because it was accidentally sent out on the internet.

webTitle: Malcolm  Dean: Social reformer in FDR's image

fields.headline: Social reformer in FDR's image
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: No living person has a wider span of social reform - but Lord (Michael) Young, at 85, is moving on
fields.body:
An era is over. Lord (Michael) Young, at 85, is moving on. In April he resigns as director of the Institute for Community Studies (ICS), and will move out of its Queen Anne House, set in the heart of Bethnal Green, his base for almost 50 years.

No living person has a wider span of social reform. As a schoolboy he stayed in the White House and discussed regeneration policies over breakfast with Roosevelt. Before he was 30, he had written the 1945 Labour party manifesto, and continued as Labour's head of research through the Attlee years. Watching the way politics distanced ministers from people, he turned down a political career and set up ICS.

Distinguished sociologist, famed reformer, best-selling novelist (The Rise of the Meritocracy) but above all else, he is Britain's most brilliant social entrepreneur. He has a unique gift for identifying needs and devising ways of meeting them.

ICS was the base from which many of the 55 institutions he invented were launched. They include the Open University; the Consumer's Association; the national (and international) extension colleges spreading distance learning; the Open College of the Arts; and the School for Social Entrepreneurs.

No one has ever turned personal experience into more productive ends. In hospital with cancer, he devised the idea of the College of Health - or, as he was originally going to call it with his sense of fun, the association of trained patients. Organising the funeral of his second wife, Sasha, he saw the need to improve the training of funeral directors: the National Funeral College was born.

He leaves the ICS in a comfortable financial position having sold Language Line, the telephone interpreting service he invented, to a commercial operator for £3m. The contrast with ICS's launch could not be starker. It began on a pittance - in an age before the social science research council, which Lord Young launched and led, in the 1960s.

The institute's four most famous names are its pioneers: Michael and the three Peters - Willmott, Townsend and Marris. Its most famous research remains Family and Kinship in East London by Young and Willmott, showing how new town planners and slum-clearing councillors lost touch with inner-city communities. Michael, alone, has produced 18 books and dozens of papers. They will continue - and the inventions- but not from ICS.

A distinguished new director, Sir Peter Hall, the celebrated geographer, takes over in September. Author of 30 books including the massive Cities in Civilisation (1998), his appointment ensures the ICS focus will remain on its host city, London.

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Police, camera, action
fields.body:
Police, camera, action...

Thank you for your article on the Nottingham project to involve local people in regeneration (Game plan, January 17). I learned more from your one page than from decades of living here.

The emphasis on "honest conversation" would be a marvellous innovation after some of the half-baked notions which have been tried out here over the years - if only it were true. In recent years, I have received perhaps four or five free papers from the city council, informing me of occasional faits accomplis in the area: the canvassing of my opinion on anything has amounted to three or four questions on a single sheet of A4, along the lines of: "Do you think that 'your area' would be safer if there were better policing?" - the sort of question you could not answer in the negative.

Sadly, the only PCs which this "local involvement" has introduced have been police cameras, and to great excess. This oppressive intrusion has now infested the area to a ludicrous degree which makes this (innocent) resident unwilling to go out on the streets to be snooped on unless absolutely necessary, and makes the streets feel much less safe even than before. When there are cameras in evidence, you know there is no copper anywhere nearby until it's too late.

While I wish the area well, I shall not see its regeneration: as soon as I can persuade the city council that it is its duty to move me out of the prison camp it has made out of my home, I shall be out of here to somewhere - anywhere - with a little respect for its citizens. Involving local people? Yes, please. When do we start?

Steve Cook

Nottingham

The wrong chemistry

You rightly highlighted the crisis facing independent chemists (Rewriting the script, January 17). However, it should be remembered that chemists have had an unfair statutory protection over others for a long time. In many inner-city deprived areas and rural areas, pharmacists were not interested in opening shops: they were either too dangerous or not profitable enough. The job of dispensing medicines was taken on by local doctors, often making considerable capital investment, to make sure that the local community was properly served.

As business expanded, a pharmacist could simply move in to the locality and use his statutory protection to have the monopoly on drug dispensing. Doctors, individually or in medical centres, were then forced to close down without any redress.

Governments have never dealt with this problem. Maybe now is the time to review the whole situation.

Alastair Yule

Bishop Auckland

Time to crack down

Pure heroin in moderate doses does wonders for the complexion - ask Clive Froggatt, former adviser to Baroness Thatcher. Problems mainly arise over "cut" heroin, excessive dosage, inexperienced use or health problems associated with injecting/inhaling (Generation gap, January 17).

While I do not advocate use of any illegal drug, this ageing group of "responsible" heroin/methadone users cannot be the main concern of my agency. We, and other agencies, would be able to assist harm reduction around heroin or methadone use for people of any age, especially street homeless people, were we not constrained by the "Cambridge two" appeal verdict. Until the law is clarified or amended, this state of affairs will continue.

That said, the most pressing and urgent need we see is to address the proliferation of crack use. The prognosis for these addicts is poor. They will be unlikely to see their 60th birthday - and if they do, they will be most unlikely to be able to enjoy it. And the economic and social cost to society of their addiction is likely to exceed that of maintaining a generation of methadone users.

Chris Edwards

Director, St Martin in the Fields Social Care, London

Bradford bull

Bradford social services may have been "agreeably surprised" by the results of its home care survey (Down your way, January 10.) My family's experience in another area of the city would not paint so rosy a picture. My relative, 95 and disabled, was not offered a "hygiene clean". Lunch calls could be as early as 11.30 and lasted 15 minutes - hardly time to serve a nutritious meal and clean up adequately. Calls could be haphazard: two or even three helpers arriving to do the same job one day; none the next.

Overall, the organisation seemed to lack flexibility, imagination and basic timetabling, which made difficulties not only for the clients but also for the workforce. On the plus side, the helpers were very caring, doing their best though hard pressed -pressed by having to help a great many people each day.

Name and address withheld

Happy days

I read Karl Roome's letter (January 10) with great interest. When he arrived in Nelson in 1939, I was attending Nelson secondary school and a boy joined us of about the same age as Karl. His name was, I think, Walter Unterberg.

The spelling may be wrong, but I remember him with complete clarity. He spoke little English, but passed his school certificate about 12 months later, which amazed me then as much as it does now.

I have always felt that the tolerant and compassionate spirit in Nelson, which Roome mentions, arose from two very different sources. The first: leftwing, nonconformist politics which preached the brotherhood of man - how old-fashioned that sounds. The second: Nelson's cricket pro - and the greatest ambassador for any sport - Leary Constantine, who reinforced that conviction by his great generosity of spirit. How we all loved him.

R Birtles

Brierfield, Lancashire

webTitle: What happens when hunting is banned where it is truly a way of life?

fields.headline: The big picture
fields.standfirst: What happens when hunting is banned where it is truly a way of life?  Nicola Graydon  on an award-winning film that charts the decline of bushman culture
fields.trailText: What happens when hunting is banned where it is truly a way of life? Nicola Graydon on an award-winning film that charts the decline of bushman culture
fields.body:
It is 5.30pm. The bottle store is closed and young men are watching an Arnold Schwarzenegger video in a khaki army tent that is hot as an oven. Women walk listlessly across the vast, dusty compound of the semi-refugee camp at Smidtsdrift in South Africa, where 4,000 !XU and Khwe San bushmen and their families have waited over 10 years for resettlement (the exclamation mark before names is another letter in their alphabet which produces a clicking sound).

Only children seem to be interested as, like latterday vaudevillians, we set up the projector, screen and generator near a large thorn tree for an open air screening of The Great Dance - a feature documentary about !Xo San bushman hunters who live several hundred miles north, in the heart of the Kalahari desert.

Earlier in the day, Meita Gooi, a tiny chisel-cheeked bushman grandmother had announced the screening on the local radio station K-X Radio. "This film made my heart sore," her voice wavers. "It reminded me of the old life. It is about people like us, about our race and it made us proud."

Meita and husband Piet, had been so moved by the film at an informal screening in Cape Town, that they asked the film-makers if they could take it home to show their families.

The tented camp, known as Mahongo - "place of suffering" - is a depressing pit-stop on the way. Stunted trees give no relief from the blinding midday sun or the wind blowing through the camp, pirouetting in dramatic "wind devils" - mini tornadoes - which send dust, paper, plastic bags high into the air. Nothing much happens here.

On a tiny fire in the centre of Katoti's tent, a weak soup with a rotting fish head is cooking. It has been a long time since her family has had meat.

But it used not to be like that. Back in Namibia, her husband Peza had been a renowned hunter. "He hunted eland, kudu, buffalo and would bring meat to the whole village," she says. "But there is nothing here: no animals to hunt, no fruit to eat, no water, no wood or grass. There is only air to live on. Sometimes God brings you a good dream, sometimes he brings you a bad dream. This is a bad dream."

The last 350 years in southern Africa has been devastating for the San. In that time they have been pushed off their land, hunted with guns, forced to work on white farms and prevented from speaking their languages. It is remarkable they have survived at all.

And it has been at least two decades since these San bushmen, former trackers with the South African Defence Force from Namibia and Angola, have lived as hunter-gatherers. The teenagers wear baseball caps and trainers, want education and computers, while many of the older men, frustrated by loss of land and animals, drink themselves into a stupor.

Last year, The Great Dance swept the awards at Wildscreen 2000, winning three Pandas, the equivalent of Oscars in the natural history world, and beating off competition from David Attenborough and Walking with Dinosaurs. In New York it was highly acclaimed by the critics and in South Africa it became the most popular feature documentary after Bueno Vista Social Club.

Co-directors Craig and Damon Foster, two South African brothers, filmed in the central Kalahari on and off for two years, travelling 50kms a day through the bush in temperatures of over 45C for a month at a time, returning to Cape Town, skeletal and dehydrated.

Their aim was to capture footage of the mythic San "chasing hunt" when, if poison runs out in the dry season, master hunters chase down their prey until the animal collapses from sheer exhaustion - running for hours in the midday heat, when (in the words of the San), the sand "burns like a second sun."

The brothers knew they were filming a lifestyle under huge pressure but had underestimated the wealth of knowledge still alive to this generation. "They have an understanding of the natural world which would confound the greatest western scientists. They feel and see the bush in a way that we could hardly grasp, reading signs invisible to our eyes and hardened sensibilities," says Craig.

"Each tiny mark in the sand tells a story. They carry the weather of the last two weeks in their heads alongside an enormous understanding of tracks and animal behaviour. These skills take at least 25 years to master."

The Fosters took early cuts of the film back to the hunters who helped them edit the footage and even gave them the idea to put miniature cameras on to the animals to best show what they are feeling as they hunt. webTitle: A scheme putting space over vacant shops to good use

fields.headline: Lots of potential
fields.standfirst: It's a common story - a good initiative struggling to make headway now faces loss of funding.  Chris Arnot  on a scheme putting space over vacant shops to good use
fields.trailText: It's a common story - a good initiative struggling to make headway now faces loss of funding. Chris Arnot on a scheme putting space over vacant shops to good use
fields.body:
The two storeys above a former outpost of car accessory retailer Motor World in Thirsk, North Yorkshire, are in even worse condition than the abandoned shop on the ground floor. Shredded plaster hangs limply from the walls. Rubble-strewn floorboards creak under unaccustomed footsteps. Pigeons roost in the rafters. Yet there are enough original features - a port-hole window here, an arched doorway there - to suggest that the housing association which will soon embark on restoration work is likely to create three characterful homes.

The enterprise could be seen as symbolic of the entire Living Over The Shop initiative, otherwise known as Lots. Lots of potential. Lots of enthusiasm. Lots and lots of work to be done. Here, in one small project, there is at least an end in sight. Elsewhere in Thirsk and, indeed, elsewhere in the country, there is frustration. Lots of it. Lots of tangled red tape to be hacked through - and lots of misunderstanding about the legal complexities involved in reversing the trends of the past 40 years.

"There is a chance for market towns to reinvent themselves as vibrant places where people live in the centre," says freelance planner Ann Petherick, who founded Lots in 1989 with a three-year grant from the Rowntree Foundation. Apart from anything else, she points out, it makes sense to use vacant space and relieve development pressure on greenfield sites. "Everyone wants this to happen," she goes on. "That includes central government, local government, housing associations, landlords, leaseholders, would-be tenants and the police. But everyone has such diverse interests that they won't get together. It won't happen without a national agency to fit together a very complex jigsaw."

Throughout its 12-year existence, Lots has been frustrated by a lack of consistent funding. Petherick is hopeful that her programme will be taken up nationally by regional development agencies. In the meantime, she's praying that, at a meeting tomorrow, the countryside agency for Yorkshire and Humberside will renew its grant to fund a continuing pilot project in eight of the region's towns. Thirsk is one of them.

The shop which Motor World abandoned is unlikely to remain empty for long. Retailers are queuing up to take out a lease on what is, after all, a prime site overlooking a handsome cobbled market place. By the summer, if all goes well, three new tenants will be moving in to self-contained one-bedroom flats in the upper reaches of this sturdy Edwardian building with Dutch gables.

They will be the first to live here since the mid-50s when this was a branch of chemist Timothy White's. The manager lived over the shop and the regular customers included the local vet, Alf Wight, who was better known to the wider world as James Herriot. Thirsk is the real-life Darrowby. But much has changed here since the days when Wight was grappling with Yorkshire porkers.

While agriculture has been decimated, the town's economy has benefited from Herriot-inspired tourism and a thriving industrial estate which houses some hi-tech companies as well as the national headquarters of Austin Reed. In other words, this is not one of those small towns that young adults necessarily have to leave in order to find work.

"We need those youngsters to stay in Thirsk or to return here after they've finished university," says the mayor, Freda Roberts. Petherick nods assent. She is convinced that there will be no lack of demand for decent flats in the middle of town, available to rent at around £300 a month.

"There's a gap in the market," she says, "for young people who want to stay in the town where they were born. They can't afford the rents in Leeds or York. They have no money to put down on a Barratt's home, yet they're not poor enough to qualify for social housing."

Already she has her eyes set across the market place on the even larger space going begging above the Co-op supermarket. But here the frustrations of Lots's role becomes all too evident. Dealing with the freeholder of the former Motor World shop was comparatively easy because he is a local man, Bill Rukin. But around 80% of retail property is owned by absentee landlords. They are national organisations for the most part - pension funds, investment companies and major retailers.

A call to one of the Co-op's offices in Bradford elicited a response that has proved all too familiar to Lots. "Too many commercial surveyors working for national companies still don't know that the law has changed with regard to security of tenure," says Petherick. In other words, they are reluctant to allow residential use of their property for fear they won't be able to get rid of undesirable tenants.

Lots has devised a legal structure to put their minds at rest. Under its terms, housing associations deal directly with tenants, leaving the freehold landlords to negotiate with the shopkeepers who lease their premises. "Everybody gains and nobody loses," says Petherick. "The landlord gets a much-improved property and the leaseholder is no longer responsible for paying insurance and rates on the upstairs part of the building."

Simple, you might think. Yet too few of the interested parties seem to have grasped the implications. Not the landlords and the leaseholders. Not officials in local authority housing departments, nor civil servants at the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions.

"Successive governments since the late 80s have fundamentally misunderstood the problem," says Petherick. "You have to deal with a freeholder, a leaseholder and sometimes a sub-leaseholder as well. It's time-consuming work because you usually have to wait until leases are coming to an end before there is any incentive for landlords to act. Yet, still there is no national funding for the assembly work that needs to be done to make this happen on a wide scale."

No wonder there is frustration. Lots of it.

A capital idea

The potential benefits of the Living Over the Shop initiative are not confined to market towns. A study produced for the London planning advisory committee in 1998 estimated that some 73,000 additional residential units could be created from existing vacant and under-used shops and upper floors in the capital alone.

The figures are quoted in the final report of the urban taskforce, chaired by Lord Rogers - one of the few figures with influence in government to have understood the nature of the issue, according to Ann Petherick of Lots. "He has adopted our two-stage legal structure as a way of reassuring commercial landlords that having residential tenants won't increase their administrative burden," she says. "If John Prescott's department [the DETR] would grasp that and act upon it, we might make some progress."
