webTitle: A scheme to harness the much-needed skills of refugees

fields.headline: Vision of a future
fields.standfirst: Raekha Prasad on a scheme to harness the much-needed skills of refugees
fields.trailText: Raekha Prasad on a scheme to harness the much-needed skills of refugees
fields.body:
Despite 17 years' experience as a civil engineer, a lengthy list of qualifications and a portfolio of work for several international companies, Ahmed Shiraly has been unemployed for almost a year in the West Midlands, a region crying out for people with his skills. He is about to have an interview for the position of site engineer with a construction company - his seventh job interview in the past few months, after more than 30 applications.

The obstacle to employment for Shiraly (not his real name) is that he is an asylum seeker - just one of an estimated 11,000 in the West Midlands whose skills could contribute to the regeneration of the region. The challenge of making refugees like him employable is a central theme of a Europe-wide conference taking place tomorrow and Friday in Birmingham, hosted by the Midland Refugee Council (MRC) with the Scottish and Welsh refugee councils.

The conference, entitled Dispersal Not Disposal, will concentrate on how to get professional refugees into employment in the regions. It will seek to spread initiatives that conference organiser David Forbes hopes will make a thing of the past the idea that "economic migrants are wicked".

Since the launch of the government's dispersal scheme last April, official figures suggest that almost 700 asylum seekers have been dispersed to the West Midlands - although Forbes says the actual number is much higher. The focus on the "burden" of asylum seekers and refugees, as they struggle to gain access to decent housing, healthcare and legal advice, has obscured how they could benefit the economy.

In contrast to London, where the national Refugee Council has a well-established employment and training section which has been running for more than 10 years, areas outside the south-east are having to mobilise fast to avoid wasting asylum seekers' valuable labour skills.

Work towards this goal includes a Birmingham-based project, Skills Match, which started in 1998 with the aim of getting professionally qualified refugees into employment. Co-funded by the European Union's integration of refugees budget, the project has worked with about 250 refugees and asylum seekers from more than 30 countries.

Almost 40 of these have got jobs through the scheme, but Forbes, the project's manager, says only a dozen or so have found employment commensurate with their professional level. "This demotion is the biggest problem for qualified asylum seekers," he says. "In my experience, the odd-job man can get cash jobs with little problem, but professional barriers prevent people such as lawyers and teachers getting work."

Professional qualifications are either not recognised or devalued, so much of the work of Skills Match concentrates on requalifying refugees in their particular field.

Saeed Hassan Ali, a freelance television cameraman in his native Somalia, has been working as a bus driver in Birmingham. He has recently registered with the project and is exploring what additional video and media courses he needs to take to secure TV work in Britain.

"Our society is more interested in appearance than substance," says Forbes. "We've got people who have got the substance - and not the appearance."

Shiraly, an Iraqi, has learnt this the hard way. He was granted permission to work within six months of arriving in Britain, though he is still waiting for his first asylum application interview. One company offered him a post after two job interviews and after agreeing a salary of £22,000. However, when he produced his Home Office papers stating that he was entitled to work, the company took one look at the large warning statement therein - "You are a person who is likely to be detained" - and withdrew its offer.

"I told them that it was routine and asked them to ring my solicitor who could explain," Shiraly says. "They were polite, but that was the end of it. I was very depressed and so disappointed."

The rejection delivered a particularly hard blow since, with the help of Skills Match, Shiraly had studied intensively for a relevant City and Guilds qualification, had support from a mentor, had an excellent reference and had reconstructed professional drawings of his past work from memory. He believes that the threat of detention in his papers has also given some employers the idea he is exploitable. One company offered him a job that had been advertised at a salary of £18,000, on the understanding that he would be paid £5 an hour. He refused.

Forbes, focusing on what he calls "institutional barriers", has worked to develop a mentoring scheme whereby doctors, engineers, lawyers and architects in the West Midlands, attached to professional bodies, introduce refugees in their field to the British system and guide them towards employment through what is often a complicated, confusing wall of bureaucracy. Skills Match is currently seeking mentors in accountancy and to develop contacts in pharmacy and architecture.

Alongside mentoring, more than 40 refugees have completed work placements in solicitors' offices, at the Arts Council, with Channel 4 and in libraries. About the same number have been advised or financially assisted in academic or professional requalification. Through the Electrical Contractors' Association and the sector's joint industry board, an Iranian refugee and one from the Ukraine were able to requalify as electricians at Wolverhampton University.

Most progress has been made in the medical field through the setting up of the Midland Refugee Doctors' Group, which has the backing of a Birmingham-based senior consultant, Edwin Borman.

"The UK damn well needs lots of doctors," says Borman. "We have a shortfall of 4,000 even after the promised government increase. Just a few refugee doctors have got through the incredibly complicated and bureaucratic system. We want it to be possible for more people, not just the rare exceptions, to be employed."

Six refugee medics met the director of Birmingham's medical school which resulted in three of them obtaining clinical attachments. After successfully passing the required English language exams, and gaining the qualifications necessary to register with the General Medical Council, one of them - Waleed Rashid, from Kurdistan - has been appointed senior house officer in public health in Dudley.

Rashid says that, aside from the financial support that Skills Match provided for exam fees, the help he received in "understanding the system" was indispensable. "Even English people within these professional bodies didn't necessarily know the answer to my detailed questions," he says. "The scheme helped me to be determined."

The shortage list

Tell a joke about how, in Britain, there are more engineers working in McDonald's than in construction, and most employers are unlikely to spilt their sides. Business and industry are pressing the government to relax the rules on asylum seekers' freedom to work.

For the first six months after an asylum seeker enters the country, they are unable to take employment. After that period, they may apply for a work permit.

Almost three-quarters of British companies are suffering skills shortages, according to a recent survey by recruitment group Reed. Compared to six months previously, there has been a 26% increase in the number of employers unable to recruit essential staff, forcing thousands to look overseas for recruits.

Liz Fekete, head of European research at the Institute of Race Relations, says the pressure on governments is Europe-wide. "In Germany, in Ireland and here, the business community is saying: 'Relax the rules.'"

Fekete points to Ireland, where the Dublin chamber of commerce has called for asylum seekers to be processed quicker in order to help fill the city's 20,000 job vacancies.

As in Britain, however, there are fierce objections among the general public about relaxing controls. An opinion poll last year found that while 60% of Irish voters agreed that a more generous approach should be taken towards refugees, particularly in view of the country's history of emigration and its current prosperity, almost three-quarters of voters wanted strict limits on the numbers allowed in.

Fekete argues that in their first six months in Britain, asylum seekers should at least be able to do voluntary work. "The government should invest in their skills in the first instance, and then they could make a positive contribution," she says. "But with the way things stand, they're being left to rot."

"In my experience, the odd-job man can get cash jobs with little problem, but professional barriers prevent people such as lawyers and teachers getting work." Professional qualifications are either not recognised or devalued, so much of the work of Skills Match concentrates on requalifying refugees in their particular field. Saeed Hassan Ali, a freelance television cameraman in his native Somalia, has been working as a bus driver in Birmingham. He has recently registered with the project and is exploring what additional video and media courses he needs to take to secure TV work in Britain. "Our society is more interested in appearance than substance," says Forbes. "We've got people who have got the substance - and not the appearance." Shiraly, an Iraqi, has learnt this the hard way. He was granted permission to work within six months of arriving in Britain, though he is still waiting for his first asylum application interview. One company offered him a post after two job interviews and after agreeing a salary of £22,000. However, when he produced his Home Office papers stating that he was entitled to work, the company took one look at the large warning statement therein - "You are a person who is likely to be detained" - and withdrew its offer. "I told them that it was routine and asked them to ring my solicitor who could explain," Shiraly says. "They were polite, but that was the end of it. I was very depressed and so disappointed." The rejection delivered a particularly hard blow since, with the help of Skills Match, Shiraly had studied intensively for a relevant City and Guilds qualification, had support from a mentor, had an excellent reference and had reconstructed professional drawings of his past work from memory. He believes that the threat of detention in his papers has also given some employers the idea he is exploitable. One company offered him a job that had been advertised at a salary of £18,000, on the understanding that he would be paid £5 an hour. He refused. Forbes, focusing on what he calls "institutional barriers", has worked to develop a mentoring scheme whereby doctors, engineers, lawyers and architects in the West Midlands, attached to professional bodies, introduce refugees in their field to the British system and guide them towards employment through what is often a complicated, confusing wall of bureaucracy. Skills Match is currently seeking mentors in accountancy and to develop contacts in pharmacy and architecture. Alongside mentoring, more than 40 refugees have completed work placements in solicitors' offices, at the Arts Council, with Channel 4 and in libraries. About the same number have been advised or financially assisted in academic or professional requalification. Through the Electrical Contractors' Association and the sector's joint industry board, an Iranian refugee and one from the Ukraine were able to requalify as electricians at Wolverhampton University. Most progress has been made in the medical field through the setting up of the Midland Refugee Doctors' Group, which has the backing of a Birmingham-based senior consultant, Edwin Borman. "The UK damn well needs lots of doctors," says Borman. "We have a shortfall of 4,000 even after the promised government increase. Just a few refugee doctors have got through the incredibly complicated and bureaucratic system. We want it to be possible for more people, not just the rare exceptions, to be employed." Six refugee medics met the director of Birmingham's medical school which resulted in three of them obtaining clinical attachments. After successfully passing the required English language exams, and gaining the qualifications necessary to register with the General Medical Council, one of them - Waleed Rashid, from Kurdistan - has been appointed senior house officer in public health in Dudley. Rashid says that, aside from the financial support that Skills Match provided for exam fees, the help he received in "understanding the system" was indispensable. "Even English people within these professional bodies didn't necessarily know the answer to my detailed questions," he says. "The scheme helped me to be determined." The shortage list Tell a joke about how, in Britain, there are more engineers working in McDonald's than in construction, and most employers are unlikely to spilt their sides. Business and industry are pressing the government to relax the rules on asylum seekers' freedom to work. For the first six months after an asylum seeker enters the country, they are unable to take employment. After that period, they may apply for a work permit. Almost three-quarters of British companies are suffering skills shortages, according to a recent survey by recruitment group Reed. Compared to six months previously, there has been a 26% increase in the number of employers unable to recruit essential staff, forcing thousands to look overseas for recruits. Liz Fekete, head of European research at the Institute of Race Relations, says the pressure on governments is Europe-wide. "In Germany, in Ireland and here, the business community is saying: 'Relax the rules.'" Fekete points to Ireland, where the Dublin chamber of commerce has called for asylum seekers to be processed quicker in order to help fill the city's 20,000 job vacancies. As in Britain, however, there are fierce objections among the general public about relaxing controls. An opinion poll last year found that while 60% of Irish voters agreed that a more generous approach should be taken towards refugees, particularly in view of the country's history of emigration and its current prosperity, almost three-quarters of voters wanted strict limits on the numbers allowed in. Fekete argues that in their first six months in Britain, asylum seekers should at least be able to do voluntary work. "The government should invest in their skills in the first instance, and then they could make a positive contribution," she says. "But with the way things stand, they're being left to rot."

webTitle: Civil rights campaign against abuse of powers to detain asylum seekers

fields.headline: Lives trapped in limbo
fields.standfirst: Civil rights campaign against abuse of powers to detain asylum seekers
fields.trailText: Civil rights campaign against abuse of powers to detain asylum seekers
fields.body:
Leon rolls up his trouser leg to reveal dozens of livid, purple scars. "I was looking for something to cut myself with and I saw a coffee jar and broke it and started to cut and cut," he says. "I wanted to die."

He tried to kill himself while he was in Rochester prison in Kent after he was told he faced immediate deportation back to Algeria. A decade-old civil war has killed almost 100,000 people there and Leon, now aged 38, is a prime target - just because he was a carpenter for the army.

Civil rights lawyers claim the Home Office immigration service is using unlawful tactics to keep people like Leon trapped in the limbo of the prison system, sometimes for years. They say refugees from the horrors of Algeria, Kosovo and the Horn of Africa - many with serious psychiatric problems - are held in conditions that would not be tolerated for convicted criminals.

The offical Home Office line is that asylum seekers are detained when there is a real danger they would abscond before deportation. But campaigners say detention is being used indiscriminately and that the immigration service rarely discloses reasons for continued detention when detainees apply for a review.

Jane Aspden, of the Refugee Legal Centre (RLC), which is campaigning to end detention for asylum seekers, says: "If someone can't be returned, then detention is unlawful under the European convention on human rights and in breach of the immigration services' own guidelines on detention."

The charity Bail for Immigration Detainees (Bid) has written to immigration minister Barbara Roche, detailing a catalogue of alleged human rights abuses of detainees. Tim Baster, Bid's coordinator, says people with profound psychiatric illness are being held in prisons when they should be in hospital. "One man spent 11 months in detention with undiagnosed post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and in another case the chief immigration officer asked us to take a man with PTSD to the local accident and emergency unit."

The charity has represented more than 300 detainees, including a man who was injured in a landmine explosion, a youth of 17 who was a minor and should not have been detained and a depressed man who tried to hang himself because detention had separated him from his wife. Baster says detainees are not given reasons when appeals are rejected. Of a sample 81 appeals backed by Bid but rejected, only 29 were rejected with any reason and, of these, 26 merely stated: "You are detained as an illegal entrant" - which Baster contends is not a valid reason for detention under immigration service guidelines.

Since August, the RLC has managed to obtain bail for 10 people from Algeria and Iran whom it considers were detained unlawfully. Aspden says: "If you are going to make a decision to deprive people of their liberty, it should have strict constraints. No such constraints exist. To the extent that there are any criteria, they are being flouted by immigration officials."

Last year, chief inspector of prisons Sir David Ramsbotham found Rochester "filthy and impoverished" and reported that some staff were guilty of the "institutional neglect" of asylum seekers.

Mohammed Derradji, 36, knows that well. During the 14 months he spent in the jail, he claims guards used racial abuse and systematic techniques to wear down asylum seekers until they signed voluntary deportation orders just to escape. "The guards play with your brains - they try to torture you," he says. "They say: 'Go home - we don't want you here. You are troublemakers.'"

Staff shortages meant it was common to be locked in cells from 5.30pm to 8.30am, Derradji maintains. "Convicted prisoners all have TV in their cells; we don't even have a radio or a newspaper. If you complain like I did, and sign a petition, they put you in segregation or [only] send you out on exercise when the board of visitors come around to see if everything is all right."

The Home Office denies detaining people "punitively" but admits that the deportation system needs speeding up after appeals have been exhausted. It agrees that "sometimes detention is for longer than we would wish", owing to delays in obtaining travel documents. "In many cases, detainees do not cooperate with applications for documents, and could reduce the length of time they spend in detention by doing so," it says.

But Aspden says Leon's case is at odds with the official line. "He had been here for 10 years with a job, a rented flat and a car. He signed on at his local police station every week - there was no danger that he would go missing - and he had a long history of complying with the immigration service."

Leon, slight and nervous, talks in his tiny, cold flat in north London about his insomnia and shows hands raw with eczema. He looks at the memories of a warmer home - potted palms and small brass kettles for fragrant sweet tea - as he tells his story.

He came to Britain in 1990 to study English and obtained a visa. He got a job and went on studying. In 1995, with violence in Algeria worsening, he applied for political asylum. Immigration officials then asked him to sign on at a police station every week. In July this year, he was called to an interview in central London.

"When I got there, I was searched," he recalls. "A women took my money and keys. Then I was asked where I worked and where I lived. They took pictures of me like a criminal and took my fingerprints. They said: 'Your asylum appeal is dismissed, you are going back to Algeria. They didn't even say I could go home to get my clothes."

He spent more than two months in Rochester until one morning last August when he received a letter stating he was an illegal alien and would be deported immediately. It was then he decided to kill himself. He was found by prison staff and taken to the prison hospital.

It was while he was in hospital that the RLC heard about his case and successfully argued for his release from detention. But his torment goes on. "I can't think of anything but deportation," he says. "I've got eczema. I can't sleep. I have no life, no wife, nothing in the world."

He produces his visa with official stamps recording his legal status in Britain since 1990. "I have proof of everything," he says, showing piles of receipts for phone cards and food and drinks from the shop in Rochester. "I have a big box. I have kept a record of everything I have ever done or bought here. Even the receipt for this pullover. And still they don't believe me."

webTitle: Clements resigns position at Mind over health problems

fields.headline: Mind's big loss
fields.standfirst: Clements resigns over health problems
fields.trailText: Clements resigns over health problems
fields.body:
Judi Clements, chief executive of Mind, is resigning after nine years with the mental health charity because of continuing health problems. The search is on for a successor to fill the £62,000-a-year post.

In a letter telling staff of her decision, Clements, 47, does not disclose the nature of her illness, but writes: "I obviously never expected to leave Mind in this way, and feel deeply sad to be in this predicament."

However, she has told the Guardian that she is upbeat about the state of the charity which she has seen grow through the past decade. And she says that criticism that Mind is this month closing five offices - in Bristol, Preston, Sheffield, Wolverhampton and one in London - is based on a misunderstanding of restructuring plans.

"We're concentrating a whole new department on working with local Mind associations in England and Wales," she says. "We've got £750,000 from the lottery over two years to develop quality standards for local associations."

The restructuring will mean one support worker for every 19 local branches. Overall, the organisation will have slightly more staff as several new posts - including website workers, a rural manager and a campaign manager - have been created.

Apart from small setbacks over funding, Clements leaves her post satisfied by what the charity has achieved during her tenure.

Her only big regret, she says, is that some sections of the media still categorise people with mental illness as "mad, bad and dangerous to know".

fields.headline: New Deal or raw deal?
fields.standfirst: Disability charities review cooperation with national scheme
fields.trailText: Disability charities review cooperation with national scheme
fields.body:
A plan to exclude one in five disabled people who volunteer for the New Deal, and put them in a control group, has met fierce criticism from disability groups which are calling on the goverment to abandon the idea.

Concern is running so high that leading disability charities may reconsider their involvement in the New Deal for disabled people, which will be extended nationally from July with introduction of a national "job broker" scheme.

Under the plan, brokers from the voluntary or private sectors will provide support, guidance and preparation to volunteer jobseekers from among the 2.5m people who claim incapacity benefit.

To measure the scheme's success, the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) plans to assess what would have otherwise happened, using random assignment to do so. Under this method, 20% of volunteers will be allocated to a control group which will be excluded from the scheme for at least a year, but will receive benefits.

A DfEE spokesman says that individuals in the control group will be told "that their eligibility will be deferred". However, details of exactly how the control group will be determined, and at what stage people will be informed, have yet to be decided. "We're speaking to evaluation experts and organisations for and on behalf of disabled people."

The extensive way in which the government intends to use random assignment, compared to what has happened elsewhere in the New Deal, has caused disability groups to question the moral and practical implications. The New Deal for young people used the method for just one week only in certain parts of the country. In the New Deal for people over 25, it was used in only two of the 28 pilot areas.

Steve Winyard, head of public policy at the Royal National Institute for the Blind (RNIB), says he first became aware of the plan last November when the chief executives of seven charities met Margaret Hodge, minister for disabled people, social security minister Hugh Bayley and health minister John Hutton. "All the chief executives expressed concern from the start," says Winyard. "The system is very objectionable. It's treating disabled people like guinea pigs and will be seen by them to be highly discriminatory."

The job broker scheme should be available to every disabled person who wants it, Winyard says. Government refusal to back down woud leave the RNIB facing "a lot of soul searching" about whether to continue to take part as a job broker.

Brian Lamb, director of policy research at the Royal National Institute for Deaf People, says: "This is potentially demotivating for disabled people who will effectively be cut loose from a scheme they wanted to benefit from."

As well as deterring potential brokers, including his own charity, random assignment might affect how disabled people behaved towards the scheme. "On all these grounds we're very unhappy with what appears to be a very unhelpful, Treasury-imposed approach," says Lamb.

John Knight, head of policy at Leonard Cheshire, another top disability charity, says that while his organisation welcomes all government initiatives to help disabled people into employment, use of random assignment is unacceptable. There is little difference between the approach and giving extra funding only to four out of five schools, Knight says. "The outcry from parents would be enormous. Such a move would be politically unthinkable and morally indefensible. So why is it acceptable to use it with disabled people?"

webTitle: New bodies win access to key data in first test of strength

fields.headline: Open to observation
fields.standfirst: New bodies win access to key data in first test of strength
fields.trailText: New bodies win access to key data in first test of strength
fields.body:
The new network of "public health observatories", billed as an independent voice on health and inequality, has flexed its muscles for the first time and forced the release of official data.

The government-funded network, which operates in each of the eight NHS regions in England, was set up with ministerial approval last year. Observatories will provide the public with an accurate picture of the health and well-being of their area, flag up inequalities, provide early warning of potential problems and draw together information on new ways to improve health.

Alison Hill, who chairs the Association of Public Health Observatories and is director of the south-west observatory, has disclosed that the Office for National Statistics was refusing to hand over detailed birth and death data, citing commercial confidentiality. "This is a wonderful data set that is available to everyone in the NHS," she says. "It's a database of public health information that is not available to the general public because they [the ONS] told us that if they made it available, they would lose a lot of revenue. We went back to the chief medical officer to explain how we wanted to make this information freely available to the public. The CMO contacted them and asked them to release it. This is only information that has come from the public in the first place in terms of data about births and deaths. The public do have a right to this sort of information."

Hill guarantees that the data - which is anonymous for data protection purposes - will be available to the public. "It will be going on to our observatory websites and we are trying to think of other ways of dissemination. It's data at local authority level at the moment, but we want to get it down to electoral ward level because that is just the kind of thing people need to know."

There has been criticism that the observatories will duplicate the work of local health authorities, local government and universities. But advocates of the network counter that it is filling a gap created by the demise of the regional health authorities in 1994.

Mark Bellis, director of the north-west observatory, describes the network as a child of the information revolution. He believes that access to information will drive a 21st century public health revolution, just as sewer engineering drove the sanitation revolution of the 19th century. "It shouldn't be inferred that we are reinventing the wheel," he says. "There is an awful lot of information out there, but it's not exploited in the way that it should be at the moment."

Bellis is coordinator of a project to map the sexual health of teenagers across England. His observatory is attempting to plot levels of class A drug use and it is providing health information to private companies, local authorities, fire, police and the judiciary. "We can do health impact assessments for new firms if they want to build a new office or factory," he says. "We will help minimise pollution and disruption and tell them what they can and can't do. But we also want to maximise jobs and community benefits because, as we know, there are health gains from these sorts of things."

In London, meanwhile, observatory director Bobbie Jacobson aims to set up an ethnic minority health surveillance unit to end what she calls "the disgrace of ignorance" about progress on ethnic minority health issues across the capital.

 More information about the public health observatories is at: www.pho.org.uk/

webTitle: Dispelling the myth that youth equals crime

fields.headline: Wassup with kids?
fields.standfirst: Soundbites stereotype them as surly no-hopers, 'the scum'. But as  Hilary Wainwright  discovers in east Manchester, a little trust goes a long way towards dispelling the myth that youth equals crime
fields.trailText: Soundbites stereotype them as surly no-hopers, 'the scum'. But as Hilary Wainwright discovers in east Manchester, a little trust goes a long way towards dispelling the myth that youth equals crime
fields.body:
It's 18 months since the launch of a tough, high-profile local police operation tagged Excalibur. But a tenants' representative in Higher Openshaw, east Manchester, concedes: "It's the youth club as much as Excalibur that's reduced crime round here." She had previously been one of the strongest advocates of the police offensive in an atmosphere where talk of youth clubs would have been seen as rewarding "the scum".

This particular scum are the Sandywell lads, whose joyriding made life hell for local residents, young and old. The youth club is Higher Openshaw Youth, set up by parents frustrated by public meetings where they never got an answer to questions about youth provision.

With the help of a voluntary sector organiser, and the headmaster of Higher Openshaw community school, the parents turned a large classroom into a club, with PlayStations, computers, a tuck bar and use of the football pitch. On two evenings a week, it was open to everyone between the ages of 12 and 25. After six months or so, the Sandywell lads started turning up, mainly to play football, use the PlayStations and have somewhere warm to hang out. "We're neutral," says Louis, one of the club organisers. "When they come they don't bring in the problems they have outside."

Crime and youth - treated as inseparable in government soundbites - is going to be a big issue in the general election. The prime minister is turning to his cabinet for manifesto ideas, but he might do better to listen to what is happening in inner-city neighbourhoods where a small number of government initiated experiments have given residents, voluntary groups and public agencies the powers to innovate.

Higher Openshaw, a neighbourhood that was part of Manchester's former industrial heartland, is now part of one of the first of the government's New Deal for Communities (NDC) programmes. Here, a combination of extra money (a modest £80m over 10 years for an area of 9,000 households), rising expectations and growing self-confidence among local people and voluntary groups, plus NDC staff with a brief to be innovative and accountable, is generating a complex new dynamic that challenges established government mechanisms.

Questions are raised about what is really meant by "community-led" policymaking and "best value". At present, national best value targets measure youth provision primarily in terms of crime reduction: the wider importance of out-of-school opportunities for personal and social fulfilment is not prioritised. East Manchester's experience points to the importance of letting young people help shape the targets.

As elsewhere, anxieties over crime have prompted a sharp response. In an initial survey of local residents' views, "crime and fear of crime" overwhelmingly predominated, and 70% of 800 respondents equated crime with youth crime. The newly-opened NDC office in the windswept Beswick precinct used its clout with local agencies, especially the police, to address these concerns. Operation Excalibur was one result, along with the issuing of an anti-social behaviour order against one local family, security cameras, new lighting and gates on alley ways, placed according to residents' instructions.

This reaction forged a bond between the residents' groups and the NDC, but young people's needs are not necessarily represented through such groups. "There can be unwillingness to talk to young people - they appear more intimidating than they are," says Judith Williams, of the Delamere and Toxteth Residents, which makes a special effort to work with young people. Aware of this, the NDC team built a commitment to a youth programme into its work from the outset.

But NDC team leader Sean McGonigle is open about the imbalance. "Tackling fear of crime was relatively easy," he says. "But working with young people requires a lot more development. Not many people are good at it."

An imaginative consultation with young people was organised, but the results languished on a shelf for a year, until a youth officer was appointed to follow them through. What do young people want? After a go-karting session at the former Parcelforce building in central Manchester, the Higher Openshaw youth divide into groups - the girls want to be separate from the lads - to discuss similar desires.

"A house - they could convert one of the boarded up ones - with sofas and music, warm and dry, with someone there so that there's no bullying or anything," say the girls. "Something as big as this hall," say the boys. "Did you see Big Brother? A house like that." They also want easier access to a modern leisure centre for the whole area. And they want to do something with cars: "A BMX track; motor repair classes..."

One of the reasons why Higher Openshaw Youth is so popular, and unvandalised, is mutual respect. It's round the corner from their homes, more or less their own, but also looked after and comfortable. Volunteer organiser, Jeff Burns, a martial arts instructor, is strongly motivated by the belief that all young people have a right to their own space and facilities. "If you come from the right area, you take it for granted," he says. "Here, you miss out on all those opportunities to build up confidence, relate to people, realise your potential."

Down at the new NDC offices, youth and community officer Alun Francis agrees. Home Office targets linking funds with crime prevention loom large, but he takes a broader view, emphasising the importance of youth provision for itself. "Sanctions are important," he says, "but so is the development of young people."

He is strongly backed - indeed, pressured - in this direction by the local youth task group, which brings together many of those working with young people. The result is robust debate on how to combine law enforcement and crime prevention with meeting the needs of all young people in the area. Francis and the task group are coordinating a growing number of exciting youth projects to tackle the inequality that blights east Manchester. During the summer, they helped fund voluntary organisations and statutory workers to provide activities for every young person. They aim to do this every holiday and half-term.

Plans are under way for a youth college, with an alternative curriculum and innovative support for disaffected young people. A "motor project" is being mooted, and the NDC is funding a general expansion of core youth provision throughout the community, with efforts to ensure that the character of such provision is shaped by young people themselves. The youth workers organising the consultations see it as their mission to eradicate all traces of what they call "adultese". Could youth houses become real? As real as the Commonwealth Games stadium at the end of the road?

Yet those working with young people report a tension between these holistic aims and the more authoritarian themes in Home Office policy. "Curfews on young offenders create obstacles to their involvement with the mentoring and inclusion work we are doing," says Viv Blow, from a local mentoring project part-funded by the NDC. "We convince them to come, and then they have to go through the bureaucracy of getting permission. It puts them off." Blow also finds negative views towards young people are reinforced by a current political consensus associating youth with crime.

Kath Byrne, manager of the nearby Crossley House youth centre, adds: "The main problem for young people here is low self-esteem. We need people who will stand up for them publicly."

At Grey Mare police station, Dave Jones has recently been appointed superintendent after being responsible for Greater Manchester's submission to the Stephen Lawrence inquiry. His message to the Home Office is a measured request for politicalpronouncements which echo, rather than undermine, his attempts to build bridges. "Fear of young people is like racism - based on ignorance," he says. "The more residents speak to youngsters, the more they realise that perhaps it isn't just their fault. But this has to come right from the top."

Glyn Williams, chair of Delamere and Toxteth Residents, says it more plainly: "I've been a Labour man till now, but the cabinet ministers must come and listen to the kids and understand what they need."

Young people need some quick wins. In a small part of east Manchester, they may be beginning to get them. As the general election draws near and populist soundbites proliferate, is the government prepared to learn from people such as Williams, and volunteers at Higher Openshaw Youth, and commit serious public resources to out of school provision for all young people?

Falling short of expectations

David Brindle

Is youth offending really on the increase, as many people and politicians appear to believe? The evidence is, at best, mixed.

According to Home Office figures, the number of young people aged 10-17 found guilty of, or cautioned for, an indictable offence in England and Wales fell from 153,000 in 1988 to 127,000 in 1998. But this was up from 120,000 in 1997.

Similarly, the number of those aged 18-20 convicted or cautioned fell from 94,000 in 1988 to 82,000 in 1996, but rose again to 91,000 in 1998. At age 21 or over, the number rose 14% between 1988 and 1998.

Eighteen is the peak age for known offending among men, but among women it is 15. In 1995, a Home Office report concluded that young people who misused drugs or alcohol were likely to become "embedded in a criminal lifestyle". To divert them, it suggested, the criminal justice system should "harness the more powerful sources of social control exercised by families, schools and neighbours".

The government's criminal justice and police bill, unveiled last week, aims to breathe new life into child curfew and anti-social behaviour orders that are widely seen to have fallen short of expectations.

fields.headline: A wolf in sheep's fittings
fields.standfirst:
With a new president comes new office decor for the White House. But the peaches and cream scheme doesn't fool Jonathan Glancey

Special report: George Bush's America
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: With a new president comes new office decor for the White House. But the peaches and cream scheme doesn't fool Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
George Bush made his supporters laugh by promising to give the Oval Office in the White House "one hell of a scrubbing" when he moved in to the famous presidential office this week. So this week, after a thorough wash-down, workers removed just about every last bit of Clinton's legacy they could - except the desk that Queen Victoria presented to President Rutherford B Hayes in 1880.

Out went big Bill's bold royal blue presidential rug, his eye-catching golden damask drapes and his plush red and cream silk-covered sofas. In came Ronald Reagan's ivory, beige and terracotta rug (though one commentator described this as "ivory ringed in melon and sage". Tasty, eh?) and a "peaches and cream" colour scheme set off with cream brocade.

The renowned pen-maker, AT Cross, has supplied the new president's favourite midnight blue felt-tip pens; these will rest on Hayes's desktop along with framed portraits of Bush's parents, wife and children.

Medallions and busts of Democrat presidents Franklin D Roosevelt and Harry S Truman have been ousted, but the following artworks have been retained: Rembrandt Peel's portrait of George Washington in his Continental Army outfit; Fred Remington's sculpture, The Bronco Buster; Thomas Moran's epic landscape, The Three Tetons; and a Norman Rockwell oil depicting the outstretched arm of the Statue of Liberty.

Bush has added a painting of a small boy fishing from a bridge, and another of a man on horseback. Oh, and there are bowls of peach roses on the coffee table. Nice.

Not much change here then, really, is there? This depends on whether you think office decor tells a story or not. It does, of course. Bush is not, nor has he ever been, Mr Nice Guy, yet the peach and cream colours, the saccharine-sweet picture of a boy fishing, the outdatedly macho picture of a rider, the peach roses and ivory carpet suggest a president who wants to appear as warm and comfortable as a family hotel in Dallas.

Bush's taste in office decor is respectable middle America. Staff and visitors will no longer be able to enter the peaches and cream Oval Office in jeans, and certainly not in T-shirts. Instead the UPS (universal politician's suit, usually grey or blue and utterly banal) for manly men and, presumably, the pleated A-line skirt for matronly women, will be the new dress code. Taken together, the couture and decor imply respectable, white, middle-aged, middle-class values. No perverts or radicals here. Not sure about dogs.

As an exercise in re-imaging Bush as a caring, compassionate politician, will this soft, sexless, pastel-shaded, post-Clinton interior take anyone in? The new-look Oval Office is rather like an electric chair covered in plush or a death-row cell in Texas being given the once-over by Nicky Haslam.

For a man who has tried hard to prove how macho he is, the peaches-and-cream trick is particularly unconvincing. If he was true to himself, Bush should really have gone for a hi-tech office, all stainless steel, chromed bolts, stressed wire and gridded metal floors with piranha fish, perhaps, swimming below them.

A reproduction of Francisco de Goya's depiction of a firing squad would surely have been a more suitable choice of painting than that of a little boy fishing. And maybe some guns sent in by good ol' Republican boys might have decorated walls lined with razor blades rather than silk-finish paint.

In the good old bad days, when rightwing politicians were true to their self-image, you could expect Adolf Hitler to plan, say, the invasion of Poland from the depths of a titanic neo-classical office designed by Albert Speer in an attempt to outbid Versailles. Such offices were clearly the haunts of fanatics and megalomaniacs. At least you knew who was out to repress you or to extend the boundaries of your empire by the whole of western Europe and a chunk of the Balkans and Russia to jackboot.

The banal near-genius of politicians like Bush, with his peaches, cream and ivory and respectable suits, is to make rightwing regimes seem almost decent. How can I mean any harm, the new look Oval Office appears to say, when I like the same kind of beige - and pastel-shaded, silk-finish decor that most of middle America does?

There is something ultimately far more chilling in having a president who likes executions garbed in a natty corporate executive's suit and sitting in an office that would appeal to the mumsiest members of the Mothers of America than having him reveal his true colours.

Hannah Arendt coined the immortal phrase "the banality of evil" to describe the culture of fascists and Nazis in power; now we are faced with the banality of decor with which to hide democratically elected rightwing regimes. Somehow, after George Bush's "one hell of a scrubbing", peaches and cream will never seem quite so innocent again.

fields.headline: Neighbourhood watcher
fields.standfirst: Paul Richards talks to Joe Montgomery, the man charged with delivering the government's neighbourhood renewal scheme
fields.trailText: Paul Richards talks to Joe Montgomery, the man charged with delivering the government's neighbourhood renewal scheme
fields.body:
When the government announced its initiative for nationwide neighbourhood renewal on Stepney's ocean estate last week, there were almost as many ministers present as journalists. Tony Blair knows that reviving the inner cities and the estates is essential if his government is to be judged a success, and his ministers want to be part of the action.

The man charged with delivering this renaissance is 39-year-old Joe Montgomery, who for the past four years has been a director at the Blairite London borough of Lewisham, covering the south-east of the capital.

As director-general of the government's new Neighbourhood Renewal Unit (NRU) with a staff of up to 90 civil servants and a budget of several millions, Mr Montgomery's job is to create joined-up working between government departments notorious for their mutual distrust and lack of cooperation.

"Director-general" may be a formal civil service grade, but the job, cutting across departments and depending on trouble-shooting to deliver results, is far from the traditional civil service role.

Joe Montgomery is as far removed from the Yes, Minister Sir Humphrey stereotype as it is possible to be. He is more Armani than Saville Row, more Groucho Club than Athenaeum. He has a reputation as a go-getter who thrives on results and hard work.

He is reluctant to admit he was "head-hunted" for his new post: "I applied for the job, but the department did use an executive search company to draw up the long list. I am enthusiastic about the modernisation project and looking forward to playing my part."

Working across departments is a style Mr Montgomery has been used to at Lewisham, where the old-style committee system has been abolished and the council departments have been merged.

"I can categorically state that the biggest benefit of Lewisham's modernisation has been the abolition of the rancorous departmentalism that sometimes got in the way of delivering shared goals. Parochial ambitions can sometimes get in the way of people seeing the larger project. The improvements in Lewisham have had benefits for staff, councillors and local residents, who are starting to see improvements in services. Modernisation means we can be more ambitious about the scale and pace of change."

Mr Montgomery's track record is impressive and he is a familiar face on the regeneration conference and seminar circuit: "I am looking forward to retaining my relationship with urban renewal practitioners across the country. My job will be to help them achieve ever greater success."

He rose to prominence in the regeneration world in the 1980s, with the Birmingham-based Cadbury Trust. His time in the city helped him develop a love of Aston Villa, but "with precious little reward. I'm confident that my second team, Millwall, will go all the way this season. South London deserves the success. The old chant 'no one likes us - and we don't care' may well have to be changed".

For four years he headed the Department of Trade and Industry's inner city task force under the Conservatives. "I have worked with Peter Lilley, Sir George Young and I have a vivid recollection of showing a deeply sceptical John Redwood around regeneration projects in Lewisham."

At Lewisham council, Mr Montgomery was instrumental in putting together the deal that brought the Docklands Light Railway (DLR) to the area. The move is already producing tangible regeneration benefits. Through the Deptford City Challenge and other regeneration schemes, he has brought millions of pounds of investment cash to the borough.

"The experience in Deptford and Lewisham is that if all the agencies work together, you can achieve real improvements. We fought long and hard to bring the DLR through Lewisham. The council made millions available, and argued the case at every level. And we were right to do so.

"The areas in the borough of Lewisham nearby DLR stations have seen real improvements. House prices are rising, new shops and businesses are starting up, people can travel to new jobs. It has been a success story, because we had the vision a decade ago to fight for the investment. Good transport links are just part of the story - but the DLR is a good example of private and public sectors working together to achieve common goals."

Mr Montgomery, a self-confessed "jazz addict" who runs 12 miles a week - "at least most weeks" - starts at the NRU, which will be based inside the DETR offices in Bressenden Place, on March 12. But the government has already started to get its money's worth. He's been in and out of Whitehall ever since local government minister Hilary Armstrong announced his appointment to the House of Commons, meeting his future civil service colleagues and getting started on fashioning the new unit. When I spoke to him, he was on his way from a ministerial meeting, heading back to Lewisham to meet the councillor responsible for the local environment.

Does he have any "early wins" in his sights?

"Regeneration can be a lengthy process - trying to create structures that are sustainable can take time. There are plenty of urgent tasks, but we're all playing a long game."

Mr Montgomery turns 40 next month, but some, including Mr Montgomery himself, might suggest his birthday came early this year: "Its true what they say, at least in my case - life begins at 40."

Tony Blair knows that reviving the inner cities and the estates is essential if his government is to be judged a success, and his ministers want to be part of the action. The man charged with delivering this renaissance is 39-year-old Joe Montgomery, who for the past four years has been a director at the Blairite London borough of Lewisham, covering the south-east of the capital. As director-general of the government's new Neighbourhood Renewal Unit (NRU) with a staff of up to 90 civil servants and a budget of several millions, Mr Montgomery's job is to create joined-up working between government departments notorious for their mutual distrust and lack of cooperation. "Director-general" may be a formal civil service grade, but the job, cutting across departments and depending on trouble-shooting to deliver results, is far from the traditional civil service role. Joe Montgomery is as far removed from the Yes, Minister Sir Humphrey stereotype as it is possible to be. He is more Armani than Saville Row, more Groucho Club than Athenaeum. He has a reputation as a go-getter who thrives on results and hard work. He is reluctant to admit he was "head-hunted" for his new post: "I applied for the job, but the department did use an executive search company to draw up the long list. I am enthusiastic about the modernisation project and looking forward to playing my part." Working across departments is a style Mr Montgomery has been used to at Lewisham, where the old-style committee system has been abolished and the council departments have been merged. "I can categorically state that the biggest benefit of Lewisham's modernisation has been the abolition of the rancorous departmentalism that sometimes got in the way of delivering shared goals. Parochial ambitions can sometimes get in the way of people seeing the larger project. The improvements in Lewisham have had benefits for staff, councillors and local residents, who are starting to see improvements in services. Modernisation means we can be more ambitious about the scale and pace of change." Mr Montgomery's track record is impressive and he is a familiar face on the regeneration conference and seminar circuit: "I am looking forward to retaining my relationship with urban renewal practitioners across the country. My job will be to help them achieve ever greater success." He rose to prominence in the regeneration world in the 1980s, with the Birmingham-based Cadbury Trust. His time in the city helped him develop a love of Aston Villa, but "with precious little reward. I'm confident that my second team, Millwall, will go all the way this season. South London deserves the success. The old chant 'no one likes us - and we don't care' may well have to be changed". For four years he headed the Department of Trade and Industry's inner city task force under the Conservatives. "I have worked with Peter Lilley, Sir George Young and I have a vivid recollection of showing a deeply sceptical John Redwood around regeneration projects in Lewisham." At Lewisham council, Mr Montgomery was instrumental in putting together the deal that brought the Docklands Light Railway (DLR) to the area. The move is already producing tangible regeneration benefits. Through the Deptford City Challenge and other regeneration schemes, he has brought millions of pounds of investment cash to the borough. "The experience in Deptford and Lewisham is that if all the agencies work together, you can achieve real improvements. We fought long and hard to bring the DLR through Lewisham. The council made millions available, and argued the case at every level. And we were right to do so. "The areas in the borough of Lewisham nearby DLR stations have seen real improvements. House prices are rising, new shops and businesses are starting up, people can travel to new jobs. It has been a success story, because we had the vision a decade ago to fight for the investment. Good transport links are just part of the story - but the DLR is a good example of private and public sectors working together to achieve common goals." Mr Montgomery, a self-confessed "jazz addict" who runs 12 miles a week - "at least most weeks" - starts at the NRU, which will be based inside the DETR offices in Bressenden Place, on March 12. But the government has already started to get its money's worth. He's been in and out of Whitehall ever since local government minister Hilary Armstrong announced his appointment to the House of Commons, meeting his future civil service colleagues and getting started on fashioning the new unit. When I spoke to him, he was on his way from a ministerial meeting, heading back to Lewisham to meet the councillor responsible for the local environment. Does he have any "early wins" in his sights? "Regeneration can be a lengthy process - trying to create structures that are sustainable can take time. There are plenty of urgent tasks, but we're all playing a long game." Mr Montgomery turns 40 next month, but some, including Mr Montgomery himself, might suggest his birthday came early this year: "Its true what they say, at least in my case - life begins at 40."

webTitle: Reversing the downward spiral of neighbourhood deprivation

fields.headline: Reversing the downward spiral of neighbourhood deprivation
fields.standfirst: Why is the government focusing on regeneration through the neighbourhood approach? Brian Robson explains.
fields.trailText: The "neighbourhood" has taken centre stage in the government's approach to regeneration. But how does deprivation begin and can it really be reversed by the government's neighbourhood renewal strategy?
fields.body:
The "neighbourhood" has taken centre stage in the government's approach to regeneration. The national strategy for neighbourhood renewal has already produced a neighbourhood management initiative to be piloted in 15 areas, and an urban renewal fund targeted at 88 authorities.

Both have been added to the longer-standing new deal for communities as lynch pins of policy intervention. All three programmes have common elements - not least their focus on small areas, and their aim of tackling problems in a coordinated way by addressing jobs, housing, crime, health and community resilience.

Each sits alongside the context of last year's urban white paper that gave welcome recognition to the importance of rolling out good practice in the delivery of services and of bending main spending to reinforce the aim of local regeneration.

There are some strong arguments for taking a neighbourhood approach. Small areas can quickly gain poor reputations. Whether they have any substance or not, they can critically affect a neighbourhood's fortunes and are often reinforced by media-generated images.

There are powerful processes that can drive neighbourhoods into a downward spiral. We have long been aware of postcode discrimination - by employers, insurance companies and potential investors. Those who leave poor areas are usually in work and with the money to afford relocation, or those who can read the runes of how best to enhance the educational prospects for their children.

What economists term "negative externalities" can apply at very small scales: an empty and abandoned house next door; a waste plot being used by drug dealers or prostitutes; graffiti on house walls; abandoned sofas in the street. All of these can start a rapid process of neighbourhood change that encourages stable households to leave and undermines confidence both by families and by institutional investors. It needs only a few "problem families" to be moved into an area, or only a few landlords to fill houses with "welfare" cases, to start this rapid process.

Part of the negative spiral is linked to the increasing perception of council housing as a tenure of last resort, but as research has shown, the rot within small areas affects all tenures - registered social landlords and new private and housing association houses as much as council housing.

The evidence of market collapse in house prices in small areas is striking - and frequently the areas with houses selling for less than £10,000, hard-to-let stock and with massive problems of negative equity are cheek-by-jowl with areas of relatively stable housing markets.

It is these local spirals that justify neighbourhood-based intervention. But there are questions about the neighbourhood focus. Most of the problems of small areas are a result of poverty and unemployment. Only if a neighbourhood and its people are connected back into the mainstream economy are its underlying difficulties likely to be ameliorated.

This means the new neighbourhood initiatives will need to be strongly tied to the local strategic partnerships proposed in the white paper (and there remains uncertainty about their roles and the capacity of areas to develop the necessary local partnerships).

Sub-regional economies are far from uniformly strong - it is far easier to re-connect neighbourhoods in east London into strong economies than those in Liverpool or Teesside.

In the case of the neighbourhood management pilots, parachuting in these well paid, local managers may be a double-edged sword unless they have the powers and resources to deliver on what they might promise. Bypassing the neighbourhood champions that already exist in deprived areas, often middle-aged women, may be a recipe for local resentment as much as a solution to the need to strengthen neighbourhood and community ties and the quality of local services. Plausible champions tend to be locally bred not imported.

It is encouraging to see the government beginning to translate into action the regeneration focus promised by the white paper, but at this stage the jury on neighbourhoods must still be out.

webTitle: Violence against social care staff must stop for the sector to survive

fields.headline: Violence against social care staff must stop for the sector to survive
fields.standfirst: To attract long-term and skilled staff into social care the profession must tackle the issues surrounding violence toward staff, writes Daphne Statham
fields.trailText: To attract long-term and skilled staff into social care the profession must tackle the issues surrounding violence toward staff, writes Daphne Statham
fields.body:
Two huge changes are impacting on social care. The sector is in competition with business, health and teaching for recruits because of the shortage of young people in the workforce and the increased options for women - the traditional source of social care staff.

Social care must recruit and retain workers who are not only in scarce supply but will increasingly have to be highly skilled.

Second, there is the quest for quality as a result of raised expectations from service users and how these services are delivered.

Services and staff regulation through the commission for care standards, the general social care council and organisations like them mean the investment in our workforce will have to increase if it is to deliver consistent services of greater quality.

The job has become complex and skilled as policies enable more people to remain in, or quickly return to, mainstream services.

Service users increasingly face social and personal problems that cannot be resolved elsewhere. Social care staff often work where individuals and families are impoverished; where people are in crisis, confronting distressing and intractable problems that have long-term effects on their life chances and those around them.

Solutions available to them are often third or fourth best, and not only through lack of resources. Many are in places and positions where they do not want, and never expected to be. The work is routinely stressful and centres on distress, hurt, anger and frustration as well as resourcefulness and strength. If solutions for those using social care services are to be achieved, something has to be done.

Violence, defined by the national task force on violence against social care staff as "abuse, threats, assaults relating to work", is common in social care and seen by some staff as "part of the job".

Many social care staff thought they had little or no support from their management and violence was not taken seriously enough. Incidents are under-reported. The task force wants organisations to establish a realistic baseline figure on violent incidents and produce an action plan on how to reduce it.

Frontline staff and service users agreed that they neither wanted "fortress social care", nor did they want complicated forms to record incidents that disappeared somewhere in the depths of an organisation.

But violence to social care staff is unacceptable and has resulted in deaths, in serious injury and in staff feeling so violated they have had to leave the sector and cope with long-term effects of the incident.

The task force is also aware of the impact on the lives of service users who resort to violence for whatever reason. We concluded that a safe environment and safe practice was good for workers and service users. We were equally convinced the incidence of violence could be reduced.

Our findings link with those of the economic and social research council's programme on violence and the work of the Royal College of Psychiatry. Together they provide a growing base of knowledge that can be used to improve practice and management.

The reviews of the research showed us it was not just a matter of spotting violent people, although one indicator of future incidence is previous violent behaviour.

Even here we found a several factors have to come together for violence to occur. Some are to do with what is happening in the service user's life. Others were the environment and its culture, the organisation's policies, and more importantly whether they are part of the day-to-day practice of its managers and workers.

Assessing and managing the risk of violence must become routine. It must be thought of when something as basic as regular maintenance of offices is taking place.

It needs to be part of basic training and staff development for all. We found that reception staff, secretaries and administrative staff were often required to cope with violence, or "help out" when there were difficulties. They had to rely on common sense to cope with uncommon situations.

The onus for reducing violent incidents cannot be left with social care staff, managers and service users.

The media and politicians also have a responsibility. Social care staff accepted the need to be accountable for their part when things go wrong, but a consistent message from frontline staff was that the constant running down of staff by the media and some politicians "softened them up for violence".

The NHS and the Department of the Environment have campaigns to reduce violence in the work place. It is hoped this time and together we can begin to achieve change.

&#149 Daphne Statham was a member of the task force on violence against social care staff.

fields.headline: The best chopstick scene
fields.standfirst: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.trailText: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.body:
The house of Tsai (Wang De Ming) and his daughter May (Li Li). Their guest, Sir Te's security guard Bo (Gao Xian), sits on the floor as May fires a small coal-fired grill on which is boiling a sizzling pot of meatballs and vegetables.

"Why were you spying on the Yus?" Bo asks.

"I'm looking for someone," Tsai replies. "Jade Fox. I'm a police inspector from Shaan Xi, Gen Su district. Jade Fox is a master criminal. I hear she infiltrated the Yus. She must have come with them when they transferred here. But with Yu's reputation, I can't just go in and accuse her."

"This Jade Fox is a woman?"

"Yes."

"Then leave her to me."

"Pardon me, but I doubt you can handle her. My wife was quite a martial arts expert."

Tsai peers at the fire for a moment.

"Jade Fox killed her, So you see, this is personal. Leave her to me."

May gestures to the pot.

"It's ready!"

As Bo fishes into the pot with his chopsticks, May stops him.

"Father gets first dip."

Tsai stiffens and snaps his chopsticks - not to pick up a meatball but to catch a dart with a note attached which has flown across the room.

"'We'll settle this at midnight on Yellow Hill,'" Tsai reads. "Good. The fox is out of her hole."

See also: The Wedding Banquet, Eat Drink Man Woman, Dim Sum

Don't see also: Showdown In Little Tokyo

Pointless trivia: Despite the plaudits surrounding Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, director Ang Lee has yet to receive any money from the film, and has recently been obliged to direct a commercial for music conglomerate BMG.

fields.headline: Defoe delight at record-breaking goal
fields.trailText:
Cambridge 0 - 2 Bournemouth
Defoe delight as scoring record falls.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin at the Abbey Stadium
fields.body:
Jermaine Defoe sank to his knees, clasped his hands to his chest in thanks and disappeared beneath a sea of delirious Bournemouth team-mates. The terrace in front of him may have been empty but this was history all the same.

By finding the net last night the 18-year-old striker set a post-war record of scoring in 10 consecutive league matches in the same season. Now he has Dixie Dean's all-time league record of 12 straight games, set in 1930-31, in his sights.

The way he sidestepped Shaun Marshall and slotted the ball into an empty net midway through the second half showed what an instinctive talent Bournemouth have taken on loan from West Ham.

Bournemouth's victory, achieved after they were reduced to 10 men in the 27th minute, was confirmed by Defoe's late replacement James Hayter. But the attention afterwards centred on one man. Smiling broadly, Defoe posed for photographs with 10 digits held up. Apart from missing an early chance he had a quiet match. But this slight, pacy England youth international has a special talent which means that he is always liable to explode into life.

"Sometimes he plays like an 18-year-old who's not had many games, but he's instinctive," said Bournemouth's manager Sean O'Driscoll. "We try not to fill his head with tactics and coaching because I don't think he's at an age where he can take that. We just try to encourage him."

The statistics show why. Only once in 13 games this season has he failed to score and in his only appearance for West Ham he came up with the winner at Walsall in the Worthington Cup.

"He goes into every game not wondering if he'll score but wondering, when will I score?" West Ham's youth manager Tony Carr has said. Even before this match Bournemouth's chairman Trevor Watkins said with a smile that it was Pele's record of scoring in 16 consecutive league games Defoe was after. At West Ham his talent has earned him the nickname "Wrighty" after Ian Wright, and if he fulfils his potential he may cost the club £1.6m rather than the initial £400,000 paid to Charlton in 1999.

As a karaoke fan who is said to prepare for games by singing to himself, it seemed Defoe had left The Verve's Lucky Man out of his pre-match repertoire when he hit the keeper's legs from an early one-on-one.

Then when Wade Elliott was dismissed for a challenge on John Dreyer he may have feared his chance of beating the record, held by John Aldridge and Kevin Russell, had gone. It had not.

Watched by five members of West Ham's coaching staff, including Frank Lampard, he coolly slotted in his next opportunity. "He's not ready for the Premiership yet," O'Driscoll said. His time, though, will surely come.

Cambridge United (4-4-2): Marshall; Joseph, Duncan, Dreyer, Cowan (Wilson, 82min); Youngs, Wanless, Ashbee, Oakes (Russell, 61); Taylor (Hansen, 68), Connor.

Bournemouth (4-4-2): Stewart; Broadhurst (Smith, 39), Tindall, Howe, Narada; Elliott, C Fletcher, Hughes, Jorgensen; Defoe (Hayter, 80), S Fletcher.

Referee: M Fletcher.

fields.headline: Liverpool 5 - 0 Crystal Palace
fields.standfirst: Match report
fields.trailText: Liverpool: Westerveld, Gerrard, Carragher, Henchoz, Hyypia, Biscan, Murphy, Litmanen, McAllister, Fowler, Smicer. Subs: Nielsen, Ziege, Hamann, Barmby, Heskey.
fields.body:
Liverpool: Westerveld, Gerrard, Carragher, Henchoz, Hyypia, Biscan, Murphy, Litmanen, McAllister, Fowler, Smicer. Subs: Nielsen, Ziege, Hamann, Barmby, Heskey.

Crystal Palace: Kolinko, Smith, Harrison, Austin, Thomson, Carlisle, Rubins, Rodger, Black, Forssell, Morrison. Subs: Gregg, Gray, Ruddock, Pollock, Kabba.

Referee: P Durkin (Dorset)

1 Liverpool kick off this beautifully poised tie. Palace are without influential defender Fan Zhiyi and Robbie Fowler comes in up front for Liverpool. Gerard Houllier's men are 5-1 on with Palace 10-1 against, but that still didn't stop one optimistic London punter placing £5,000 on the Eagles.
2 Fowler wins the first corner of the game; Gerard misses it, but Hyppia gets his head in to force a save. Fowler certainly eager to impress on this his first start in five games - so eager, he is immediately caught offside.
3 Smicer finds space on the right and centres for McAllister to stroke the ball out left to Carragher. McAllister gets it back but Liverpool lose possession. Gerard lucky to get away with a kick at Rubins.
5 All Liverpool so far. Murphy plays a one-two with Fowler on the edge of the area before forcing Palace's Latvian international keeper Kolinko down to his left with a shot.
6 Palace rattle the home side with their first significant move upfield and win a corner. Comes to nothing although Palace do manage to keep the ball in the Liverpool half for almost a minute. Well done, boys.
9 Solid defending by Smith to keep Fowler away from a long clearance by Gerard and thus deny a break.
10 Kolinko does well in the Palace when he leaves his area to head the ball to safety.
13 GOAL: Liverpool 1 - 0 Palace Fowler on the half-way line finds Smicer wide on the right with a pinpoint pass. Carlisle unable to keep up and Smicer has a free run into the Palace area before beating Kolinko at the far post with a right-foot shot.

fields.headline: Orton still entertains and shocks
fields.standfirst:
Entertaining Mr Sloane
Arts Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Entertaining Mr Sloane

Arts Theatre, London

Rating: ***
fields.body:
Does is it still shock? Thirty-seven years after its premiere at this same theatre, does Joe Orton's play retain its primal kick? On the evidence of Terry Johnson's coolly farcical production, emphatically yes: partly because we are more alert now to the play's misogynist cruelty and partly because of the glittering contrast between style and content.

Coldly considered, the action is unremittingly sordid. Sloane, a murderous, bisexual thug, insinuates himself into the home and bed of the sexually infantile Kath while also attracting her gaily butch brother, Ed. He impregnates Kath, excites Ed by working as his leather-clad chauffeur and then brutally kicks their father to death. But the exploiter turns victim when Ed and Kath blackmail him into becoming their shared sexual slave.

What makes the play shocking - and funny - is the formal decorum of Orton's language. Harold Hobson, in his original review, compared the play to Jane Austen's Northanger Abbey, and it is precisely the Janeite contrast between the Gothic substance and the elevated style that gives the play its charge. When Kath famously says "Until I was 15 I was more familiar with Africa than my own body", or when Ed claims that it is his "liberal principles" that have led him to be foolishly protective, we are in a world where language is used as an elaborate masquerade.

But the virtue of Johnson's production is that it exposes Orton's genuine heartlessness, and it does this by heightening the play's farcical quality. When Kath vamps the willing Sloane, she appears from behind swagged curtains to a Mario Lanza record like a downmarket Cleopatra; when Sloane attacks her in the final scene her dentures go flying across the room, only to be caught by Ed. Even if Kath is finally triumphant, there is no escaping the rancid misogyny behind Ed's line to his sister that "you showed him the gate of Hell every night".

Johnson, in short, brings out the play's cold-hearted swagger. He is helped by a wonderfully over-the-top William Dudley set that, with its murky mural of swirling bodies, reminds one of the collage that decorated Orton's own room. And the performances tread a fine line between verbal comedy and physical farce. As Kath, Alison Steadman veers superbly between an affected gentility and a rank coarseness when the chips, and the trousers, are down. Clive Francis as Ed almost salivates at the prospect of a uniformed Sloane and captures exactly a certain kind of blazered, gay muscularity. Neil Stuke's Sloane is a ruthless blond predator who always sits with legs conveniently splayed.

In the end, I find something slightly chilling about Orton's own amorality. But there is no denying his power as a comic stylist or the play's ability, even after all these years, to leave one pleasurably shocked.

Until April 6. Box office: 020-7863 3334.
