fields.headline: Keep off the grass
fields.standfirst:
The BBC is installing a hotline for staff to inform on misbehaving colleagues. But, as Anita Chaudhuri reports, whistleblowing in Britain is still a dangerous occupation

MediaGuardian.co.uk
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The BBC is installing a hotline for staff to inform on misbehaving colleagues. But, as Anita Chaudhuri reports, whistleblowing in Britain is still a dangerous occupation.
fields.body:
In these days of Erin Brockovich and John Grisham-inspired legal thrillers, we are beginning to grow accustomed to the idea that the individual crusader can sometimes win David-and-Goliath battles against Evil Corporations.

So when the BBC confirmed this week that it has introduced a telephone hotline to encourage its 23,600 employees to inform on colleagues they suspect of behaving improperly, it seemed like another victory for whistleblowing: another example of how, following the introduction of the "Whistleblowers' Act", the 1998 Public Interest Disclosure Act, it really is easier now for workers to reveal corporate malpractice without fear.

Cards bearing a 24-hour free phone number have been distributed among BBC staff; anyone who reports a workmate whom they suspect of taking bribes, fiddling expenses, harassment or health and safety breaches can now provide full details anonymously.

The move is a timely one: a survey in this month's Management Today magazine reveals that 30% of senior managers have blown the whistle, while recent high-profile cases such as Stephen Bolsin, the anaesthetist at Bristol Royal Infirmary who spent five years trying to alert the authorities to unsatisfactory standards of paediatric heart surgery, have raised awareness about the devastating consequences of remaining silent.

But if you see heinous acts of corruption going on under your nose every day, is an anonymous telephone helpline really going to expose the culprit without landing you in the dole queue? The answer is: not necessarily - particularly if the organisation you work for is using the services of a commercial call-handling company.

The BBC has opted for Expolink, an outfit that offers similar "snitch lines" for 600,000 individuals worldwide, including several benefit fraud lines for local authorities in England and Wales. Its services don't come cheap: a quick glance at Expolink's charge sheet reveals that the cost for an organisation of the BBC's size is £1,100 per month, with an additional 80p per employee for a "welcome pack", plus VAT.

Which comes in at nearer £40,000 - a pricey package considerably greater than the £10,000 estimated by the BBC in news reports last weekend.

Companies such as Expolink offer the same services as any call centre - specially trained staff available round the clock to read out a pre-rehearsed script. "We're not a counselling service, we're not there to advise on what is or what is not the right course of action," says David Crook, the company's director.

"We're merely a channel of communication between the organisation and its workforce. Our phone people are trained to get as much information about the case as possible and then pass it on. That's the end of our involvement - it's then up to the BBC or whoever to take a view on how to investigate and resolve the matter. Even if it's a case of serious malpractice, we as the call handler have to be careful not to get drawn into the case."

But can a hired call service really fulfil the spirit of a good whistleblow ing policy? "It's very odd that the BBC has decided to go down this route," says Guy Dehn, director of Public Concern at Work, a charity providing free telephone advice to anyone contemplating whistleblowing. "These call firms are nothing but glorified answering services, and they don't provide independent advice. How can they, since they are hired by the organisation's management?"

Dehn's organisation represents 450 NHS trusts, as well as private-sector firms, and was crucial in lobbying for a change in the law. The 1998 act means, in theory, that it much easier for workers to bring cases into the open: they can claim compensation if they are victimised for bringing a case, and can claim unfair dismissal if they lose their job. The ceiling on compensation has also been raised.

But it doesn't always work out so well in practice. The BBC's decision to hire Expolink, Dehn argues, is at odds with government guidelines on standards in public life. "The Nolan Committee made it clear that public bodies would be expected to provide, and authorise their staff to get, independent advice when they were concerned about a whistleblowing issue. The NHS follows this to the letter, so why can't the BBC?

"The spirit of the new BBC is meant to be all about openness and transparency, yet this move suggests that they won't practise what they preach. They're always attacking other organisations for being secretive, but now they're encouraging their workers not to speak out in public but to hide behind an answering machine. It's a classic case of sauce for the goose."

The BBC rejects the charges. "We want to make it easier for employees to communicate these issues and we feel this is the best way of doing it," says a spokesman. "Anyway, why on earth would we need people to offer counselling or advice? The line is just for them to report malpractice."

But specialists in the field argue that counselling is anything but irrelevant. "Anyone who rings our helpline usually needs a lot of counselling about what their options are," says Dehn. "We'd start off by asking them what they want to achieve by exposing the wrongdoing. It's certainly not always appropriate for them to take on their bosses, or even to take legal action. It depends whether what's at stake really is in the public interest, and it depends on individual circumstances. Someone rang the other day wanting to expose appalling standards in a care home.

"In that case, what they ended up doing was writing a pseudonymous article for Community Care magazine." The whole issue of anonymity is hugely risky. "It's a question of access to information. In many organisations, if you blow the whistle, even if you do it anonymously, people will know who was responsible."

Dehn cites the case of a firm in Liverpool, where an employee last year reported an incident to a telephone helpline. His contract was subsequently not renewed, and he took his case to tribunal. He won the case - but it was far more difficult to prove victimisation because he had made the complaint anonymously, and someone in the firm had guessed his identity.

There is another, wider problem: whistleblowing has become a catch-all term, but as far as the law is concerned it applies only to the disclosure of information that is in the public interest - so the BBC's system, which will cover all complaints, expands the scope of the definition.

Many employees do find themselves wanting to report conduct that does not fall within the letter of the law. One book editor, who wishes to remain anonymous, found herself in just such a scenario three months ago when she decided to speak out against a superior who was persistently harassing young women who came to their offices on work placement schemes. "He was basically promising them full-time jobs if they would have sex with them," she explains. "And then of course that would be the last we'd see of them. Since I told my boss, the culprit has been reprimanded, but now I still have to work alongside him and I'm sure he knows it was me who complained."

The largest payment made to date under the new law has been to Toni Fernandes, an accountant with the Reading-based telecommunications firm Netcom. He was sacked for gross misconduct after faxing company directors in America to tell them how the firm's chief executive had claimed £371,000 in cash advances and expenses without receipts, following detective work that had involved reassembling shredded documents. Fernandes was awarded £293,441 compensation by an employment tribunal.

But it is still the case that being branded a whistleblower does not exactly improve one's CV. "Other employers may avoid people who make these claims," says Laurence Anstis, the lawyer who acted for Fernandes. "They see them as troublemakers." Fernandes has not worked since the ruling.

fields.headline: Equitable rubs salt in wounds
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: In a move condemned by independent financial advisers as throwing good money after bad, Equitable Life is spending policyholders' own money to ask them just how they feel about the mutual insurer.
fields.body:
In a move condemned by independent financial advisers as throwing good money after bad, Equitable Life is spending policyholders' own money to ask them just how they feel about the mutual insurer.

It has hired researchers to cold call pension plan customers to ask if they want to pump yet more cash into the wounded insurer.

The questions are likely to anger the firm's 900,000 policyholders whose expectations of a golden retirement have turned to dust.

Last month, Equitable closed its books to new business following a House of Lords decision that exposed a £1.5bn hole in the with-profits fund. It warned policyholders that returns in the with-profits fund would be cut, and imposed a 10% penalty on those taking their money elsewhere.

The 238-year-old insurer hired Financial Dynamics, a City publicity firm, to poll customers. The move was criticised yesterday by the Equitable Life Policyholders Action Group.

Lobby chairman Ron Bullen said: "I can't see the point of asking questions when the choice of paying a penalty to exit or facing lower returns if you stay in is so stark."

Equitable Life said it was "a small survey designed to get a scientific rather than an anecdotal view about how members feel on various issues. The cost is trivial in relation to the overall sales process".

fields.headline: Marcus Roberts Trio
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London

Rating: ***
fields.body:
The 37-year-old Florida pianist Marcus Roberts has an elegant plasticity of line and fragility of articulation that makes him one of the circuit's most gifted keyboard virtuosi. He divides listeners, however, because he's a Marsalis-school classicist who devotes his talents to polishing jazz music's family silver. At the Queen Elizabeth Hall, his trio (with, appropriately, Jason Marsalis on drums and Roland Guerin on bass) devoted the set to the pianist's Duke Ellington suite, written for last year's Centennial.

The performance by the Americans was preceded by British trumpeter Byron Wallen's Indigo, an intense, intricate freebop quartet that played the kind of rugged, improv-driven jazz that the fastidious Roberts and his cohorts wouldn't touch. Wallen has also developed a talent for composition and an appetite for free-jazz methods that were developed before he was born and are generally out of favour with his fusion-oriented generation.

In a densely textured and only occasionally over-solemn set, Wallen brought to mind a fusion of the fragmentary lyricism of late-period Miles Davis and the spiky euphoria of Don Cherry. His contrapuntal improvising with sax man Tony Kofi brought the best from melodies of deceptive innocence (at times they suggested an early music ensemble playing jazz licks), and young drummer Tom Skinner confirmed all the immense polyrhythmic gifts he has been hinting at since his mid-teens.

Roberts's group began In Honour of Duke with soft, airy arpeggios intensifying and fading; the low volume drew attention to the pianist's phrasing, which was personal and original even on the well-travelled idiomatic roads. The first uptempo episode climaxed in a swell of thunderous chords, then shifted into a Roberts favourite, the chiming, jangling stride-piano swinger. Without cloning Ellington's themes directly, he caught the Duke's headlong jubilation at the keyboard, as well as ingeniously sketching in the line between Ellington and Thelonious Monk.

Roland Guerin's slap-bass episodes sounded exhilarating and purposeful, and the clear, precise Jason Marsalis was the ideal drummer for this meticulous music-making. Marsalis explores a very wide range of drum sounds but keeps them clear and distinct, reserving particular tonalities for specific episodes of the music. At times he sounded as if he was playing wood-blocks, sometimes he sustained the beat with snare-accents in one hand and a tambourine in the other, and in intense moments he often engagingly suggested the sound of a giant knitting.

As happened with this trio at Ronnie Scott's last year, the old studiousness is being replaced by an infectious sense of pleasure shared. It's not cutting-edge, but it's not dusty retro either.

fields.headline: Marnie
fields.standfirst:
Haymarket, Basingstoke
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Haymarket, Basingstoke

Rating: ***
fields.body:
Sean O'Connor's stage adaptation of the Winston Graham novel about Marnie is a case of style over substance.

In his 1964 film, Alfred Hitchcock had located the story of the compulsive liar and thief in Philadelphia, but O'Connor restores the British post-war backdrop with some success. Marnie's tragedy is played out not merely as psychodrama but as a gritty parable of repressiveness in which sex, class, money and even vowel sounds are major motivators.

Set in what looks like a vast tiled public lavatory, which echoes Marnie's obsessive urge to wash herself clean after every "job", the production seamlessly melds past and present, linking the damaged psyche of the apparently cold- hearted, frigid Marnie with her 10-year-old self, appearing down the train tracks of the past. From the endlessly ticking clock to the shadows thrown up against the back wall and the pre-Coalite smog that invades the stage, this is all exquisitely done, simultaneously conjuring the dream world of psychoanalysis and the harsh reality of a strictly stratified society where hypocrisy and privilege flourish.

But for all his stylistic flourishes, O'Connor - like Hitchcock before him - never really gets inside either Marnie's frozen heart or her strange, forced marriage to Mark Rutland, the boss from whom she steals and who then traps her like a wounded animal.

Just as most of the attempts to explain Marnie's behaviour look ludicrously simplistic to a modern audience - the workings of the subconscious are infinitely more understood than they were 40 years ago - so the failure to explore Rutland's equally bizarre behaviour and motives in marrying Marnie create a hollow centre. The absence makes this otherwise watchable evening seem cynical, sometimes even repulsive.

Try as they may, the actors can't always fill the emotional gap. Sophie Shaw as Marnie initially substitutes woodenness for emotional reticence and damage, but gets better as the evening progresses; in the final scene, the vision of a lonely future, cut off from all humanity, is truly pitiful. But by then it is a close run thing as to whether you will have lost all interest.

Until February 3. Box office: O1256 465566. The production then transfers to the Gateway, Chester (01244 340392), from February 7.

fields.headline: First woman to head LSE
fields.standfirst: 200-year tradition broken as exchange seeks to end turbulence
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange, enduring one of the most turbulent periods in its history, will today break with 200 years of tradition by appointing a woman as chief executive.
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange, enduring one of the most turbulent periods in its history, will today break with 200 years of tradition by appointing a woman as chief executive.

Clara Furse, a 43-year-old banker little known in the broking community, will be charged with setting the LSE on a new course after its failed merger with Deutsche Börse and the humiliating, ill-fated, takeover bid by OM of Sweden.

The appointment of the mother of three is expected to be accompanied by a revamp of the LSE board, with the old-guard being replaced. Among those expected to step down are Simon Robertson, a managing director of Goldman Sachs, and Nigel Sherlock, a director of stockbrokers Wise Speke.

Ms Furse's new role, which is expected to be ratified by the LSE board this morning, caused some confusion in the City yesterday. One source described her as an "obscure" choice but an attempt by the exchange to show it was serious about change.

The exchange has already undergone a painful demutualisation but is now said to need alliances or mergers with other exchanges after recently rebuffing an approach from US hi-tech market Nasdaq.

But overall, a broking community that until recently appeared irreconcilably divided between the big banks and small firms, appeared to give her benefit of the doubt. Brian Winterflood, chairman of Winterflood, a broker of small stocks and one of the most vocal opponents of the exchange's management, said: "The boys have made a mess of it, so why not let the girls have a go."

Ms Furse is not of the traditional ilk for chief executives of the LSE, which has proved a poisoned chalice for the men drawn from the broking community. Her predecessor, Gavin Casey, resigned when OM launched its hostile bid last year.

She was deputy chairman of London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange in the late 1990s, a period when LIFFE underwent a radical technological facelift.

New technology is one of the main challenges for the LSE, an area she tackled at French-owned Credit Lyonnais Rouse, which she left a month ago.

Of Dutch origin but born in Canada, Ms Furse speaks five languages. Her appointment means that the exchange's two most senior executives will have no direct experience of the elite world of buying and selling shares. Don Cruickshank, the often unpopular chairman who oversaw her appointment, is also an outsider.

One survivor of the board room shake-out is expected to be Michael Marks, the veteran City broker at Merrill Lynch who bore the brunt of the accusations of the small brokers by pushing through decisions which favoured larger firms.

OM, which reported 2000 earnings below expectations, has not ruled out another bid for the LSE later this year, possibly with other players.

webTitle: Pop review: A Silver Mt Zion

fields.headline: A Silver Mt Zion
fields.standfirst:
Union Chapel, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Union Chapel, London

Rating: ****
fields.body:
The trouble with musical side-projects is that they are impossible to evaluate on their own merits. The trio at the heart of A Silver Mt Zion also form one-third of the Canadian outfit Godspeed You Black Emperor!; so far, any writing on the offshoot has merely muttered vaguely about flamboyant titles, the presence of a piano and the fact that the band's debut album, He Has Left Us Alone But Shafts of Light Sometimes Grace the Corner of Our Rooms, was dedicated to the dying dog of Efrim, pianist, guitarist and occasional singer.

Although the two bands share a miserabilist ethos, the music they produce is subtly different. Godspeed favour tempestuous dynamics: they are the sound of cities collapsing into rubble and of the shock that follows. Mt Zion approach desolation in a hazier way: listening to Stumble Then Rise on Some Awkward Morning, you can imagine dehydrating in a desert, drifting into hallucinations in seductive waves of sand. When they do launch into a crescendo - Efrim punching at the piano, Thierry dragging lugubrious slugs of sound from his double bass, the two violinists and cellist making notes crash like panes of glass - they do so with a sweetness that the stomach-churning Godspeed sometimes lack.

The striking difference, however, is in the endearingly earnest vocals that Mt Zion use to express their unease with society, to communicate Godspeed's own message, hope. Movie (Never Made) is a hymn for would-be dissidents declaring: "The people united is a wonderful thing." Efrim's voice slices bravely through the cold air, quelling potential sniggers at his hippie notions. The new songs veer from a slightly uncomfortable blend of hardcore rock and classical to beautiful lullaby mantras: the words "These hands could move mountains" falteringly sung over a shy burble of bass, cello and guitar.

The instrumental music, however, still presents the more affecting eloquence, born of their other, instrumental band's taciturnity. The silent narrative driving Blown Out Joy From Heaven's Mercied Hole, of drunken wanderings in drizzle, unfurls with absorbing deliberateness. It wouldn't stand up to the scrutiny of people who like only classical music - the screechy notes from the strings, and the way the pounded piano keeps collapsing into tunelessness, would make them cringe - but there is a stateliness about A Silver Mt Zion's music that leaves most bands in the shadows.

fields.headline: Bad boy Manson delivers the goods
fields.standfirst:
Marilyn Manson
Manchester Arena
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Marilyn Manson

Manchester Arena

Rating: ****
fields.body:
Speculation that Eminem has now toppled Marilyn Manson as the number one bad boy of pop will have to be discounted. Visitors to Manchester Arena are greeted with a large crowd, singing "Kum-bay-a my lord". Eminem may be baaad, but his concerts have yet to be picketed by armies of Christians.

Manson is routinely demonised, particularly in America, where over his "Antichrist Superstar" status. offends everything the Christian Right hold dear. And yet, beneath the schlock horror, his interviews and hilarious autobiography reveal an intelligent, witty and even moral man. It's hard not to chuckle at a man who lists his influences as "Satan, the Bible, Dr Seuss and Dr Hook". The heretics outside apart, his UK audience recognises Manson for what he is: a supreme media manipulator, an adolescent sympathiser, a consummate rock star and a glorified pantomime dame.

During this extraordinarily entertaining performance, Manson dresses as a bishop and a goose-stepping leather boy, sings from the top of a 30ft hydraulic crane concealed beneath a dress, and stalks the crowd on enormous metal stilts. Laugh? It's almost Carry On With the Devil.

Although Manson flirts with demonic imagery, he is no more disturbing than all the old Hammer horror movies. Looking like a genetically modified reptile who crawled from the Black Lagoon, losing most of his clothes in the process (basically, a modern Alice Cooper), Manson knows exactly where to draw the line - at removing his underpants, with which he teases us all night. His songs point out the ironies of a society that worships God and the gun, but the search for anything actually sinister ends with his command of the audience, which itself is more fascinating than dangerous. He leads a chant of "Fuck you", and later mock-abuses a delighted boy. But otherwise he says little: to appear too human would diminish his aura.

The music is the weak link, but when Mazza welds a Glitter stomp to his goth metal, as on the pulverising Disposable Teens, the results are fantastic. A true old devil, Manson vanishes in a puff of smoke. By now the protesters outside have also disappeared. Perhaps they had sneaked in, excited, at the back.

At the Docklands Arena, London E14 (0207-734 8932), tonight.

fields.headline: At this price?  Sportingbet.com
fields.trailText: Sportingbet.com yesterday did what dozens of other aspiring internet companies can only dream of - raising £18m on the stock market.
fields.body:
Sportingbet.com yesterday did what dozens of other aspiring internet companies can only dream of - raising £18m on the stock market.

In the present climate, with internet stocks out of fashion, it was a laudable performance even if management had hoped to raise £30m.

The shares, placed at 120p each and valuing the firm at £156m, are set to start trading on January 30. The company, which specialises on sports betting over the internet, is no ordinary dot.com.

Unlike many it has genuine revenues - taking £114m in the six months to September 30 from 50,000 customers in 103 countries.

However, it still reported a pretax loss of £3.5m for the period as the company had spent heavily on marketing and brand building.

The big push was designed to grab as large a share of the global sports betting market as possible before traditional players such as Ladbrokes and William Hills move in.

Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, the bank handling the float, believes the market is set to grow 31% every year for the next five years. It thinks clients who would never enter a betting shop might be tempted to place a bet over the internet or through interactive television, making such gambling a mass phenomena.

Alderney-based Sportingbet is not only targeting UK sports. It also offers odds on everything from American football to horseracing in Hong Kong. The new cash will be used to expand its geographic spread in areas such as the US and Far East, and to build brand awareness. It needs to move fast, however. Sportingbet is merely a foal in a field of seasoned thoroughbreds.

Companies such as Ladbrokes, hampered by their own bricks and mortar operations which they are loathe to undercut, have not been able to capture overseas markets as rapidly. But it would be unwise to bet against them putting on a late spurt.

There are also smaller competitors in play, such as Victor Chandler International and Blue Square.

The last betting company to list, IG Index, has performed strongly doubling in price since the summer.

Sportingbet shares could rise on the first day as investors who missed out on the placing seek stock. But history suggests institutions tend to bail out if they scent an early profit. Wait a few days to see how the land lies; a speculative punt after that.

fields.headline: Bach and Hewitt spring-clean the soul
fields.standfirst:
Angela Hewitt
St Paul's Concert Hall, Huddersfield
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Angela Hewitt

St Paul's Concert Hall, Huddersfield

Rating: *****
fields.body:
Bach passed off the Goldberg Variations as a piece of "keyboard practice composed for music lovers to refresh their spirits". It does more than that: a good performance of the Goldbergs is like spring-cleaning for the soul, and there are few better able to provide it at the moment than the Canadian pianist Angela Hewitt.

Hewitt's mesmeric recording of the work - captured in a single take in the middle of the night - struck many as the finest single contribution to the Bach frenzy that broke out during the anniversary last year. Hewitt seemed to have raised the bar for modern Bach pianists at a single vault; possibly even dislodging her fellow countryman, the hallowed Glenn Gould, in the process.

In fact, comparing Hewitt with Gould is like comparing apples with artichokes. The difference between them is that which separates classical ideals from the baroque: Hewitt a paragon of symmetrical good taste, Gould a throbbing generator of erratic brilliance. With her sinuous deportment and regal, Roman profile, Hewitt is a figure you feel you have seen before, on the side of a Greek vase, or as one of those alluring, slightly mysterious ladies of sensibility John Singer Sargent loved to paint.

Her conception of the work - lush, romantic, even old-fashioned - has the distinction of making all stylistic arguments irrelevant when her placing of components seems so authoritatively correct. Played entirely from memory, the Goldberg Variations seem to have seeped into Hewitt's genetic make-up. It is one of those rare occasions where the distinction between composition and expositor becomes so blurred that you wonder if the Variations have begun to play her.

Yet the performance is still illuminated by spontaneity. Generally eschewing repeats for the sake of brevity, Hewitt sprinkles some back in where the mood takes her, frequently pointing up a particular turning point in the work, such as the sublime cantabile of Variation 22, which feels like leaning into the final bend, or the extraordinary gear change in Variation 13, where the work, so full of life, acquires its soul.

A transcendent evening could have ended on the dying note of the aria. Pressed into an encore she launched into the chorale from Cantata 147 (Jesu Joy of Man's Desiring) and fluffed the second bar. At least it proves it's impossible to capture Bach's humanity without being human.
